webTitle: Mother of parliaments strikes a blow for women

fields.headline: Mother of parliaments strikes a blow for women
fields.standfirst:
Guardian Unlimited editor Emily Bell, back at work after 22 weeks of maternity leave, urges the health minister to follow through on her laudable decision to take time off after her baby is born

Special report: Labour in power
fields.trailText:
Guardian Unlimited editor Emily Bell, back at work after 22 weeks of maternity leave, urges the health minister to follow through on her laudable decision to take time off after her baby is born
Special report: Labour in power
fields.body:
Junior health minister Yvette Cooper has made history as the first ever minister to take maternity leave - on the relatively generous terms of 18 weeks on full pay. Finally it seems that the department of health has produced its most positive contribution to the public health debate.

Ms Cooper is doing something politicians rarely manage - which is to lead by example. Even Tony Blair's fudged paternity leave after the arrival of baby Leo - taking things easy for a couple of weeks while refusing to let John Prescott actually take the reins of power - smacked of a Third Way that hardly put the new baby or its mother first.

Despite enormous improvements in maternity benefits, there is still a lingering suggestion that women who either choose between career and family or who squeeze out babies between meetings and pretend nothing has happened are somehow better employees.

Acres of newsprint were devoted to the case of Sue Clark, director of corporate affairs at Scottish Power, when, two years ago, she stayed at her desk during labour and was able, via the magic of teleconferencing, to complete a deal within two days of her baby being born.

For those of us returning from a leisurely maternity leave - even longer than Ms Cooper's - this example is enough to make the blood run cold. The incessant crying, insecurity and constant need for food which follow childbirth makes it impossible for most of us to contemplate returning to work within four or five months. And that is even before one takes into account the needs of the baby.

In Ms Clark's case she planned only eight weeks off - barely time to establish a routine for a newborn - but the company's feelings were quite clear. "Everyone in the company appreciates Sue's determination," a Scottish Power spokesman purred.

He should have been saying: "The chief executive's furious she put her own health at risk for the sake of a commercial transaction and he's ordered her not to come back for at least six months."

Because the truth is that when you take proper time off after giving birth you actually come back able to handle the real world without bursting into tears or forgetting where you live.

Ms Cooper has made history but now she has to follow through. Announcing you are taking 18 weeks off is one thing; actually sticking to it while the phone rings off the hook and ministerial briefings arrive at your door by the cartload is entirely another.

webTitle: Newham ordered to improve social services

fields.headline: Newham ordered to improve social services
fields.trailText: Newham council in London has joined 14 other authorities on "special measures" because of ministerial concerns over the quality of its children's services. Linda Steele reports
fields.body:
Newham council in London has joined 14 other authorities on "special measures" because of ministerial concerns over the quality of its children's services.

Health minister John Hutton has written to the council ordering it make improvements across a range of social services, including child protection.

Mr Hutton wrote: "There remains a substantial professional and managerial change agenda which is needed to bring your services up to a safe standard."

He added: "It is essential that services for children are protected and immediate action must be taken."

A council is added to the special measures list when there are serious concerns about the quality of its social services. The council must then develop an action plan and submit monthly monitoring information to the social services inspectorate (SSI).

The social services department, which was the subject of a daming report by the SSI and the audit commission in January, has until the end of February to produce an action plan.

The council must:
 Develop a "statement of priorities" for its social services
 Ensure that its work with children and families is safe
 Make improvements in assessment, care planning and review, including access to specialist services
 Make sure that service users have better information
 Build an "effective, stable workforce by improving all aspects of human resource management"
 Develop effective performance management frameworks
 Manage change better to ensure that all staff understand and are committed to professional objectives and outcomes
 Develop a robust medium-term financial strategy.

A Newham council spokesman said: "While no one wants to be in special measures, we're now looking forward. It's about everyone being focused on the services that people want and need.

"There's still a lot to do. But many of the things that were found when they carried out the inspection have been addressed."

"We're doing a lot to communicate the way we work with service users, such as looking at the publicity materials we use.

"We've got a number of recruitment and retention schemes to ensure that vacancies are covered.

"The number of children without an allocated social worker has more than halved [since the inspection last July]. All those on register have been allocated a social worker."

Other councils on special measures are Barking and Dagenham, Barnsley, Cambridgeshire, Coventry, Hackney, Haringey, Hillingdon, Lambeth, Lancashire, Merton, North East Lincolnshire, Peterborough, Sheffield, Wirral.

Last month's SSI report said Newham's children's services were of particular concern. Risks to young people were neither promptly identified nor reliably managed. When the joint review took place during June and July 2000, more than 500 children at risk or in care had not been allocated a social worker.

The review found that a split existed between senior staff, who were enthusiastic for change, and staff on the ground, who were dissatisfied, under "considerable pressure" and suffering "change fatigue".

webTitle: Police accused of racial harassment hope to sue

fields.headline: Police accused of racial harassment hope to sue
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Forty-seven Metropolitan police officers accused of waging a vendetta against the black activist Delroy Lindo are hoping to sue either the force or Tarique Ghaffur, the senior officer who led the inquiry which investigated their behaviour, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Forty-seven Metropolitan police officers accused of waging a vendetta against the black activist Delroy Lindo are hoping to sue either the force or Tarique Ghaffur, the senior officer who led the inquiry which investigated their behaviour, it emerged yesterday.

The officers are seething over Mr Ghaffur's report, saying it relied entirely on the allegations of Mr Lindo, who had been arrested on 37 occasions and charged with 18 offences over eight years. Only one arrest resulted in a conviction and that was overturned on appeal.

Mr Lindo has described being stopped for sucking his teeth in the presence of a police officer, driving with a dirty number plate and carrying a copy of the Observer.

Mr Ghaffur, the Met's most senior Asian officer, did not interview any of the police officers involved in these incidents before sending his findings to Ian Blair, the deputy commissioner.

Mr Ghaffur concluded that Mr Lindo, 41, was the victim of three unlawful arrests and had been the victim of harassment as a result of racial stereotyping.

Through the Metropolitan Police Federation, the officers have asked London solicitors Russell, Jones and Walker to establish if there are any grounds to sue the force or Mr Ghaffur, who is a deputy assistant commissioner.

"We have asked for a wide-ranging review of all the options, including what possible violations there may have been of new human rights legislation," said Bob Elder, a federation spokesman. "Mr Ghaffur's report is not balanced. He spoke to Mr Lindo and Mr Lindo's family. But he didn't have the common decency to speak to the officers who were being accused. There is an enormous amount of anger about the way this has been handled."

Mr Elder said the police complaints authority had cleared the officers of any wrongdoing.

Mr Ghaffur's report has also caused concern among senior officers at Scotland Yard and the force's in-house legal team. They believe it has made the Met "highly vulnerable" to civil action by the Lindos, who are pursuing five civil suits claiming £1m compensation.

A Met spokesman said the force had not received notification that any legal action had started, but was aware several officers were seeking advice. "We cannot comment further at this stage."

webTitle: Judge rejects racial motive to man's murder

fields.headline: Judge rejects racial motive to man's murder
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: A judge was criticised yesterday after claiming that the murder of an Indonesian-born man who had been called "nigger" before being kicked and beaten was not racially motivated.
fields.body:
A judge was criticised yesterday after claiming that the murder of an Indonesian-born man who had been called "nigger" before being kicked and beaten was not racially motivated.

Jan Pasalbessy, 48, was beaten by a gang of four while his 14-year-old stepdaughter begged them to stop outside the Royal Gwent hospital in Newport in June 12 in what police described as a racial attack.

Roger Talbot, 21, of Cwmbran; Ashley Haynes, 18, of no fixed address; Carl Rosser, 16, of Newport; and Emma Oates, 19, of Newport were found guilty of murder by a jury at Newport crown court. All four denied murder, though Talbot, Haynes and Rosser had admitted manslaughter.

Talbot was jailed for life. Oates and Haynes were sentenced to custody for life and Rosser to be detained at her majesty's pleasure.

Mr Pasalbessy had given up his job as a merchant seaman to care for his stepdaughter, Christina, after her mother died from cancer. Christina told the jury: "The 16-year-old was calling my father names like nigger. They pushed him and dad tripped over the foot of one of them. When he landed on the road there was a loud crack.

"He landed on his stomach with his arms by his side. All four of them landed hard kicks on my dad as he lay on the ground. "I was on the floor crying my eyes out saying get off him. They heard a police siren and said: 'Quick let's go'."

Mr Justice Richards said that Mr Pasalbessy had been "a party in this incident" and that despite the racial abuse shouted by Oates and Rosser, he did not consider it a racist attack.

He said: "Looking at the television evidence and from what I have heard, I am not satisfied that this was a racially motivated attack." However he was satisfied that Oates and Rosser had taunted Mr Pasalbessy with racist comments.

The family of Mr Pasalbessy said they were "pleased that justice had been done" but disagreed with the judge's remarks.

Suzanne Dupon, 30 and Paul Heard, 32, also stepchildren of Mr Pasalbessy, said the whole family had been devastated by his death, but particularly Christina.

Mr Heard said his stepfather had been murdered because of his colour: "If Jan had been a white person he would be here today," he said. "There may have been a bit of a fight but he wouldn't be dead."

Before the murder the family had had to move from a Newport council estate because of racial abuse and threats.

Detective Superintendent Des James, the senior investi gating officer, also said the case had been "dealt with as a racially motivated incident", using the Home Office definition.

Maggie Simpson of the National Association Against Racism, which monitored the trial, said there was no doubt Mr Pasalbessy was the victim of a racist attack.

She said: "Mr Pasalbessy was a black man and he was killed because he was a black man. Racism is never a minor matter and it obviously contributed towards this crime."

The court heard that Mr Pasalbessy had gone to the hospital with his stepdaughter after she had been attacked by a girl. Oates had told the girl she would pay her £10 to punch Christina.

At the casualty unit Christina and Oates bumped into each other. Fearing trouble the teenager called the police. As Mr Pasalbessy and his daughter left the hospital grounds the gang pounced, with Oates, who had her baby with her, acting as ring leader.

Though Oates, a mother of two children, did not touch Mr Pasalbessy, she was accused of inciting the group.

Mr Justice Richards told her: "You may not have taken part in the physical violence yourself, but I have no doubt that by the things you said you helped to inflame the others.

fields.bodyText: A judge was criticised yesterday after claiming that the murder of an Indonesian-born man who had been called "nigger" before being kicked and beaten was not racially motivated. Jan Pasalbessy, 48, was beaten by a gang of four while his 14-year-old stepdaughter begged them to stop outside the Royal Gwent hospital in Newport in June 12 in what police described as a racial attack. Roger Talbot, 21, of Cwmbran; Ashley Haynes, 18, of no fixed address; Carl Rosser, 16, of Newport; and Emma Oates, 19, of Newport were found guilty of murder by a jury at Newport crown court. All four denied murder, though Talbot, Haynes and Rosser had admitted manslaughter. Talbot was jailed for life. Oates and Haynes were sentenced to custody for life and Rosser to be detained at her majesty's pleasure. Mr Pasalbessy had given up his job as a merchant seaman to care for his stepdaughter, Christina, after her mother died from cancer. Christina told the jury: "The 16-year-old was calling my father names like nigger. They pushed him and dad tripped over the foot of one of them. When he landed on the road there was a loud crack. "He landed on his stomach with his arms by his side. All four of them landed hard kicks on my dad as he lay on the ground. "I was on the floor crying my eyes out saying get off him. They heard a police siren and said: 'Quick let's go'." Mr Justice Richards said that Mr Pasalbessy had been "a party in this incident" and that despite the racial abuse shouted by Oates and Rosser, he did not consider it a racist attack. He said: "Looking at the television evidence and from what I have heard, I am not satisfied that this was a racially motivated attack." However he was satisfied that Oates and Rosser had taunted Mr Pasalbessy with racist comments. The family of Mr Pasalbessy said they were "pleased that justice had been done" but disagreed with the judge's remarks. Suzanne Dupon, 30 and Paul Heard, 32, also stepchildren of Mr Pasalbessy, said the whole family had been devastated by his death, but particularly Christina. Mr Heard said his stepfather had been murdered because of his colour: "If Jan had been a white person he would be here today," he said. "There may have been a bit of a fight but he wouldn't be dead." Before the murder the family had had to move from a Newport council estate because of racial abuse and threats. Detective Superintendent Des James, the senior investi gating officer, also said the case had been "dealt with as a racially motivated incident", using the Home Office definition. Maggie Simpson of the National Association Against Racism, which monitored the trial, said there was no doubt Mr Pasalbessy was the victim of a racist attack. She said: "Mr Pasalbessy was a black man and he was killed because he was a black man. Racism is never a minor matter and it obviously contributed towards this crime." The court heard that Mr Pasalbessy had gone to the hospital with his stepdaughter after she had been attacked by a girl. Oates had told the girl she would pay her £10 to punch Christina. fields.headline: Shortcuts
fields.standfirst: Oversubscribed | Overheard | Overexposed
fields.trailText: Oversubscribed
fields.body:
Oversubscribed

William Reid

Shock horror - a new label making pretty, wearable clothes. Designer William Reid showed his menswear and womenswear collection off-schedule in New York this week, without any of the pretensions that bug many of the Big Apple's new generation catwalks. Reid puts a fresh spin on what America does best, making a modern version of what they call sportswear, which is basically the cover-all term for easy-to-understand separates. For men he produced downtown makeovers of military jackets and pinstripe trousers; his recently-launched women's line had ruffle shirts effortlessly constructed from jersey, chunky cardigans and a great red wool coat trimmed with leather - easy to translate into real life.

Reid launced his own collection three years ago after a career on the other side of the industry, working for US department store Saks Fifth Avenue, as well as for Reebok and Nautica USA. Obviously the commercial edge has given him a strong understanding of what will sell, as his spring/summer collection is full of covetable, light pieces cut for both men and women to a breezily tailored silhouette. These will be the first of Reid's clothes to be sold in the UK (available from Yasmin Cho, 22 Poland St, London W1, 020-7287 6922) which is great news if, in the midst of the 80s/bondage clash, you secretly yearn for something sweet and preppy.

Overheard

'Camo'

If fashion this summer will be all about "fluoro" (fluorescent), autumn/winter's must-have colour scheme will be "camo", aka camouflage. Fashion folk are too cool, you know, to bother uttering words of more than two syllables.

Overexposed

Waistcoats

Divided by a common language we may be, but those Americans can't pull the linguistic wool over our eyes. At his diffusion line show in New York this week, Marc Jacobs used the American term "vests" when describing a particularly popular number in the collection. Unfortunately,even this quaint American term does not disguise the fact that it is, in fact, a waistcoat.

Waistcoats have been on nearly every catwalk in New York this past week. If you think about it, there is a natural thought process going on here. For the past couple of seasons, designers have been thinking again about suits. Bored of that, they have now moved on to the outfits that go with suits.

To cure yourself of any desire to own a "wool vest", simply ask any male friend how they feel when they have to wear the full regalia at weddings - the only time most men ever wear waistcoats these days. They're finicky but also unflattering - by focusing attention on the stomach, they broaden the area. There's no escaping it, we have a trend here. See it as a test for your fad avoidance radar - the one that failed you when it came to batwings.

fields.headline: The Insider
fields.standfirst: (she goes to the parties so you don't have to)
fields.trailText: The New York shows are enthralling. Sure, the clothes are a bit dull, but the eavesdropping is delicious.
fields.body:
The New York shows are enthralling. Sure, the clothes are a bit dull, but the eavesdropping is delicious. In a Bedouin tent in the Lower East Side, waiting for the Miguel Adrover show to start, I was busy panicking about the evident fire risk (overcrowding, wooden benches, canvas roof, kerosene lamps, cigarettes) when distracted by a woman in the row behind me earnestly confiding in a friend: "I feel like my life just went up a notch, now that I've seen Tori [Spelling, we assume]. AND I've seen Jason Priestley. And Noah [Wyle, from ER, I'm guessing]. I'm still waiting to see Shannon Doherty. But Tori . . . you know, that was major."

I was still reeling when a catty exchange began next to me. "I'm exhausted! I just got back from Aspen," announced a woman with expensive highlights to no one in particular. My neighbour, who was wearing a bracelet of diamonds the size of hothouse grapes, couldn't resist a dig. "Oh, Aspen is so darling. I learnt to ski there, of course. But my husband and I always go to Val d'Isere."

At that moment, the music struck up and models in North African-style djeballahs and turbans appeared. After a few moments, Miss de Beers opened her notebook and wrote with a flourish: "Ghandi [sic] for fall!!!!!"

After dark, the cult of the hotel is still going strong. Puffy's Saturday night after-party was held at the W, Custo Barcelona went old-school at the Chelsea and Erin O'Connor celebrated her 23rd birthday at the just-completed penthouse of the Hudson. But from six till eight, the old stand-around-the-shop rules apply. Calvin Klein caused a sensation at his early evening bash, thrown at his Madison Avenue store for celebrity hairstylist Guido, by serving mounds of bread and cheese instead of the usual quails' egg benedict. Fashion etiquette always demands studiously ignoring the canapés, but confronted with such terrifyingly fattening foods as bread and cheese, female guests went one step further and physically avoided the entire food area, lest calories turn out to be airborne.

fields.headline: BBC3 lines up gay show
fields.trailText: 4.30pm: The BBC is lining up a weekly gay lifestyle show for new digital youth channel BBC3, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The BBC has given a sneak preview of the type of programming digital youth channel BBC3 will carry with a commission for a weekly gay lifestyle show.

That Gay Show has been ordered for BBC Choice by controller Stuart Murphy.

But BBC Choice is expected to be transformed into BBC3 later this year or early in 2002 and Mr Murphy has been tipped as the new channel's controller.

"The gay audience is going to figure quite prominently in our programming plans should we get the go-ahead for the channel," said a BBC spokesman.

That Gay Show is being billed as a "light-hearted" magazine series for gay men, featuring a team of reporters who will present regular items on fashion, lifestyle, music and television.

It will launch on BBC Choice in April.

The programme will be presented by Kristian Digby, Tom Ashton, Robbie Robertson and Queer as Folk star Jonathan Natynczyk.

In addition, American comic Scott Capurro will front a regular look at the US gay scene, with features on subjects including a gay rodeo.

"There is huge diversity in the gay community and That Gay Show is surprising and entertaining, finding common ground without the burden of political correctness," Mr Murphy said.

Culture secretary Chris Smith is currently assessing the BBC's proposals for BBC3 and three other new digital TV services.

A consultation period on the proposals, during which interested parties can submit comments to the Department of Culture, Media and Sport, runs until the end of the month.

The BBC's plans for youth channel BBC3 is one area of concern for rival commerical broadcasters.

They claim the channel will use public money for a service that will compete for the youth audience with established commercial offerings such as E4, Sky One and MTV.

But the BBC spokesman defended the proposals for BBC3. "It is a public service channel. It is the BBC communicating with a specific audience, in a certain way, delivering things that broadcasters would otherwise not produce."

fields.headline: Future's bleak
fields.standfirst: Recently hailed as a publishing success story, Future Network's fall from grace has been sudden.
fields.trailText:
4pm: Jessica Hodgson and Amy Vickers on Future Network's fall from grace.
Feb 16: Future names doomed mags
Feb 16: Future axes 350 jobs
fields.body:
Lis Murdoch could be regretting her decision to become involved with a certain Bath-based magazine publisher after news of today's drastic cutback plans.

Once one of the shining lights of the magazine publishing world, over the past six months Future Network has fallen from grace - and then some.

It was set up in 1985 by Chris Anderson - who started the company after buying out a single computer magazine from Emap - and until last year, Future seemed unassailable.

Future built up an impressive portfolio of IT and computing magazines, of which the biggest sellers were Official PlayStation Magazine and .net.

The west country outfit also diversified, buying and starting consumer magazines including Total Film and the Manchester United magazine.

In 1994, Mr Anderson sold his majority stake in the company to Pearson, who guided the company into the big publishing league.

Then in 1998, the company was bought back by a consortium comprising Mr Anderson, Future managing director Greg Ingham and venture capitalists Apax Partners.

Future reached its zenith in the first few months of 2000, when its share price rose to a high of 926p.

But by lunchtime today its share price had fallen to 89p, a drop of more than 90% in less than a year.

The company's market capitalisation has fallen from £1bn in 1999 to just over £100m.

Future was once mentioned in a newspaper as one of the 10 best British companies to work for.

But the firm's fortunes began to nosedive with the first of three profit warnings issued last year.

The first was in October, when around £300m of Future's value was wiped out after it announced that an accounting error in the accounts of its French arm had overstated sales.

Two further profit warnings were issued, the most recent in January, when the share value nearly halved again.

Pundits and analysts agree that it was not just the accounting blip that was to blame - Future Network seems to have been hit by every weapon the gods can throw at it.

In the first part of last year, backers Apax Partners pulled out.

This was merely a harbinger of trouble ahead in the dot.com sector, as - following the fallout in technology stocks - confidence from advertisers and investors bombed.

Computing and new economy magazines lost out as dot.coms went to the wall and advertising revenue slumped following profit warnings from computer hardware manufacturers.

And to cap it all, the computer games market is reported to have seen an unexpected softening.

But other things seemed to conspire against Future.

Sony's decision to cut back on production of PlayStation 2 was cited as a reason behind the profit warnings.

Another reason was the cost of hiring accountants Deloitte and Touche to investigate the accounting errors in Future's French business.

webTitle: Barak criticised for joining national unity government

fields.headline: Barak criticised for joining national unity government
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israel's two major parties are putting the final touches on a national unity government today, amid widespread press derision of outgoing prime minister Ehud Barak's decision to join the cabinet.
fields.body:
Israel's two major parties are putting the final touches on a national unity government today, amid widespread press derision of outgoing prime minister Ehud Barak's decision to join the cabinet.

Meanwhile, violence in the region continued with the murder of a Palestinian security officer in the West Bank. Anwar Mustafa Merhi, a lieutenant in the Palestinian security services, was apparently beaten to death in the northern West Bank village of Karwati Beni Hassan, witnesses said.

Sources close to the security services said Merhi was probably killed by Palestinians who "collaborate" with Israel to avenge the executions of other alleged collaborators.

Elsewhere, one Israeli soldier was killed and two more were wounded in an explosion today as the country experienced another Palestinian "day of rage" following weekly Muslim prayers.

The explosion occured in Chebaa Farms, an area that is in dispute between Israel and Hizbullah guerrillas in Lebanon. The Israeli army said an anti-tank missile fired from Lebanon hit an Israeli vehicle traveling in a convoy.

The deaths bring to 414 the number of people who have died since the start of the Palestinian uprising on September 28.

It is against this backdrop that Mr Barak and the rightwing prime minister-elect, Ariel Sharon, agreed late yesterday to form a national unity government, with Mr Barak agreeing to take part even though he had announced his temporary retirement from politics following his humiliating electoral defeat last week.

The two parties still need to bridge their differences and create a joint government programme, but Mr Barak said he hoped to announce the decision to his Labour party's leadership early next week. Mr Barak is likely to take up the post of defence minister in Mr Sharon's government, while Labour elder statesman Shimon Peres will fill the foreign affairs post.

However, the Israeli press had no doubts that he had accepted and harshly criticised him for it. An editorial in the Haaretz daily said Mr Barak's decision was "a high-wire act in which Barak mocks the very principle of political ethics he claimed to defend."

A Maariv editorial headlined "Barak, champion of inconsistency" pointed out that the majority of Israelis who did not want Mr Barak as prime minister would now get him as defence minister.

Yediot Aharonoth quoted a Barak voter as saying he was ashamed of his choice. "I am ashamed that I voted for a man who is incapable of drawing the simplest, most obvious and human conclusions from his immense defeat - to go home," wrote Sever Plotzker.

Mr Sharon, who has until the end of March to form his cabinet, wanted a national unity government to avoid having to depend on far right parties and ultra-orthodox Jews.

Israeli radio said after the agreement was announced that Mr Sharon's Likud and Mr Barak's Labour would have seven portfolios each and equal representation in the security cabinet.

The one issue still to be decided is that of the decision-making process at the top.

fields.headline: NUJ fears for Future jobs
fields.trailText:
4pm update: The NUJ is 'sceptical' of Future's assertion it will not axe any editorial jobs, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Analysis: Future's fall from grace
Feb 16: Future names doomed mags
Feb 16: Future axes 350 jobs
fields.body:
The NUJ says it is "sceptical" of Future Network's assertion it will not axe any editorial jobs in its forthcoming restructure.

Michael Wilson, the NUJ's Bath organiser, said the union had been pushing Future for some time to provide information about potential job cuts.

Mr Wilson said Future journalists had already suffered as a result of the company's financial problems.

"Staff have been working themselves into the grave on these magazines," he said.

"I know some of the staff and several of them have said they haven't seen their families for weeks.

"Future can afford to work these kids so hard because they love their magazines so much."

He added: "This business is run like a family. They don't like consultation and they don't take kindly to union working regulations."

Mr Wilson said the NUJ would use Future's problems as an opportunity to press for an NUJ presence in the company and other magazine publishers.

The NUJ's Bath chapel is to meet this evening to discuss the situation.

Relevant story

Feb 16: Future axes 350 jobs

webTitle: G7 nervously await new kid on the block

fields.headline: G7 nervously await new kid on the block
fields.standfirst: The new US administration's hands-off attitude to the world economy is likely to cause a stir among the other G7 states, writes Charlotte Denny
fields.trailText: The new US administration's hands-off attitude to the world economy is likely to cause a stir among the other G7 states, writes Charlotte Denny.
fields.body:
The arrival of a new kid always has the rest of the class in a bit of tizzy. This weekend's meeting of finance ministers from the world's leading economies in Sicily is no exception.

The other six members of the class are dying to meet the new US treasury secretary Paul O'Neill and to find out how the Bush administration regards the Group of Seven. So far, the signs are not encouraging.

Ahead of his arrival, Mr O'Neill suggested in an interview that he could find out as much about the world economy from his office in Washington as he could by attending the Palermo meeting.

The rest of G7 - Japan, Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada - will be watching him carefully this weekend to see if that was an off-the-cuff remark or a deliberate signal that the US is less interested in the machinery of international economic management.

During the Clinton administration, the US was the leading G7 power, revelling in the strength of its domestic economy while lecturing the Europeans on the need for reform and telling the Japanese on to bump up demand.

Mr O'Neill has already ruled out any lectures, and with the US economy tumbling into recession, the other members are unlikely to be in the mood for listening.

More importantly, Mr O'Neill has suggested that he does not favour intervening in the markets to rescue struggling currencies.

Last September, the G7 mounted a coordinated attack on the speculators to prevent the euro from falling below 80 cents to the dollar. A repeat appears unlikely, although the single currency has found its feet since the intervention in any case.

In fact, the next currency in the firing line could well be the dollar itself. Weaker economic data is likely to weigh heavily on the greenback as foreign investors reconsider whether the US will continue to be a source of healthy returns.

Mr O'Neill's line on the G7's other concerns is likely to be similarly hands off. He does not favour interventions to rescue struggling economies any more than currencies, so the massive bailouts of the 1997-8 Asian financial crisis are unlikely to be repeated - unless the economy in trouble is close enough to home to threaten US prosperity.

fields.headline: Brown rules out 'pre-election giveaways'
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Election countdown
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Chancellor Gordon Brown today rejected the possibility of "irresponsible pre-election giveaways" and promised he would put economic stability first for every term of a Labour government.
fields.body:
Chancellor Gordon Brown today rejected the possibility of "irresponsible pre-election giveaways" and promised he would put economic stability first for every term of a Labour government.

In a speech that laid out the groundwork for Labour's election manifesto, Mr Brown pledged that his budget on March 7 - likely to be the last before a predicted May 3 vote - would lock in tough public spending rules.

But he added he would introduce "responsible tax cuts where affordable, for families, pensioners, savings and investment".

He identified five "economic goals for our generation":
 Full employment;
 Closing the productivity gap with competing nations;
 The majority of young people going on to higher education;
 Eradicating child poverty:
 Delivering the best public services.

The chancellor also criticised the Tories for "their irresponsible, unfunded, unaffordable and unbelievable tax promises" in his passionate keynote speech to more than 2,000 delegates at Labour's spring conference in Glasgow.

Mr Brown promised that Labour would continue to tackle poverty among children and pensioners, and attacked the Tories for planning to cut public investment and undermine public services.

"We want a Britain where what matters is not the privilege you were born to but the potential you were born with," he said.

"We will seek a very specific mandate from the people of this country to take the next million children out of poverty, to halve child poverty by 2010 and abolish it in a generation," he added.

The chancellor said he would be urging a meeting of the G7 finance ministers from the leading industrialised countries tomorrow to follow Britain's lead in cancelling "the crippling burden of Third World debt".

And he launched a campaign calling on governments and drug companies to give greater access to life-saving drugs and healthcare to eradicate avoidable infant death.

In a rallying cry to party activists, the chancellor concluded: "Let us pledge that for our generation our party's place in history will be measured not just in votes, seats or majorities but in better lives for people who may never know us but whose security and opportunities will, as a result of our common endeavour, be transformed."

fields.headline: EU beefs about BSE
fields.standfirst: Mad cow disease may be old news in the UK, but in Europe the press talks about little else, reports Andrew Osborn
fields.trailText: Mad cow disease may be old news in the UK, but in Europe the press talks about little else, reports Andrew Osborn.
fields.body:
It used to be the biggest story in the UK, but mad cow disease is granted precious few column inches in the British press these days. Been there, done that, seen it all before as the saying goes.

But in the rest of Europe, BSE is the biggest story of the moment and has been for months. Nor does it show any signs of going away.

Europe's public and press are transfixed, obsessed, angry and scared and, as the disease slowly spreads across the continent, hysteria is growing.

When Brussels announces draconian new measures to combat BSE - which it seems to do once a month these days - UK officials nonchalantly trot out the same old phrase along the lines of "because we had it first and worst, we're already doing everything we can so this measure will make no difference to us."

In contrast, every new twist in the story has continental journalists rushing to the nearest phone to relate the latest appalling new revelations and obligations to their national capitals.

Europe is going through what the UK endured in the mid-1990s and, for many people, it is a rude awakening.

The continent's dwindling band of anglophiles used to love telling Brits abroad that 'yes, the British are great, but of course you have that terrible mad cow problem don't you?'

But you don't hear that anymore - the French and the Germans have fallen silent because now they have BSE too.

Along with overweight football hooligans, mad cow disease has become Britain's most notorious export.

The fact that the incidence of the disease is only a fraction of what it was in the UK during the 1990s doesn't seem to matter - people are panicking.

Beef consumption is in freefall and has dropped by some 30% across Europe since October and by at least 40% in Germany alone. People are becoming vegetarians, eating more chicken and fish and shunning the ubiquitous steak/frites.

The bad old days of beef mountains are back and there is even controversial talk of getting rid of the unwanted red meat by exporting it as food aid to the third world.

Europe's abattoirs are working overtime slaughtering as many cattle as they can or freezing it for happier days when public confidence may have improved.

Incinerators across the continent are struggling to cope with demand and a black pall of smoke is drifting across Europe - beef is definitely off the menu.

Few noticed in the UK, but the EU this month moved to ban T-bone steaks or beef on the bone in 10 European countries, including France, Germany and Italy.

Nor does Brussels make any secret of the fact that it suspects some European farmers are still feeding cattle ground up animal remains or meat and bonemeal illegally, a practice which is thought to have sparked the disease in the first place.

This week, Franz Fischler, the EU's burly Austrian farm chief, unveiled a controversial new plan which will cost one billion euros alone next year, but which is designed to encourage farmers to curb beef production.

Do anything, go organic, but for god's sake don't give us any more cows was the gist.

In Spain, people can scarcely believe what is happening - not only do they have to put up with an ageing British nuclear submarine HMS Tireless on their doorstep, but now they risk having their national past time, bullfighting wound down because of the so-called British disease.

Under new EU rules, cattle aged over 30 months must be tested for BSE or destroyed and that means that the age-old practice of selling the carcasses of fighting bulls to butchers for meat just got a lot more expensive.

Spain's two largest farm unions are so angry that they are actively considering suing the British government for spreading the disease in the first place through tainted animal feed.

Between 1990 and 1996, the UK exported almost 170,000 tonnes of potentially BSE-infected animal feed to some 70 countries around the globe.

And that was at a time when BSE was most prevalent in the British herd. If Europeans did not have enough to worry about already, the European Commission this week revealed that it has drawn up contingency plans in case the disease spreads to sheep.

Laboratory tests have shown that BSE can be passed on to sheep and goats, although the disease has not, so far, been detected in the field.

EU scientists have concluded, however, that "it has to be assumed that BSE could have been introduced into parts of the sheep and goat population" - again because they have been fed meat and bonemeal in the 1990s.

To the disbelief of countries like France, where some obviously revelled in Britain's BSE misfortunes a few year ago, the European Commission is actually holding the UK up as an example of how best to fight the disease.

But Britain would do well not to crow too loudly or say 'I told you so' too many times, for there is a risk that the government may still face a rash of lawsuits from countries all over Europe for gross negligence in allowing so much tainted feed to be exported.

webTitle: Need to work together greater than ever

fields.headline: Need to work together greater than ever
fields.trailText: Comment: Now that Ken Livingstone's budget is finally set, it is time to move on and to see how we can improve the process in the future, writes Sir Robin Wales
fields.body:
Now that Ken Livingstone's budget is finally set, with a 22.6% increase in the Greater London Authority (GLA) precept, it is time to move on and to see how we can improve the process in the future.

We are, of course, disappointed that the assembly did not further reduce the increase proposed by the London mayor. However, it is ultimately a matter for the mayor and the assembly, and not the London boroughs, and much has been achieved in ensuring both a far better budget than originally proposed and concessions for the future.

The increase in the precept is nearly a third less than the excessive demands first proposed by the mayor, and London boroughs can take much of the credit for these savings.

We now need to work to ensure that any future increase in the GLA precept proposed by the mayor is kept to a minimum and that next year's budget setting process is far more transparent and efficient. It is vital we ensure that council tax payers in London do not bear the brunt of high council tax increases two years running.

Throughout this process, I have been gratified to witness the heartfelt response from boroughs and their willingness to work together across the political boundaries to argue for a better deal for the people they serve. Without their strength and commitment, London council tax payers would almost certainly be facing an even higher council tax bill this April.

This debate has not - and has never been - about extra policing and improvements to our transport system. All London boroughs are in favour of these proposals. It has been about the burden on London's council tax payers. It has been about remembering that council tax is regressive and hits poor people hard, and it has been about making sure that all our public services deliver value for money.

Metropolitan police commissioner Sir John Stevens has clearly stated that he can not achieve efficiency savings straightaway, and that these will be found next year. Although it is a shame that these savings can not be made immediately, we do welcome the fact that, hopefully, next year, more money will be spent on providing the frontline police services we all want. In the meantime, we look to transport commissioner Bob Kiley to deliver the improvements to the London Underground that he has said he can make with this extra funding.

Even despite this increase, some very good things have already taken place. For the first time, there has been scrutiny in the budget setting process, and this will continue. We welcome all of the concessions secured by the London assembly from the mayor, which include greater powers for the assembly in the scrutiny process, as well as more control over how the money levied this year is spent. We also welcome the invitation for a member of the Association of London Government (ALG) to sit on the mayor's advisory cabinet, as this recognises the vital role played by all London boroughs and the necessity of working with them in any future dealings.

No matter what has gone before, the mayor, the ALG, London councils and all parts of the GLA must now come together. We must ensure that London continues to attract its fair share of resources from central government. We must continue to promote our great capital city so it remains the powerhouse of the UK economy, from which the whole nation benefits. There will always be times when, as with the budget, we do not agree, but, despite these, we must never stop working together for the benefit of all Londoners.

 Sir Robin Wales is leader of Newham council and chairman of the Association of London Government

fields.headline: Crisis worsens for debt-laden BT
fields.trailText:
3.15pm: A credit rating firm has threatened to downgrade BT's status, reports Dan Milmo.
Feb 15: BT under pressure from Oftel
fields.body:
The debt crisis at UK telecoms giant BT is set to worsen after an influential credit rating firm threatened to downgrade the company's status.

A credit downgrade will harm BT's chances of raising the cash needed to build the network infrastructure for third generation mobile phones and offer high-speed internet and video services.

Standard & Poor's said it had put BT's "A" rating under review for a possible downgrade.

This will increase the cost of borrowing for the company.

"Based on current information, Standard & Poor's considers it highly likely BT's ratings will be lowered by at least one notch," the firm said.

The agency added that BT had failed to "adequately communicate a debt reduction strategy".

Standard & Poor's effectively scorned BT's announcement late last year that it would spin off parts of its business to pay its £30bn debt.

fields.headline: Rush to meet donor deadlines
fields.standfirst: Aid workers are rushing to respond to donor pledges as the relief effort moves into a second stage, explains GP Prue Peart
fields.trailText: Aid workers are rushing to respond to donor pledges as the relief effort moves into a second stage, explains GP Prue Peart
fields.body:
This visit to the office in Herat feels quite different from my previous ones because of the pressure to get documents typed up for donors. For the past two nights, senior staff have been working at computers until after 1am, trying to meet deadlines. Last time I was here, there was an urgency to get the projects started - to get quilts made and shelters built before the cold really arrived - but that work could not be done after the 9pm curfew. Now, Ockenden International is building up a good reputation in Herat and donors are approaching the office, asking if we can help to run new programmes.

Last night, however, I managed to sneak out for an hour after dinner and see a friend of mine who is also "in town". The UN agency that she works for has been offered $60,000 by a European government to buy non-food relief items for the displaced people living in the camps - the same camps where we are going to spend $50,000 donated by an Asian government. There now seems to be no shortage of money for the camps and it is becoming increasingly difficult to know how best to spend it. There are more than enough shelters to accommodate the families but some remain empty, as the local authorities are reluctant to move families in. Of course, there are still needs to be met, but it is becoming increasingly difficult to identify needs that can be met locally and fairly quickly.

This morning I went with Latifer, a woman recommended by the ministry of planning, and her brother to Mazlagh Camp, where Ockenden has built shelters for 1,800 families. The drive out is very bumpy and dusty. We pass the customs houses, where hundreds of vehicles are waiting for permission to enter Afghanistan, and an artillery base, filled with tanks waiting to go into action.

On the drive, I explained to Latifer that today's job was to try and identify a project that we could give the women in the camps, enabling them to earn food for work. There are too many quilts in Herat now and the World Food Programme has suggested finding something new to do. Knitting was proposed - to produce jumpers, socks and hats - but we didn't know if the women knew how to knit. As it turned out, after interviewing a number of them, one said that she could only make socks. I handed her a ball of pink wool and a pair of knitting needles, but she said that she only knew how to use six needles! Most of the women claimed to be good with a sewing machine, but several said they had sold theirs to buy food.

After being away, it was really good to see families living in the shelters built by Ockenden. Some have made their shelters quite comfortable, with wood-burning stoves, tarpaulins on the floors, and quilts piled in the corner. Others are concerned that the roofs are wooden - they are used to mud roofs - and are worried about fire as they all cook in the room, but these worries are slowly being overcome.

Later, I met a visitor from an Irish agency that is interested in working through Ockenden in Herat while they get established. I reported back to him on the knitting project, but suggested that a project to make children's clothes might be successful, given the number of women who can use a sewing machine and the number of children who are running around scantily clad. So, this afternoon it was back to the drawing board as I tried to work out how many shalwar kameezes a woman can make each day, how much cloth is needed, how much thread, how many buttons and how many pairs of scissors, etc. And, if the women are paid at 6kg of wheat a day, how much wheat would be needed. All this information must be ready for when he leaves tomorrow, so I guess will have to stand in line for the computer again this evening!

webTitle: Talks held over social service's £205m overspend

fields.headline: Talks held over social service's £205m overspend
fields.trailText: Social services directors and local government leaders held preliminary talks with health minister John Hutton earlier this week over a projected £205m combined overspend in social services department budgets in England this year. Marcia White reports
fields.body:
Social services directors and local government leaders held preliminary talks with health minister John Hutton earlier this week over a projected £205m combined overspend in social services department budgets in England this year.

Wednesday's meeting came two weeks after both the Local Government Association (LGA) and the Association of Directors of Social Services (ADSS) called for urgent talks with government to address the massive budget deficit facing social services departments by the end of March.

The financial crisis came to light after a survey by the societies of county and municipal treasurers found that 85% of the 146 social services departments surveyed expect to go £2m in the red - equal to 2% per authority.

Government policies to improve children's services have been blamed for most of the overspend - accounting for 64%. One important reason is the cost of placing children in both residential and specialist foster care - particularly in the south-east - which has proved a drain on children's services budgets. A further 21% is because of older people's services with 12% going on learning difficulties services and 3% on other services.

Calling for ministers to recognise the spending pressures faced by local authorities, Local Government Association chairman Jeremy Beecham said: "This is obviously a serious financial problem for councils and cannot be sustained in the long term. The number of children in care is rising and the cost of provision especially in residential settings is also increasing."

He warned that other council services could suffer as a result and council tax bills could soar if the matter was not addressed swiftly.

This concern was driven home by Rita Stringfellow, chairwoman of the LGA social affairs and health executive, in a letter to councillors. "The assumption that significant resources over the next three years will be funded by local authorities, reliant on the standing spending assessment (SSA) formula, was not widely understood," it stated.

Earlier surveys this financial year had signalled social services departments were facing particularly severe problems, said ADSS president Moira Gibb. In particular, local authorities had been forced to absorb a 4% rise in the number of looked-after children since the previous year.

This week an LGA spokesman confirmed preliminary talks had taken place with government ministers over a solution for the problem in the long term.

Brian Parrott, chairperson of the ADSS resources committee, said: "On the children's element of the spending pattern there has been a first meeting between DoH officials, LGA and ADSS representatives with a view to doing further work to examine in detail some of the trends in order to have really good information for the next public expenditure process.

"There is a real willingness to work together, I would be encouraged by that."

Local authorities are currently planning their budgets for the next financial year and setting council tax levels. However there is no certainty that social services departments will be in line for extra funding before the end of the financial year.

The current financial pressures on social services departments have been said to be a result of the cumulative effect of increases in social services provision.

While the government has pumped a record £885m into its Quality Protects initiative to improve the care of and services for looked-after children, most of the cash has been earmarked for new services or specific improvements to current provision.

The costs of meeting existing service provision are said to "significantly exceed" both the SSA and local authority budgets for social services departments.

Mr Parrot added: "The government will argue that they put money into the SSA and have provided a lot of specific grants - both of which are true - but some of the expectations about the things which will be done are very desirable, but the funding isn't adequate to meet some of the cumulative pressures which social services departments are currently dealing with."

fields.headline: The president's first foreign foray
fields.standfirst:
The new resident of the White House is making his first trip away from the US, and Derek Brown assesses the state of Bush Jnr's foreign experience

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The new resident of the White House is making his first trip away from the US, and Derek Brown assesses the state of Bush Jnr's foreign experience.
fields.body:
George Bush, who does not count foreign affairs as one of his main strengths, is today taking his first modest trip outside the US since his inauguration.

He is having informal talks with his friend and counterpart in Mexico, President Vicente Fox. Though the discussions will be friendly, they will cover some thorny ground, including immigration, drugs and trade.

The meeting will help both countries prepare for the Summit of the Americas, due to be held in April, in Canada. Bush's first meeting with a foreign head of government was with Canadian prime minister Jean Chretien, days after he took over the White House.

Today's meeting, at President Fox's country retreat in the dusty town of San Cristobal, some 200 miles from Mexico City, symbolically underlines the US president's commitment to closer cooperation in the western hemisphere.

He has talked, rather grandly, of building "a century of the Americas".

The US, Canada and Mexico already have economic links, through the North American Free Trade Area (Nafta). But US-Mexican relations have been bedevilled by other forms of trade: illegal immigration and drugs.

Mexicans fiercely resent the US system that requires the president to certify each year how some 30 countries are cooperating in international efforts to stamp out drug smuggling.

Mexico has never failed the test, but is annually insulted by it. Its officials point out that the trade is fuelled by soaring demand in the US, and that Washington should tackle its own problem of drug consumption, rather than humiliate the producer and transit countries.

Bush evidently has some sympathy with that view. White House aides say the new administration is reviewing the value of the certification process.

In spite of their differences on drug policy, Washington and Mexico City are close on most issues, with the warm personal friendship of the two presidents - forged while Bush was governor of Texas - is an important part of the relationship.

That factor too is likely to encourage Bush to look south for his main foreign policy thrust, rather than east or west. The new president has never concealed his shaky grasp of world geography and diplomacy, or his desire to make domestic policy his presidential priority.

Nevertheless, he will be obliged to step - however gingerly - into the mire of diplomacy from time to time. The two looming issues before the State Department are the crisis in Israeli-Palestinian relations, and the more cerebral matter of US-European relations.

The new regime in the White House is darkly suspicious of EU moves to set up a rapid reaction military force, believing - like the British government - that if it develops too much independence of action, it could gravely undermine Nato.

The Bush administration is also viscerally opposed to the deployment of US forces overseas in peacekeeping operations. It believes that Europe - through Nato - should be contributing more to current operations in the Balkans.

Military matters are likely to figure high on the agenda of next week's talks in Washington by Bush and Tony Blair.

The prime minister has at least some tenuous common ground on which to build a personal relationship with the new president.

There is a widespread fallacy that Bush has only been out of the US once or twice in his life. The truth is a little more encouraging: he has been to Mexico, China, France and the Gambia. But, according to some sources, the country he is said to have visited most is Scotland.

His father, the last president but one, apparently had a close business and personal relationship with Jimmy Gammell, an Edinburgh financier and oil man.

George Bush the younger spent several holidays on Gammell's family farm in Perthshire, where he, in his turn, made friends with Gammell's son Bill - who, as luck would have it, attended the same Edinburgh school as Tony Blair.

fields.headline: Readers switch off TV listings titles
fields.trailText:
ABC update: Readers switched off TV listings mags in their thousands according to the latest circulation figures, writes Julia Day.
Feb 16: Rave reviews for dance mags
Feb 16: Home interest titles demolished
Feb 16: Men's lifestyle titles suffer
Feb 15: Heat rises 138%
Feb 15: Esquire sheds readers
fields.body:
The future of the TV listings magazine sector is looking bleak, with the new July to December Audit Bureau of Circulations figures show declines across the board.

IPC's cash-cow TV Times suffered a 12.9% drop in circulation year-on-year to 689,137, although the period-on-period fall was only 2.3%.

But the company is relaunching the magazine to cover 60 channels compared with the previous 40, including the Sky Digital movie package and additional digital hours on all major channels.

"The last year has seen unprecedented change and growth in the television and television listings markets, bringing both intense competition and significant new opportunities," said Caroline Ward, managing director of IPC's TX division, which handles the publisher's TV titles.

H Bauer Publishing's TV Quick saw its circulation fall 13.4% year-on-year to 553,148.

But TV Quick slowed its decline over the past six months, with a drop of only 4.4% period-on-period.

There was no joy for the soap-oriented titles. A 14.6% year-on-year circulation decline to 111,099 was recorded at All About Soap and Inside Soap saw an 8.5% drop year-on-year to 241,328.

The UK's biggest-selling paid-for magazine, IPC's What's On TV, held up rather better.

What's On TV lost only 2.3% of its circulation in the year to December 2000, finishing with a 1,701,064 circulation.

The BBC's Radio Times, the second biggest-selling magazine in the country, recorded a 5.4% year-on-year drop in circulation to 1,264,315. But the title actually rose 1.1% period-on-period.

The one exception to the rule in the paid-for TV listings sector over the past 12 months was IPC's TV & Satellite Week, which recorded a 22.4% increase year-on-year to 221,018.

Media buyers said the paid-for TV listings market was taking a big hit from free titles.

BSkyB's free Sky Customer Magazine, formerly Skyview Digital, saw a 212% increase in circulation year-on-year to 3,873,637.

The magazine TV listings sector is also suffering from newspapers' increased emphasis on TV listings products.

fields.headline: BBC1 claims second 10pm news victory
fields.trailText: 3pm TV overnights: Live football helped BBC1's Ten O'Clock News to beat its ITV rival last night, reports Wale Azeez
fields.body:
BBC1's Ten O'Clock News beat its ITV rival for the second time in three days last night, after a leg-up from live European football.

The BBC1 bulletin had 5.2m viewers and a 26% audience share, according to unofficial overnights. It narrowly beat ITV's News at Ten, which had 4.9m and 25%.

From 7.55pm until 10pm, Match of the Day Live, featuring Liverpool's 2-0 Uefa Cup win against Roma, gave BBC1 a 31% share with 7.5m viewers.

But BBC1's football coverage still lost out to ITV.

Ratings juggernaut Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? took 10m viewers and a 41% share from 8pm.

Drama At Home With The Braithwaites had 8.2m and a 33% share between 9-10pm.

Elsewhere last night, Channel 4 documentary Danger! Unexploded Bomb beat its 9pm BBC2 competition Horizon.

Danger! Unexploded Bomb had 2.2m viewers, while Horizon, about a stuntman who is using Ecstasy to relieve his Parkinson's Disease symptons, managed only 1.9m.

webTitle: A Painted House by John Grisham

fields.headline: A Painted House by John Grisham
fields.standfirst:
Century, £16.99
Condensed in the style of the original
Buy it at a discount from BOL
fields.trailText: Seven-year-old boy observes two murders and a failed cotton crop before moving north to become a bestselling author writing crime thrillers about lawyers
fields.body:
I was seven years old in 1952. My Mom and my father lived with Pappy and Gran on a rented cotton farm in Arkansas. My Mom always wanted a painted house, but we were desperate poor and had to make do with bare boards.

"C'mon Luke," said Pappy. "It's time to get us some hill people and Mexicans for the harvest."

I climbed into the truck and we headed off to Black Oak. We picked up the Mexicans, Miguel, Cowboy and the others in Main Street and on the way home we met some hill people.

"You looking for work?" asked Pappy. I didn't much care for money talk so I walked round to the back of the trailer. There was a mighty pretty girl in there.

"Hi, I'm Tally Spruill," she said. "This here is Trot. He ain't right. He's a crip. And that's Hank." Hank glowered.

We got home and Gran made sure they was all comfortable as she never did see why foreigners should be treated bad.

It was awful hot as the harvest started and the sweat clung to our backs. "Looks like there's a storm coming," said father.

We went into town on Saturday and I saw a fight between Hank and the three Sisco boys. I heard later that one died, but I was too scared to say nothing.

"What happened?" asked the deputy.

"It's like Hank said," I replied.

"Leave it till after the harvest," Pappy added, "We need the help."

Hank and Cowboy fell out over a baseball game and Cowboy drew a blade. My father broke up the fight but the atmosphere was always mighty tense after that. "Looks like there's a storm coming," said father.

"The deputy wants to talk to Hank again," said Pappy. "He'd better leave."

I saw Cowboy follow him down the road; I hid in the grass as Cowboy knifed Hank and pushed him in the river. Food for the catfish. I shivered and didn't say a word.

"Cowboy and Tally have gone off together," said Mom. "There's a storm coming," said Pappy.

The flood waters rose. Trot had started painting the house: I was desperate to finish it but I couldn't afford the paint.

"The crop's ruined," said father. "We're heading north."

fields.headline: Sugar wins libel battle
fields.trailText: 2.45pm: Sir Alan Sugar has won his libel case against the Daily Mail, writes Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
Sir Alan Sugar has won his libel case against the Daily Mail.

Mr Sugar was awarded £100,000 in damages today by the high court.

The case centred on a Daily Mail story that accused him of being "miserly" in his stewardship of Tottenham Hotspur Football Club.

"I didn't do it for the money. Newspapers will have to be more responsible," Mr Sugar said afterwards.

Sugar won a unanimous verdict from the jury in the case.

The 53-year-old businessman sued the Daily Mail over a December 1999 story by soccer writer Jeff Powell.

The piece stated Sugar must come out of his "counting house" and give manager George Graham money to buy high-class players.

Mr Powell denied libel and pleaded fair comment.

"This case was about freedom of expression," a spokesman for the newspaper said.

"Jeff Powell and the Daily Mail were defending their right to comment in hard-hitting terms on a matter of public interest."

Mr Sugar recently relinquished his chairmanship of Spurs after complaining about constant pressure from fans.

Former Spurs striker Teddy Sheringham, among others, gave evidence at the trial.

fields.headline: Sugar wins Mail libel damages
fields.trailText: Tottenham chairman Sir Alan Sugar has won £100,000 High Court libel damages over a newspaper article which called him "miserly" in his stewardship of the club.
fields.body:
Tottenham chairman Sir Alan Sugar has won £100,000 High Court libel damages over a newspaper article which called him "miserly" in his stewardship of the club.

The 53-year-old multi-millionaire businessman had sued the Daily Mail over a December 1999 story that said he must come out of his "counting house" and give manager George Graham the cash to buy high class players.

Associated Newspapers and soccer writer Jeff Powell had denied libel and pleaded fair comment.

Sir Alan mopped his brow with a handkerchief and smiled at his wife Ann, who squeezed his arm in congratulation, as the unanimous verdict came after the jury had retired for just two hours.

"I am just pleased it's all over really. It has been a terrible time," he told reporters outside the court. He said he would donate all the damages to Great Ormond Street Hospital in London.

Sugar had denied in evidence that it was his fault that Spurs had not won the Premiership title. He said that during his time at White Hart Lane, nearly £100m gross had been spent on the club, with Graham appointed in October 1998 to build a successful side.

"All I've ever tried to do is my best for this football club. I can't help it if managers went out and bought the wrong players. I can only provide the money.

"To see this rubbish here - and it is total rubbish - has just devastated me," Sir Alan said.

A spokesman for the newspaper said afterwards: "This case was about freedom of expression. Jeff Powell and the Daily Mail were defending their right to comment in hard-hitting terms on a matter of public interest."

webTitle: Francis resigns as manager of QPR

fields.headline: Francis resigns as manager of QPR
fields.trailText: Gerry Francis has stepped down as manager of relegation-threatened Queens Park Rangers to spend more time with his family.
fields.body:
Gerry Francis has stepped down as manager of relegation-threatened Queens Park Rangers to spend more time with his family.

A new manager will be appointed to take immediate control of first-team affairs although Francis will remain at the club until the end of the season.

Rangers are currently bottom of the First Division with just four victories from 30 games. But today Francis insisted his decision had nothing to do with his side's struggle against relegation.

He said: "It would have been much nicer if it had been last year when we were in no danger whatsoever but whatever the situation in terms of our position - even if we had been second from top - it would have happened.

"I've got a young family and I want a bit of time with them. I've been in football now with only one break since 1967 which is a hell of a long time."

Francis, who managed Rangers from 1991 to 1994 and returned in October 1998 after nearly a year out of the game following his departure from Tottenham, said he was happy to remain at Loftus Road until the end of the season. However, he is yet to accept his club's offer of a seat on the board.

"Any help I can give to the new manager I will give but at the same time the new person coming in will have full responsibility for team affairs," Francis added.

fields.headline: Media Week
fields.standfirst: Publication date: February 16
fields.trailText: February 16: Pfizer is to review is media planning and buying in the UK and Europe.
fields.body:
Pfizer, which this week appointed Carat to its consolidated $700m media planning and buying account in the US, is to hold a similar review of its business in the UK and Europe.

Emap Digital has revealed all the major magazine brands that have yet to launch dedicated websites will do so by the end of the year.

Andria Vidler, the newly appointed managing director of Capital Radio London, has announced a restructure of its marketing and communications department.

True North is to step up its investment in True North Media, its standalone UK media brand.

The MXR digital radio consortium is to offer listeners an on-demand service dubbed "TiVo for radio".

IPC Media is to establish a standalone events and exhibitions business division called IPC Live!.

webTitle: Home interest sector loses out in ABCs

fields.headline: Home interest sector loses out in ABCs
fields.trailText:
11am update: The home interest sector has joined the wounded in the latest ABCs, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Feb 16: Men's lifestyle titles suffer
Feb 15: Heat circulation up 138%
Feb 15: Esquire sheds downmarket readers
fields.body:
The homes and home interest sector has been severely dented in the latest ABCs, with seven titles reporting double-digit circulation falls.

Two of IPC's home interest magazines, Country Homes and Interiors and Homes and Ideas, reported declines of more than 10%.

Homes and Ideas lost 32% of its circulation in a year, falling from 181,090 in the last six months of 1999 to 122,830 in the second half of last year.

Country Homes and Interiors fell 14.8% from 111,616 to 95,063 over the same period.

BBC Good Homes has had a 12% fall, from 151,763 to 133,220, while The National Magazine Company's Your Home lost 24.6%, from 181,263 to 136,642.

Inspirations for Your Home, published by GE magazines, sank to 72,291 from 112,121.

One media buyer said the market was "totally oversaturated" and suggested the proliferation of TV shows such as Changing Rooms may have contributed to the decline in the magazine audience.

"I regret to say that this is a magazine market that has become totally saturated," said Duncan Edwards, deputy managing director of NatMags.

He added that the company was "committed" to House Beautiful, the magazine launched in the late 1980s and credited with revolutionising the sector.

IPC Southbank managing director Tim Brook said the home interest market was due for a shakeout.

"There have been a lot of launches over the past year from smaller companies trying to grab a slice of the market," he said.

He added that the market was "Darwinian" and predicted that "as new species enter the market, some titles will go to the wall".

Mr Brook claimed he was not "overly worried" about IPC's position because it "controls over a third of the market".

fields.headline: Bus bomb kills Serbs
fields.standfirst: Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: Ten Serbs were killed and at least 40 others wounded today, as a blast wrecked the bus that was carrying them into the southern Yugoslav province of Kosovo.
fields.body:
Ten Serbs were killed and at least 40 others wounded today, as a blast wrecked the bus that was carrying them into the southern Yugoslav province of Kosovo.

Lt Neil Tomlin, spokesman for British troops stationed in Kosovo, said that a bus, travelling from the city of Nis in Serbia to the Serb-majority town Podujevo in Kosovo, was attacked shortly after it crossed the boundary into the province.

The attack occurred around 11.30am (10.30 GMT) Lt Tomlin said. No other details were immediately available.

Kosovo has been the scene of violent attacks by ethnic Albanian militants against the dwindling minority of Serbs ever since the United Nations and a Nato-led peacekeeping force took over after the pullout of the Yugoslav army.

Ethnic Albanians are pushing for independence for Kosovo, after suffering repression for some 10 years under the rule of former Yugoslav president Slobodan Milosevic.

However, this has been rejected by international officials, who are seeking to reestablish a multi-ethnic Kosovo.
