fields.headline: 'I'm no scouse specialist'
fields.standfirst: He made a reputation playing John Lennon - twice. Then Ken Loach cast him as the Liverpudlian lead in Land and Freedom. But there's more to Ian Hart than Merseyside. He talks to  Claire Armitstead
fields.trailText: He made a reputation playing John Lennon - twice. Then Ken Loach cast him as the Liverpudlian lead in Land and Freedom. But there's more to Ian Hart than Merseyside. He talks to Claire Armitstead
fields.body:
It is hard to keep up with Ian Hart. One minute he's deadpanning it in a silly romantic comedy and the next he's gone all sepia in one of those unflinching Depression movies that see craggy faces like his as part of the industrial landscape. To get his opinions on these two latest outings, he has to be hauled off the set of Harry Potter. What's he doing in that? "Well, put it like this, if you're not a kid, you're a wizard."

Hart is acerbically witty and one of the most scratchily, self-laceratingly talented actors to not-quite-arrive in the last decade. He is big enough to carry your average British movie, but unfortunately the average British movie is, well, average, and there doesn't seem to be an easy way out of it for a first-class character actor.

In Liam, a low-budget film released next week, you see exactly his predicament. Hart plays the father of the seven-year-old title character: a Liverpool shipyard worker who loses his job, his pride and finally his head in the slump of the 1930s. Written by Jimmy McGovern and directed by Stephen Frears, it is a humane and all too credible portrait of the corrosive power of poverty, which draws its emotional strength from understatement.

At 36, Hart is rather young to play the father of three children, two practically grown-up, and yet he creates a character who is entirely credible. The camera hikes around his features, revelling in the bleakness it finds in them. That bleakness echoes the spareness of the dialogue. There is such an obvious understanding between writer and actor - quite apart from the fact that they are both from Liverpool - that it seems bizarre that this is the first time Hart and McGovern have worked together. "The great thing about Jimmy's writing is that the dialogue is so clear," says Hart. "It's all very simple and should be done that way. The images are woven into it."

The images are born of Catholic guilt and repression - and Hart remembers them well from his own childhood. One of three children born to a Catholic family in an "arse-end estate in Knotty Ash", he emerged from his altar-boy phase with a healthy contempt for authority, parti- cularly when wielded by men in frocks.

"When you get to 15 and most of your teachers are priests, there's bound to be a conflict," he shrugs. After leaving grammar school (where he was advised by his careers officer to join the army), he went to college to take A levels. There, by his own report, he fell out with just about everyone. He won a place at drama school in London at 18, but left after two weeks' sleeping rough. "It was an abomination: nothing to do with acting. I went and got a job; you learn more doing that than doing training."

Though some of his jobs were in the theatre, others were not. Over the years, he has delivered cakes and worked in kitchens, on a farm and in a plastics factory. He also spent a while making corporate videos on subjects like "sewage treatment and John West salmon". It wasn't glamorous, but "it meant I was relatively technically adept, I can edit and wire up a light".

His career path might suggest that he is one of those instinctive actors with little time for technique, and yet he is a ferociously intelligent performer who is conscientious to a fault. That much was clear when, back in the summer, he appeared in The Closer You Get, a sort of Irish Full Monty, as a village butcher involved in a plan to lure some willing blondes from Texas. Hart seemed to have conceived the character of Kieran around the testicles: his absent-minded rubbing became not only a comic motif but a defining characteristic of a young man in a state of primal, and pongy, innocence. For once, he wore his technique on the outside.

He is not usually so obvious. He played John Lennon so well, in two separate films (notably in Backbeat), that he has spent years since proving that he is not simply a Scouse specialist. Anyone who dismisses him as a one-tune wonder clearly hasn't seen his 18th-century clockmaker's son in the TV costume drama Longitude, his psychopathic Unionist thug in Thaddeus O'Sullivan's Belfast-set chiller Nothing Personal, or his hapless private eye in Neil Jordan's adaptation of The End of the Affair.

It's a curious fact, he says, that he has probably made as many Irish films as most Irish actors. "In fact, I've only used my own voice about four times on film." Yet when he recently appeared as Nobby Stiles in a biopic of George Best, the tag "resolutely Scouse" came back to haunt him. "That bugged me because it implied that I hadn't done my job properly and that's not the case." In fact, he based his portrayal on a scrupulously studied tape recording of the footballer's voice.

If he is scornful of the lazy and the second-rate, he is also his own toughest critic. There is a scene in Liam in which he lurches to his feet in church and begins to hurl insults at the pulpit. "I did it again and again in all different ways, and the next day when I woke up I knew what I should have done: but that's the performance I gave and the audience won't know any different."

Of The End of the Affair, he says: "I could enjoy the 60% of the film I wasn't in. I hate me. I always see the mistakes I made. Just because someone else didn't notice it, it doesn't mean that it isn't there."

His reluctance to watch himself on film can have results which even he finds sickly funny. Once, returning to the US two years after making a film there, he plucked up courage to watch it on video in his hotel room, only to find that his part had been almost entirely erased. Worse, the bit that did remain was a scene in which he played an American playing an Englishman. "It was out of context so it looked as if I was bad at both."

At the last count, he knows that he has to shrug it off; it is part of the actor's lot to be at the disposal of directors and producers. "I only ask that everyone should be good at what they do. What I don't like is having to be on set and working your bollocks off and some bloody production assistant hasn't got the bag of crisps you need. That's what I like about Neil Jordan's films: everyone is better at what they do than you are."

He has made three films so far with Jordan, and, in a rare and expensive mark of respect, Jordan agreed to reshoot Hart's death scene in Michael Collins, even though it involved helicopters and crowds of extras. "The thing about Neil," says Hart, "is that he creates a very good atmosphere to work in. He trusts actors. He's very honest - sometimes brutally so. If it's not working you're going to hear about it. You're not left to hang yourself."

There, perhaps, is one key to Hart - a fear of hanging himself which has led to a raw, strafing bolshiness that is not to be confused with arrogance. Ken Loach, who directed him in Land and Freedom, one of his first and finest successes, says: "The film we did together was quite extraordinary in a way, in that it was a group of people, some of whom were actors and some of whom were not, and we had to turn them into a militia.

"I think it was probably quite unnerving for Ian to begin with, particularly since many of them were Spanish. But he chipped in very well. He was very direct and straight, which are the qualities I tend to look for. Even though he had the main part, he didn't ask for, and wasn't given, any special attention. But he made it his own. He's also got a good dry sense of humour."

Land and Freedom is the film Hart is proudest of, and one of his regrettably few starring roles. That dry sense of humour stands him in good stead as he contemplates the future - in particular his sudden professional leap in age. In the salsa comedy Born Romantic, he is a greasy-spoon cynic whose sour observations on women and relationships frame the romantic shenanigans of just such young oddballs as he might himself have played a couple of years back. He reckons he has finally waved goodbye to a long line of arrested adolescents. "It's not any desire on my part to start playing dads, but it's a convention of drama. If you don't get the parts of young people going out to nightclubs, you have to play their fathers."

At least the scripts keep on coming in, enabling him to pick and choose, while living in comfort in north London with his teacher wife and their four-year-old daughter. He will only take parts that interest him, however small they are. "I've done some poop," he says, "but only because it turned out that way."

Liam is released on February 23 and Born Romantic on March 9.

Hart seemed to have conceived the character of Kieran around the testicles: his absent-minded rubbing became not only a comic motif but a defining characteristic of a young man in a state of primal, and pongy, innocence. For once, he wore his technique on the outside. He is not usually so obvious. He played John Lennon so well, in two separate films (notably in Backbeat), that he has spent years since proving that he is not simply a Scouse specialist. Anyone who dismisses him as a one-tune wonder clearly hasn't seen his 18th-century clockmaker's son in the TV costume drama Longitude, his psychopathic Unionist thug in Thaddeus O'Sullivan's Belfast-set chiller Nothing Personal, or his hapless private eye in Neil Jordan's adaptation of The End of the Affair. It's a curious fact, he says, that he has probably made as many Irish films as most Irish actors. "In fact, I've only used my own voice about four times on film." Yet when he recently appeared as Nobby Stiles in a biopic of George Best, the tag "resolutely Scouse" came back to haunt him. "That bugged me because it implied that I hadn't done my job properly and that's not the case." In fact, he based his portrayal on a scrupulously studied tape recording of the footballer's voice. If he is scornful of the lazy and the second-rate, he is also his own toughest critic. There is a scene in Liam in which he lurches to his feet in church and begins to hurl insults at the pulpit. "I did it again and again in all different ways, and the next day when I woke up I knew what I should have done: but that's the performance I gave and the audience won't know any different." Of The End of the Affair, he says: "I could enjoy the 60% of the film I wasn't in. I hate me. I always see the mistakes I made. Just because someone else didn't notice it, it doesn't mean that it isn't there." His reluctance to watch himself on film can have results which even he finds sickly funny. Once, returning to the US two years after making a film there, he plucked up courage to watch it on video in his hotel room, only to find that his part had been almost entirely erased. Worse, the bit that did remain was a scene in which he played an American playing an Englishman. "It was out of context so it looked as if I was bad at both." At the last count, he knows that he has to shrug it off; it is part of the actor's lot to be at the disposal of directors and producers. "I only ask that everyone should be good at what they do. What I don't like is having to be on set and working your bollocks off and some bloody production assistant hasn't got the bag of crisps you need. That's what I like about Neil Jordan's films: everyone is better at what they do than you are." He has made three films so far with Jordan, and, in a rare and expensive mark of respect, Jordan agreed to reshoot Hart's death scene in Michael Collins, even though it involved helicopters and crowds of extras. "The thing about Neil," says Hart, "is that he creates a very good atmosphere to work in. He trusts actors. He's very honest - sometimes brutally so. If it's not working you're going to hear about it. You're not left to hang yourself." There, perhaps, is one key to Hart - a fear of hanging himself which has led to a raw, strafing bolshiness that is not to be confused with arrogance. Ken Loach, who directed him in Land and Freedom, one of his first and finest successes, says: "The film we did together was quite extraordinary in a way, in that it was a group of people, some of whom were actors and some of whom were not, and we had to turn them into a militia. "I think it was probably quite unnerving for Ian to begin with, particularly since many of them were Spanish. But he chipped in very well. He was very direct and straight, which are the qualities I tend to look for. Even though he had the main part, he didn't ask for, and wasn't given, any special attention. But he made it his own. He's also got a good dry sense of humour." Land and Freedom is the film Hart is proudest of, and one of his regrettably few starring roles. That dry sense of humour stands him in good stead as he contemplates the future - in particular his sudden professional leap in age. In the salsa comedy Born Romantic, he is a greasy-spoon cynic whose sour observations on women and relationships frame the romantic shenanigans of just such young oddballs as he might himself have played a couple of years back. He reckons he has finally waved goodbye to a long line of arrested adolescents. "It's not any desire on my part to start playing dads, but it's a convention of drama. If you don't get the parts of young people going out to nightclubs, you have to play their fathers." At least the scripts keep on coming in, enabling him to pick and choose, while living in comfort in north London with his teacher wife and their four-year-old daughter. He will only take parts that interest him, however small they are. "I've done some poop," he says, "but only because it turned out that way." Liam is released on February 23 and Born Romantic on March 9.

fields.standfirst: Publication date: February 16
fields.trailText: February 16: The Leith London has won the Marie Claire account after a four-way pitch.
fields.body:
The Leith London has landed its first account, beating three agencies to the task of revamping Marie Claire.

Triumph International is to centralise its pan-European creative and media accounts.

A press campaign for Unison, featuring a wrist that has been slit because of government cutbacks, has been condemned by the Samaritans for potentially inspiring "copy-cat behaviour".

The lads' magazine sector is to enjoy a revival in today's ABC figures, while several high-profile women's titles take a circulation dive.

The government is about to launch a £3m campaign to encourage people to vote.

Harry Enfield is turning his comedic talents to advertising by becoming a commercials director.

fields.headline: Future names doomed mags
fields.trailText:
2pm update: Future Network, which is closing 20 magazines worldwide, has named the doomed titles. By Jessica Hodgson.
Feb 16: Future axes 350
fields.body:
Future Network, the beleaguered publishing house that this morning announced plans to close 20 magazines worldwide, has put names to some of the doomed titles.

Future's technology-based magazines have taken the brunt of the cuts. Quick and Easy Windows, WAP, Digital Camera User, DC UK and Your Imac are all to close.

But a Future spokesman said most of the job cuts would be from commercial, administrative and support departments and the company did not anticipate making journalists or designers redundant.

Video Gamer, Best Games Ever and PlayStation Tips are also suspending publication.

In addition, Future Network is to suspend five websites: mbuk.co.uk, sfx.co.uk, cross-stitch.com, totalfilm.co.uk and the German Powderplay.de.

Future Network is planning to amalgamate its online magazine sites into a single "portal" with different channels.

But an estimated 75 online staff internationally will lose their jobs.

Staff at the company's Bath headquarters were given further details of the cuts at a meeting this morning.

Future Network is also considering putting its high-profile new economy title Business 2.0 up for sale.

The French arm of the business is to sell five of its titles, while the US company will sell six.

Future Network has 130 magazine titles worldwide and employs 2,000 staff, of whom 1,200 are based in the UK.

It is not known whether the launch of Future's high-profile Xbox magazine is to shelved.

The cutbacks follow a series of profit warnings from the company, with the share price falling by 87% in the past six months.

At the end of last year Future reported a black hole in the accounts of its French subsidiary.

The firm's ABC figures, announced this morning, showed that most of the publisher's titles had seen falls in circulation.

webTitle: Bulger father loses bid to block killers' release

fields.headline: Bulger father loses bid to block killers' release
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the Bulger case
Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: Ralph Bulger, the father of murdered toddler James Bulger, today lost his high court challenge to keep his son's killers, Robert Thompson and Jon Venables, in prison.
fields.body:
Ralph Bulger, the father of murdered toddler James Bulger, today lost his high court challenge to keep his son's killers, Robert Thompson and Jon Venables, in prison.

Three senior judges rejected accusations that the lord chief justice, Lord Woolf, had set a minimum sentence for the child killers which was so low - given the enormity of the crime - that it threatened to "undermine confidence in the criminal justice system".

Lord Justice Rose, sitting with Mr Justice Sullivan and Mr Justice Penry-Davey, ruled that Ralph Bulger did not have legal standing to challenge the tariff. They also refused Mr Bulger permission to appeal against their decision. The heart of the decision is that victims do not have the right to intervene in tariffs set by the court.

The decision was a bitter defeat for Mr Bulger in his attempt to overturn Lord Woolf's recommendation last October which allows Thompson and Venables to be considered for parole in the near future.

"I am absolutely devastated by today's ruling. I have spent two years trying to get this back to court and it now seems it is all over," Mr Bulger said in a statement.

In his ruling in October Lord Woolf took into account that neither boy had shown "any aggression or propensity for violence during his period of detention" after being sentenced for the crime.

But lawyers for Mr Bulger argued that Lord Woolf's recommendation to reduce the child killers' tariff for retribution and deterrence to seven years and eight months should be quashed because of the new evidence about Thompson and other flaws in the judge's decision.

It was claimed the tariff should be reconsidered because of the "astounding" failure of the Home Office authorities to tell the judge of newspaper reports that Thompson had been involved in two violent incidents.

Lord Woolf went wrong in law when he cut the tariff because he put rehabilitation before the needs of punishment and deterrence, lawyers for Mr Bulger claimed.

Thompson and Venables, who were 10 when they abducted and tortured two-year-old James on a railway line in Liverpool in 1993, have so far served their sentences in secure local authority accommodation.

fields.headline: Clickmango set for comeback
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: Defunct health and beauty website Clickmango is set to return and wants to resign Joanna Lumley, writes Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
Defunct health and beauty dot.com Clickmango is set to reappear, this time on the high street, and is looking to rehire brand spokeswoman Joanna Lumley.

US firm Red Beach, which bought the brand from its founders Toby Rowland and Robert Norton, will relaunch it in the next few months.

European e-business consultancy Adcore Strategy is co-ordinating the launch and said it was close to signing a deal with "a major high street chain" to feature the Clickmango brand in its stores.

It has not yet been decided whether this will be take the form of licensing an exclusive product range or an in-store concession.

The Clickmango website will also be relaunched.

Clickmango, which specialised in selling natural health and beauty products online, hit the wall last September.

With Joanna Lumley writing for the site and appearing in advertising, it was one of the year's most high-profile online casualties.

"Despite its initial failure, Clickmango has a well-known, fun and funky brand," said Sarah Collins, UK manager at Adcore Strategy.

"Joanna Lumley gave the brand a friendly association and it would be nice to get her back."

Ms Collins did not believe the brand has been tarnished by its well-publicised collapse last year.

"Our research shows that unlike Boo.com, Clickmango went down in a positive fashion. It was well-respected business and didn't leave a chain of creditors."

Adcore Strategy said the exciting nature of the project encouraged it to buy a "significant minority stake" in Clickmango.

Ms Collins acknowledged the need to relaunch quickly due to the "short shelf-life of brands".

fields.headline: Warner Bros launches Warnerbros.co.uk
fields.trailText: 1pm: Warner Bros has taken the first step in a global online expansion, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Entertainment giant Warner Bros has launched the first of its country-specific websites as part of its planned global online expansion.

Providing TV and movie clips, entertainment news, shopping and community elements, Warnerbros.co.uk is hoping to position itself as one of the leading entertainment sites on the web.

Kevin Tsujihara, executive vice-president of new media at Warner Bros, which is a subsidiary of AOL Time Warner, said the move was intended to reinforce the Warner brand internationally.

"By presenting these sites in the local language and offering localised content, we're maximising the effectiveness of our promotional efforts," said Mr Tsujihara.

"And, by customising content from the world's largest entertainment company, we're extending the web users' relationship with our product and programming."

Warner Bros has turned its strategic focus on developing content specifically for digital media distribution.

In addition, the outfit will be showcasing existing entertainment content, which includes Harry Potter, The Matrix, Friends, ER and Looney Tunes, through the websites.

Warner Bros also plans to release a number of full-length feature films for download over the internet and use its new websites to salvage the remnants of the now-defunct AOL entertainment portal Entertaindom.com.

The UK website launch will be followed by others in Germany, France, Italy and Spain before the end of the year.

The move bucks the recent trend of media companies scaling back online operations.

Last month, Disney cut back many of its online activities and said it would close its flagship portal Go.com.

The high-profile US-based entertainment portal Z.com last week announced it would be shutting up shop, just days after competitor Icebox.com closed down.

webTitle: Deprived areas missing out on funds

fields.headline: Deprived areas missing out on funds
fields.trailText: Socially deprived areas of the UK are failing to get their fair share of the £280m of grants handed out each year by the national lottery charities board, according to a critical report by MPs published today. Patrick Butler reports
fields.body:
Socially deprived areas of the UK are failing to get their fair share of the £280m of grants handed out each year by the national lottery charities board, according to a critical report by MPs published today.

The board, which has distributed more than 28,000 grants to charities and voluntary groups over the past five years, needs to do more to open up access to funds for disadvantaged groups, says the report.

It recommends that the charities board work more closely with local authorities to ensure they can exploit council's "knowledge and expertise" to ensure grants reach the neediest areas. It should also look at ways of simplifying the grant application and monitoring process, and helping "less capable" organisations prepare successful applications for funding.

"Although the charities board already take account of social exclusion when distributing grants, they need to do more to ensure that grants reach the most disadvantaged areas," says the report by the common's public accounts committee.

It adds: "Some of the most deprived areas have yet to see the full benefit of lottery money."

Although 80% of projects from the board's first three grant projects were progressing as planned, up to £145m may have gone to projects that had "gone off track," says the report.

Committee chairman David Davis said: "The charities board has done much to help the most disadvantaged in society and I am pleased that the vast majority of their projects are doing well."

"But a proportion of projects across all lottery distributors seem to go off track and there is little evidence of those bodies learning from mistakes."

It says the board, which will change its name in April to the community fund, needed to further strengthen its management arrangements to ensure that projects are properly evaluated. The board needs to be "vigilant" of fraud, and ensure that applicants, particularly on smaller projects, have proper fraud awareness training. The board is aware of then current cases of suspected fraud.

webTitle: World dispatch: The US love affair with its military

fields.headline: The danger of boys with toys
fields.standfirst: The reaction to the sinking of a Japanese fishing vessel by the USS Greeneville was symptomatic of America's unhealthy adoration of its armed forces, writes Martin Kettle
fields.trailText: The reaction to the sinking of a Japanese fishing vessel by the USS Greeneville was symptomatic of America's unhealthy adoration of its armed forces, writes Martin Kettle.
fields.body:
Confronted with any issue involving the US military, American politicians go brain dead.

With an occasional honourable exception, they revert to being boys with toys, adopting a servility and a sycophancy more appropriate to a dictatorship than to a democracy.

In modern American politics, as in some other countries, the military exists only to be flattered, praised and fawned over. But the intensity of the American adoration of the military is exceptional.

As a result, American politicians use the military to parade their patriotic credentials rather than their capacity for objective judgment. To attempt even constructive criticism of the military is to invite political suicide, especially for a Democrat, so most of them never bother to try.

This week, George Bush has been on a series of defence related events, helping to promote his plans for extra military spending and new military deployments, notably the missile defence system. True to type, he has made the usual speeches about brave men and women in uniform.

Equally true to type, he has avoided any discussion of the latest American military disaster, an event from which most Americans seem instinctively to have averted their eyes.

It is now nearly a week since the USS Greeneville nuclear powered attack submarine rose from the ocean just south of Hawaii, in an area where it was not supposed to be, and smashed into a Japanese fishing vessel, the Ehime Maru.

The fishing vessel rapidly sank to the floor of the Pacific, taking nine of its 35-strong crew with it. Four of the dead were school students on a training exercise.

In the US, the incident was a big story when it happened, but it rapidly disappeared from the front pages - though not from the Japanese front pages.

But now, with the revelation that the Greeneville was full of civilian businessmen getting a grace and favour spin in a US Navy sub, and that two of the civilians were actually sitting at the controls as the sub surfaced, the story has forced its way back into the headlines. Even so, it is an object lesson in the inadequacy of civilian scrutiny of military matters.

Yesterday, two of the 16 civilians who were on the Greeneville went on NBC television's breakfast show to describe their experiences. One of them, John Hall, described how he was allowed to pull the levers for the Greeneville's emergency ascent drill that led to the destruction of the Ehime Maru.

Another, Todd Thoman, explained that the sub came up to periscope depth and completed a series of 360-degree scans of the ocean, but without spotting the fishing boat.

Then as the Greeneville surged to the surface there was "a very loud noise and the entire submarine shuddered". Commander Scott Waddle then uttered words which, in the circumstances, are to be applauded for their restraint. "Jesus, what the hell was that," he said.

Separately, a Hawaii television station reported yesterday that another two of the civilian guests were local businessmen. All 16, the station reported, were large donors to the USS Missouri Restoration Fund, a fund whose purpose is to maintain the old battleship now used as a visitor centre in nearby Pearl Harbour on Oahu island in Hawaii.

Five years ago, when a US air force fighter sliced through a ski-lift cable in the Italian Alps, killing a cable-car full of skiers, the instinctive reaction of the military was to deny responsibility, destroy incriminating evidence, and refuse to hand the suspects over to local jurisdictions. Instead, the pilot and navigator were eventually tried in a court martial in the US.

Now, in the Greenville incident, several of the same reflexes have come into play. The Navy has been slow to respond truthfully, evasive about the events, and insensitive to the feelings of its foreign victims.

In particular, one gets a nagging sense in some responses that Japanese losses at American hands in the vicinity of Pearl Harbour are not all that serious, what with one thing and another. The good news is that some of the things that should have been done much more quickly are at least now being done.

A proper search is being organised. Japanese sensibilities are beginning to register. The sloppiness of the Navy's behaviour is beginning to be criticised, though not by any politician that I have yet noticed.

But the Greeneville has been an illustration of the difficulty which Americans have about looking their military in the eye. Too often, proper scrutiny of military matters is blinded by the flag and by an obsequious attitude to US military power and authority.

And if it is difficult to get the facts and to be objective about a relatively small thing like this accident, then how much more difficult is it to get the facts and be objective about a really big thing like the multi-billion dollar missile defence programme? But it is all part of the same failing.

Commander Scott Waddle then uttered words which, in the circumstances, are to be applauded for their restraint. "Jesus, what the hell was that," he said. Separately, a Hawaii television station reported yesterday that another two of the civilian guests were local businessmen. All 16, the station reported, were large donors to the USS Missouri Restoration Fund, a fund whose purpose is to maintain the old battleship now used as a visitor centre in nearby Pearl Harbour on Oahu island in Hawaii. Five years ago, when a US air force fighter sliced through a ski-lift cable in the Italian Alps, killing a cable-car full of skiers, the instinctive reaction of the military was to deny responsibility, destroy incriminating evidence, and refuse to hand the suspects over to local jurisdictions. Instead, the pilot and navigator were eventually tried in a court martial in the US. Now, in the Greenville incident, several of the same reflexes have come into play. The Navy has been slow to respond truthfully, evasive about the events, and insensitive to the feelings of its foreign victims. In particular, one gets a nagging sense in some responses that Japanese losses at American hands in the vicinity of Pearl Harbour are not all that serious, what with one thing and another. The good news is that some of the things that should have been done much more quickly are at least now being done. A proper search is being organised. Japanese sensibilities are beginning to register. The sloppiness of the Navy's behaviour is beginning to be criticised, though not by any politician that I have yet noticed. But the Greeneville has been an illustration of the difficulty which Americans have about looking their military in the eye. Too often, proper scrutiny of military matters is blinded by the flag and by an obsequious attitude to US military power and authority. And if it is difficult to get the facts and to be objective about a relatively small thing like this accident, then how much more difficult is it to get the facts and be objective about a really big thing like the multi-billion dollar missile defence programme? But it is all part of the same failing. fields.headline: PR Week
fields.standfirst: Publication date: February 16
fields.trailText: The directors of Freud Communications are understood to be attempting to buy the company back from parent AMV.
fields.body:
The directors of Freud Communications, including chairman Matthew Freud, are understood to be attempting to buy the company back from parent AMV.

The World Gold Council has hired Edelman PR Worldwide to spearhead a five-year global campaign to combat weak gold prices.

Cable & Wireless is putting its global financial and corporate PR business up for pitch as part of a communications overhaul.

A committee of Mercedes Benz dealers has appointed Burson-Marsteller in a bid to save its members' jobs. DaimlerChrysler intends to take control of the 156 dealerships in a year.

Weber Shandwick Worldwide's public affairs team has won a brief from the Blackpool Challenge Partnership to help turn Blackpool into a gambling mecca.

Miller Brewing Company has handed Republic its European PR brief.

London Underground's media relations manager of six years, Philip Carter, has resigned. Claire Filby takes over the role.

Whisky producer the Edrington Group, whose brands include Famous Grouse and the Macallan, has hired Emrys Inker as corporate affairs director.

Tomy has appointed freelance Jane Bookham and agency Attenborough Associates to handle PR for the next 12 months.

webTitle: Restoring faith in the organ donor system

fields.headline: Restoring faith in the organ donor system
fields.standfirst: The contradiction that surrounds medical care and research has been highlighted by the recent Alder Hey scandal. But how do individual clinicians deal with the problems this duality creates? Accountability is essential if consent for organ donation is to be achieved constantly, writes Julia Neuberger.
fields.trailText: "Doctors in crisis as complaints soar." Yesterday's news headlines have a familiar ring to them. This time, it's the news that complaints to the General Medical Council have risen by 50% in the past year. Two weeks ago, the headlines were rather larger, bolder and even more disturbing for anyone working in or around the health service.
fields.body:
"Doctors in crisis as complaints soar." Yesterday's news headlines have a familiar ring to them. This time, it's the news that complaints to the General Medical Council have risen by 50% in the past year. Two weeks ago, the headlines were rather larger, bolder and even more disturbing for anyone working in or around the health service.

"The baby butcher," said the front page of the Mirror. "We buried our daughter like a jigsaw at three funerals," ran the headline in the Sun. Nor were such headlines confined to the tabloids. "The basement of horrors," was the Independent's front-page banner, while the Guardian led its coverage with the headline: "He stripped the organs from every dead child he touched". All these refer, of course, to the report of the inquiry into the retention of dead children's organs for research at Alder Hey hospital in Liverpool.

As time passes, and the stories about Alder Hey fade from the media, what we are left with are some extremely difficult questions about the future of organ donation, of medical research and of the complex set of relationships that mediate between patients, relatives, researchers, clinicians and other health workers. There are both immediate concerns about the morale of staff working in and around Alder Hey and similar services elsewhere, and some longer-term considerations about the practices and processes they use to obtain organs for research.

Initial media coverage of Alder Hey focused very clearly on the wrongdoings of one man, creating in the process a "folk villain" to take the blame for the distressing stories related by the parents of the dead children. Such an approach is, of course, rather easier than one that examines the systems which allow individual doctors to behave in ways the secretary of state for health condemned so vehemently the day the report was published. But, without a thorough examination of those issues, we will have only sticking-plaster solutions to the short-term problems of staff morale and we may never solve the problems that led to the report's publication in the first place.

The key question, I believe, is one of accountability. How, we need to ask, do universities and NHS trusts manage their relationships over research and medical care? How do individual clinicians deal with the dual loyalties that such relationships imply? What effect do these relationships have - not just on doctors but on nurses in children's wards, on bereavement counsellors and on laboratory staff? Unless we are clear about how all these lines of accountability operate, it will be impossible to put in place systems to ensure that consent is achieved at all times in the process of removing organs from dead children, either for research or for transplant.

There is little doubt that, at present, public faith in the organ donor system has been dented very badly. That loss of faith is extremely damaging for staff. But it is also an opportunity to rebuild public confidence by rebuilding the system for obtaining meaningful consent for organ donation. Across the NHS, and at children's hospitals in particular, arrangements for gaining consent need to be examined thoroughly. Trust boards, managers and senior clinicians need to work with nursing staff, parents and others to develop systems for obtaining informed consent, based on understanding of the value of research and transplant, as well as consideration of the feelings and beliefs of individuals from different cultural and social backgrounds.

Dialogue of this kind, if it is organised effectively, not only produces results but forms the beginning of a new set of relationships and can help to boost morale simply by showing people that their views are valued and that they can communicate with each other, given the right support.

It is questionable whether the NHS, the professions and the universities can ever resolve all of the dilemmas that surround organ retention. It is even less likely that any system of procedures and regulations can ever prevent "rogue" practitioners from at least some inappropriate behaviour. But, if we want to see real progress emerging from the current gloom, it is vital that the discomfort is used positively to create a sense of shared responsibility and a future in which consent is genuine and accountability effective.

 Julia Neuberger is chief executive of the King's Fund

fields.headline: Stranded Britons rescued in Indonesia
fields.trailText: Six Britons and two New Zealanders last night reached dry land after being stranded for more than two days on a rickety wooden boat off the coast of the Indonesian island of Lombok after the vessel's engines broke down.
fields.body:
Six Britons and two New Zealanders last night reached dry land after being stranded for more than two days on a rickety wooden boat off the coast of the Indonesian island of Lombok after the vessel's engines broke down.

The four other tourists on the boat, all Britons, reached safety yesterday morning by paddling 300 metres to the shore from the stricken Ombak Indah on their surfboards.

However the sea was too rough for all the others to dare risk the journey so they waited until 6.30am (10.30pm GMT) when rescuers, wha had stood by all night, deemed it safe enough.

Hannah Gaisford, 18, from Cornwall, Rebecca Fyfe, 19, from Ayrshire, Richard Ealin, from Cornwall, Joanne Philips, from Cornwall, Marcus Whitney, from East Sussex, Matt Perry, from London, and the two New Zealanders were transported to the shore in the Ombak Indah's dinghy, local police commander Eko Suchayo said this morning.

"There was lots of laughing and everyone was smiling," he said. "They were all very glad that it was all over. The conditions had calmed down a lot, so there were no problems evacuating them from the boat." The eight tourists, who had booked to go on a seven-day surfing cruise from Bali on Tuesday, were taken to join their friends, Oliver Vetter, 22, from Cardiff, Ben Lewis, from London, Shayne Howell, from Eastbourneand Matt Smith, 24, from Cornwall, at a nearby five-star hotel.

The alarm was raised when one of the Britons sent a text message via mobile phone to her boyfriend in Britain. The SOS message told Nick Hodgson to contact Falmouth coastguard in Cornwall.

Mr Hodgson, who was in London, then phoned Thames coastguard. The alarm was passed to the coastguard centre in Falmouth, then on to Australia, then on to Bali and eventually to Lombok.

A naval search vessel was sent out at 6pm on Wednesday to search the Lombok Strait but could find nothing in pouring rain and two-metre high waves. Yesterday morning an airplane joined the search but failed to spot the boat.

The crew of an Indonesian navy ship eventually managed to find the boat and transferred an electricity generator on to the boat to power lights and to enable the travellers to cook a meal.

The travellers are said to have kept up their morale during the hours of darkness by playing cards, videoing each other with Ms Philips's camera and drinking beer.

The Ombak Indah is now being towed by a navy vessel to Lembar, the main port on Lombok.

fields.headline: Civil rights, civil wrongs
fields.standfirst: Strange Fruit is one of the most potent protest songs ever written. But few know that its three short anti-racist verses were written by a white New York schoolteacher - or that it contributed to the early death of the singer who came to embody it, Billie Holiday. David Margolick reports
fields.trailText: Strange Fruit is one of the most potent protest songs ever written. But few know that its three short anti-racist verses were written by a white New York schoolteacher - or that it contributed to the early death of the singer who came to embody it, Billie Holiday. David Margolick reports
fields.body:
As Billie Holiday later told the story, a single gesture by a patron at a New York nightclub changed the history of American music. It was early 1939, the night that Holiday first sang Strange Fruit. The venue was Café Society in Greenwich Village, New York's only truly integrated nightclub, a place catering for progressive types with open minds. Even here, Holiday was afraid to sing this new song, a song that tackled racial hatred head-on at a time when protest music was all but unknown. "There wasn't even a patter of applause when I finished," she wrote later. "Then a lone person began to clap nervously. Then suddenly everybody was clapping."

The famed songwriter EY Harburg called Strange Fruit a "historic document". The jazz writer Leonard Feather said it was "the first significant protest in words and music, the first unmuted cry against racism". The record producer Ahmet Ertegun called the song, which Holiday first sang 16 years before Rosa Parks refused to yield her seat on an Alabama bus, "a declaration of war... the beginning of the civil rights movement".

Strange Fruit pops up in many places now. Leon Litwack, the Pulitzer prize-winning historian of the American civil war, uses it in his classes at the University of California at Berkeley. A federal appeals court judge cited it a few years ago to show that execution by hanging was inherently "cruel and unusual". Khallil Abdul Muhammad, Louis Farrakhan's notoriously anti-Semitic disciple and maestro of the Million Man March, has quoted it in speeches assailing American racism - unaware, apparently, that the song was written by a white Jewish schoolteacher from New York City named Abel Meeropol.

Meeropol, who wrote under the pen name Lewis Allan, did not write the song for Holiday; and yet so completely did Holiday come to own Strange Fruit that Meeropol spent half a lifetime reminding people that it was really his creation, and his alone. Few people seemed to be able to accept that so potent a song could come from so prosaic a source. Newspaper articles saddled Meeropol with a range of purported collaborators. "One Lewis Allen [sic] is cited as the author of Strange Fruit, but did he compose both words and music?" the composer and diarist Ned Rorem, a passionate Holiday devotee, wrote in the New York Times in 1995, nine years after Meeropol's death. "Indeed, who was he? Was he black?" (To the organisers of a celebration of black composers at the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts in 1999, the answer was yes, for they included Strange Fruit on the programme.)

In a way, Meeropol sealed his own fate, his status as a historical footnote, when he decided that it was Billie Holiday to whom he'd bring the song: she made it her own more effectively than any other artist ever could have. "When you listen to her, it's almost like an audio tape of her autobiography," said Tony Bennett. "She didn't sing anything unless she had lived it."

Holiday was only 24 years old in 1939, but she had already experienced enough prejudice and despair by then to call herself a "race woman". She began performing in Harlem in the late 1920s; by 1933, she had been discovered by the record producer John Hammond, who quickly teamed her with Benny Goodman, Teddy Wilson and other legendary musicians of the day. Together, they made what became some of Holiday's finest and most beloved records: I Wished on a Moon, What a Little Moonlight Will Do and Me Myself and I, to cite just three. In the late 1930s, she toured with the bands of Count Basie and Artie Shaw.

Though all of the hard knocks helped Holiday infuse everything she sang with a unique mixture of resilience, defiance, exuberance and shrewdness, her songs, at least on paper, were invariably what her first biographer, Linda Kuehl, called "second cousins to her favourite reading: love comics and true romance magazines" - that is, bland, banal ballads. Politics, and particularly racial politics, had never influenced her choice of material until Strange Fruit came along.

Holiday's autobiography - co-written by William Dufty and entitled Lady Sings the Blues - offers an account of the song's origins that may set a new record for most misinformation per column inch. (Holiday later tried to fob off the blame on Dufty: "Shit, man, I ain't never read that book," she said. In fact, because her publishers were skittish about the entire undertaking, they made her read and sign every page of the manuscript.) "The germ of the song was in a poem by Lewis Allen," Holiday declared in the book. "When he showed me that poem, I dug it right off. It seemed to spell out all the things that had killed Pop."

As Holiday told the story, her father, a musician in Fletcher Henderson's band, was exposed to poison gas as a soldier during world war one and died of pneumonia in 1937 after several segregated Southern hospitals refused to treat him. "Allen had heard how Pop died and of course was interested in my singing. He suggested that Sonny White (who had been my accompanist) and I turn it into music. So the three of us got together and did the job in about three weeks."

In fact, Meeropol had never met Holiday and apparently knew nothing about her father, who probably never fought in Europe in world war one and is unlikely to have been gassed there.

An English teacher at De Witt Clinton High School in the Bronx for 27 years, Meeropol led two other, parallel lives. One was as a political activist: he and his wife were closet communists, donating a percentage of their earnings to the party. The other was as a writer, poet and composer. Meeropol wrote incessantly - poems, ballads, musicals, plays - all using the nom de plume "Lewis Allan", the names of his two natural-born children, neither of whom survived infancy. Though he had his admirers - including Ira Gershwin, Kurt Weill and the Nobel prize-winning novelist Thomas Mann - most of his work was quickly forgotten and now sits in dusty heaps at Boston University.

Lynchings - during which black people were murdered with unspeakable brutality, often in a carnival-like atmosphere and then hung from trees for all to see - were rampant in the South following the civil war and for many years thereafter. Conservative figures put the number of people lynched between 1889 and 1940 at 3,833; 90% of them were murdered in the South, and four fifths of them were black. Lynchings tended to occur in poor, small towns - often taking the place, as the newspaper columnist HL Mencken once said, "of the merry-go-round, the theatre, the symphony orchestra". They involved either the whole community or a cabal of vigilantes, often in disguise. And they were meted out for a host of alleged offences - not just murder, theft and rape, but for insulting a white person, boasting, swearing or buying a car. In some instances, there was no infraction at all; it was just time to remind "uppity" blacks to stay in their place.

The numbers gradually declined. Officially, there were only three lynchings in 1939 - the year Holiday first sang about them. Still, a survey taken that year revealed that more than six in 10 Southerners thought lynchings to be justified in cases of sexual assault. And despite a long campaign by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, Congress had never managed to pass a federal anti-lynching law.

Lynchings may have been localised affairs, but as Gunnar Myrdal pointed out in An American Dilemma, his 1944 study of race relations in the US, they brutalised people everywhere. "Even in the north, some people have ceased to be concerned when another lynching occurs, and they jest about going south to see a lynching," he wrote.

Meeropol, clearly, was not among them. In fact, it is possible that what inspired him to write Strange Fruit was a double lynching that took place north of the Mason Dixon line - in Marion, Indiana, in 1930 - immortalised in a shocking and widely publicised photograph. In any case, it was around that time that Meeropol came across a photograph of a particularly ghastly lynching in a civil rights magazine which, he said, haunted him for days. So he wrote a poem about it, which first saw print - as Bitter Fruit - in the January 1937 issue of the New York Teacher, a union publication.

Meeropol often asked others to set his poems to music. But with Strange Fruit he insisted on doing the task himself. The song was then performed regularly in left-wing circles - by Meeropol's wife, by progressive friends at gatherings in hotels and bungalow colonies around New York, by members of the local teachers' union, and by a quartet of black singers at a fund-raiser for the anti-fascists during the Spanish civil war. As it happened, the co-producer of that fund-raiser, Robert Gordon, was also directing the first floor show at Café Society, which had opened in December 1938. The featured attraction: Billie Holiday, who had just quit Artie Shaw's band, in part because she'd been forced to take the freight elevator during a gig at a New York hotel.

Café Society was unusual even for New York City. The brainchild of Barney Josephson, a shoe salesman from New Jersey with progressive sympathies, it mocked the empty celebrity worship, right-wing politics, snootiness and racial discrimination of popular New York hangouts like the Stork Club. The doormen wore rags and stood by as the customers opened the doors themselves; the bartenders were all veterans of the anti-fascist Abraham Lincoln Brigade; blacks and whites fraternised on stage and off. As one press account described it, the club had "no girlie line, no smutty gags, no Uncle Tom comedy". It was probably the only place in America where Strange Fruit could have been sung and savoured.

Meeropol brought Strange Fruit to Josephson and Bob Gordon at the new nightclub in or around January 1939. "I read the lyrics, and I was just floored by them," Josephson told a documentary crew in 1983. "I said, 'What do you want to do with this?' He said, 'I would love to have Billie do this song.' " Shortly afterwards, Meeropol sat down at Café Society's piano and played it for Holiday. Neither Tin Pan Alley nor jazz, closer to the cabaret tradition of Blitzstein than anything else, it was alien to her, and she appeared indifferent.

"To be perfectly frank, I didn't think she felt comfortable with the song," Meeropol wrote later. "I feel almost certain that if she had to choose from a number of songs at that time, it would not have been Strange Fruit." The Holiday he remembered was "not communicative at all" that day and had asked only one question about the song: what did "pastoral" mean?

Josephson, who rarely asked Holiday to perform anything, later maintained that she "didn't know what the hell the song meant" and sang it originally only as a favour to him. "She looked at me after [Meeropol had] finished and said, 'What do you want me to do with that, man?' and I said, 'It would be wonderful if you'd sing it. If you care to. You don't have to.' And she said, 'You wants me to sing it? I sings it.' " Not until a few months later, when he spotted a tear running down her cheek during one performance, was Josephson convinced that she had finally grasped just what those strange fruit were.

According to Meeropol, who went to Café Society to hear her introduce the song, Holiday sang Strange Fruit with conviction and understanding from the beginning. "She gave a startling, most dramatic and effective interpretation, which could jolt an audience out of its complacency anywhere," he wrote. "This was exactly what I wanted the song to do and why I wrote it_ The audience gave her a tremendous ovation."

So did Holiday grasp the meaning of Strange Fruit or was she oblivious to it all? Holiday, it is true, was in some ways unsophisticated, and the song was unlike anything she had done. Josephson's version of events nonetheless seems harsh and patronising. That Holiday could not have known precisely what she was singing about and felt it deeply is inconceivable. Barry Ulanov, a jazz scholar who heard her sing it while he was a student at Columbia, suggested an alternative: Holiday understood the song but was uncomfortable with it and was particularly uncomfortable that others were pressuring her to sing it. That she sang with such ferocity and anger, he speculated, reflected both what the song said and what she wanted to say herself: So you say you want to hear about lynching, do you? Well then I'm really going to give it to you!

"She was not out there simply making a social or political plea," Ulanov said. "She was saying something in her own complex way."

One story has it that Holiday's mother objected when she began singing Strange Fruit and asked her why she was doing it. Because it could make things better, Holiday replied.

"But you'll be dead," her mother insisted.

"Yeah, but I'll feel it," Holiday said. "I'll know it in my grave."

Witnessing Strange Fruit at Café Society was a visual as well as an auditory experience. Josephson, who called the song "agitprop", decreed elaborate stage directions for each of the three nightly performances. Holiday was to close each set with it. Before she began, all service stopped. Waiters, cashiers, busboys were all immobilised. The room went completely dark, save for a pin spot on Holiday's face. When she was finished and the lights went out, she was to walk off the stage, and no matter how thunderous the ovation, she was never to return for a bow. "People had to remember Strange Fruit, get their insides burned with it," Josephson later said. Miscreants were apparently dealt with harshly. "At Café Society I used to wonder at how quiet for a nightclub it was when I sang," Holiday recalled in 1949. "I found out later the waiters made a habit of going up to the noisiest characters and saying, 'Miss Holiday is afraid you aren't enjoying yourself. Pay up and go.' "

Holiday left Café Society after nine months, moving up to the jazz clubs of West 52nd Street. When it came to singing Strange Fruit, she chose her spots carefully, but even in ostensibly safe locales the song wasn't always well received. "Lots of people walked out on the song, party after party, because they said, 'We don't call this entertainment'," Josephson said. "I remember a time a woman followed Billie into the powder room. Billie was wearing a strapless gown and she tried to brush the woman off. The woman became hysterical with tears - 'Don't you sing that song again! Don't you dare!' she screamed - and ripped Billie's dress. I asked her to leave. She started to cry again. She explained she came to Café Society to have fun and here she heard Billie sing about 'burning flesh' and it brought back a lynching she had seen when she was seven or eight years old down south. She saw a black man tied by the throat to a back fender of a car, dragged through the streets, hung up and burned. She thought she forgot it and Billie brought it back."

Drugs and alcohol had been part of Holiday's life for years - between sets at Café Society she would routinely smoke marijuana in a cab riding around Central Park - but only in the early 1940s did she begin taking heroin, then mainlining it. That, plus the death of her mother and a series of disastrous relationships with abusive men, sent her life into a desperate, downward spiral. In the spring of 1947 she checked into a New York hospital for detoxification. A few months later, in Philadelphia, she was busted and spent nearly a year in a federal penitentiary in Pennsylvania.

With every increment of abuse Holiday endured, Strange Fruit became more personal to her. The confidence with which she'd first sung it gave way to pure pathos. Watching her undertake it could be both exhilarating and excruciating.

Even decades later, the experience of listening to and watching her perform Strange Fruit - eyes closed and head back, the familiar gardenia over her ear, fingers snapping lightly - lingered in many memories. The actress Billie Allen Henderson recalled how, during Holiday's appearance at New York's Birdland in 1952, the maitre d' actually confiscated all cigarettes before Holiday began singing it. "I was trying to be sophisticated and all of a sudden something stabs me in the solar plexus and I was gasping for air. It was so deeply felt. She painted a picture of a lovely land, pastoral and bucolic, then added eyes bulged and mouths twisted, onto the Southern landscape.

Guy broke into her song. "What's a pastoral scene, Miss Holiday?" Billie looked up slowly and studied Guy for a second. Her face became cruel, and when she spoke her voice was scornful. "It means when the crackers are killing the niggers. It means when they take a little nigger like you and snatch off his nuts and shove them down his goddam throat. That's what it means."

The thrust of the rage repelled Guy and stunned me.

Billie continued: "That's what they do. That's a goddamn pastoral scene."

Holiday performed it again in London in February 1959, in a televised concert that has since been excerpted in several documentaries. Haggard, largely wasted away, she had grown oddly, sadly suited to capture the full grotesqueness of the song. Now she not only sang of bulging eyes and twisted mouths. She embodied them.

Holiday died in July that year, aged 44. Meeropol died in 1986, in a Jewish nursing home near Springfield, Massachusetts. Strange Fruit was sung at his memorial service.

To some, the song remains too hot to handle. In the 1980s, a disc jockey in North Carolina came across a collection of Billie Holiday standards in the station's library. Strange Fruit was circled, with the admonitions "Watch" and "Do not play" printed next to it. And when Robert Meeropol, Abel's younger son, flew on United Airlines a couple of years ago, he noticed that Cassandra Wilson's album New Moon Daughter was among the in-flight entertainment, but that its first cut - Strange Fruit - was missing.

fields.bodyText: As Billie Holiday later told the story, a single gesture by a patron at a New York nightclub changed the history of American music. It was early 1939, the night that Holiday first sang Strange Fruit. The venue was Café Society in Greenwich Village, New York's only truly integrated nightclub, a place catering for progressive types with open minds. Even here, Holiday was afraid to sing this new song, a song that tackled racial hatred head-on at a time when protest music was all but unknown. "There wasn't even a patter of applause when I finished," she wrote later. "Then a lone person began to clap nervously. Then suddenly everybody was clapping." The famed songwriter EY Harburg called Strange Fruit a "historic document". The jazz writer Leonard Feather said it was "the first significant protest in words and music, the first unmuted cry against racism". The record producer Ahmet Ertegun called the song, which Holiday first sang 16 years before Rosa Parks refused to yield her seat on an Alabama bus, "a declaration of war... the beginning of the civil rights movement". Strange Fruit pops up in many places now. Leon Litwack, the Pulitzer prize-winning historian of the American civil war, uses it in his classes at the University of California at Berkeley. A federal appeals court judge cited it a few years ago to show that execution by hanging was inherently "cruel and unusual". Khallil Abdul Muhammad, Louis Farrakhan's notoriously anti-Semitic disciple and maestro of the Million Man March, has quoted it in speeches assailing American racism - unaware, apparently, that the song was written by a white Jewish schoolteacher from New York City named Abel Meeropol. Meeropol, who wrote under the pen name Lewis Allan, did not write the song for Holiday; and yet so completely did Holiday come to own Strange Fruit that Meeropol spent half a lifetime reminding people that it was really his creation, and his alone. Few people seemed to be able to accept that so potent a song could come from so prosaic a source. Newspaper articles saddled Meeropol with a range of purported collaborators. "One Lewis Allen [sic] is cited as the author of Strange Fruit, but did he compose both words and music?" the composer and diarist Ned Rorem, a passionate Holiday devotee, wrote in the New York Times in 1995, nine years after Meeropol's death. "Indeed, who was he? Was he black?" (To the organisers of a celebration of black composers at the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts in 1999, the answer was yes, for they included Strange Fruit on the programme.) In a way, Meeropol sealed his own fate, his status as a historical footnote, when he decided that it was Billie Holiday to whom he'd bring the song: she made it her own more effectively than any other artist ever could have. "When you listen to her, it's almost like an audio tape of her autobiography," said Tony Bennett. "She didn't sing anything unless she had lived it." Holiday was only 24 years old in 1939, but she had already experienced enough prejudice and despair by then to call herself a "race woman". She began performing in Harlem in the late 1920s; by 1933, she had been discovered by the record producer John Hammond, who quickly teamed her with Benny Goodman, Teddy Wilson and other legendary musicians of the day. Together, they made what became some of Holiday's finest and most beloved records: I Wished on a Moon, What a Little Moonlight Will Do and Me Myself and I, to cite just three. In the late 1930s, she toured with the bands of Count Basie and Artie Shaw. Though all of the hard knocks helped Holiday infuse everything she sang with a unique mixture of resilience, defiance, exuberance and shrewdness, her songs, at least on paper, were invariably what her first biographer, Linda Kuehl, called "second cousins to her favourite reading: love comics and true romance magazines" - that is, bland, banal ballads. Politics, and particularly racial politics, had never influenced her choice of material until Strange Fruit came along. Holiday's autobiography - co-written by William Dufty and entitled Lady Sings the Blues - offers an account of the song's origins that may set a new record for most misinformation per column inch. (Holiday later tried to fob off the blame on Dufty: "Shit, man, I ain't never read that book," she said. In fact, because her publishers were skittish about the entire undertaking, they made her read and sign every page of the manuscript.) "The germ of the song was in a poem by Lewis Allen," Holiday declared in the book. "When he showed me that poem, I dug it right off. It seemed to spell out all the things that had killed Pop." As Holiday told the story, her father, a musician in Fletcher Henderson's band, was exposed to poison gas as a soldier during world war one and died of pneumonia in 1937 after several segregated Southern hospitals refused to treat him. "Allen had heard how Pop died and of course was interested in my singing. He suggested that Sonny White (who had been my accompanist) and I turn it into music. So the three of us got together and did the job in about three weeks." In fact, Meeropol had never met Holiday and apparently knew nothing about her father, who probably never fought in Europe in world war one and is unlikely to have been gassed there. An English teacher at De Witt Clinton High School in the Bronx for 27 years, Meeropol led two other, parallel lives. One was as a political activist: he and his wife were closet communists, donating a percentage of their earnings to the party. The other was as a writer, poet and composer. Meeropol wrote incessantly - poems, ballads, musicals, plays - all using the nom de plume "Lewis Allan", the names of his two natural-born children, neither of whom survived infancy. Though he had his admirers - including Ira Gershwin, Kurt Weill and the Nobel prize-winning novelist Thomas Mann - most of his work was quickly forgotten and now sits in dusty heaps at Boston University. Lynchings - during which black people were murdered with unspeakable brutality, often in a carnival-like atmosphere and then hung from trees for all to see - were rampant in the South following the civil war and for many years thereafter. Conservative figures put the number of people lynched between 1889 and 1940 at 3,833; 90% of them were murdered in the South, and four fifths of them were black. Lynchings tended to occur in poor, small towns - often taking the place, as the newspaper columnist HL Mencken once said, "of the merry-go-round, the theatre, the symphony orchestra". They involved either the whole community or a cabal of vigilantes, often in disguise. And they were meted out for a host of alleged offences - not just murder, theft and rape, but for insulting a white person, boasting, swearing or buying a car. In some instances, there was no infraction at all; it was just time to remind "uppity" blacks to stay in their place. The numbers gradually declined. Officially, there were only three lynchings in 1939 - the year Holiday first sang about them. Still, a survey taken that year revealed that more than six in 10 Southerners thought lynchings to be justified in cases of sexual assault. And despite a long campaign by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, Congress had never managed to pass a federal anti-lynching law. Lynchings may have been localised affairs, but as Gunnar Myrdal pointed out in An American Dilemma, his 1944 study of race relations in the US, they brutalised people everywhere. "Even in the north, some people have ceased to be concerned when another lynching occurs, and they jest about going south to see a lynching," he wrote. Meeropol, clearly, was not among them. In fact, it is possible that what inspired him to write Strange Fruit was a double lynching that took place north of the Mason Dixon line - in Marion, Indiana, in 1930 - immortalised in a shocking and widely publicised photograph. In any case, it was around that time that Meeropol came across a photograph of a particularly ghastly lynching in a civil rights magazine which, he said, haunted him for days. So he wrote a poem about it, which first saw print - as Bitter Fruit - in the January 1937 issue of the New York Teacher, a union publication. Meeropol often asked others to set his poems to music. But with Strange Fruit he insisted on doing the task himself. The song was then performed regularly in left-wing circles - by Meeropol's wife, by progressive friends at gatherings in hotels and bungalow colonies around New York, by members of the local teachers' union, and by a quartet of black singers at a fund-raiser for the anti-fascists during the Spanish civil war. As it happened, the co-producer of that fund-raiser, Robert Gordon, was also directing the first floor show at Café Society, which had opened in December 1938. The featured attraction: Billie Holiday, who had just quit Artie Shaw's band, in part because she'd been forced to take the freight elevator during a gig at a New York hotel. Café Society was unusual even for New York City. The brainchild of Barney Josephson, a shoe salesman from New Jersey with progressive sympathies, it mocked the empty celebrity worship, right-wing politics, snootiness and racial discrimination of popular New York hangouts like the Stork Club. The doormen wore rags and stood by as the customers opened the doors themselves; the bartenders were all veterans of the anti-fascist Abraham Lincoln Brigade; blacks and whites fraternised on stage and off. As one press account described it, the club had "no girlie line, no smutty gags, no Uncle Tom comedy". It was probably the only place in America where Strange Fruit could have been sung and savoured. Meeropol brought Strange Fruit to Josephson and Bob Gordon at the new nightclub in or around January 1939. "I read the lyrics, and I was just floored by them," Josephson told a documentary crew in 1983. "I said, 'What do you want to do with this?' He said, 'I would love to have Billie do this song.' " Shortly afterwards, Meeropol sat down at Café Society's piano and played it for Holiday. Neither Tin Pan Alley nor jazz, closer to the cabaret tradition of Blitzstein than anything else, it was alien to her, and she appeared indifferent. "To be perfectly frank, I didn't think she felt comfortable with the song," Meeropol wrote later. "I feel almost certain that if she had to choose from a number of songs at that time, it would not have been Strange Fruit." The Holiday he remembered was "not communicative at all" that day and had asked only one question about the song: what did "pastoral" mean? Josephson, who rarely asked Holiday to perform anything, later maintained that she "didn't know what the hell the song meant" and sang it originally only as a favour to him. "She looked at me after [Meeropol had] finished and said, 'What do you want me to do with that, man?' and I said, 'It would be wonderful if you'd sing it. If you care to. You don't have to.' And she said, 'You wants me to sing it? I sings it.' " Not until a few months later, when he spotted a tear running down her cheek during one performance, was Josephson convinced that she had finally grasped just what those strange fruit were. According to Meeropol, who went to Café Society to hear her introduce the song, Holiday sang Strange Fruit with conviction and understanding from the beginning. "She gave a startling, most dramatic and effective interpretation, which could jolt an audience out of its complacency anywhere," he wrote. "This was exactly what I wanted the song to do and why I wrote it_ The audience gave her a tremendous ovation." So did Holiday grasp the meaning of Strange Fruit or was she oblivious to it all? Holiday, it is true, was in some ways unsophisticated, and the song was unlike anything she had done. Josephson's version of events nonetheless seems harsh and patronising. That Holiday could not have known precisely what she was singing about and felt it deeply is inconceivable. Barry Ulanov, a jazz scholar who heard her sing it while he was a student at Columbia, suggested an alternative: Holiday understood the song but was uncomfortable with it and was particularly uncomfortable that others were pressuring her to sing it. That she sang with such ferocity and anger, he speculated, reflected both what the song said and what she wanted to say herself: So you say you want to hear about lynching, do you? Well then I'm really going to give it to you! "She was not out there simply making a social or political plea," Ulanov said. "She was saying something in her own complex way." One story has it that Holiday's mother objected when she began singing Strange Fruit and asked her why she was doing it. Because it could make things better, Holiday replied. "But you'll be dead," her mother insisted. "Yeah, but I'll feel it," Holiday said. "I'll know it in my grave." Witnessing Strange Fruit at Café Society was a visual as well as an auditory experience. Josephson, who called the song "agitprop", decreed elaborate stage directions for each of the three nightly performances. Holiday was to close each set with it. Before she began, all service stopped. Waiters, cashiers, busboys were all immobilised. The room went completely dark, save for a pin spot on Holiday's face. When she was finished and the lights went out, she was to walk off the stage, and no matter how thunderous the ovation, she was never to return for a bow. "People had to remember Strange Fruit, get their insides burned with it," Josephson later said. Miscreants were apparently dealt with harshly. "At Café Society I used to wonder at how quiet for a nightclub it was when I sang," Holiday recalled in 1949. "I found out later the waiters made a habit of going up to the noisiest characters and saying, 'Miss Holiday is afraid you aren't enjoying yourself. Pay up and go.' " Holiday left Café Society after nine months, moving up to the jazz clubs of West 52nd Street. When it came to singing Strange Fruit, she chose her spots carefully, but even in ostensibly safe locales the song wasn't always well received. "Lots of people walked out on the song, party after party, because they said, 'We don't call this entertainment'," Josephson said. "I remember a time a woman followed Billie into the powder room. Billie was wearing a strapless gown and she tried to brush the woman off. The woman became hysterical with tears - 'Don't you sing that song again! fields.headline: Rocastle fighting cancer
fields.trailText: Former Arsenal and Leeds midfielder David Rocastle is battling against cancer.
fields.body:
Former Arsenal and Leeds midfielder David Rocastle is battling against cancer.

The 33-year-old has been diagnosed as suffering from non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, which attacks the immune system, and has been undergoing a course of chemotherapy for several weeks.

Rocastle's agent, Jerome Anderson, said: "I can confirm that, unfortunately, David is suffering from non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. He has a very young family and, obviously, this is a very difficult time for them.

"Of course, everybody is rooting for him. David is known worldwide and has been a hero to many people throughout his career."

Rocastle made his name at Arsenal where he won the League Championship in 1989 and 1991 as well as picking up a Littlewoods Cup winners' medal in 1987.

He was capped 14 times by England and also enjoyed spells at Leeds, Chelsea and Manchester City, but could not recapture his form and found himself loaned out to Norwich before ending his career at Hull in 1997.

webTitle: In brief: London film critics honour Billy Elliot

fields.headline: London film critics honour Billy Elliot
fields.standfirst: Plus: Warner Bros goes global on the Internet; Miramax takes a piece of the Onion
fields.trailText: Plus: Warner Bros goes global on the Internet; Miramax takes a piece of the Onion
fields.body:
 Billy Elliot star Jamie Bell, who missed out on an Oscar nomination earlier this week, was named the Best British Newcomer at the London Film Critics' Circle Awards. According to ananova, Billy Elliot also won four other prizes, including Best British Film of the Year, Best Actress for Julie Walters and Best British Director for Stephen Daldry. Jim Broadbent was named Best British Actor for his role in Topsy-Turvy, while Being John Malkovich won three awards, including Film of the Year and Best Director for Spike Jonze.

 Warner Bros ups its efforts on the web today, launching a number of new Internet ventures, including the official site for the Harry Potter film. The company is also expanding its efforts worldwide. According to Variety, the company is launching sites for specific countries, the first being for Britain. Sites for Germany, Spain, France and Italy will follow later this year.

 The Onion, the satirical newspaper and website, has signed a deal with Miramax films to develop scripts and feature projects. "We're proud to welcome the Onion to our city with this first-look deal," Variety reports Miramax co-chair, Harvey Weinstein as saying. Onion chief Robert Siegel added: "The goal for this Miramax deal is to create movies that don't suck." The Onion, which was created as a free paper twelve years ago by University of Wisconsin undergraduates, now claims more than 1m weekly readers. It is also a rapidly expanding franchise. Two Onion books have been published and DreamWorks, the film studio run by Steven Spielberg, David Geffen and Jeffrey Katzenberg, has optioned two articles.
