fields.headline: Council dismay at budget go-ahead
fields.trailText: London mayor Ken Livingstone has pushed his budget through the capital's divided assembly to the "disappointment" of the boroughs. The move will put almost £30 on the average London council tax bill.
fields.body:
London mayor Ken Livingstone has pushed his budget through the capital's divided assembly to the "disappointment" of the boroughs.

The Greater London Authority's (GLA) budget will now rise by 22.6%, or £166.48m, putting nearly £30 on the average council tax in London.

The chairman of the Association of London Government (ALG), Sir Robin Wales, said he was disappointed with the result, but added: "The figure being discussed at today's assembly meeting is still a reduction on the excessive demands first proposed by the mayor. We must now concentrate on ensuring a more consultative and effective process for the future that will involve all London boroughs."

The assembly has, however, forced several concessions from the mayor, including a seat on his advisory cabinet for an ALG representative. Mr Livingstone has also pledged greater powers for the assembly to stop him shuffling money between different arms of the GLA, and promised a budget-setting process that will involve the boroughs at an earlier stage.

Today's decision should bring to an end the first major conflict between Mr Livingstone and the London boroughs, which had previously enjoyed good relations - the mayor is still a member of the ALG.

But the boroughs' opposition to the mayors' budget demands led on Monday to what one insider said were furious discussions between ALG leaders and Mr Livingstone.

His original budget proposals could have added more than £40 to band D council tax, but he was forced to rein in the increases after the London assembly protested. Mr Livingstone backed down on Monday, conceding almost all the assembly's proposed cuts. He maintains that Transport for London (TfL) needs at least £10m, despite assembly attempts to block any increase.

The budget was passed because the Tory and Labour groups failed to agree on a replacement.

Baroness Sally Hamwee, the Liberal Democrat chairwoman of the assembly budget committee, said: "The Labour group and our own took the view that we would only have managed to shave a few pence off - at the most 4p - had we brought it down to under 20% We're not happy that TfL or the metropolitan police have got their budgets under control."

fields.headline: Dance magazines hit new high
fields.trailText:
12pm: Emap's Mixmag has stormed up the music magazine circulation charts with a 47.1% year-on-year increase, writes Julia Day.
Feb 16: Home interest titles demolished
Feb 16: Men's lifestyle titles suffer
Feb 15: Heat circulation up 138%
Feb 15: Esquire sheds downmarket readers
fields.body:
The UK's reputation as a dance nation has been confirmed, with Mixmag storming up the music magazine circulation charts with a 47.1% year-on-year increase.

The Emap dance music magazine turned in a 106,111 circulation in the new Audit Bureau of Circulations figures for July to December 2000.

This is up from the 72,115 figure recorded for the same period the previous year.

Mixmag increased sales 10% period on period from 96,483 in June.

webTitle: You Bet Your Life: week twenty-five

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life: week twenty-five
fields.standfirst: Betting site Blue Square have given us £400 to gamble with. Join us as we squander it
fields.trailText:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties):

Scott Murray = £190.67

Sean Ingle = £46.95

Paul MacInnes = £39.39

Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective = £29.12
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties):

Scott Murray = £190.67

Sean Ingle = £46.95

Paul MacInnes = £39.39

Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective = £29.12

Scott Murray: Inverness Caledonian Thistle to beat Kilmarnock - £5 @ 4/1

Kilmarnock are the best team in the SPL who are not the Old Firm who are not Hibs. But that's hardly Brazil, whichever way you look at it. And if there's going to be a Cup upset this weekend, this could be it.

The Caley Jags are nearly always involved in high-scoring scrapes - a good example of this being their 4-3 victory over Ayr in the last round (they were 3-0 down at half-time). Their front-line of Dennis Wyness (13 goals in 17 games this season), Paul Sheerin (9 in 23) and Davide Xausa (8 goals in 17 games) is potent enough to cause anyone trouble. You may, for example, care to get John Barnes opining on the subject of Mr Sheerin.

Sadly, the ICT defence is equally adept at providing excellent entertainment. So as they're sure to concede, the question is this: can they outscore their more illustrious opponents? Opponents who have scored 16 goals less in three more games?

Sean Ingle: Brescia to win at Parma - £5 @ 11/2

I can't do it, I really can't. For the last few months I've sat opposite Scott Murray, watching him conjure up unlikely winner after unlikely winner out of his gambling hat. And I want to do the same. Sadly, I possess no such headgear.

Looking at my Blue Square column, I see a perfect opportunity "to do a Murray". In-form Brescia, who boast three wins and two draws in their last five games - are an overpriced 11/2 to win at Parma, who have only the twelfth best home record in Serie A and who lost 2-1 away at PSV on Thursday night in the Uefa Cup.

But deep down I can't really see Brescia actually winning. This is Serie A after all, where home teams always seem to win. Then again, I couldn't see Liverpool beating Roma last night - even when Mr Murray confidently backed them at 4/1. Oh, screw it. For one week only I'm going to hang loose, live free, go loco. Brescia it is - and if they go down to a 1-0 defeat, as I suspect they will, I'm back on the doubles.

The Prince of Punts (aka: the punter formally known as Paul MacInnes): Bristol City to beat Leicester - £4.39 @ 8/1

Before we go any further, after last weekend's stunning success I have decided, like that noncey bloke in Dead Poets' Society, to change my name to something ludicrously inappropriate. From now on, I am to be known as the Prince of Punts. At all points. Anybody found to be addressing me as anything else will hear from my lawyer. And believe me, if necessary, I will get one.

Anyway, on to this week's guaranteed winner. Having heeded Mr Murray's words on Monday about betting on results you think might happen, I have decided to place my cash (taking me down to a nice even £35) on something that surely won't. But would be nice if it did.

What's more, I have combined that reasoning with a factor I believe proved crucial in my Chelsea/Man Utd draw success - a patent lack of research. Basically I know that Bristol City are doing alright under Danny Wilson and have won away six times in the league this season (and three times in the Cup). I also know that Peter Taylor has brought in a lot of average personnel to Filbert Street, and doesn't seem to know his best formation. So, what with this being the magic of the Cup and all, 8/1 looks good to me.

Yours truly,

The Prince of Punts

Dominic Callaghan of the Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective: Liverpool v Manchester City, draw half-time, City full-time - £5 @ 16/1

Romeo was a gambler. We know this. He gambled, won a bit and then lost it all. Quite similar to the punters collective, in fact. But we're not dead yet. And finally, here's the chance to prove I been watching and listening all season.

Liverpool are, quite rightly on a high after beating Roma. But with only two days to recover they'll find City a difficult opponent.

City have introduced some good players and at 13/2 are great value. But I think I can read even more into this game. Liverpool will hold City, but they'll tire. Four key players are coming back from injury, not 100 percent fit.

In the words of Romeo, "May this bud by summers ripening breath, turn into a beauteous flower when next we meet". That's £80 to me and you!

fields.headline: Coke withdraws from Premier League bidding
fields.trailText: Coca-Cola has pulled out of the race to become the Premier League's next sponsor, reports Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
The glittering prize of global sponsorship rights for Premier League football is being fiercely contested by just two leading brands, after Coca-Cola today withdrew from the race.

The Premier League has refused to reveal the identity of the bidders, but Budweiser, Pepsi and now Coke have all pulled out of negotiations.

A source close to talks said the winning brand was likely to "come as some surprise" to the business world.

There is still speculation that current sponsor Carling, which stormed out of negotiations at the beginning of the year, may yet renew its eight-year relationship with the league.

It is thought that a technology brand is in the running.

Carling's existing four-year deal cost it around £27m annually and the new deal is thought to be worth at least £45m.

However the size of the bid is no longer believed to be the issue.

One source said that the Premier League is "selecting" a brand that best fits its own global marketing strategy.

The league has said it will not announce the sponsor until it has tied up its overseas broadcasting rights, which will cover 147 territories.

This includes the huge markets of north America and Asia/Pacific.

Coke made its announcement to pull out of talks this morning.

"Coca-Cola absolutely loves football. But we could not make the Premier League's valuation work," said director of communications Andrew Coker.

"We were evaluating it to see if it was right for us and, having gone through that process, we have decided it's not."

The move comes days after Coke's arch-rival Pepsi declared it was no longer in the bidding.

Budweiser withdrew its offer two weeks ago.

fields.headline: Cautious welcome for all-day courts
fields.standfirst: Special report: Policing crime
fields.trailText: Calls to introduce US-style 24-hour courts in Britain, today received a cautious welcome from civil rights and legal groups.
fields.body:
Calls to introduce US-style 24-hour courts in Britain, today received a cautious welcome from civil rights and legal groups.

Metropolitan police commissioner Sir John Stevens urged the introduction of round-the-clock courts in London and other cities to fast-track offenders through the criminal justice system.

The civil rights group Liberty said that it supported the idea, provided it did not compromise justice.

The Magistrates' Association echoed that cautious welcome, saying that getting defendants into preliminary hearings as soon as possible after they were arrested would be beneficial.

Sir John said that he had seen the 24-hour courts system in operation in New York and believed it could work here.

He told the Times newspaper: "I have seen it in New York and it works.

"When [people] are arrested they go straight to court, whatever the time, day or night. It saves time. It allows you to process them in a far, far quicker way.

"Some of these persistent offenders, these youngsters, society quite honestly needs a rest from them."

Home secretary Jack Straw was "very keen" on the idea or a similar way of tackling persistent young offenders, Sir John said.

The government promised to halve the average time from arrest to sentence for persistent young offenders from 142 to 71 days. But recent figures showed that the average in October last year was 94 days.

Magistrates' Association chairman Harold Mawdsley said that he welcomed the proposal, but he voiced concerns over magistrates sentencing people at "two in the morning", when they might not be able to concentrate properly.

However, he added that getting defendants through a preliminary hearing as quickly as possible was a good thing.

Shadow home secretary Ann Widdecombe said she believed the 24-hour courts could be a good idea, but called on the government to work closely with the police to avoid making the system too bureaucratic.

Sid Brighton, the chief executive of the Justices' Clerks Society, said the possibility of 24-hour courts had been talked about some years ago but never really got off the ground.

Potential difficulties would include costs, staffing levels and availability, Mr Brighton said, adding that the majority of people were already taken before a court within 24 hours of arrest.

The Home Office refused to confirm or deny that 24-hour courts were being considered, but it said an ongoing review of the criminal justice system could lead to "radical changes" for the courts.

Magistrates' courts could already sit during the night or at the weekend if they choose to do so, the Home Office said.

webTitle: Pregnant minister praised for taking maternity leave

fields.headline: Pregnant minister praised for taking maternity leave
fields.trailText: Yvette Cooper, one of Labour's rising stars, is to become the first government minister in Britain to take maternity leave.
fields.body:
Yvette Cooper, one of Labour's rising stars, is to become the first government minister in Britain to take maternity leave.

In a move hailed last night by maternity rights campaigners, Ms Cooper, the public health minister, announced that she will take 18 weeks leave on full pay when she gives birth to her second child, which is due in August.

Ms Cooper, 31, who is married to Ed Balls, Gordon Brown's closest adviser, plans to stop working in July. She will return to work by the end of the year. After discussions with the health secretary Alan Milburn, she will take her maternity leave in line with Department of Health guidelines. Civil servants in the department are entitled to 18 weeks leave on full pay. Ms Cooper will therefore continue to draw her salary of £76,657 while she is on leave.

This is more generous than women's statutory rights. By law women are entitled to 40 weeks' maternity leave, 18 of which is paid - six weeks at 90% at full pay and 12 weeks at £60.20p a week. Mr Balls, 33, who is the treasury's chief economic adviser, will take paternity leave, as he did when their first child was born.

Ms Cooper, MP for Pontefract and Castleford, said yesterday that she was planning to have her baby at the NHS hospital in her constituency where she had her first child, Meriel, who is 20 months old. "We are planning to have the baby in Pontefract," Ms Cooper said. "The NHS staff there were wonderful to us last time round."

Maternity rights campaigners last night congratulated Ms Cooper for setting a good example to employees and employers alike.

Joanna Wade, a spokeswoman for the Maternity Alliance, said: "It is good to know that she feels confident enough to be up front that she will be taking time off. We strongly hope that this will set an example to high level employees that there are times when family has to come before work and mothers should not be punished for that."

Ms Cooper's announcement came as ministers finalise details of a government review of parental rights. They are expected to approve an increase in statutory maternity pay and in the amount of time mothers are allowed to take off work.

Campaigners are hoping that Tony Blair, who took two week's paternity leave after the birth of Leo last year, will endorse radical changes. Ms Wade said: "We are very hopeful, but there is a danger that the changes may not be as wholehearted as we would have liked to see."

Ms Cooper is regarded as one of the brightest stars in the government who is favoured by both the Blair and Brown camps. A former journalist, she was appointed to the frontline post of public health minister in 1999, two years after her election to parliament.

fields.headline: Met chief calls for 24-hour courts
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Britain's top police officer has called for the introduction of 24-hour courts to tackle soaring levels of street crime and anti-social behaviour.
fields.body:
Britain's top police officer has called for the introduction of 24-hour courts to tackle soaring levels of street crime and anti-social behaviour.

The Metropolitan police commissioner, Sir John Stevens, said he had seen round-the-clock courts working successfully in New York. He said they could deal with a growing number of street robbers and thugs in British cities.

"You ensure people go through the system quickly. When they are arrested they go straight to court whatever time of day or night," he told the Times.

Britain is facing an alarming youth crime wave, caused partly by the thefts of mobile telephones and the lack of recreational facilities in many inner-city areas, he warned.

Senior officers in London have warned that street robberies are expected to reach 50,000 this year. Increases in street robberies have been experienced in cities across the country, with numbers rising by about a quarter in Manchester and Birmingham.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, is believed to be considering round-the-clock courts as part of his review on speeding up access to justice.

A Home Office spokeswoman said: "The home secretary is working on reforms of the criminal justice system ... he is looking at speeding up access to justice and equipping the courts so they can respond effectively to changes in crime."

The proposals for 24-hour courts have been supported by the civil rights group Liberty, which said they would mean people would not have to be held for long periods in police cells before appearing in court.

Related article
All-day courts receive careful reports

fields.headline: Why mouse-hunting is fun
fields.standfirst: It's quick and you've got choice: Marianne Curphey on the benefits of finding a mortgage on the web
fields.trailText: Sometimes arranging a mortgage can feel like you're being taken for a ride. All you want is a simple loan to buy a house, but there are so many products on offer and so many people taking a cut that you feel like throwing all the glossy brochures in the bin.
fields.body:
Sometimes arranging a mortgage can feel like you're being taken for a ride. All you want is a simple loan to buy a house, but there are so many products on offer and so many people taking a cut that you feel like throwing all the glossy brochures in the bin.

You could also be overpaying for your mortgage, either because you haven't got a competitive deal, or because you are tied in to buying your mortgage lender's uncom- petitive buildings insurance as part of the mortgage deal.

This is where the internet is really shaking up the market - and it's great news for consumers. Searching online for a mortgage has three advantages over tramping down the high street or using the telephone: speed, choice and interactivity.

It's good to have an idea of how much disposable income you have, particularly if you are planning to buy a house in the future and want to calculate how long it will take you to build up a deposit.

One of the best online calculators is from Abbey National which works out how much spare income you have based on the information you input.

Contact:

www.abbeynational.co.uk/organiser

Once you have decided to start looking for a suitable mortgage, you could visit every mortgage lender's site but that would end up being almost as time-consuming as visiting every mortgage lender on the high-street. An alternative is to use an online mortgage broker.

For a list of mortgage brokers and lenders try:

www.find.co.uk/mortgages

One of the best-known high street mortgage brokers is Charcol. The company makes its money as a fee-based mortgage broker. As an online broker, however, it does not charge a fee, but allows you to compare around 500 different mortgages and mortgage products from a panel of up to 45 lenders.

The Charcol online site guides you through the process of deciding which sort of mortgage you want, but you still need to read through the small print of the mortgages you choose. You won't have to pay a brokerage fee if you apply via the internet, but if you use the Charcol site as a mortgage comparison tool and then phone up for advice about the products on offer, you'll probably end up being charged. If you do phone, ask for details on when the fee kicks in.

Contact:

www.charcolonline.co.uk

Charcol also powers the "mortgage supermarket" available from Tesco. It takes you to the front page of Tesco's financial services page where you can also find details about credit cards, loans, savings and insurance.

Contact:

www.tesco.com/finance

Arranging a mortgage is only part of the home buying process. It can take months to find the home you want to buy, solicitors and councils can be slow in drawing up contracts and completing searches, and you can end up being stuck in a long chain of buyers and sellers. There are some simple ways in which you can speed up the process, which are available from Money, the personal finance site of the Guardian and part of the GuardianUnlimited network of sites.

You can find help and tips for saving time at:

www.theguardian.com/money

Go to the Advice Bank section, click on the section called "Buying a home" and you'll find a series of articles under the heading "Homebuyers timetable". There's even a checklist of things to remember for the day you move. The Data pages of the Money site also have a wealth of useful information on mortgages, savings and credit cards.

Contact:

www.money.theguardian.com/data

One of the best ways to reduce your monthly outgoings is to remortgage your home without actually moving. If you are remortgaging, or want to work out how much you might save, Paragon Mortgages has a series of downloadable spreadsheets and calculators.

The interactive calculators are in the section entitled "Tools and calculators". The calculators can work out how much the value of your house has accelerated since you bought it (called the house evaluator). There is also a savings calculator, income calculator, and a buy-to-let calculator.

Contact:

www.paragon-mortgages.co.uk

Another personal finance site, Moneynet , has a section on mortgages. It includes a search for flexible mortgages, buy to let and impaired credit mortgages (the latter may be useful if you are unable to get a mortgage from a traditional lender, but watch out for the small print).

Contact:

www.moneynet.co.uk

Or you could try the Motley fool website which has an unconventional attitude to home ownership, but may give you some food for thought. The search is powered by Netmortgage (backed by Savills Private Finance, an independent mortgage broker).

Contact:

www.fool.co.uk

The Moneysupermarket site has news about the best deals currently available and allows you to look for personal loans and credit cards as well.

Contact:

www.moneysupermarket/mortgages

Whichever site you use, you will be asked first to specify what type of mortgage you want - fixed rate, capped rate, discounted, or flexible. Most sites have a section which explains these terms , but you can also find out more in the Advice Bank of the Guardian Unlimited Money site.

An online mortgage comparison tool will ask you what your preferences are in terms of:

The type of mortgage: repayment, interest only, fixed rate?

Flexibility - do you want the facility to over or underpay?

Tie-in deals - depending on how sophisticated the tool is, you will be asked to refine your search to mortgages without tie-ins or penalties.

Disposable income - how much do you want to borrow each month.

You can keep changing your search criteria until you find a deal which suits you.

You can click on your chosen lender for more details

webTitle: Israel bus stop killer was on medication

fields.headline: Israel bus stop killer was on medication
fields.trailText: The Palestinian driver who mowed down and killed eight Israeli at a bus stop has a history of psychiatric illness, the Guardian has learned.
fields.body:
The attack by Khalil Abu Olbeh, 35, has raised questions in Israel about how a man vetted by the security services just two weeks ago could inflict the highest Jewish casualties in nearly four years: seven conscripts, four of them women, and a woman civilian.

Far from being the calculated aim of a dedicated terrorist, the carnage south of Tel Aviv was inflicted by a man who has been taking medication for depression for two years.

That Wednesday morning he added antihistamines and antibiotics to the pharmaceutical cocktail. Both can cause drowsiness, according to the pharmacist who prescribed them.

Israeli security officials said yesterday that Mr Olbeh, who is wounded and in detention, had told his interrogators that he had carefully planned the attack, and they were investigating whether he was connected to the militant Islamic Jihad.

In the Gaza Strip, meanwhile, he is being seen as a sort of Palestinian everyman who finally snapped because of the combined pressure of the four-month uprising and Israel's economic blockade. "Anyone of us could be Khalil," said a woman passing through his local pharmacy. The reality may be very different. In Gaza's conservative society mental illness carries a stigma, and Mr Olbeh's family would admit that he has been suffering from depression only after the local pharmacist revealed that is on medication. "What do you want - that I should go and tell everybody that my poor son is psychologically ill?" his mother Fatima Abu Olbeh said.

Then Mr Olbeh's wife, Manal, admitted: "He had a psychological disease." Mr Olbeh has been on another antidepressant, Anafranil, for two years, his mother said, producing a strip of tablets. In her desire to shield her son from shame she used to get the prescription filled herself. Mr Olbeh's family is convinced that the carnage was the result of an accident. "All I can think of is that it is a regular road accident, because he was sick for two days before that," his wife said. "He had the flu. His face was pale, and he was vomiting and felt dizzy."

Meanwhile it was agreed last night that the outgoing prime minister Ehud Barak, defeated soundly in last week's election, will remain in office as defence minister in a unity government under his successor, Ariel Sharon. The Labour party secretary, Raanan Cohen, said the elder statesman Shimon Peres would be foreign minister. "I think that with the appointment of Ehud Barak on the one hand and Shimon Peres on the other, this will be a government which will determine all the diplomatic policy," Mr Cohen told Israel television.
Mr Barak was defence minister throughout his his 20 months as prime minister.

fields.headline: Emap sells games titles to Dennis
fields.trailText: 11.45am: Emap Active has sold two of its three gaming titles to Dennis Publishing for an undisclosed sum, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Emap Active has sold two of its three gaming titles to Dennis Publishing for an undisclosed sum.

The news, which was announced internally yesterday, does not affect Emap's flagship gaming title Nintendo Official Magazine.

The Titles to be transferred to Dennis are The Player, a recently launched magazine for the Sony PlayStation market, and Computer & Video Games, the market-leading multi-format games magazine that sells around 45,606 copies per month.

As part of the deal, Dennis has also acquired computerandvideogames.com, the Emap website that launched in 1999 and claims to attract more than 50,000 unique users per week.

Twenty staff, including all members of the two magazines' editorial and advertising teams, will be transferred over to Dennis Publishing without any redundancies envisaged.

The magazines will be published by Dennis from their April issues.

"The development of Computer and Video Games online and offline and The Player is better served by Dennis," said Emap Active managing director Ian Templeton.

"They have a stronger commitment to the multi-format sectors and we have other markets where we need to concentrate our efforts. We are committed to our Nintendo magazine and in this niche we will be offering content and marketing support to Dennis as they develop their cross-platform internet venture."

webTitle: Zeta-Jones to play Liz Taylor in Clift biopic

fields.headline: Zeta-Jones to play Liz Taylor in Clift biopic
fields.trailText: Catherine Zeta-Jones will portray the legendary Hollywood star in a film about the life of Montgomery Clift, one of the biggest film stars of the 1950s
fields.body:
Catherine Zeta-Jones is set to play Elizabeth Taylor in a biopic about her friend and co-star, Montgomery Clift. According to ITN, the as-yet nameless film is expected to go into production later this year.

Clift, one of the top Hollywood stars of the 1950s, earned his first best actor Oscar nomination as a young soldier in The Search. Extremely handsome, he was daring in his choice of roles, turning down, among others, Sunset Boulevard and On the Waterfront. His greatest successes include A Place in the Sun (in which he starred with Taylor) and From Here to Eternity, which also earned him Oscar nominations.

In 1957, Clift was involved in a car accident which left him permanently scarred. Taylor was reportedly one of the first people to rush to his aid at the scene of the crash. Although he continued acting, appearing in such well remembered films as The Misfits and Suddenly, Last Summer, in which he again co-starred with Taylor, his career never hit the peaks it once had. He died aged just 46.

Newly married Zeta-Jones is currently a Hollywood darling, despite not winning an Oscar nomination for her role in Traffic.

Meanwhile, her father-in-law, Kirk Douglas has been speaking of his pride in Zeta-Jones and his new grandson, Dylan. "She's a wonderful girl, not only beautiful, but she's a family girl," said Douglas. "And what I'm most proud about is that she gave Michael a baby boy and that boy has the single biggest dimple on his chin."

Douglas was talking at the Berlin Film Festival where he received a Golden Bear award for lifetime achievement. According to the Hollywood Reporter, the actor wowed members of the press when he spoke at a news conference in German.

fields.headline: The Rumour Mill
fields.standfirst: Today's rumours are just like page 3 soldier Roberta - stripped to the bone
fields.trailText: Manchester United have made an offer for Real Zaragoza midfielder Roberto Miguel Acuna, according to Planet Football. The website's "Spanish sources" claim that Sir Alex Ferguson wants to sign the Paraguayan international before the English transfer deadline next month - but Zaragoza are determined to hang onto their star player at least until the end of the season.
fields.body:
Manchester United have made an offer for Real Zaragoza midfielder Roberto Miguel Acuna, according to Planet Football. The website's "Spanish sources" claim that Sir Alex Ferguson wants to sign the Paraguayan international before the English transfer deadline next month - but Zaragoza are determined to hang onto their star player at least until the end of the season.

Roberto Mancini could have played his last game for Leicester. Rumours abound that he'll be lined up to replace Fatih Terim at Fiorentina at the end of the season. Fiorentina vice-president Mario Sconcerti, dropped the biggest hint, saying: "Mancini was a big player and he will be a big manager."

Ipswich are close to signing 20-year-old Belgian winger Tom Soetaers, who plays for Dutch club Roda, reports the Star.

Hull City manager Brian Little is favourite to become Portsmouth's new first-team coach, according to the Sun.

Sunderland are watching Belgian international midfielder Marc Hendrikx, who plays for Genk, claims the Star.

Wigan Athletic are close to completing the signing of Peter Beagrie, reports Planet Football.

fields.headline: The guzzler
fields.trailText: Cheapskate | Quick bites | On the menu | On the net | Just out | The taste test
fields.body:
Cheapskate ... Where to eat out for under £15

Phuket, 246, Battersea Park Road, SW11 020-72235924

Not exactly the most marvellous Thai you will ever consume (Pad Thai Jay a little glutenous; fragrant rice a smidgen stick; an excessive number of those damned serrated carrots; and altogether in want of a hefty squeeze of lime juice) but it's a chirpy alternative to Battersea Park Road's endless line-up of Chinese, Indian, Italian and Spanish. Phuket is a good place to warm up on a frosty weekday night. It generates a pleasing sort of hubbub and you can't help warm to the sight of a chap sipping milk as he gobbles his noodles. Look out for the dinky spring rolls, the size of corks, which are themselves darkly, crisply enticing, but pass on the dipping sauce, which tends towards a tomato puree tendency.

Quick bites ... Where to eat out in 15 minutes

Boho Bohemian Bar, 517, Battersea Park Road, SW11 Tel: 020-7228 4562

Boho is one of those faintly draughty establishments, with a pretty, tiled aisle and plenty of those strangely glowing box-shaped lights that loom a little too low over picnic-style tables. It's also brand spanking new and so a little short of polish here and there. The staff possess a sort of labradorish enthusiasm. Boho serves absurdly cheap grub - spot-on grilled trout at £5.50; steak with rosemary potatoes came to £10 . Salads can be a little too Mr Sainsbury's, the potatoes could do with less fat, and vegetarians get short shrift. Actually, they get no shrift at all. But all in all at these prices, Boho is set fair to become a popular watering hole for the Battersea casual eating set.

On the menu

Pithiviers

Sounds like a small town in France. Warm, but not hot.

OK, get on with it. It's the nearest the French get to the great British pie.

Where's the difference? It is a small, all-in-one pastry case, usually made of pate brise, or short crust pastry to you.

And then? It is stuffed with all manner of goodies - or leftovers, as the case may be.

Give us some example. Game pithivier, quince pithivier, lobster, chocolate pithivier, which are usually chopped up fineish. The pithivier is usually served warm or hot accompanied by a smashing sauce.

Give me a pork pie any day.

On the net

teddingtoncheese.co.uk

Teddington cheese arrives wrapped in waxed paper, nestling in straw, small cards tucked beneath the pleat explaining exactly the origins of your cheese. You almost expect it to read: "Please look after this bear." With more than 130 varieties of British and continental cheeses to choose from, it's difficult to decide which particular Teddington fromage one wishes to sample. The Cornish Yarg, the Ashed Golden Cross and the Kirkham's Lancashire are all fantabulous. For those of you who are still foxed, there are plenty of cheeseboard selections available. Not to mention biscuits, hampers, pickles and wine.

Delivery: Next-day delivery available for orders placed before 12 o'clock.

Charges: £5.95 p&p.

Just out

Patak's Jaipuri Chicken Jalfrezi

Form: Two containers, one of ghee, marinated chicken bits, vegetables, and Jalfrezi goo; the other with rice and bay leaves.

Flavour: It says medium hot, but it's medium rather than hot; distinctive, fresh spicing with one spice (fenugreek?) rather dominant. The rice is suffused with cardamom.

Verdict: Easy to cook, took the 10 minutes promised on the packaging and the portions are generous. The chicken was tender and rather tasty, and the rice unusually good for something from the chiller cabinet. Even the goo was good. There was an over-dominant something, which skewed the flavour somewhat, but it tasted fresh and lively

Cost: £3.99 for 1kg.

The taste test: Greek-style yoghurt (or the real thing)

Real Greek yoghurt is made from sheep's milk rather than cow's (responsible for most of these) and by the fat content - 6g per 100g for sheep, 10-15g per 100g for cows

Brand: Sainsbury Authentic Greek Yoghurt
Price: £0.45/150g
What it's like: Sheep's milk gives it a fresh edge.
How it rates: *****

Brand: Waitrose Greek Style
Price: £0.31/150g
What it's like: Rich stuff, marked acidity; soft, creamy, texture.
How it rates: ****

Brand: Somerfield Greek Style

fields.bodyText: Cheapskate ... Where to eat out for under £15 Phuket, 246, Battersea Park Road, SW11 020-72235924 Not exactly the most marvellous Thai you will ever consume (Pad Thai Jay a little glutenous; fragrant rice a smidgen stick; an excessive number of those damned serrated carrots; and altogether in want of a hefty squeeze of lime juice) but it's a chirpy alternative to Battersea Park Road's endless line-up of Chinese, Indian, Italian and Spanish. Phuket is a good place to warm up on a frosty weekday night. It generates a pleasing sort of hubbub and you can't help warm to the sight of a chap sipping milk as he gobbles his noodles. Look out for the dinky spring rolls, the size of corks, which are themselves darkly, crisply enticing, but pass on the dipping sauce, which tends towards a tomato puree tendency. Quick bites ... Where to eat out in 15 minutes Boho Bohemian Bar, 517, Battersea Park Road, SW11 Tel: 020-7228 4562 Boho is one of those faintly draughty establishments, with a pretty, tiled aisle and plenty of those strangely glowing box-shaped lights that loom a little too low over picnic-style tables. It's also brand spanking new and so a little short of polish here and there. The staff possess a sort of labradorish enthusiasm. Boho serves absurdly cheap grub - spot-on grilled trout at £5.50; steak with rosemary potatoes came to £10 . Salads can be a little too Mr Sainsbury's, the potatoes could do with less fat, and vegetarians get short shrift. Actually, they get no shrift at all. But all in all at these prices, Boho is set fair to become a popular watering hole for the Battersea casual eating set. On the menu Pithiviers Sounds like a small town in France. Warm, but not hot. OK, get on with it. It's the nearest the French get to the great British pie. Where's the difference? It is a small, all-in-one pastry case, usually made of pate brise, or short crust pastry to you. And then? It is stuffed with all manner of goodies - or leftovers, as the case may be. Give us some example. Game pithivier, quince pithivier, lobster, chocolate pithivier, which are usually chopped up fineish. The pithivier is usually served warm or hot accompanied by a smashing sauce. Give me a pork pie any day. On the net teddingtoncheese.co.uk Teddington cheese arrives wrapped in waxed paper, nestling in straw, small cards tucked beneath the pleat explaining exactly the origins of your cheese. You almost expect it to read: "Please look after this bear." With more than 130 varieties of British and continental cheeses to choose from, it's difficult to decide which particular Teddington fromage one wishes to sample. The Cornish Yarg, the Ashed Golden Cross and the Kirkham's Lancashire are all fantabulous. For those of you who are still foxed, there are plenty of cheeseboard selections available. Not to mention biscuits, hampers, pickles and wine. Delivery: Next-day delivery available for orders placed before 12 o'clock. Charges: £5.95 p&p. Just out Patak's Jaipuri Chicken Jalfrezi Form: Two containers, one of ghee, marinated chicken bits, vegetables, and Jalfrezi goo; the other with rice and bay leaves. Flavour: It says medium hot, but it's medium rather than hot; distinctive, fresh spicing with one spice (fenugreek?) rather dominant. The rice is suffused with cardamom. Verdict: Easy to cook, took the 10 minutes promised on the packaging and the portions are generous. The chicken was tender and rather tasty, and the rice unusually good for something from the chiller cabinet. Even the goo was good. There was an over-dominant something, which skewed the flavour somewhat, but it tasted fresh and lively Cost: £3.99 for 1kg. fields.headline: EM.TV chief quits
fields.trailText:
11.30am: Chairman Nickolaus Becker has resigned in protest at the Kirch rescue deal, writes Dan Milmo.
Feb 15: Kirch bails out EM.TV
fields.body:
The future of German media group EM.TV is hanging in the balance following the resignation of Nickolaus Becker, the chairman of the company's supervisory board.

He has quit in protest at a last-minute rescue deal, agreed yesterday with EM.TV's German rival Kirch.

This deal could, in any case, be scuppered by formula one tycoon Bernie Ecclestone.

In addition to Mr Becker, several senior figures within EM.TV are known to be opposed to the rescue package as it gives Kirch a 16% stake in the company.

EM.TV chief executive Thomas Haffa brokered the deal.

Mr Ecclestone is threatening to exercise his right to veto the deal between Kirch and EM.TV.

Kirch yesterday agreed to bail out EM.TV by buying half of its 50% stake in formula one holding company SLEC for £380m, plus a 16% stake in the struggling German group.

SLEC is controlled by Mr Ecclestone, which gives him the power to block the deal.

EM.TV appeared to be in the dark this morning about Mr Ecclestone's opposition to the agreement, claiming it had received no notification from SLEC.

"We have just seen the reports and, as far as we know, there has been no phone conversation between Mr Haffa and Mr Ecclestone," said a spokeswoman for EM.TV.

This contradicted Mr Ecclestone's claim that both EM.TV and Kirch have been notified of SLEC's opposition to the deal.

EM.TV needs the green light for the Kirch package, as it is struggling to pay off a £680m debt burden created by a wave of acquisitions last year.

There are also doubts over Kirch's ability to raise the £1bn needed to finance the rescue deal, which includes buying a further 25% of SLEC under the terms of a shareholding agreement signed between Mr Ecclestone and EM.TV.

fields.headline: Hannibal
fields.standfirst: Dr Lecter's back for a second helping and audiences will be flocking like lambs to the slaughter to see Ridley Scott's take on the cannibalistic psychiatrist. Here's our guide to the best sites on the movie event of the year
fields.trailText: Dr Lecter's back for a second helping and audiences will be flocking like lambs to the slaughter to see Ridley Scott's take on the cannibalistic psychiatrist. Here's our guide to the best sites on the movie event of the year.
fields.body:
1. The silence will finally be broken tonight, when Hannibal opens in British cinemas, so celebrate with our monster film quiz.

2. This time, the eponymous "hero", Dr Lecter, will be on screen for a great deal longer than the 26 minutes of Silence of the Lambs that won Sir Anthony Hopkins a best actor Oscar.

3. Thomas Harris took a decade to pen the sequel to his first two phenomenally successful tales of the cannibalistic psychiatrist.

4. It's 10 years since Jonathan Demme's masterly thriller first terrified audiences - and the epicurean eccentric's latest adventure is bound to turn the stomachs of more than a few viewers.

5. Demme thought Harris's new book was unfilmable, and Jodie Foster spurned the opportunity to return to the role of FBI starlet Clarice Starling, so that honour went to Julianne Moore.

6. There are critics, of course, such as the Evening Standard's Alexander Walker, who think that Silence and Hannibal are tasteless and utterly beyond the pale. Why not file your own review?

7. The new movie is already a cultural icon, with the poster pastiched on the cover of this week's New Statesman and elsewhere.

8. We may not have seen the end of Hopkins's Lecter. Harris's first book, Red Dragon, was filmed in 1986 as Manhunter, with Brian Cox as the doctor, but there may be a remake of that. Hopkins himself is said to have drafted an idea for a sequel to Hannibal.

9. If you yearn for something a little gentler, then perhaps you should pick the "vegetarian" alternative, Fried Green Tomatoes.

10. In the meantime, we can reveal that there's a touch of brain on the Hannibal menu, but the question is, will it be served with fava beans and a nice Chianti?
