webTitle: MPs warn Kirch over World Cup rights

fields.headline: MPs warn Kirch over World Cup rights
fields.trailText:
10.30am: UK politicians have warned German media company Kirch that an auction of World Cup rights will fail, writes Dan Milmo.
Feb 15: Minister intervenes in World Cup row

Feb 15: World Cup rights battle hots up
fields.body:
UK politicians have warned German media company Kirch that an auction of World Cup broadcasting rights will fail because pay-TV companies will want to avoid a possible public relations disaster.

A cross-party group of MPs believe that public opposition will mount against Kirch, which is waging a court battle to be allowed to sell off the UK rights to the highest bidder, which would be a pay-TV company rather than free-to-air broadcasters ITV and the BBC.

Labour MP John Grogan, who yesterday signed an early day motion protesting at the company's plans, said pay-TV operators such as BSkyB would be unlikely to risk the wrath of the football-loving public by bidding for the World Cup rights. BSkyB owns 22% of Kirch's pay-TV subsidiary.

"A company like BSkyB would have to calculate the public relations consequences of doing a deal with Kirch. The World Cup is unlike any other event because of the volume of people who watch it," said Mr Grogan.

Fellow Labour MP Ivor Caplin, the treasurer of the Commons all-party football group, called for Kirch to enter negotiations with the BBC and ITV immediately, as pay-TV operators may avoid bidding altogether.

"Our pay-TV providers may see this as an argument they do not want to get involved in. Kirch will be far better advised to settle for a deal with the BBC and ITV," said Mr Caplin.

Mr Caplin also brushed off Kirch's argument that it has to recoup the £670m it paid for the rights and that a ban on an auction would restrict its trading rights.

"If you have bought something at a shop, no matter what the price, you cannot always take it back," said Mr Caplin.

The MPs' arguments are backed by UK broadcasting sources close to the talks between the BBC, ITV and Kirch.

One industry insider said that because the 2002 tournament will be held in Japan, the kick-off times will be too early to attract a massive UK audience and this will reduce the value of the rights.

"Most of the games will be kicking off between 7 and 8am, UK time, and that can only affect the commercial value of the rights," said the source.

Kirch has asked the European court of justice to overrule the EU Commission's decision to enshrine the UK 1996 Broadcasting Act within European law.

The act lists the World Cup as a sporting event of national importance that must seen on free-to-air channels in the UK.

Kirch is arguing that the Commission's decision to include this list within EU law is a restraint of its trading and property rights.

fields.headline: Obituary: Alan Ross
fields.standfirst: Poet, writer and cricket devotee whose brilliant editorship of the London Magazine kept alive a literary tradition
fields.trailText: Poet, writer and cricket devotee whose brilliant editorship of the London Magazine kept alive a literary tradition.
fields.body:
Great editors are even more rare, and perhaps more necessary, than great writers: they are seldom the same people. A plausible history of 20th-century English literature can be extrapolated from magazines such as John Lehmann's New Writing, Cyril Connolly's Horizon, and Alan Ross's London Magazine. Of these the third, belonging to a period when the solid, book-shaped literary monthly seemed to have had its day, is in some respects the most extraordinary achievement.

Alan Ross, who has died aged 78, was born in Calcutta, where his father worked in the coal-mining industry. He was educated at Falmouth, and then at private school in East Grinstead, where in the holidays he pursued his passion for cricket at the Sussex county ground at Hove. He then went to Haileybury and St John's College, Oxford, to read modern languages.

His undergraduate career was, however, interrupted by naval war service on Russian convoys, and, demobilised in 1947, he had no wish to return to Oxford. He had completed, in Germany, the poems for his first full-length collection, The Derelict Day (1947); he had made important friendships among writers and artists; and he almost immediately set off for Corsica, with the painter John Minton, to write his first travel book, Time Was Away (1948).

He landed on his feet financially too, receiving an award from the Rockefeller Foundation, working for the British Council, and, from 1950, becoming a sports writer on the Observer. In 1949, he married Jennifer Fry, of the chocolate-making dynasty; their son, Jonathan, was born in 1953.

If Ross's reputation as a poet is somewhat blurred, this is partly because his own writing was inevitably overshadowed by his editorial self, and partly because his poems are dominated by two themes uncongenial to contemporary English taste - war and travel.

Poems 1942-67 (1967), which, he wrote in a preface, "replaces my five previous volumes", includes revised versions of some war poems; they are full of reportage, yet oddly impersonal, and often reveal (especially in the long JW 51B) a fondness for adventurous yarn-spinning. Three later collections - The Taj Express (1973), Open Sea (1975) and Death Valley (1980) - confirm his delight in places and things caught with a journalist's sense of the significant occasion, but his eye is usually keener than his ear, and the poems, for all their attention to detail, lack resonance.

When he inherited the London Magazine from Lehmann in 1961, Ross had the enormous advantage of being neither a disappointed academic nor a creative writer in need of regular work, but a literary all-rounder whose interests and contacts spanned the arts and sporting worlds.

Introducing volume 1, number 1 of his "new series" that April, he announced that the magazine would grow from a "monthly review of literature" into a "review of the arts"; it would have gravity and astringency, but never solemnity nor malice, and "at all costs experiment, the hopefulness that the best, even most melancholy art, always must generate, even in despite of itself". It was an ambitious programme, and an expensive one, but he was as good as his word.

Throughout the 1960s, London Magazine (Ross dropped the definite article in 1966) was an exemplary success, alert to a time of artistic fluidity yet never losing sight of its civilised principles; indeed, its editorial quirks - strange pieces on sporting subjects or exotic places, and an apparently inexhaustible supply of minor writers' interlocking memoirs among them - helpfully kept the magazine anchored beyond the fluffy ephemera of the decade. In 1965, he launched two parallel ven tures, a hardback list (Alan Ross Ltd) and the eclectic London Magazine Editions, slender paperbacks elegantly set in Juliana and bound in grainy brown covers - "like wholemeal bread", said one reviewer.

Both were in style and substance extensions of the magazine; early hardbacks included Barbara Skelton's Born Losers, J Maclaren-Ross's Memoirs Of The Forties, TC Worsley's Flannelled Fool and Keith Vaughan's Journals And Drawings, while the paperback series concentrated on younger writers and anthologies. It was entirely characteristic of Ross that 15 years later, when he had virtually given up book-publishing, he should have revived the LME imprint to produce two hardbacks by his old and abruptly publisherless friend Roy Fuller, and made a great success of them.

In 1971, exactly 10 years after taking over LM, Ross decided to transform it into a bi-monthly, citing the success of the double 100th issue in 1969 and a summer double number in 1970. But they were special occasions, and the fat, but infrequent, magazine seemed to lose focus. Monthly publication was resumed in 1977, and, for a while, the magazine seemed restored to its old self, until in July 1973 Ross published a provocative article by Dotson Rader, The Private Letters Of Tennessee Williams, which led to an expensive libel action. The magazine survived, though only after an appeal and a "final reminder" from Ross in the fraught double issue of February/March 1981. LM's 20th anniversary was almost its wake.

All times are difficult for literary publishers, but the 1980s - with soaring costs, declining advertising revenue, and the whole concept of a literary culture more than ever under threat - were next to impossible. They took their toll of LM; a retrenchment to bi-monthly publication, fewer pages, poorer illustrations, a daunting cover price. But its commitment to good and various writing remained and, as magazines such as Encounter and the Listener folded, it became indispensable.

Ross, meanwhile, pursued a wide range of other projects. He was on the Observer staff until 1971, and, as cricket correspondent, twice toured Australia, South Africa and the West Indies . He edited the Cricketer's Companion, wrote half a dozen other books on the game. He edited numerous anthologies, wrote several books for children, and, in the late 1980s, produced two witty and civilised volumes of autobiography, Blindfold Games (1986) and Coastwise Lights (1988); the latter ends, charmingly, not on a literary note but with a chapter on The Racing Game. With Ross, the two were always intermingled - his horses ran in brown and pink, the colours of the LM of July 1965, the month they were registered.

Ross's promptness in dealing with manuscripts was legendary and open to varying interpretations. Hugo Williams, his assistant at LM for many years, once wrote of him turning contributions round at the door - for which their authors, said Williams, were pathetically grateful. But he may have missed the point. When, as a sixth-former, I sent my first, almost-publishable poems to Ross, he returned them, but not with a printed rejection slip. "I like these, though not quite enough to take: AR." Slender encouragement, but it was enough, more than I deserved, and it kept me writing. He must have done the same for thousands of others. In that way, too, he was a great editor.

Ross divorced Jennifer, and, at the end of last year, married Jane Rye; Victoria is the stepdaughter of that marriage.

Neil Powell

Michael Davie writes: Alan Ross seemed to change remarkably little in style and appearance, and not at all in character, during 50 years. I first met him in the cricket XI at Haileybury. He was a very good opening bowler, but a sloppy fielder. When Alan, at mid-on, failed to stop a drive with his boot, a stout, businessman parent called out: "Why doesn't Ross get his hair cut?" I sympathised. with the parent. Alan never liked to exert himself in the field or throw himself around, possibly because he thought it would look inelegant.

He used to bring Baudelaire into the pavilion, and paid for a poem of his own, Summer Thunder, to be printed in a red paper cover. The rest of us thought the poetry an adolescent affectation that would pass. Nevertheless, he was not a thorough-going aesthete. What he liked best was to talk to the cricket pro, Bert Wensley, formerly of Sussex, about such heroes as Maurice Tate, Duleepsinhji and HT Bartlett, and to encourage Bert to enlarge on his reasons for describing Sir Home Gordon, Bart, the overlord of Sussex cricket, as a "shit" - the first time we heard that word.

There was a bolshie strain in Alan, too. He treated the masters as equals, and he never followed intellectual fashions, or showed any automatic respect for big names. He had little interest in the past. He liked what was fresh and original and contemporary, with complete confidence in his own judgment. He attached importance to appearances: Mediterranean landscape, racehorses, cover-drives, paintings, photographs, handsome new books.

He was never an intellectual; at Oxford, he did no work, and was proudest of playing squash and cricket for the university, though against Cambridge at Lord's he failed to take a wicket and made a duck.

Surprisingly, the restrictions of naval life did not bring out his bolshie side. On leave, he used to hang around Fitzrovia with louche characters; one high spot came when he took out Judy Campbell, the singer who made A Nightingale Sang In Berkeley Square famous. He claimed she had actually sung the song to him in Berkeley Square. Quite possibly she did; he had plenty of charm. Women liked him, and he liked them.

Being a magazine editor suited him down the ground. It enabled him to dodge having to pursue anything so constricting as a career. The only aspects he disliked were the battles with landlords and worries about funding; he and the magazine were both lucky to have had the prolonged support of his well-to-do wife, Jennifer. Many middle-aged writers must feel in his debt. Not long ago, I introduced him to the Australian David Malouf: "He published my first poems," said Malouf.

Alan himself seemed to write with unusual facility, whether about cricket and soccer or about places and paintings, or his own life. As a sports writer, he never missed a deadline, which was surprising for a poet. Some press-box colleagues and professional sportsmen never realised he was a poet, though the sub-editors used to raise the odd eyebrow at a fancy image. John Woodcock, the Times cricket correspondent and editor of Wisden for many years, said recently that Alan's Australia 55 is about the best cricket book ever written.

Charles Osborne writes: I first met Alan Ross in 1958 when I was working for London Magazine, and he was a frequent contributor, both as a poet and as a reviewer. When he bought the magazine in 1961, he asked me to stay on as assistant editor. Early on, we agreed to differ about cricket, and our conversation tended to range from critical discussion of poetry to scurrilous gossip about writers and artists.

He was witty, sympathetic and generous, with an engaging stammer that tended to come and go. When he had his first severe bout of depression, which necessitated electric shock treatment, he was out of action for about a year. The depression returned last year, but his resilience triumphed. He never ceased to write poetry.

He will certainly be remembered; by some for his books on cricket, by others as a lyric poet of rare perception, an editor of genius, and an encourager of younger writers, and, by his many friends, as a rare human being.

 Alan Ross, writer and editor, born May 6 1922; died February 14 2001

Late Gower

Arm confined below shoulder level
As if winged, the slight
Lopsided air of a seabird
Caught in an oilslick. 'Late' Gower,
As of a painting by Monet, a 'serial'
Whose shuffled images delight
Through inconstancy, variety of light.

Giambattista Tiepolo
In his 'Continence of Scipio' created
Just such a head and halo.
For this descendant no confines
Of canvas, but increasing worry lines,
Low gravity of a burglar.

Stance, posture, combine
To suggest a feline
Not cerebral intelligence. A hedonist
In his autumn, romance lightly worn,
And now first signs of tristesse ,

fields.bodyText: Great editors are even more rare, and perhaps more necessary, than great writers: they are seldom the same people. A plausible history of 20th-century English literature can be extrapolated from magazines such as John Lehmann's New Writing, Cyril Connolly's Horizon, and Alan Ross's London Magazine. Of these the third, belonging to a period when the solid, book-shaped literary monthly seemed to have had its day, is in some respects the most extraordinary achievement. Alan Ross, who has died aged 78, was born in Calcutta, where his father worked in the coal-mining industry. He was educated at Falmouth, and then at private school in East Grinstead, where in the holidays he pursued his passion for cricket at the Sussex county ground at Hove. He then went to Haileybury and St John's College, Oxford, to read modern languages. His undergraduate career was, however, interrupted by naval war service on Russian convoys, and, demobilised in 1947, he had no wish to return to Oxford. He had completed, in Germany, the poems for his first full-length collection, The Derelict Day (1947); he had made important friendships among writers and artists; and he almost immediately set off for Corsica, with the painter John Minton, to write his first travel book, Time Was Away (1948). He landed on his feet financially too, receiving an award from the Rockefeller Foundation, working for the British Council, and, from 1950, becoming a sports writer on the Observer. In 1949, he married Jennifer Fry, of the chocolate-making dynasty; their son, Jonathan, was born in 1953. If Ross's reputation as a poet is somewhat blurred, this is partly because his own writing was inevitably overshadowed by his editorial self, and partly because his poems are dominated by two themes uncongenial to contemporary English taste - war and travel. Poems 1942-67 (1967), which, he wrote in a preface, "replaces my five previous volumes", includes revised versions of some war poems; they are full of reportage, yet oddly impersonal, and often reveal (especially in the long JW 51B) a fondness for adventurous yarn-spinning. Three later collections - The Taj Express (1973), Open Sea (1975) and Death Valley (1980) - confirm his delight in places and things caught with a journalist's sense of the significant occasion, but his eye is usually keener than his ear, and the poems, for all their attention to detail, lack resonance. When he inherited the London Magazine from Lehmann in 1961, Ross had the enormous advantage of being neither a disappointed academic nor a creative writer in need of regular work, but a literary all-rounder whose interests and contacts spanned the arts and sporting worlds. Introducing volume 1, number 1 of his "new series" that April, he announced that the magazine would grow from a "monthly review of literature" into a "review of the arts"; it would have gravity and astringency, but never solemnity nor malice, and "at all costs experiment, the hopefulness that the best, even most melancholy art, always must generate, even in despite of itself". It was an ambitious programme, and an expensive one, but he was as good as his word. Throughout the 1960s, London Magazine (Ross dropped the definite article in 1966) was an exemplary success, alert to a time of artistic fluidity yet never losing sight of its civilised principles; indeed, its editorial quirks - strange pieces on sporting subjects or exotic places, and an apparently inexhaustible supply of minor writers' interlocking memoirs among them - helpfully kept the magazine anchored beyond the fluffy ephemera of the decade. In 1965, he launched two parallel ven tures, a hardback list (Alan Ross Ltd) and the eclectic London Magazine Editions, slender paperbacks elegantly set in Juliana and bound in grainy brown covers - "like wholemeal bread", said one reviewer. Both were in style and substance extensions of the magazine; early hardbacks included Barbara Skelton's Born Losers, J Maclaren-Ross's Memoirs Of The Forties, TC Worsley's Flannelled Fool and Keith Vaughan's Journals And Drawings, while the paperback series concentrated on younger writers and anthologies. It was entirely characteristic of Ross that 15 years later, when he had virtually given up book-publishing, he should have revived the LME imprint to produce two hardbacks by his old and abruptly publisherless friend Roy Fuller, and made a great success of them. In 1971, exactly 10 years after taking over LM, Ross decided to transform it into a bi-monthly, citing the success of the double 100th issue in 1969 and a summer double number in 1970. But they were special occasions, and the fat, but infrequent, magazine seemed to lose focus. Monthly publication was resumed in 1977, and, for a while, the magazine seemed restored to its old self, until in July 1973 Ross published a provocative article by Dotson Rader, The Private Letters Of Tennessee Williams, which led to an expensive libel action. The magazine survived, though only after an appeal and a "final reminder" from Ross in the fraught double issue of February/March 1981. LM's 20th anniversary was almost its wake. All times are difficult for literary publishers, but the 1980s - with soaring costs, declining advertising revenue, and the whole concept of a literary culture more than ever under threat - were next to impossible. They took their toll of LM; a retrenchment to bi-monthly publication, fewer pages, poorer illustrations, a daunting cover price. But its commitment to good and various writing remained and, as magazines such as Encounter and the Listener folded, it became indispensable. Ross, meanwhile, pursued a wide range of other projects. He was on the Observer staff until 1971, and, as cricket correspondent, twice toured Australia, South Africa and the West Indies . He edited the Cricketer's Companion, wrote half a dozen other books on the game. He edited numerous anthologies, wrote several books for children, and, in the late 1980s, produced two witty and civilised volumes of autobiography, Blindfold Games (1986) and Coastwise Lights (1988); the latter ends, charmingly, not on a literary note but with a chapter on The Racing Game. With Ross, the two were always intermingled - his horses ran in brown and pink, the colours of the LM of July 1965, the month they were registered. Ross's promptness in dealing with manuscripts was legendary and open to varying interpretations. Hugo Williams, his assistant at LM for many years, once wrote of him turning contributions round at the door - for which their authors, said Williams, were pathetically grateful. But he may have missed the point. When, as a sixth-former, I sent my first, almost-publishable poems to Ross, he returned them, but not with a printed rejection slip. "I like these, though not quite enough to take: AR." Slender encouragement, but it was enough, more than I deserved, and it kept me writing. He must have done the same for thousands of others. In that way, too, he was a great editor. Ross divorced Jennifer, and, at the end of last year, married Jane Rye; Victoria is the stepdaughter of that marriage. Neil Powell Michael Davie writes: Alan Ross seemed to change remarkably little in style and appearance, and not at all in character, during 50 years. I first met him in the cricket XI at Haileybury. He was a very good opening bowler, but a sloppy fielder. When Alan, at mid-on, failed to stop a drive with his boot, a stout, businessman parent called out: "Why doesn't Ross get his hair cut?" I sympathised. with the parent. Alan never liked to exert himself in the field or throw himself around, possibly because he thought it would look inelegant. He used to bring Baudelaire into the pavilion, and paid for a poem of his own, Summer Thunder, to be printed in a red paper cover. The rest of us thought the poetry an adolescent affectation that would pass. Nevertheless, he was not a thorough-going aesthete. What he liked best was to talk to the cricket pro, Bert Wensley, formerly of Sussex, about such heroes as Maurice Tate, Duleepsinhji and HT Bartlett, and to encourage Bert to enlarge on his reasons for describing Sir Home Gordon, Bart, the overlord of Sussex cricket, as a "shit" - the first time we heard that word. There was a bolshie strain in Alan, too. He treated the masters as equals, and he never followed intellectual fashions, or showed any automatic respect for big names. He had little interest in the past. He liked what was fresh and original and contemporary, with complete confidence in his own judgment. He attached importance to appearances: Mediterranean landscape, racehorses, cover-drives, paintings, photographs, handsome new books. He was never an intellectual; at Oxford, he did no work, and was proudest of playing squash and cricket for the university, though against Cambridge at Lord's he failed to take a wicket and made a duck. Surprisingly, the restrictions of naval life did not bring out his bolshie side. On leave, he used to hang around Fitzrovia with louche characters; one high spot came when he took out Judy Campbell, the singer who made A Nightingale Sang In Berkeley Square famous. He claimed she had actually sung the song to him in Berkeley Square. Quite possibly she did; he had plenty of charm. Women liked him, and he liked them. Being a magazine editor suited him down the ground. It enabled him to dodge having to pursue anything so constricting as a career. The only aspects he disliked were the battles with landlords and worries about funding; he and the magazine were both lucky to have had the prolonged support of his well-to-do wife, Jennifer. Many middle-aged writers must feel in his debt. Not long ago, I introduced him to the Australian David Malouf: "He published my first poems," said Malouf. Alan himself seemed to write with unusual facility, whether about cricket and soccer or about places and paintings, or his own life. As a sports writer, he never missed a deadline, which was surprising for a poet. Some press-box colleagues and professional sportsmen never realised he was a poet, though the sub-editors used to raise the odd eyebrow at a fancy image. John Woodcock, the Times cricket correspondent and editor of Wisden for many years, said recently that Alan's Australia 55 is about the best cricket book ever written. Charles Osborne writes: I first met Alan Ross in 1958 when I was working for London Magazine, and he was a frequent contributor, both as a poet and as a reviewer. When he bought the magazine in 1961, he asked me to stay on as assistant editor. Early on, we agreed to differ about cricket, and our conversation tended to range from critical discussion of poetry to scurrilous gossip about writers and artists. He was witty, sympathetic and generous, with an engaging stammer that tended to come and go. When he had his first severe bout of depression, which necessitated electric shock treatment, he was out of action for about a year. The depression returned last year, but his resilience triumphed. He never ceased to write poetry. He will certainly be remembered; by some for his books on cricket, by others as a lyric poet of rare perception, an editor of genius, and an encourager of younger writers, and, by his many friends, as a rare human being.  Alan Ross, writer and editor, born May 6 1922; died February 14 2001 Late Gower Arm confined below shoulder level As if winged, the slight Lopsided air of a seabird Caught in an oilslick. 'Late' Gower, As of a painting by Monet, a 'serial' Whose shuffled images delight Through inconstancy, variety of light. Giambattista Tiepolo In his 'Continence of Scipio' created Just such a head and halo. For this descendant no confines Of canvas, but increasing worry lines, Low gravity of a burglar. Stance, posture, combine To suggest a feline Not cerebral intelligence. A hedonist In his autumn, romance lightly worn, And now first signs of tristesse , Faint strains of a hunting horn.  from Green Fading Into Blue: Writings On Cricket And Other Sports, André Deutsch (1999)

fields.headline: Men's lifestyle titles suffer
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The latest Audit Bureau of Circulations figures present a far from rosy picture for men's magazines, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Sky's circulation has plummeted 35.2% year on year to 65,080 but the Emap title is by no means the only men's lifestyle magazine to have lost sales.

The latest Audit Bureau of Circulations figures for the period July to December 2000 show a far from rosy picture for men's titles.

Esquire's circulation has fallen 39% year on year to 61,271, having undergone an upmarket revamp.

But Esquire editor Peter Howarth claimed the title was attracting a heftier advertising spend.

Arena has lost 21.3% of its circulation year on year, down to 37,080, a figure that puts it in last place in the men's magazine league table.

FHM Collections is down 13.2% year on year to 71,064 but is stable compared with its performance in the first half of 2000.

Later's circulation is down 22.4% year on year to 70,267 and Focus has lost 17.2%, falling to 55,976.

Even IPC's Loaded, the original lads' mag, has slipped 5.4% year on year to 351,353.

However, the figure equates to losing just 0.4% period on period.

GQ and Bizarre maintained stable figures, with 140,112 and 119,057 respectively.

But laddism is far from dead. Way out in front is Emap's FHM with a circulation of 716,679 - a year-on-year increase of 2% but only 0.1% up period-on-period.

Other men's mags to increase their figures were the more niche titles.

The aspirational style and travel bible Wallpaper has enjoyed a 6.7% year-on-year increase to 134,402 and a period-on-period increase of 3.1%.

Gadget magazine T3's circulation was up 8.6% year on year to 50,059, but down period on period 2.1%.

Stuff recorded a 5.4% increase year on year to 55,239 and Men's Fitness was up 4.3% year on year to 40,756.

The success of niche titles over the past 12 months could herald a trend in the men's market.

IPC is rumoured to be launching a men's title focused on technology, codenamed Project Spider.

Media buyers see room for growth away from the generic tits-and-bums lads' mags.

"Laddism is not over - FHM is still enormous - but there is room for niche launches, maybe seeing some titles blending men's editorial with sport, computers or other areas of specific interest.," said Steve Goodman, MediaCom TMB press director.

fields.headline: Press watchdog rebuffs minister
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Parliament
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Keith Vaz last night hit a hurdle in his attempt to take on newspapers investigating his affairs, writes David Hencke.
fields.body:
Keith Vaz, the Europe minister, last night hit a hurdle in his attempt to take on newspapers investigating his affairs over the series of complaints being investigated by the Commons standards and privileges committee.

The embattled minister won permission from Downing Street to take the Sunday Telegraph to the Press Complaints Commission. But he also got his lawyer, Geoffrey Bindman, to warn the paper's editor, Dominic Lawson, that he would start legal proceedings as soon as the report by the committee is published later this year.

Last night the commission said that it would not even look at Mr Vaz's submission because of his threat to take legal action. Under PCC rules he is not allowed to pursue both courses simultaneously.

Mr Vaz has also been stymied in the courts because he cannot issue a writ until MPs decides to publish the result of their inquiry into the allegations against him.

No date has been set for that, leaving the possibility that the minister may have to issue the writs during the election campaign.

Mr Lawson said the paper intended to defend itself.

Mr Vaz also faces a further major hurdle before he can take legal action against newspapers. Under the ministerial code he must obtain the go-ahead of the Foreign Office legal department. Last night it became clear that the Foreign Office lawyers had not yet been consulted.

The Foreign Office's interpretation of the code was that as Mr Vaz was only issuing "warnings" against newspapers that he might sue, he did not need to put his full case to government lawyers yet.

Mr Vaz's complaint to the complaints commission concerns articles written in the newspaper on February 4. They alleged that his Leicester East constituency party had never received some £163;15,000 of donations made by wealthy supporters. The paper quoted constituency officials saying they could not trace the money. Mr Vaz claims the article is inaccurate.

Geoffrey Bindman, Mr Vaz's lawyer, said his client had threatened the legal action because he did not want newspapers to believe that accusations against him had gone unchallenged. Mr Vaz was unable to comment until the report of the standards and privileges committee was published but his position had been undermined by leaks to the press.

In a separate move last night political advisers close to Mr Vaz accused Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary standards commissioner and her staff of being behind the leaks. This was denied by her office.

fields.headline: Big services can never entirely be a local matter
fields.trailText: Local democracy is a wonderful thing, in principle; the little platoons trundling along to parish polls to decide on street lighting, bins and Ms Y's application to stick a conservatory on the back of her house. Practice can be something else.
fields.body:
Local democracy is a wonderful thing, in principle; the little platoons trundling along to parish polls to decide on street lighting, bins and Ms Y's application to stick a conservatory on the back of her house. Practice can be something else. Big services such as schooling and child protection can never be entirely a local matter. Then there is the question of who pays for vital community functions when locals cannot or will not.

So, while welcoming Bristol's efforts to stimulate local involvement, we have to register some misgivings about using a plebiscite to decide a specific and detailed question of governance. Budget-making is for elected representatives, not for postal voters. The ballots of 21.6% of Bristolians (the proportion who said they wanted nil increase in council tax this year) have now apparently determined that the quality of education offered the city's children should diminish. The council said it needed a tax increase - the government says 5% should be about the norm across the country - to underpin classroom improvements. But a zero increase implies either 180 fewer teachers or no new books.

That is a worst-case scenario. Municipal treasurers have been known before to reach into secret stashes and obviate cuts. None the less it is an unappetising result. So much so that the council's Labour majority should be ready to set it aside. When they come next month to set the 2001-02 budget, councillors should dare to invoke a former Bristol MP - Edmund Burke, not Tony Benn - and place their judgment about what is right before a pointer from a partial poll. Let them make a public case for what after all is Labour's policy for schools. A third of council seats are up for grabs on May 3, most of them held by Labour or the Liberal Democrats (who, nationally at least, believe in taxation for education). The four-fifths of the electorate who did not vote in the referendum are winnable to a good cause.

webTitle: Guardian takes royal treason law to court

fields.headline: Guardian takes royal treason law to court
fields.standfirst:
Guardian to fight royal treason law

Special report: the future of the monarchy
Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: The Guardian is launching a high court challenge under the Human Rights Act to a 153-year-old law, writes Clare Dyer.
fields.body:
The Guardian will make legal history today when it launches a high court challenge under the Human Rights Act to a 153-year-old law which threatens anyone calling in print for abolition of the monarchy with life imprisonment.

The Guardian's editor, Alan Rusbridger, and columnist Polly Toynbee will file a claim at the high court in London today against the attorney general, Lord Williams of Mostyn, and the director of public prosecutions, David Calvert-Smith.

The case is the first to be brought purely under the Human Rights Act since it came into force last October. The act has been invoked in criminal and civil cases but the Guardian's is the first to be brought under a freestanding right to bring proceedings in a court or tribunal.

The claim alleges that the 1848 Treason Felony Act violates article 10 of the European Convention on Human Rights, which guarantees the right to free speech.

The paper launched a campaign last December 6 - the date of the Queen's speech at the state opening of parliament - urging readers to support moves to establish Britain as a republic. The editor contacted the attorney general before publication seeking assurances that he and his staff would not be prosecuted if they advocated change by peaceful means only.

Lord Williams replied that such conduct "may be criminal" and refused to confirm that there would be no prosecution. None of the journalists who called for a republic has been threatened with prosecution. But the December 6 edition is still available as a back issue, the articles can be downloaded from the Guardian website, and the paper plans to continue its campaign.

"It is of importance to the right of freedom of expression guaranteed to the claimants and to their readers that the threat to prosecute should be authoritatively declared either baseless or real," papers filed with the court say.

The Guardian is seeking to clarify the Treason Felony Act as the first step in a legal campaign which will see it backing a challenge the Act of Settlement, the 300-year-old law which bans non-Protestants from succession to the British throne and discriminates against women and those born out of wedlock.

Mr Rusbridger said: "The Treason Felony Act is one more piece of archaic legal nonsense surrounding the monarchy. People may say it's meaningless but meaningless laws are bad laws. Like the Act of Settlement, it's about time it was scrapped."

He and Ms Toynbee are asking the court to interpret the Treason Felony Act to mean that advocating the overthrow of the monarchy by non-violent methods is no longer a crime. Under the Human Rights Act, judges have power to amend the wording of acts of parliament to make them comply with rights guaranteed by the European Convention.

If this is impossible, they may declare the statute incompatible, leaving it to parliament to amend it or face proceedings at the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg.

fields.headline: Future axes 350 jobs as magazines close
fields.trailText: 10am: Future Network, the IT and games publisher, is to close or sell off 20 loss-making magazines with the loss of 350 jobs. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Future Network, the IT and games publisher, is to close or sell off 20 loss-making magazines with the loss of 350 jobs.

The company, which counts Lis Murdoch among its non-executive directors, blamed the cuts on the sharp decline in copy sales in its core gaming market.

Future is shedding around 15% of its magazine titles and 17.5% of its staff.

"Tougher times require tough measures and this is absolutely the right decision for Future," said Chris Anderson, the company's founder and chairman.

Staff at the publisher's head office in Bath were being told the bad newsthis morning.

Future said it was unfair to give details of which six British titles would be affected until after all staff had been informed.

In the US six magazines will be closed, including music title Revolution and gadget title T3.

Eight titles will be closed in France and Germany and five websites will be shut down.

Future has also appointed Morgan Stanley Dean Witter to look at sale options for its recently launched internet business fortnightly, Business 2.0.

After the drastic cost-cutting measures, which will save the company £5m this year, Future will be left with 114 titles and 1,650 employees.

Future said last month it expected total revenues and profit for 2000 to fall short of already reduced forecasts because of poor sales.

Yesterday's ABC figures confirm this downturn, with the bulk of Future's portfolio showing drastic slumps.

Sales of its worst performing title, Dreamcast magazine DC-UK, dropped by 40.5%.

Other gaming and computer titles were also badly hit, with N64, Official Playstation Magazine, PC Guide and Playstation Max all recording declines of more than 30% in the past year.

The company's shares have fallen 87% in the past six months. Preliminary results will be announced on March 19.

webTitle: ONdigital puts a premium on football

fields.headline: ONdigital puts a premium on football
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: ONdigital is to launch its own premium sports channel to coincide with the start of the next football season, reports David Teather.
fields.body:
ONdigital, the pay-television group, is planning to launch its own premium sports channel to coincide with the start of the next football season.

The channel will screen coverage of the Nationwide League and Worthington Cup after ONdigital secured the broadcast rights in partnership with ITV in a three-year deal worth £315m last year.

ONdigital is adding the Nationwide League to its cover age of the European Champions' League and the so called "super nine" ATP tennis tournaments. The two events are now screened on ONsport, a channel included in the broadcaster's basic package.

A spokeswoman for ONdigital said the new channel would be offered to rival platforms in the same way that Sky Sports and the NTL-owned British Eurosport are carried by rival broadcasters. It is not yet decided whether the new channel will use the ONsport branding.

The launch represents a further ratcheting up in the competition for sports rights. NTL, which owns British Eurosport, is also planning the launch of a channel which will include the BBC as a minority share holder, provisionally called British Sport.

The Nationwide League deal will see live matches broadcast on Thursdays and Sundays, with pay-per-view games played on Friday nights.

ITV will also screen some Sunday matches and a high lights show as part of the deal which netted the league four times more than its existing TV package.

The spokeswoman said that ONdigital has enough quality content to sustain a premium channel but was also on the look out for other sports rights to include.

Presenters for the new channel are being kept under wraps as is the subscription price - although the spokeswoman said it would be competitive with the likes of Sky Sports.

fields.headline: City 'mishandled exercise in local democracy'
fields.standfirst: Voters opt for school cuts over tax rise prompting fears of teacher strike action
fields.trailText: Labour councillors in Bristol were yesterday left pondering a much vaunted exercise in local democracy which could cut a £4.5m hole in the town hall budget and provoke a strike among teachers over possible redundancies.
fields.body:
Labour councillors in Bristol were yesterday left pondering a much vaunted exercise in local democracy which could cut a £4.5m hole in the town hall budget and provoke a strike among teachers over possible redundancies.

If councils throughout Britain were stunned by the result of a local referendum in which voters opted for cuts in services, teaching unions were furious.

Accusing the Labour authority of a lack of responsibility, some teachers urged the council to ignore the results of the poll among 278,000 electors in which 54% voted for no increase.

"If one teacher loses their job because of this, we will be balloting for strike action," said Paulette North of the National Union of Teachers. "The council are like jellyfish. They could not take the political decision we put them into power for."

Peter Smith, general secretary of the Association of Teachers and Lecturers, said the council was playing to the gallery "when surely politicians are elected to be leaders, not followers". Marius Frank, of the Bedminster Down comprehensive school, said: "It's a massive step backwards".

'Groundbreaking'

Ministers and MPs had been hailing the referendum, the first of its type in a large city, as a groundbreaking consultation exercise which could lead to other experiments designed to rekindle interest in local democracy. Council election turnouts often drop to just 20%. In Bristol, which used a combination of postal and e-voting, turnout for the referendum was 40%.

Some accused the council of mishandling the exercise by warning specifically of education cuts instead of a wider threat to public services posed by a zero tax rise. In Bristolan estimated one in five secondary pupils are in private education. Other parents send their children to neighbouring authorities.

But polling experts cautioned against using the Bristol referendum as evidence that voters, when faced with a stark choice, would never vote for tax increases. In a similar exercise two years ago in Milton Keynes, taxpayers opted for a 10 % increase, almost four times the rate of inflation, after being presented with the option of big cuts in services.

Nick Sparrow, managing director of ICM Research, the Guardian's pollsters, said: "You can get the answer you want depending on the way you ask the question." He thought attitudes had changed since the 1980s. "Now people do not mind paying extra taxes and do not necessarily feel they are overtaxed, as long as the money is going to fund key services and they are efficiently run."

He thought it would be possible for a council to a get an endorsement from voters for at tax rise if they made the case, in the preamble on a referendum form, that an increase was necessary to maintain public services at an adequate level.

The Bristol Evening Post argued that the city council's exercise in "direct democracy" had been badly derailed because it was linked purely to education. "It immediately obliterated all other subjects from people's minds _ a referendum exercise has by its nature to be specific, but to load it in such a way is to undermine it as a democratic exercise. It is now left to the city council to pick up the pieces of a vote which has badly misfired."

The Liberal Democrats claimed the vote was predictable "given that Bristol still has one of the highest council taxes in the country". Barbara Janke, the group leader, added: "Labour has used the referendum to get themselves off the hook of having to make a hard decision."

With Labour having a majority of only two in the council chamber, it is possible that the Lib Dems could form an administration after local elections on May 3.

Hard choices

But the Lib Dems, accused of populism and irresponsibility by Labour, clearly face hard choices. Earlier this week several Labour councillors rebelled by siding with the opposition in voting down plans to close two primary schools.

Today all eyes will be on the south London borough of Croydon, the largest authority in the capital, when the council produces the results of its council tax referendum. Voters have been presented with three options: a 2%, 3.5% or 5% increase - with the Labour administration, like its counterpart in Bristol, making no recommendation. Some believe that voters, like those in Milton Keynes, will opt for a middle course.

Council leader Hugh Malyan, insisted that a 2% rise - Tories have taken out advertisements in the local press calling for the lowest option - would enable the council to maintain services at their present level, while 3.5 % would allow a modest £1.5m increase. At least they are playing safe.

fields.headline: Cricket drives Tour de France off Channel 4
fields.trailText: Channel 4 has dropped the Tour de France from its schedules after 15 years to concentrate on Test cricket, writes William Fotheringham.
fields.body:
Channel 4 faces a furious reaction from British fans after it decided to drop the Tour de France from its schedules after 15 years to concentrate on its coverage of Test cricket.

The move comes in spite of the spate of British cycling medals in the Sydney Olympics and last year's British success in the Tour, where David Millar held the leader's yellow jersey for three days.

"I think there is going to be an enormous backlash against Channel 4," said Caroline Vickery, the managing director of VTV, the company which produces the Tour coverage for Channel 4 and stations in Australia and the United States.

Last July the arrival of cricket on Channel 4 meant the Tour was juggled around the schedules at different times, sometimes late at night, as Test matches over-ran.

"There were hundreds of phone calls a day - and those were just the ones that got through; there were loads of letters and their website was inundated," says Vickery. Viewing figures fell from over 1m to about 700,000.

This year the three-week Tour would clash with the first two Ashes Tests and Channel 4 said yesterday that, in spite of "15 years of proud association with the Tour", it would be "unable to do it justice".

Ironically the broadcaster could be forced to continue paying the European Broadcasting Union for the rights, even though it is not going to show the race.

Channel 4 has a four-year contract, renewed last year, with the EBU, which holds the European rights to the race; unless Channel 4 can sell or license the rights, it will have to pay.

The BBC is not ruling out taking up the coverage - "we'll never say never," said a spokeswoman - although it is unlikely this year. The Tour starts on July 7, the day before Wimbledon finishes, and clashes with golf's Open.

ITV has been approached but has not covered cycling since the early 1980s, while Channel 5 has said it is not interested. The Tour does, however, receive extensive live coverage on Eurosport.

 The Spanish cyclist Ricardo Ochoa died yesterday and his twin brother Xavier, a stage winner last year in the Tour de France at Hautacam, was in a coma after they were hit by a car while training near Malaga.

webTitle: Business: Deadline set for £10 unmetered net

fields.headline: Deadline set for £10 unmetered net
fields.standfirst:
Oftel puts price cap on fee BT can charge for opening exchanges

More net news
fields.trailText: Consumers could be offered unmetered web access for £10 a month after the telecoms regulator ordered BT to cut prices, writes Polly Sprenger.
fields.body:
Consumers could be offered unmetered internet access for as little as £10 a month after the telecoms regulator yesterday ordered BT to open up more of its exchanges - and cut prices - to rivals.

Oftel, the industry watchdog, said BT must offer rival internet companies access to its network of lines as far as regional exchanges for an annual fee from February 26.

That charge will be £507 per year for every 10 customers, a discount on current levels. This means consumers could have unmetered access at £10-£14 per month.

A spokesman for BT said the slightly lowered fixed price should not affect profits, but high demand could overburden its network.

In May, Oftel ordered BT to offer unmetered access on local exchanges but yesterday that was extended to regional exchanges where competing operators are more likely to have a presence.

A spokesman for AOL Europe, one of the largest ISPs in the country, said: "The reason we fought for this for so damn long is now if you want unmetered access you don't have to get it from BT. If all the telecom players can offer [unmetered access] on a regional basis that is great news for consumers."

While internet service providers were quick to applaud the move, telecom operators such as Colt Telecom, Energis and Cable & Wireless, were less sure of the benefits.

"We need to review the details of the offering, specifically the cost structure," an Energis spokesman said. "The details are not very straightforward."

Oftel's ultimatum came the same day BT admitted to falling behind in its schedule of rolling out high-speed internet access to consumers.

The company was supposed to have the service available to 70,000-80,000 consumers by March but executives said yesterday the figure was likely to be closer to 50,000.

The delay comes as the government places increasing pressure on BT to offer services that will encourage the public to spend more time online.

 France Télécom faced more gloomy news yesterday when Moody's Investor Service cut its short- and long-term debt ratings, saying the telecoms group had deviated from its debt reduction plans of a year ago. Meanwhile, US telecoms company AT&T announced it would look to the debt markets next week to raise $4-5bn.

webTitle: Ariel and Persil launch detergent bomb

fields.headline: Bombs away in wash war
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Ariel and Persil are to launch rival versions of a laundry product - the detergent bomb, writes Felicity Lawrence.
fields.body:
A new battle in the "washing war" between Ariel and Persil loomed yesterday when it emerged the two brands are to launch rival versions of a laundry product - the detergent bomb.

Unilever announced that it would be launching Persil liquid soap capsules at the end of April, only to be outflanked by rival Procter & Gamble, which is said to be ready to send out its new Ariel Liqui-Tabs to shops next month.

The capsules are sachets of pre-measured doses of liquid detergent which can be put in the machine and dissolve on contact with water, thus saving the house spouse the bother of working out how much soap to use.

Research suggests that many users, dazed by all the different dosing systems, use more detergent than is necessary.

Pre-measured tablets of soap powder were first launched by Lever in 1998 and have proved popular - tablets now account for just over a quarter of the £1bn laundry detergent market. They also helped the Persil brand win back market leadership.

Laundry is a dull business, and, when the differences between brands are seen as largely cosmetic, competition is fierce.

"As a premium-priced product", liquid capsules "offer good profit opportunities", Procter and Gamble told trade customers.

Unilever and Procter and Gamble are both hoping that liquid capsules will give them an edge, and whoever is first with the innovation is likely to gain a significant advantage.

Persil capsules will get a £163;9m marketing campaign and Ariel Liqui-Tabs will also be supported by a multimillion pound advertising campaign.

webTitle: Back on the market: one slightly soiled dome - £125m

fields.headline: Back on the market: one slightly soiled dome - £125m
fields.standfirst:
BBC bid emerges as frontrunner as Legacy drops out

Special report: the Millennium Dome
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The BBC last night emerged as a potential saviour of the troubled Millennium Dome, report Kevin Maguire, Michael White and Jill Treanor.
fields.byline: Kevin Maguire, Michael White and Jill Treanor
fields.body:
The BBC last night emerged as a potential saviour of the troubled Millennium Dome as the Legacy consortium prepared to withdraw its bid following the government's decision to reopen competition to buy the Greenwich site for a second time.

The corporation's commercial arm, BBC Worldwide, disclosed it is already in talks with a consortium that includes the Duke of Westminster, Britain's richest aristocrat, and which could also involve the group behind Alton Towers and Madam Tussauds.

While prospects of the dome reopening as a visitor attraction soared, Legacy and the Tories rounded on the government and left Tony Blair facing the possibility of going into a May election with the complex still in public hands.

Legacy said it will formally decide what to do during the next few days but a senior adviser said: "We'll pull out, we're gutted."

Robert Bourne, the Labour donor who fronted the bid, complained it had been a "wasted exercise, at great cost to everyone, including the taxpayer".

He added: "Rather than being able to sign a deal with Legacy within the next few weeks, the government has now decided to introduce even more uncertainty into the process. This is not good news for anyone."

Legacy - made "preferred bidder" last November when the Japanese bank Nomura, the original frontrunner, withdrew - saw its plans to build a high-tech "knowledge city" rejected amid concern over its business plan and company structure.

Both sides blamed each other, Legacy claiming it had fulfilled the terms of a draft contract, while the government suggested serious questions remained over the bid.

Government opposition to extending the Valentine's Day deadline was led by the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, despite signs that Tony Blair and the dome minister, Lord Falconer, were prepared to give the controversial consortium more time.

The dome disaster follows the fiasco over the awarding of the contract for the national lottery, in which Richard Branson was led to believe he had won only for Camelot to be picked again.

Downing Street claimed that 70 individuals and firms had expressed an interest in taking over the site and Lord Falconer appeared to confirm that. "We will wrap it up as quickly as we can but we won't be rushed into a decision," said Lord Falconer. "This will not be driven by any sort of electoral terms."

The decision to invite fresh offers opened the door for Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, the dome's former chief executive, to organise his own bid as he floated several options, including separate sales of the dome and surrounding land or a deal that would see him rent the building for 10 or 15 years as an entertainment centre.

Mr Gerbeau, reported to have had a lunch with Lord Falconer cancelled on Wednesday, said: "We have the business plan to run the dome and the creative vision to make it a success. We will now go forward with putting the backers together to rent or buy the dome. Our plan is to combine a world-class visitor attraction with a global entertainment venue. That will keep the dome as a public building and is the best possible outcome."

It is the involvement of the BBC, however, that could be the public link the government needs to turn the disaster round. The corporation has admitted it is interested.

Managers expressed an interest late last year and, along with the Tussaud Group and rock promoter Harvey Goldsmith, have been approached by four property developers.

Discussions are at a preliminary stage but the Duke of Westminster's Grosvenor Estates, Quintain Estates, Lend Lease and Stanhope would build on land around the dome while attracting visitors to the structure itself. A BBC spokeswoman said: "I can confirm that we are in talks with the consortium to discuss possibilities about a visitor attraction based on BBC output."

The dome costs up to £3m a month to maintain and the New Millennium Experience Company, which is responsible for the site, said a four-day auction opening on February 27 would not include equipment needed for a visitor attraction. The home planet ride and Timekeepers softball game, as well as turnstiles, security systems and fixed floodlighting, will be withheld from the sale.

The Tories made their ritual call for Lord Falconer's resignation as the shadow enviroment secretary Archie Norman said ministers should relinquish responsiblity for the sale, leaving it to English Partnerships. He said developers should be allowed to demolish the dome if that would raise proceeds. "This is a woeful story of incompetence and shabby dealing," he added.

fields.headline: 29 new hospitals to be built
fields.trailText: A £3bn NHS hospital building programme announced yesterday will include 26 "fast-track" centres to speed up the treatment of non-urgent patients who often have their appointments cancelled.
fields.body:
A £3bn NHS hospital building programme announced yesterday will include 26 "fast-track" centres to speed up the treatment of non-urgent patients who often have their appointments cancelled.

Health secretary Alan Milburn said 29 building projects, worth £3.1bn, had been approved by his department. There will be an 11% increase in funding for training NHS staff, to alleviate the shortage of doctors, nurses and other professionals.

Every region in the country would be required to increase hospital beds to end the misery of patients being shipped to hospitals miles from home because of bed shortages.

"This is an unprecedented expansion in new hospital developments in the NHS," Mr Milburn told the House of Commons. "For millions of patients and thousands of staff it will provide modern state-of-the-art hospital treatment and care." The Department of Health was preparing to allow 18 schemes, but is approving all 29 recommended by its expert advisers.

The hospital projects will be built under the public finance initiative, with an option for the NHS to resume ownership at the end of the contract.

Work will begin this year on the first 12, in Birmingham, Bradford, Bristol's mental health services, Central Middlesex, East Kent, Leicester, Lewisham, Peterborough, Salford, Tunbridge Wells, Wakefield and Whipps Cross in London.

"You cannot deliver 21st century care in 19th century buildings," Mr Milburn said. "For too long investment in NHS infrastructure has been a low priority when it should have been a high priority.

"The consequences are plain for all to see: buildings that are shoddy, equipment that is unreliable, hospitals that are out of date. In too many places the environment where staff work and patients receive care is simply unacceptable."

Sixteen of the new hospitals will have the fast-track centres, which will treat only patients who need routine operations such as hip replacements. In most hospitals, planned surgery is always at risk of being cancelled to make way for emergencies. Ten other fast-track facilities will be built at existing hospitals.

"Patients will be able to book their admissions at their convenience rather than simply being given an appointment date," said Mr Milburn.

"Some will operate at weekends. Crucially they will mean greater reliability for patients by helping to end the misery of last-minute cancelled operations."

There are serious shortages of doctors and, particularly, nurses in the NHS, but Mr Milburn claimed that numbers have already risen in response to recruitment campaigns and new training places.

Between September 1999 and September 2000, there were 2,500 more doctors, 3,500 more scientists, therapists and technicians and over 6,300 more nurses in the NHS. The new money is intended to keep staff numbers increasing until 2010. The bed-cutting which has been a feature of the NHS for four decades is at an end, Mr Milburn said.

He told the Commons that 157,000 were cut between 1980 and 1997 alone. Every new hospital will have more beds than the one it replaces - 3,000 more in all.

Peter Hawker, chairman of the British Medical Association's consultants committee, said the big rise in beds was "excellent news provided the NHS is successful in recruiting the nurses and doctors required to staff them".

webTitle: Polly Toynbee: We can save the dome

fields.headline: We can save the dome
fields.standfirst:
Imagine a development in total contrast to Canary Wharf, with space dedicated to people not profits

Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Imagine a development in total contrast to Canary Wharf, with space dedicated to people not profits.
fields.body:
Round one - victory! The government has done the right thing and the dome gets another chance. Other bidders - now suddenly many more - can come forward and suggest something better than a disgraceful fire-sale at a knock-down price to property developers. It would have been the final scandal of the dome's history. The panic that seized the government at the end of last year is over. There is time to stop and think, time to consider every option - "as long as it takes," says Lord Falconer - no artificial deadlines. But will it be saved as a public space?

Now the dome is closed, the spate of bad news that hung over it like a thick smog has lifted. Panic was the danger - the same panic that seized governments before. The Festival of Britain of 1951, besieged by many of the same headlines calling it a monstrous waste of public money, was razed to the ground the day it closed to save further public embarrassment. The incoming Conservative government smashed the Skylon to pieces and bulldozed the Dome of Discovery, both icons that would now be loved and revered landmarks.

They couldn't move fast enough to pull down the Crystal Palace after the Great Exhibition of 1851 and remove it to a distant suburb where it later burned to the ground. The moment a great public exhibition closes is the moment when it is least fashionable and least valued. Its value plummets so low people can't even see the value of the land around it. By the time the final deal is done, we will look back on the idea of selling this majestic site for a fraction of its true worth with utter incredulity.

Talking to top London property dealers yesterday, they said there had been a phenomenal conspiracy of silence among the five big property companies who stood by and looked on as Legacy seemed about to be given it almost as a gift. "We could not believe it," said one leading estate agent.

Why the silence? Well, it was government business and no one wanted to make trouble, with future contracts in mind. But consider this, said one. Canary Wharf is just 40 seconds' travel time from the dome peninsula. Last November the Canary Wharf Group plc acquired a new 6.3-acre tract of land for development in North Canary Wharf called Shed 35. It cost them £53m. That is the same sum Legacy was proposing to put down on 63 similar acres, with just another £75m to follow later. "The site value has soared in the past 20 months since bids were first invited. Now there is a tube and infrastructure, it's a different game." He reckons a full and fair global competition will bring in a sizeable fortune for the site - and still leave plenty of room for publicly owned space.

Now for round two. This spectacular peninsula is the most beautiful piece of undeveloped urban landscape in the capital, surrounded by the Thames on three sides, under a great wide sky with breathtaking views in all directions. Reached by boat and by one of London's most architecturally exciting new tube stations, this is a dream public space, a park, a treasure. Once sold off and built over, it will be gone for ever, unreclaimable for the public.

Richard Rogers, architect of this mighty white structure, is one of those who has been fighting hard behind the scenes to keep it as a publicly owned place for ever. If the Skylon, the Dome of Discovery and the Crystal Palace still stood, how extraordinary it would seem now ever to sell them off. If some of the dome land is now sold well, the dome and its park can remain a public place, with no need to sell it, though it might be rented.

The day will come - probably soon - when some Olympic or other sporting or cultural event will need the dome in a capital bereft of wonderful sites. The failure of Wembley Stadium plans is just another example of how badly Britain does great national monuments. But now we have a chance to get this right.

The last great dome crisis forced the Millennium Commission angrily to fork out a final £47m last October. But this sum was never actually drawn down. In its last three months, according to one millennium commissioner, increased numbers of visitors meant the dome broke even and never used those final funds that caused such volcanic public fury. The money is there, already given to the dome, and it should be used to help ensure the dome remains a public space. But the real endowment comes from the land around it, sold to create a trust for it in perpetuity.

Richard Rogers has an ambitious vision for the place and is likely to join better developers to propose a scheme for the North Greenwich peninsula that would be a model for the kind of regeneration his Urban Task Force advocates. It would include at least 40% affordable housing for the local community: he has been talking with Peabody and Rowntree about social housing possibilities.

It would be a high density cityscape with shops and offices as well as homes, looking on to a leisure park around the dome that would be a national attraction for sports and concerts - run by PY or the BBC/Tussauds group, or any other entertainment consortium. He talks of things built in Barcelona and Amsterdam, and London's terrible past mistakes.

Last time I wrote about the dome, a fair number of emails from around the country complained bitterly at any more public time, money or attention being thrown at this London site. They have a point. It would have been better had the dome been built elsewhere. But there it is now in Greenwich, a national treasure on a site of natural beauty. Huge sums have been wasted, but that is no reason to waste the only good that can come from it.

Rogers points across the water to Canary Wharf, the great emblem of the Thatcher era - all offices, stylish restaurants and expensive houses, a pure property developers' hygienic, anodyne heaven straight from the brochure. It is an eerie place - no children, schools or old people, no workers, beggars, misfits, everything crisp and pricey for its cloned battalions of young professionals, with none of the eccentric, random oddity that breathes real city life. Now imagine across the water a Labour era development in complete social contrast, a regeneration project as a model for other city schemes.

The question is: does this mark new thinking by Labour? In the early days, how avidly they sought to show they were as friendly to private developers as any conservative government. The tube is the next big question, as bargaining continues ferociously behind the scenes.

Gordon Brown, jaw set, says the risk of major construction programmes must all be borne by private companies, despite passionate public opinion in favour of keeping it publicly owned. He ploughs on with the sale of air traffic control too, against the public will. But somewhere in the heart of government, the dome decision may herald the start of a welcome change of attitude for the second term.

fields.headline: Runners and riders waiting for the race to begin
fields.trailText: Government officials yesterday boasted that there were scores of individuals and companies interested in buying the dome after the race was reopened.
fields.body:
Government officials yesterday boasted that there were scores of individuals and companies interested in buying the dome after the race was reopened.

The runners and riders face Whitehall and public scrutiny as the government, which has bungled the sale twice, realises it must be third time lucky.

Possible bidders include some big names - and the creation of some new alliances is on the cards.

Pierre-Yves Gerbeau

The dome's former chief executive is talking up grand plans to run it as a visitor attraction during the day, with virtual reality technology rather than big dippers to woo trippers, and a 50,000-seat sporting and entertainment venue at night.

The Frenchman is backed by James Palumbo, boss of the London nightclub group Ministry of Sound.

He has spoken of reuniting the Beatles, inviting Madonna and Michael Jackson and staging a Lennox Lewis world championship fight; but serious questions remain over whether he will get financial backing. He has said he might have to rent, rather than buy, the structure.

The Duke of Westminster

Britain's richest peer is considering a return to the fray with his own consortium after rejecting overtures from Legacy. The group has cont-acted the BBC, Tussauds and Harvey Goldsmith. The bil lionaire duke's privately-owned Grosvenor Estates is in a consortium with three other property developers: Stanhope, Lend Lease and Quintain Estates, which already owns land next to the Greenwich site.

If it did a deal with the BBC, Tussauds or Harvey Goldsmith, the dome could be a public attraction surrounded by homes, offices and shops.

Guy Hands

Best man at William Hague's wedding and head of Nom-ura's Principal Finance Group which specialises in buying unfashionable businesses at bargain prices. Nomura has already bought service quarters from the Ministry of Defence and owns 6,000 pubs.

The preferred bidder until it dropped out last September, Nomura must decide if it is worth another go, and could yet finance a bid.

Nomura's original plan was Dome Europe, a visitor attraction featuring fashion, innovations, food, traditions and arts. PY Gerbeau suggested earlier this week he had support from the Japanese bank. Nomura said not so and may be reluctant to bid again.

BBC

Wanted to transform the dome into a virtual reality theme park, possibly including working models of the Walking with Dinosaurs variety. Could provide a useful public sector link for a wider bid. Interested in the dome, not the surroundings.

Tussauds Group

The owner of the world famous waxworks museum and Alton Towers proposes a mixed business and leisure centre including a theme park focusing on the latest technology.

Harvey Goldsmith

Veteran pop promoter who has expressed an interest in putting on concerts in the giant indoor arena.

Galliard Homes

The housebuilder is one of a number of developers that formed consortiums to make a bid if Legacy failed.

Proposing high-rise flats on the site, Galliard is said to be more interested in the land than the dome.

fields.standfirst:
'Heavyweight hopefuls' on sidelines but no one ready to jump in

fields.trailText: If the loss of the first dome bidder could be explained away by ministers as a tragedy, the rejection of a second has turned the process into a farce.
fields.byline: Kevin Maguire, Michael White  and Jill Treanor
fields.body:
If the loss of the first dome bidder could be explained away by ministers as a tragedy, the rejection of a second has turned the process into a farce.

Legacy chairman Richard Bourne, a millionaire Labour donor fond of throwing parties for the glitterati of the people's party, was sitting in his Chelsea office yesterday when the phone rang at 12.27pm.

John Walker, head of English Partnerships, the government agency advising ministers on the sale of the building and land, told him during an awkward 90-second conversation that an official statement would be made at 12.30pm.

Mr Walker should not have bothered. Sitting on Mr Bourne's desk was a copy of the statement, obtained via an unofficial route.

Once pencilled in as the first paragraph of Mr Blair's manifesto, the Greenwich white elephant now threatens to be an election liability as William Hague cites the failure to sell it as evidence of government incompetence.

As Legacy prepared to pull out and potential bidders - ranging from the BBC and Pierre-Yves Gerbeau to the Duke of Westminster and countless property developers - considered stepping in, the government and Legacy were left to reflect on how it had gone so badly wrong.

In the blame game the government accused Legacy, fronted by Mr Bourne and dominated by the controversial Irish group Treasury Holdings, of failing to put together a viable business plan or company structure.

Deputy prime minister John Prescott, who has been leading the sale process, believes the dome should remain in public hands and is against Legacy's proposals. He is said to have sided against Tony Blair and the dome minister, Lord Falconer, who wanted to give Legacy more time.

Mr Prescott is thought to want a project to be put together by English Partnerships which would allow the government to retain some ownership over the dome's future.

"There does appear to be an opinion forming that the dome should stay in the public sector," one source said last night.

Ministers have complained that they were repeatedly required to advise Legacy over four months of negotiations after it was anointed "preferred bidder" in November - two months after the Japanese bank Nomura, the original favourite, had pulled out.

The £125m price was to be paid in instalments, with £50m up front and the rest over three years.

English Partnerships and the government were worried that Legacy was planning to delay investing £150m to transform the site into knowledge city, an indoor town of hi-tech firms, and questioned whether firms mentioned by Legacy would rent space.

And the consortium's structure, 15% owned by Mr Bourne, 80% by Treasury Holdings and 5% by the Bank of Scotland, did not foster confidence in Whitehall.

Treasury's owners, Richard Barrett and John Ronan, have been embroiled in political and business controversies on the other side of the Irish sea, and ministers urged Legacy to seek new partners to widen its share base and experience.

Legacy maintained that it did everything the government asked and pinned the blame on ministers. "Quite frankly we could have exchanged contracts in three weeks. Only the government knows why it has done this," said a Legacy source.

Mr Bourne thought he had played his joker on Monday when he introduced Lord Falconer to his new backers, executives of the Teesland Group property development body. Teesland, lined up for a 10% stake, had worked closely with English Partnerships but it was too late, according to government sources, who indicated that ministers thought "the game was up" in the middle of last week.

Legacy had the champagne on ice and remained confident until Wednesday night, but abortive talks at the weekend with the Duke of Westminster's consortium added to the perception of a consortium going nowhere.

The normally ebullient Mr Bourne said he was "surprised and disappointed" as he prepared to throw in the towel and one colleague raised the possibility of suing the government to recover the £8m cost of the bid.

Downing Street is struggling to put a brave face on the latest dome disaster.

No 10 talked up the prospect of a fresh surge of interest from "70 groups and individuals" even as it stressed Mr Blair's insistence that the dome cannot be pulled down for at least 15 years.

Though Whitehall will not admit it, this may prove the crucial stumbling block - with some estimates that the cleared site would be worth at least three times the £125m offered by Legacy.

Only two specific alternatives were cited by Downing Street - a possible renewed interest from Nomura in tandem with PY Gerbeau and a formidable consortium which includes the BBC, Madame Tussauds, Harvey Goldsmith, Grosvenor Estates (the Duke of Westminster's company), and the property firms of Quintain, Stanhope and Lend Lease.

They were called "heavyweight proposals" but no indication was given that any bid was a frontrunner.

There was evident dismay that Legacy had failed to "move to closure" and match its promises during its threemonth negotations as preferred bidder - but no admission either that Lord Falconer and his five-man ministerial team had overrated the Dublin-dominated consortium's capacity.

Officials refused to be drawn on why the Legacy bid failed, but it was clear that the viability of its proposals rather than its cash offer was the vital factor.

At Legacy, the team tried to make a joke of the disaster. "We've opened a book on how long the government can hang on to the dome without selling it," quipped an adviser.
