webTitle: Leader: Any more for the dome?

fields.headline: Any more for the dome?
fields.standfirst:
Suddenly, the contest is wide open again

Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Psst: want to buy a used dome? Sought after position; only one previous user ...
fields.body:
Psst: want to buy a used dome? Sought after position; only one previous user ... Yesterday's government advice to English Partnerships, which owns the place, makes Legacy, preferred bidder until St Valentine's Day, no more than one in a list of contenders which will certainly include P-Y Gerbeau; might include Nomura (the first preferred bidder, which then pulled out, but could pull back in again) the BBC and the Duke of Westminster; and could even, who knows, be augmented by Madame Tussaud's, Raymond Gubbay, Madonna, Chris Evans ... It amounts to a king-size millennium fiasco, with echoes of that which first put Camelot out of the lottery race in favour of Richard Branson and then put it back again. But then, the miscalculations could be blamed on a quango. Here, the politicians, who dreamed up the place without knowing what they wanted to use it for and have got things consistently wrong ever since, are firmly in the frame.

While manoeuvres continue, there are two solid principles on which the final decision ought to be based. First, unless the portents are even more dire than they seem at present, the structure has to be saved. The place feels disconsolate now, with processions of buses arriving and leaving empty, the occasional roller skater, a clutch of avid photographers taking their chance while it's still there. The vast and splendid station is near-deserted. But see it from across the river in the February sun and the prospect of its destruction seems like the kind of vandalism which should have died with the 70s. Next, it ought to be inclusive, not exclusive: a place for the people, not reserved, as it would be with Legacy, for the workforce of Knowledge City.

The most enticing solution so far is that put forward by the exuberant Mr Gerbeau, the nearest thing the project has had so far to a hero. But his huge entrepreneurial charm must not spare him from searching and painful questions. He would hope to stage entertainments featuring Madonna and Michael Jackson; but would they be there again in year two? How often could he stage as certain a sell-out as a Lennox Lewis prize fight? Mr Gerbeau has argued so far that he could not put forward hard and fast plans while Legacy had preferred bidder status. Now he needs to move fast and persuasively, with the firm endorsement of figures of proven financial acumen and resources, to demonstrate that his dream is more than a dream.

fields.headline: British Library seeks marketing head
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The institution is to appoint its first dedicated marketing chief in a bid to modernise its image, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
The British Library is to appoint its first dedicated marketing chief as the institution gears up to modernise its image.

The new director will develop a marketing strategy that is likely to include the creation of a new brand for the library and its first ever corporate advertising.

Lynne Brindley was appointed chief executive of the UK national library a year ago.

She has now started to restructure the top layer of management and has created the new role of director of strategic marketing and communications.

The new recruit will oversee 100 staff, consolidating the various existing marketing and communications departments - including press and PR.

There are 70 marketers in Yorkshire, who work on the library's multi-million-pound document supply business.

The remaining staff are based in the library's London headquarters in St Pancras.

"The library is gearing up to provide a lead in the new information-rich world and increase access to our collections," said a British Library spokesman.

"This is a complete refocus of our business.

"Building the brand and advertising will be on the agenda - we will look at all the options available.

"We need to find new ways of communicating our products and services to all our customers - users, stakeholders, the public and the media," he said.

The internet will play a major part in the new vision for the library.

The institution recently signed a deal with IBM, which will provide the infrastructure to support electronic collections.

The aim is to make the British Library accessible on everyone's virtual bookshelf.

The management team is also seeking a director of e-strategy and programmes, who will develop the library's internet projects and services.

webTitle: Intel unveils global campaign for Pentium 4

fields.headline: Intel unveils global campaign for Pentium 4
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Intel is set to launch a global advertising drive to promote its Pentium 4 microprocessor. By Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
Computer-chip giant Intel is to launch a global ad campaign to promote its Pentium 4 microprocessor and revive flagging PC sales.

The campaign will be at least as big as last year's £207m drive to launch the Pentium 3.

Once again it will feature the offbeat US theatre troupe the Blue Man Group.

The campaign will break next week in the US and on March 1 in the UK.

It will also be shown across Europe and the Asia/Pacific region

TV commercials, produced by Euro RSCG's New York office, will show the blue-faced characters interacting with a huge number 4.

Three 30-second TV executions are entitled "tubes", "lightbulbs" and "raising four".

The strapline will be: "The Pentium 4 processor: the centre of your world."

The adverts will emphasise the improved music, video and internet capabilities of PCs that incorporate the new processor.

UK work will be co-ordinated by London-based Euro RSCG Wnek Gosper.

Euro RSCG will produce additional TV work and develop a campaign comprising radio, in-store and internet advertising.

The aim of Intel's latest campaign is to convince consumers to trade up their PCs for Pentium 4 models.

It will be a tough task in a maturing market, where modern PCs are already sufficiently powerful for most home users.

The global PC market grew only 9.2% year on year in the fourth quarter of 2000.

The US market grew only 0.3%.

webTitle: Business: Davies accuses Equitable of obstruction

fields.headline: Davies accuses Equitable of obstruction
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Sir Howard Davies, chairman of the financial services authority, yesterday attacked Equitable Life for obstructing his organisation's calls more than two years ago for the insurer to increase its cash reserves.
fields.body:
Sir Howard Davies, chairman of the financial services authority, yesterday attacked Equitable Life for obstructing his organisation's calls more than two years ago for the insurer to increase its cash reserves.

At a Commons Treasury select committee inquiry, Mr Davies said Equitable initially rejected the FSA's attempts to force it to increase reserves ahead of a court case demanding the insurer pay up on promises made to some policyholders. Equitable "threatened" to seek a judicial review, alleging the FSA was "imposing" its view.

Eventually the two sides came to an agreement and Equitable took out £800m of reinsurance against its liabilities. In July last year the insurer was landed with a £1.5bn bill after the law lords ruled its approach to 90,000 customers with guaranteed annuities was illegal and it must honour these guarantees.

Sir Howard said the FSA was investigating allegations of mis-selling of Equitable Life policies last year and carrying out a review to see whether there were investors who should be compensated. webTitle: Join euro or lose out, Prodi tells UK

fields.headline: Join euro or lose out, Prodi tells UK
fields.standfirst: Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Britain stands to lose more of its influence and national sovereignty by staying outside the eurozone than it will by joining the European single currency, the president of the Brussels commission, Romano Prodi, predicted yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain stands to lose more of its influence and national sovereignty by staying outside the eurozone than it will by joining the European single currency, the president of the Brussels commission, Romano Prodi, predicted yesterday.

In doing so he implicitly rejected the conviction of Tony Blair and Gordon Brown that the 12 eurozone nations cannot conduct day-to-day management of the currency without reference to the group of the 15 European Union finance ministers.

"In practice, if you don't fully participate in the family, your voice will be less heard. To be different makes you less important in the total decision-making process," he told the Guardian in an interview.

Mr Prodi, a former prime minister of Italy, echoed this theme in a speech in London yesterday: "How can you control your economy being surrounded by the euro and not having your man inside the European central bank?"

He argued that a potential loss of sovereignty should be "judged in practical terms". These are the arguments that Labour will deploy in any referendum.

"The euro will go well and it is convenient for you to get into. But you must decide," he said. It was a point he emphasised on his flying visit to London, during which he breakfasted with the prime minister at No 10.

The Tories declared that he had "exposed the defeatist agenda of Tony Blair and Gordon Brown". The shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude, said: "Like Mr Prodi, Labour believe that Britain has no future as an independent state."

Mr Prodi pleaded with Britain's famously Eurosceptic media to "talk about facts, not about theory" when deciding whether to go in or stay out.

Undeterred by the euro's weak performance since its launch in 1999, Mr Prodi predicted that the eurozone would quickly spread to eastern Europe and north Africa: "Even here [in Britain] it will become a very popular currency."

Mr Prodi also sidestepped the political pitfalls in the House of Commons. When asked about sensitive EU tax matters he replied: "Tax is like sex, you cannot talk about it."

fields.headline: 'If you stay out, don't pretend to be in'
fields.standfirst:
In an exclusive interview, Romano Prodi says Britain can't have it both ways on the euro

Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: In an exclusive interview, Romano Prodi says Britain can't have it both ways on the euro.
fields.body:
If Britain is still prevaricating over the euro in 2004, it will lose decisive influence over the political shaping of the European Union which is due to conclude at a special summit meeting that year. That is the judgment of Romano Prodi, president of the European commission, who told me yesterday: "In theory, it might not be so. But in practice, if you don't fully participate in the family, your voice will be less heard. To be different makes you less important in the total decision-making process."

Mr Prodi counselled against Britain trying any longer to influence the management of the euro. "If you stay out, that's your choice," he said, "but you can't then pretend to be in." It was already awkward for the UK to be excluded from the room, as a non-member of the euro-12, the committee that runs the currency. This was bound to have knock-on effects as the political agenda developed. While Mr Prodi would clearly like Britain to be a central player in all EU projects, his bleak assessment takes its place in what he regards as his respect for objective facts - rather than the visionary unrealism with which he is sometimes charged.

Tainted as a woolly federalist, he insists on the primacy of fact. "I am completely empirical," he said. As a former prime minister of Italy, he knows all about the need to impress people with facts, or fail to win their votes. Had Britain, he enquired, ceased to be empirical? The problem mystified him, as he looked at this country's European debates. "Have you lost your tradition? I always consider Britain the most empirical country in the world. Look at the facts, you always say. But now you seem to have become theological. It is strange to see Germany and Italy as empirical nations, and the UK as a theological nation."

Misplaced theological obsession, he considers, contributed to the British attitude to him, the commission and the proposals they jointly made about almost anything. For example, in the build-up to last year's Nice summit, he had made some rational proposals to deal with double taxation and tax fraud, which any sensible person would welcome. But Britain regarded anything to do with tax as untouchable. "I couldn't get any discussion of the subject, in any part of British society."

Although by temperament mild and scholarly, Mr Prodi also became exercised on the subject of his own lack of democratic credentials, a point made with increasing scorn by British ministers, notably Gordon Brown, when the commission challenges any of their decisions. Mr Prodi gets his credentials, he insists, through these very ministers.

"Tell them they appointed me," he said. "I've been appointed by democratic leaders. I've been approved four times by the European parliament, twice by the old one and twice by the new. I report to it every month. Who else has been put in front of so many democratic tests? So if they call me a bureaucrat, I don't know what they are. Let them tell me one reason why I should be called a bureaucrat while they are democrats."

Nor does he accept the conventional wisdom, stretching further than Britain, that the European parliament supplies an inadequate basis for democratic accountability. "The parliament may get only half of Europe's voters out, but the American president is voted for by only half America as well."

Besides, it is all a very slow process. The main difference between a conversation with Mr Prodi and paying daily attention to the British domestic argument is one of tone and perspective. For him, the integration of Europe is something that calls for patience, not only as regards enlargement, which is perhaps his strongest dream, but even for the existing members.

His talk is littered with references to historic time. "Democracy needs not years but decades to express itself," he said. It had taken five years to organise for the euro, and there were more to go to complete the single market. There wasn't yet a single market for services, nor for patents, a subject which, along with scientific research, is a particular focus of Mr Prodi's integrating ambitions. "We shall take decades to construct a common area with common rules. But there is no doubt it will be in the service of the people."

Selected areas of further integration are, in short, inevitable. They are the only empirical response to the facts of the modern world, he said. By which he means, at bottom, the danger of American hegemony brought about by economic globalisation. "The only way to express ourselves in the new world," he said, "is by being together. I don't like to be a colony. If we do not get together, we will disappear from world history."

The model he takes is from his native Italy. In the 15th century, Italy dominated the world. "Optical science, military science, therefore military strength, banking, finance. But then we split into mini-states. Italy disappeared from the geographical map. We couldn't cope with the discovery of America, and the new means of transport, the big ship." This was the historic fate Europe would be in danger of emulating if, while recognising the length of time the process would take, it did not cleave to an integrationist purpose.

After a rocky first year, Mr Prodi is gaining confidence. Arguably, this reached a peak with his willingness to beard the British parliamentary lobby journalists at their own trough yesterday. He now prides himself on launching the 2004 constitutional argument months before Joschka Fischer, the German foreign minister, and is beginning to find his speeches reported more seriously.

He is also prepared to do battle for his much reviled commission. That struggle is in the balance. The Brussels reforms which Neil Kinnock is seeking to push through are coming up against a combination of trade union and national job-protectionism. To Mr Prodi, there's an adamantine clarity about the commission's own historic importance, which seems to cause him less intellectual or emotional doubt than the scathing verdicts heard in London and Paris might indicate. "To destroy the commission is to destroy Europe," he said. "How many times have people tried to fight against history and lost?" He sees what he terms "the failure of Nice" - the December EU summit that made minimal progress towards further integration - as vindicating his vision of the facts.

But the British problem remains. Last time he was here, he left for Milan, only to be accosted at the airport with a demand for his ID card, a document now just about redundant within the continental EU. The president protested. "But you have travelled from London," said the Italian immigration officer. To or from London, passports must be produced.

Suddenly Mr Prodi felt the full impact of British exceptionalism. Like the currency, open borders could not be rejected without a price. "To be different in such basic facts," he told me rather sadly, "just makes you less important in the exercise of power. I don't like it. But it's your decision."

fields.headline: Feelgood factor fuels retail boom
fields.standfirst: Shopping site
fields.trailText: The strength of the "feelgood factor" among Britain's consumers prompted a sharp rise in sales in high street shops last month, according to official figures released yesterday.
fields.body:
The strength of the "feelgood factor" among Britain's consumers prompted a sharp rise in sales in high street shops last month, according to official figures released yesterday.

Despite industry fears of poor sales in the key trading months of December and January, data from the office for national statistics showed buoyant activity.

Sales in January were up 0.7% over the month, while sales over the critical December period were revised up from 0.1% to 0.5%, according to the office for national statistics.

"Consumers are not just feeling better: they are spending more as well," said Michael Saunders from Schroder Salomon SmithBarney.

Evidence of robust consumer spending could dissuade the Bank of England from a quick repeat of this month's cut to borrowing costs, City analysts said. "We still believe [interest] rates will be cut again but this data is not conducive to a March move," said Ciaran Barr, UK economist at Deutsche Bank.

The Bank is expecting household spending to slow to allow room for the government's boost to public spending, but so far there are few signs that recessionary fears are forcing households to tighten their belts. The three month on three month rate of sales growth, which irons out monthly distortions, remained at 1.3% in January, a healthy rate of expansion.

"We doubt such a slowdown in consumer spending will happen," Mr Saunders said. Wages were rising and job growth remained strong. "Consumer confidence is high," he added.

Clothing and footwear sales had enjoyed particularly robust growth in January, rising 5.6% on the month, while non-store retailing, which includes mail order, repairs and internet-only selling, surged 7.4%. But household goods sales were poor, falling 2.5% over the month.

Some economists are concerned that the trend of falling prices that has helped keep inflation under control could be coming to an end.

fields.headline: £28m two-book deal lures Crichton to HarperCollins
fields.standfirst: US writer signs £28m deal
fields.trailText: The author Michael Crichton has left his publisher after 32 years in favour of a £28m two-book deal with HarperCollins, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
The author Michael Crichton has left his publisher after 32 years in favour of a £28m two-book deal with HarperCollins, it emerged yesterday.

The writer and film director began his lucrative relationship with publisher Alfred A Knopf in 1969 with The Andromeda Strain, the first of 12 bestsellers which turned him into the publisher's most commercially successful author.

HarperCollins, a part of NewsCorp, is understood to have acquired the world English rights to publish Crichton's next two thrillers, with the first book due next year.

His latest book, Timeline, sold more than 1.5m hardback copies in the United States and remains a bestseller in paperback. Considered to be one of the highest earning authors in the world, Crichton also receives additional income from film and television projects.

Ten of his books have been translated to the big screen including the blockbuster Jurassic Park, one of the highest grossing films in history.

Commenting on his decision, the author, 58, said: "I felt that in a relationship of such duration you can take the publisher for granted and the publisher can take you for granted. I was concerned that in my way of working I wasn't being as sharp. I don't want to get complacent."

Crichton's agent, Lynn Nesbit, said she favoured HarperCollins in part because, over the last three years, it had consolidated hardback and mass-market paperback publishing under the direction of a single executive, Jane Friedman. That consolidation would ease coordination of both formats for Crichton's books, she said.

The deal was described as a "reunion" by Ms Friedman, 55, who, as an aspiring publicist at Knopf in 1969, landed the promotion of The Andromeda Strain as one of her first assignments.

With a medical degree and two books to his credit, Crichton was then an accomplished and intimidating figure, Ms Friedman said. They became friends and continued to work together until she left Knopf in 1998 to become chief executive at HarperCollins.

"We are absolutely thrilled," she said. "Everybody here is raring to go to do whatever we can to publish his next books in the way they should be published."

Knopf spokesman William Loverd said the company regretted the loss of one of its stars. "All we can say is that we made a very aggressive offer and greatly regretted that we couldn't come to terms," he said. "We are very proud of the way we developed Michael Crichton into one of the world's leading brand-name authors."

fields.headline: Blinded by limelight
fields.standfirst: Esther Rantzen's book reveals intimate details of her husband's last days. It's more than we need to know
fields.trailText: Confession is a human need and an ancient discipline. Early Christians tried group confession. But since lying, clamming up, or hamming it up with attitude was the result, they went one-to-one instead. Now the old confessional box is empty but its literary power lives on giving form to experience as writer speaks to reader.
fields.body:
Confession is a human need and an ancient discipline. Early Christians tried group confession. But since lying, clamming up, or hamming it up with attitude was the result, they went one-to-one instead. Now the old confessional box is empty but its literary power lives on giving form to experience as writer speaks to reader.

Augustine grieved over the death of a pupil: "I was his second self and now lived with only half a soul." The loves of his Confessions changed the western landscape. They invented the idea of the private, the power of the introspective, something deep which also becomes something understood when it's told to others.

The literary-confessional, expressed in art, spoke to the many. It was Goethe in bed beating out the metres of his verse on his mistress's naked back. It was the Persian Sufi worshipping the ecstatic universal love embodied in human form. It was Robert Graves and his White Goddess.

What it wasn't, though, was today's confessional - that debased, sickly form placed in the service of ambition and ego. It certainly isn't Esther Rantzen.

The book of Esther (available with a dreaded inevitability from that friend of the stars, BBC Publications) is being serialised by the Mail on Sunday. No cliché is unexplored. Nerve endings are hopefully prodded. All human shallowness is here. The centre-piece is that central drama of our time: "The Last Days of Des".

Thrill to the tale of Esther, photographed by Des, as she dances naked yet glorious on the grass. Wonder at the chance that brought TV gardening's mammalial glory - Charlie Dimmock ("now the toast of the nation") - to the Wilcox garden. Learn how Des "would grunt contentedly" when Ether told him "How admired you are for your talent".

And in the final moments of this Diary of A Somebody, behold Des taking off the oxygen mask and observing: "There is a bright white light." Perhaps Des's camera crew were in place to get some extra footage of suffering. (The nurse thought it was just the light bulb.)

Then pause and consider the other oxygen mask - that which provides publicity for a self-advertised "60-year-old woman, working in a highly competitive medium where youth is prized above all". Well - that's life.

Or, at least, it's media-class life. The one where the pri vate is killed and the self, on or off the shelf, is shallow and so easily available. Here is a life lived but barely examined because there really is nothing left to look at.

The death of stoicism is a good thing. In Britain it's now as defunct as clipped accents, Lyons Corner Houses and the music of Arthur Bliss. But the unzipped psyche has its own oppressive tedium to offer in its place.

It is abnormal to write about a dead husband in this way and to strip him of so much privacy. The degradation seems to me only understandable as an episode in the service of a career.

It comes over as a loveless and manipulative act - though one perhaps that has its own savage logic as the tombstone is placed on a career which involved such apparently adroit televisual use of so much suffering over so many years. But this terrible shallowness in communicating the self is something new and 21st century. It is part of the world we all live in now. It is the corruption of love and the death of the heart.

M edia class is different - they do things differently there. Thousands bought John Bailey's books describing his wife's destruction by Alzheimer's disease. But in all the clamour of acclaim it seemed that few stopped to wonder what it felt like to be Iris Murdoch - fodder in the service of a minor novelist's career as he geared up for late literary celebrity.

"Private faces in public places," thought Auden, "Are wiser and nicer/Than public faces in private places." But in celeb-land the private face is dissolved behind a mask which has only a limited number of fixed expressions. This is the land of antic hollowness where real self-hood has gone and all is smoothed down, glossed over, rendered platitudinous.

Anne Atkins grinds its crass certitudes on Today and it's there in John Peel's sinister faux-domesticity which always threatens to turn into something very nasty indeed. It's sold in The Erotic (not) Review - that monument to middle-aged public schoolboy prurience through which emotional falsity runs like a coarse thread in a bit of Harris tweed.

But since lying, clamming up, or hamming it up with attitude was the result, they went one-to-one instead. fields.headline: Bard fares badly on royalties front
fields.standfirst: Catherine Cookson heads library league
fields.trailText: Shakespeare would have felt more than a touch of "the whips and scorns of time" if he had been around to collect his royalty cheque from public libraries yesterday.
fields.body:
Shakespeare would have felt more than a touch of "the whips and scorns of time" if he had been around to collect his royalty cheque from public libraries yesterday.

After 450 years of fame and despite the backing of a mammoth school textbook industry, the Bard was trumped by the creators of Squirrel Nutkin, Winnie the Pooh, Goosebumps, hobbits, and that tight-trousered Mr D'Arcy.

Shakespeare's payout under the public lending right, computed by the number of his titles borrowed from libraries, would have been £3,535 - barely enough to throw a good party at his restored Globe theatre in London.

This means that just over 500,000 copies of his work are officially estimated to have been borrowed last year.

His royalty is a humiliating £25 less than Jane Austen's and is dwarfed by the £5,229 that would have arrived on Beatrix Potter's doorstep this week and the £6,000 which would have gone to AA Milne.

Milne qualified for the maximum payment, for authors reckoned to have clocked up 1m or more library loans for the year, under the Public Lending Act.

The lending rights office, in Stockton-on-Tees, carried out the calculations to celebrate a recent government promise of an extra £2m funding next year. It stressed how vital the yearly royalty cheque was for the 75% of living British writers who earn less than half the £20,000 national average wage.

Shakespeare came seventh in the hypothetical top 20 of cheques for dead classic authors. He was also beaten by Daphne Du Maurier, JRR Tolkien and Charles Dickens. But he would have had the satisfaction of trouncing Ernest Hemingway, EM Forster and the Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, the creator of Sherlock Holmes.

Among living authors, real-life top cheques of £6,000 went to a serried list of 12 children's, romantic, thriller and adventure writers with over 1m borrowings.

The late Catherine Cookson again headed the list; and her title The Solace of Sin, one of a store of books published after her death, was the year's most-borrowed fiction book. One reviewer wrote that it "covers topics such as forbidden passions, family secrets and conflict".

The US children's author RL Stine, who specialises in safe horror stories, came second to Cookson and is now a fixture in the list. Otherwise the top 12 is full of familiar faces, including Danielle Steel, Josephine Cox, Dick Francis and Agatha Christie. Enid Blyton, the creator of Noddy and Big Ears, who died 33 years ago, continues to hang on as 12th favourite.

Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone was the most borrowed children's fiction title. But JK Rowling was not among the top 20 children's authors, lending weight to the theory that readers prefer to buy rather than borrow her astronomical bestsellers.

Bill Bryson's Notes from a Big Country beat three Delia Smith cookbooks and a driving test manual as the most popular non-fiction title.

fields.headline: The moronic inferno
fields.standfirst: The insidious march of unattributed sources and junket journalism
fields.trailText: The insidious march of unattributed sources and junket journalism
fields.body:
When Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman announced their divorce last week, the media reaction was instant, carnivorous, frenzied - and horribly predictable. Old, unfounded rumours and sneery double-entendres about the couple's sexual functionality, or alleged lack thereof, were endlessly warmed over and rehashed by empty-handed entertainment editors. Catty speculation ran rife about the exact nature of their nuptial arrangements, and their supposed pertinence to Kidman's green-card status. Cruise and Kidman's links to the Church of Scientology were again subjected to minute scrutiny. All of it was old hat. None of it was really news. And most of it was infected by the Aids virus of modern entertainment journalism: the unattributed source.

All journalists had to work with was a one-page press release that said, in bald summary: "Divorce. Scheduling Pressures. Amicable. Great Pity." From that single press release, based on those meagre crumbs of information, was born that great maelstrom of rubbishy coverage.

The Cruises were merely practising the kind of news management pioneered by the Reagan administration in the early 1980s. The principles are simple: control the flow of information; say nothing; never apologise, never explain; if the coverage you receive is unfavourable, cut off the offending journalists or media outlets from "access".

Two things will arise naturally from this policy. The first is a Gadarene rush of arse- kissing journalists into your camp - newsmen need news, even if it's managed, massaged news. The second is an equally unhealthy exodus of those sceptics and doubters who keep things at least partially honest. The end result is the kind of sterile, artificial news coverage we've become accustomed to in the last decade, heavily prone to spin-doctoring and outright mendacity, cravenly admiring of its subjects, and based on cozily corrupt relationships between news-makers.

As in politics, so too in Tinseltown. Reagan ran a "Hollywood presidency" and deployed news-management techniques honed in California state politics during his stint as governor. Hollywood happily adopted them wholesale. I've borne the brunt of these practices, particularly in the months on the junket circuit a few years ago. Junkets are studio-backed affairs in which journalists are flown in en masse and housed, fed and watered in LA hotels that cater to the junket trade.

They will be shepherded from one suite to another, meeting stars and directors for 15-minute blocks of time. You will be the only reporter from your "market". Thus I was surrounded by Danes, Italians and Scandinavians, many of whom were practising the approved form of entertainment journalism that requires no combative instincts and almost demands cinematic illiteracy. The gently lobbed questions rarely rose above the level of "What was it like working with a great star like him/her?" The answers were delivered in the lingua franca of Hollywood bullshit: "What an amazing, magnificent, talented, generous, humanitarian artist" (rough translation - "I'd gas myself before working with that arsehole again"). I tried some mild rough stuff a few times - and was rewarded with pissed-off household names glaring at me, followed shortly thereafter by spittle-flecked bollockings from pink-faced publicists.

When I was removed from a perfectly amicable interview once, it was discovered that my employer wouldn't give some micro-star a cover story, I decided I was through with junkets for good.

But media coverage is more likely to arrive courtesy of journalists who make a living on the junket circuit, who need to maintain cordial, uncritical relationships with studio publicists to pay the rent, and who are providing editors with exactly the kind of glorified PR they've asked for. Often they work for outlets owned by the same conglomerate that owns the movie they're covering. The hacks didn't make the rules, and you can't really blame them if they choose to stay in the game (or more precisely, on it).

It wasn't always this way. In a series on Hollywood and the entertainment media in this week's Los Angeles Times, Variety editor Peter Bart remembers the system as it worked from the late 1960s until the early 1980s: "You'd call a press agent and say you wanted to do a story on Steve McQueen, and you'd wind up seeing more of Steve McQueen than you ever wanted to, no conditions attached." Now, says John Horn, formerly of Premiere, "there are more magazines than there are celebrities to go around. It's out of control - it's a seller's market."

They sell. We buy. The garbage piles up. The cycle continues. I have an idle reverie about how to end it. The entire Hollywood press corps goes on strike and refuses to participate in any mutual back-scratching. We decline to attend studio press events, review any movies or cover Tinseltown. The oxygen mask of publicity is withdrawn, pending the restoration of the old McQueen-era rules of engagement. Fat chance, but then what are idle reveries for?

fields.headline: Breakfast at Tiffany's
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: You would need a heart of stone not to love the final clinch between Hepburn, George Peppard and her cat.
fields.body: Set in a clean New York, where the street cops idly twirl their nightsticks and people ask cabbies to take them somewhere called "Idlewild Airport", Breakfast at Tiffany's is back in a new print after 40 years. Audrey Hepburn's performance as the kooky gamine looks a little bit effortful - but it is still one of unique charm. Blake Edwards's direction ably shapes the sense of giddiness and George Axelrod's script gently transforms the harsher realities in Capote's novella into the Runyonesque misadventures of a good-time girl. You would need a heart of stone not to love the final clinch between Hepburn, George Peppard and her cat; and you might even forgive the outrageous turn by Mickey Rooney as the comedy Jap

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: The House of Mirth | Snatch
fields.trailText: The House of Mirth | Snatch
fields.body:
The House of Mirth
Rental and DVD (£19.9) FilmFour/VCI Cert PG ****

Sad, poetic and restrained, Terence Davies's take on the small, enclosed world Edith Wharton wrote about takes its time, but grips you in the end, largely as a result of Gillian Anderson's convincing descent from refinement to desperation in the title role. If "inaction movie" was a category, this would fit the bill. It's less glossy than Scorsese's Wharton revival, The Age of Innocence, but has many similarities in its themes: integrity and love denied by the pressing needs of propriety, reputation and social position. If TV star Anderson is a surprise choice, the rest of Davies's cast is no less unexpected - Dan Aykroyd, Terry Kinney from Oz and Anthony LaPaglia, perfectly dreadful as Daphne's brother in Frasier. All acquit themselves well in an ensemble cast. That it works at all, with a plot as doomy as any by Thomas Hardy, is a bit of a triumph. Few performances will stick in your mind as firmly as Anderson's.

Snatch
Rental and DVD (£24.99) Columbia Tristar Cert 18 ***

Given the chance to follow up Lock, Stock with a big-budget Hollywood movie, Guy Ritchie took the sensible compromise of importing a little Hollywood talent into his fantasy gangland London and carrying on much as before. Brad Pitt steals the show as a Gypsy boxer with an incomprehensible Irish accent (Tyler Durden meets John Cole) and it's weirdly funny to see Dennis Farina (from Get Shorty and Out of Sight) sharing scenes with Vinnie Jones and Mike Reid in conversation with Benicio del Toro. Brilliant filming and editing, some nicely polished lines and another amazingly convoluted plot. The DVD includes loads of extras.

fields.headline: Digimon: The Movie
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Digimon has slightly better animation than the two Pokémon horrors, with a more cogent relationship with the real world.
fields.body: Some films are so bad that watching them feels like being the victim of an existential larceny. And at the end of this one, I felt that 88 minutes of my life had been taken from me, never to return. Let's put it like this: Digimon is known for being like Pokémon - only not as good . Actually, as far as I could discern through the heat haze of resentment and boredom that soon rose up in front of the screen, Digimon has slightly better animation than the two Pokémon horrors, with a more cogent relationship with the real world. But life is still very much too short.

fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: The rascally "Archmage" Profion, played by Jeremy Irons, grinning evilly with what may be stunt teeth and screeching lines like: "I must have the Rod of Savrille!"
fields.body: Did we really need a film version of the swords'n'sorcery game Dungeons and Dragons? Did we really need a big-screen extrapolation of that well-known displacement activity for young men with no girlfriends? Anyway, we've got one now, exec-produced by action maestro Joel Silver. Thora Birch (from American Beauty) keeps her top on as the demure Princess Savina, at odds with the rascally "Archmage" Profion, played by Jeremy Irons, grinning evilly with what may be stunt teeth and screeching lines like: "I must have the Rod of Savrille!" Tom Baker plays a very large elf with pointy ears.

fields.headline: The Emperor's New Groove
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A very nice film and a very sure bet for the half-term holidays.
fields.body: At last: proof that a cartoon aimed at young people does not have to be valueless ordure. This Disney production is wittily designed and richly voiced - sharp, lively and funny. Saturday Night Live comic David Spade is the voice of the arrogant emperor out to destroy the village home of the blameless Pacha, voiced by John Goodman. But then he is turned into a llama by the scheming courtier, Yzma, played terrifically by Eartha Kitt, 10 times as Cruella as Glenn Close. A very nice film and a very sure bet for the half-term holidays.

fields.headline: State and Main
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: An amiable screwball comedy about a film crew invading a Vermont backwater.
fields.body:
David Mamet's surprisingly soft-boiled new work positions itself literally and figuratively in the centre of small-town America. It's an amiable screwball comedy about a film crew invading a Vermont backwater. Philip Seymour Hoffman plays Joe White, an idealistic young dramatist who has sold his soul to the movies. He is employed by fast-talking director Walt Price, played by Mamet regular William H Macy, into whose mouth Mamet pops comic jewels by the dozen. There's excellent support from Rebecca Pidgeon as the local girl who waltzes off with Joseph's heart: a subtle, charming performance.

So is Mamet softening? Or is this a rom-com register he can access at any time? Perhaps it will evolve into a sort of late style. Whatever the truth, it is intriguing to be present at the flowering of such a distinctive cinema talent.

fields.headline: Centre Stage
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: There's some more than competent dancing on show, but the movie is utterly without any feeling for its passion or poetry.
fields.body: Having won golden opinions for The Madness of King George and The Crucible, Nick Hytner has bafflingly directed a dull and derivative movie about young hopefuls at a ballet academy, following them from tryouts to the all-important end-of-year production. There's some more than competent dancing on show, but the movie is utterly without any feeling for its passion or poetry. Billy Elliot it ain't - still less Singin' in the Rain. And there's a risible "modern dance class" sequence so marooned in the 1980s everyone might as well wear leg-warmers and have done with it.

fields.headline: Songs from the Second Floor
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: The climactic set-piece in which a young girl is sacrificed to ward off the world's catastrophe surely has to be one of the most extraordinary moments in modern cinema.
fields.body:
Now in the UK after winning the special jury prize at Cannes, this movie just looks more remarkable than ever on a second viewing. Swedish director Roy Andersson presents us with loosely connected scenes from the end of the world, in a series of bizarre tableaux unfolding in weirdly lucid dream-landscapes of vast plains, endless corridors and vertiginous perspective lines - each scene filmed in one long take from a static camera.

They are peopled by wrecked, wretched characters, gaunt and pale, twitching and whimpering at the upcoming apocalypse. One man appears covered in soot, having burned down his furniture shop for the insurance, and he is pursued by ghosts: a man who lent him money, and a boy who was hanged by the Nazis. A conjuror accidentally saws into the body of an audience volunteer.

Each sequence is suffused with spectral disquiet and a black comic squeak of hysteria; together they form a secret theatre of millennial anxiety. And the climactic set-piece in which a young girl is sacrificed to ward off the world's catastrophe surely has to be one of the most extraordinary moments in modern cinema.

Andersson has something of Woody Allen and Terry Gilliam, but with strains of anarchy and melancholy that are unique. Here is a film to try the patience of the non-believer, but astonish everyone else. Some might find it a curate's egg of strangeness. But it's one of the Fabergé variety.

fields.headline: Hannibal
fields.standfirst: Anthony Hopkins turns up the camp as Hannibal Lecter in another showstopping performance
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Anthony Hopkins turns up the camp as Hannibal Lecter in another showstopping performance
fields.body:
So much has happened since Dr Hannibal Lecter murmured his farewells to agent Clarice Starling over the phone in 1991. Jeffrey Dahmer, the most prominent of America's un-charming, un-cultured serial killers, has been beaten to death in Portage state prison, Wisconsin, by another inmate, without benefit of chianti or fava beans. British enthusiasm for psychological profiling as the new rock'n'roll came to an embarrassed halt with the collapse of the Colin Stagg prosecution over the Wimbledon Common murder.

And by 1993, chilled by the atmosphere following the Jamie Bulger case, Anthony Hopkins was saying: "We are living in an age of such horrors, and there are such terrifying films coming out, that I think it might be time to say: 'Enough is enough'. I don't think glorifying somebody like Lecter is a very good idea. It was an interesting portrait of the character – but let's not go on."

Times have changed. The moral anxiety of the 1990s has receded, along with our saucer-eyed credulity about the science of forensic psychology. The show goes on; Hannibal goes on. But he has returned as the hero, not of a serious psycho-thriller, but a Guignol horror comedy: sleek, fast-moving, more than a little absurd.

Clariiiiiiice is now at the peak of her brilliant career at the Bureau. But a bungled drug raid (not her fault) results in ignominy and leads to Dr Lecter himself getting back in touch. He may be a star of the FBI website (and none of us had heard of websites in 1991) but he chooses the most quaintly old-fashioned means possible: perfumed writing paper. He is in Florence, luxuriating in a Jamesian torpor in that ancient city of violence, cunning and refinement, and from afar he experiences in Clarice's distress a resurgence of his twisted gallantry and appalling appetites.

Julianne Moore takes over from Jodie Foster as Clarice and she does the quasi-military jogging-through-the-woods thing, familiar from the first time around, ploughing along with her Titian hair in a bright ponytail flopping from side to side. For action sequences, she can more or less carry off the combination of T-shirt, combats and handgun. But let's face it, neither Clarice nor Julianne is getting any younger. So Moore seems happier bringing a new, languorous sensuality to Clarice's personality – a sexy woman-of-the-world maturity – most prominently when she reclines on a bed in a sexy gown, drugged up with morphine, while Dr Lecter is downstairs in the kitchen rustling up something unspeakable.

All that can be said of Anthony Hopkins is that he gives a showstopping turn at the centre of the picture. Ridley Scott does an expert job of – well, not directing him as such, but organising the flash-bang pyrotechnics around his reptilian yet bull-like figure, and just letting Hopkins get on with it.

Then there's that voice . It was always a mixture of Blanche Dubois and Richard III as spoken by Hopkins's first employer, Laurence Olivier. Now Blanche has got the upper hand. It's gamey, stagey, super camp: and distinctly un-American. (Despite being one of Baltimore's most famous products – along with Edgar Allan Poe and John Waters – Dr Lecter teasingly denies being American. In his menacing playfulness Hannibal is quite similar to Hopkins's fondly remembered stage performance as the Murdochesque newspaper proprietor in Howard Brenton and David Hare's Pravda.

Hopkins does not really look any older than when we last saw him as Dr Lecter, and he is one of those extraordinary actors whose age is indeterminate – now playing a character hardly different in age to the old war criminal he played in the TV series QB VII in 1974. The disappointment for Hannibal fans is that at no stage does Hopkins do that extraordinary rattlesnake-hiss with his tongue against his top teeth. On the loose, moreover, Hannibal loses some of the awful glamour he had when he was, for the want of a better word, restrained, and he can't do any of the forced encounters with Clarice that made Jonathan Demme's 1991 movie so interesting.

Like a vampire, Dr Lecter is at his best indoors, in darkness, or in the gloom of Florence's cloisters, where he affects sunglasses and a jaunty panama. He lectures on art history; he plays the Goldberg Variations. (In Hannibal 2, I'd like to hear him, in this high culture mode, read aloud from Ash Wednesday: "Lady, three white leopards sat under a juniper tree/In the cool of the day, having fed to satiety/On my legs my heart my liver and that which had been contained/In the hollow round of my skull.")

Speaking of which, we critics are forbidden on pain of being chomped from revealing the grisly finale. But anyone could see that the crooked justice department official Paul Krendler (Ray Liotta) is coming to a bad end. Not merely does he come on to Clarice in the most ungentlemanly way possible, but seriously disses Hannibal – calling him gay, of all the slanderous things! Krendler is certainly punished for the offensive assumptions underpinning that remark, and Dr Lecter's culinary predilections are given full and horrible expression. Ridley Scott has made a quite a meal of all this. But in 1991 Demme made it an intricate Le Caprice creation. This one leaves open the possibility of any number of sequels, like a franchise. I'm not sure I want fries with that.

webTitle: Business: Autonomy bites back - then falls

fields.headline: Autonomy bites back - then falls
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Mike Lynch, founder and chief executive of software company Autonomy, hit back at his critics yesterday as his company posted its first full year profit.
fields.body:
Mike Lynch, founder and chief executive of software company Autonomy, hit back at his critics yesterday as his company posted its first full year profit.

Autonomy, which makes software to sort unstructustructured text and was until recently regarded as a stockmarket darling, has been embroiled in a public row with investment bank Merrill Lynch over a controversial sell note. It was dealt another blow yesterday when analysts at ABN Amro downgraded the shares from hold to reduce.

The group's full year profits were bang in line with expectations, but the shares dropped 10% in early trading, before closing down 28p, or 1.79%, at £15.40. Four months ago - just after a London listing - they were changing hands at £41.

Mr Lynch said the company had been hit by "a barrage of rumours" and described the reaction as "rather annoying". The problems with Merrill had been particularly destructive.

A note to clients from the bank's technology sales team, headed "Trading ideas - Sell Autonomy," had said Microsoft was developing a product that would compete with Autonomy's knowledge management software, with workers it had poached from the Cambridge firm

The note, aimed at the interests of short term investors, was meant to be seen only by trading staff within the com pany but fund managers circulated it outside the firm.

Mr Lynch insisted the note was untrue. He said the Microsoft staff had not come from Autonomy and insisted that the American product was "irrelevant" because it was not aiming at the same market.

Merrill issued a retraction the following morning - though defending the trader's "sell" note - but not quickly enough for a ruffled Mr Lynch, who reached for his lawyers to put pressure on the bank. Merrill's research analysts have a neutral recommendation for long term investors.

Yesterday ABN Amro added to the increasingly negative sentiment surrounding Autonomy by issuing a downgrade.

An analyst, Iain Staples said: "We were concerned before the results about the relative and actual valuation of the stock compared to other mar ket leaders in the software technology sector."

Mr Staples said Autonomy would have to generate unprecedented rates of growth and returns to justify its rating. It "needed to hit through targets and not just reach them".

Autonomy's pretax profits for the quarter to the end of December - before the one-off costs associated with listing on the London stock exchange last November - were $7.9m (£5.4m), up $1m on the last quarter, and up from a $4.8m loss for last year.

Revenues were up 22% on the quarter at $65.4m, from $21.9m last year.

Recourse to lawyers

Mike Lynch has called in lawyers to defend his company's reputation on two other occasions in the past month:

 Technology group Bright Station was threatened with legal action for allegedly telling journalists that its new pact with Intel would undermine Autonomy's existing relationship with the chip maker.

Bright Station denied defaming Autonomy and said it had only been "emphasising the key points" about the deal.

 Autonomy issued a trading update after ABN Amro analysts compared Autonomy with Inktomi, a US technology company that issued a profits warning.

"We have not experienced a slowdown in our overall revenue growth during the fourth quarter of 2000 and have seen strong growth from the third quarter of 2000. Our business continues to be strong," Mr Lynch said.

webTitle: Business: Weaker demand for computers drives Dell cuts

fields.headline: Weaker demand for computers drives Dell cuts
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Dell cut 4% of its workforce yesterday - about 1,700 jobs - in the latest sign that the computer industry is struggling with weak demand and slower economic conditions.
fields.body:
Dell cut 4% of its workforce yesterday - about 1,700 jobs - in the latest sign that the computer industry is struggling with weak demand and slower economic conditions.

The announcement marked the first time that the world's leading direct seller of computers had cut a large number of jobs in its 16-year history.

Some 22,000 administrative and other support workers at the company's Texas headquarters will be hardest hit by the restructuring.

Dell, which employs 40,200 people worldwide, said that its faster growing international operations would remain largely unscathed by the cuts, announced before its fourth-quarter results last night.

The news came just hours after Cisco, Silicon Valley's biggest company, told the BBC it will stop recruiting new staff.

John Chambers, the chief of Cisco Systems, said the company had discovered that since the beginning of this year orders for its products have dropped.

Dell's shares rose 8% to $24.90 (£17) after yesterday's announcement although some analysts had expected the job cuts to be as high as 10% of the workforce. The shares traded as high as $59 last March.

Tracey Akresh, analyst at JP Morgan, said: "It's the first time in their history that they have cut jobs in this way, but times have changed."

Wall Street analysts were expecting Dell to significantly reduce its revenue growth estimates for 2001 last night.

The company, which was started by Michael Dell while he was still a student in the early 1980s, achieved revenue growth rates of as much as 50% in the 1990s.

Last year, it scaled back these estimates to 20% and most analysts expected a further cut last night. Dell blamed "lower expectations of industry and company growth" as well as a recent reorganisation for the job cuts.

The consensus forecast was for the company to report earnings of 19 cents a share in the fourth quarter and 85 cents for the year as a whole on annual revenues of about $8.65bn.

Several analysts have downgraded the company since a profits warning in December. Steve Fortuna, analyst at Merrill Lynch, lowered his ratings for the company yesterday when he forecast essentially flat earnings for next year because of lower margins.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Vauxhall staff vote for strike
fields.body:
Vauxhall staff vote for strike

Thousands of workers at Vauxhall are to strike next week in protest against the ending of car production at Luton and the loss of 2,000 jobs, it was announced yesterday.

The TGWU said its members at Luton and at Ellesmere Port would walk out from the night shift next Thursday and from all shifts on Friday.

There would also be an overtime ban the following weekend. The union represents about four out of five workers at Vauxhall and said the strike would cripple production.

Cheap tickets hit P&O results

Cheaper tickets for Caribbean cruises filled the decks but hit the finances of P&O Princess Cruises last year when profits fell 11%, according to results posted yesterday.

Most of the damage was done in the fourth quarter, when operating profits fell more than 70% to $15.9m (£11m) due to high fuel prices, choppy exchange rates and the suspension of cruise calls to ports in Israel because of violence.

With prices of cruises booked through next autumn still lower than last year, trading conditions at the company are likely to remain tough in 2001.

O'Neill banks on US tax plan

US treasury secretary Paul O'Neill said yesterday that his future likely rides upon keeping the Bush administration's $1.6 trillion (£1.1 trillion) tax cut plan from ballooning higher.

Speaking before heading to a meeting of finance ministers and central bankers from the Group of Seven nations, Mr O'Neill said president Bush was firm on the size of the tax cut that occurs over a decade.

Allen bales out of Priceline

Paul Allen, co-founder of Microsoft, has sold his entire stake in Priceline.com, the troubled online ticketing company, it emerged yesterday.

The news that Mr Allen had sold his 5% holding came as a blow to the firm as it prepared to announce its fourth-quarter results late last night.

Priceline's shares have fallen from a high of $104.25 a share last March to about $2.50 yesterday - a decline of more than 90%. The company has struggled in the face of increased competition, the downturn in investor confidence and a series of lawsuits from shareholders and former employees.

Rolls-Royce in Qantas deal

Australia's Qantas Airways will soon announce a decisive $1.2bn (£828m) order for aircraft engines, industry sources said, with Britain's Rolls-Royce tipped as the likely winner.

The order, to power 12 Airbus A380 superjumbo aeroplanes and 19 other aircraft, will probably determine which manufacturer becomes Qantas's leading engine supplier for decades to come.

webTitle: MPs may opt for secret ballot to choose next Speaker

fields.headline: MPs may opt for secret ballot to choose next Speaker
fields.standfirst:
Reform urged to avoid repeat of seven-hour fiasco

Special report: Commons Speaker
Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: MPs are to introduce sweeping changes to the rules governing the election of the Commons Speaker to avoid a repeat of last year's fiasco when it took nearly seven hours to elect Michael Martin to the post.
fields.body:
MPs are to introduce sweeping changes to the rules governing the election of the Commons Speaker to avoid a repeat of last year's fiasco when it took nearly seven hours to elect Michael Martin to the post.

In the most radical reform of the election rules in centuries, MPs are expected to choose their next Speaker by secret ballot. Candidates will only be able to stand if they are nominated by 12 other MPs, three of who must come from another party.

The Commons procedure committee called for the changes after admitting that the system for electing a speaker was "fundamentally flawed".

The House of Commons was widely criticised last October when MPs took just under seven hours to elect Mr Martin, the Labour MP for Glasgow Springburn, to succeeed Betty Boothroyd.

Mr Martin finally took the chair at 9.20pm on the night of October 23 - the debate had started at 2.30pm - after MPs voted on a total of 11 candidates, each of whom made a lengthy speech after being proposed and seconded.

Sir Edward Heath, the 84-yar-old former prime minister who presided over the election in his role as father of the house, was criticised during the debate for resisting backbench calls to hold a ballot. Sir Edward insisted that he could not change Commons procedures on the hoof.

The events surrounding Mr Martin's election descended into farce when a Labour MP later admitted that he bet £200 on Mr Martin's election at odds of 20-1, giving him £3,400. Frank Roy, MP for Motherwell and Wishaw, was censured by the parliamentary standards watchdog.

Under the committee's proposals, the Commons will break with convention and elect the speaker by an "exhaustive" secret ballot system. If a candidate received 50% of the vote, he or she would be automatically elected. If no candidate received 50% of the vote, the candidate with the lowest number of votes would be eliminated and another vote held until a winner emerged.

The committee's proposal will dismay parliamentary traditionalists who believe that all votes at Westminster should be open to ensure that MPs are accountable to their constituents. However, MPs on the procedure committee said there was no danger that their proposal would change normal Commons votes.

"We note the long developing tradition that this pre-eminently is a matter for the house and not for the government or the party leaderships," the MPs concluded. This was seen as a coded rebuke to the Labour whips who tried unsuccessfully to pressurise their backbenchers to support the Tory MP, Sir George Young.

The MPs also called for future elections to be presided over by the clerk of the house - the most senior official in the Commons - rather than the father of the house, a title which denotes the longest serving MP. This is in line with the system which was in force before the last changes to the rules were made in 1972.

Members of the procedure committee insisted that their report did not question the legitimacy of Mr Martin, saying that he would still have been elected if their rules had been in force.

However, their recommendation that an aspiring Speaker should be nominated by three MPs from another party is designed to avoid a repeat of the partisan nature of the last election.

Mr Martin was the only candidate in the election who was proposed and seconded only by MPs from his own party.

In a sign of the modest modernising spirit of today's commons, the committee also recommended reforming a quirky tradition of the Speaker's election.

The report said a new Speaker should decide whether he or she wants to be "dragged" to the chair to denote their supposed unwillingness to take up the job in the light of the fate of nine speakers who lost their heads in the course of their duties.

MPs will vote on the committee's recommendations.

webTitle: Stricken El Salvador fears donor fatigue

fields.headline: Stricken El Salvador fears donor fatigue
fields.standfirst: Hope fades for survivors days after the second quake
fields.trailText: Hope fades for survivors days after the second quake
fields.body:
As mass funerals for earthquake victims take place across El Salvador for the second time in a month, a United Nations official has warned that "international donor fatigue" may damage the effort to bring relief to the country.

"Without an indication that there is some lesson learned from one natural disaster to another, there is disenchantment," Bruno Moro, the UN coordinator in El Salvador, said.

The crisis of confidence was not limited to El Salvador, he added.

Rather, it was "the consequence of a global situation where you have a recurrence of natural disasters or manmade disasters that create stress on the international community's response to this situation".

Salvadorean officials complained after the first earthquake on January 13 that only $2m (about £1.4m) had been received in aid.

Aid workers say that more than 15% of the country's 6m inhabitants have been affected by the disasters, the second of which struck on Sunday.

As well as building houses for the more than 700,000 homeless, major work will be needed on the main roads: a section of the PanAmerican highway, which links El Salvador with neighbouring Honduras and Nicaragua, collapsed on Sunday.

With a national disaster budget of less than $2.2m, the government had planned to seek a large slice of the $1bn estimated reconstruction costs of the first quake at a meeting of donor countries in Madrid on March 7.

It is too early to say how much more will now be needed; in one province more than two-thirds of the housing was destroyed.

Now that rescuers are close to giving up hope of finding more survivors, a poignant focus of the nation's grief has been the funeral of the children who died beneath the walls of their parish school in the town of Candelaria. The town, almost 20 miles east of the capital, San Salvador, twas close to the epicentre.

The bodies of four small children and their teacher have been recovered from the ruins. Witnesses said that Ana Elizabeth Chicas de Chavez, 25, had run to safety from the toppling building but turned back to save some of her tiny pupils.

In San Miguel Tepezontes, the living, too afraid to return to their damaged homes, have been sharing the village square with the dead.

webTitle: Clinton defiant as FBI opens inquiry

fields.headline: Clinton defiant as FBI opens inquiry
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: An indignant Bill Clinton denied yesterday that he pardoned the fugitive financier Marc Rich in return for political donations, but a criminal investigation into the controversial pardon began, and it seems certain to keep the latest Clinton scandal on the boil for several weeks.
fields.body:
An indignant Bill Clinton denied yesterday that he pardoned the fugitive financier Marc Rich in return for political donations, but a criminal investigation into the controversial pardon began, and it seems certain to keep the latest Clinton scandal on the boil for several weeks.

Mr Clinton issued his denial as a federal prosecutor in New York was authorised by the justice department to investigate whether money played a part in the pardoning of Mr Rich on January 20.

US attorney Mary Jo White, a Clinton appointee, is expected to examine bank and telephone records for evidence of illegal conduct by Mr Rich and his supporters, as well as by Mr Clinton himself.

"As I have said repeatedly, I made the decision to pardon Marc Rich based on what I thought was the right thing to do," Mr Clinton's statement said.

"Any suggestions that improper factors, including fundraising for the Democratic national committee or my library had anything to do with the decision, are absolutely false. I look forward to cooperating with any appropriate inquiry."

Ms White's office and the FBI said that they had opened a joint investigation to find out if federal laws were breached.

Mr Clinton and some of his closest former colleagues and supporters are now braced for at least three intensifying investigations into the pardons, which were issued just two hours before he left the White House.

Ms White's is likely to become the most important. She runs the federal prosecution office in New York, which was once run by the New York mayor, Rudolph Giuliani.

Mr Giuliani secured the original 51-count indictment of Mr Rich in September 1983 on charges of arms trading, fraud and $48m (£33m) tax evasion. The case is still the biggest tax evasion prosecution in US history.

Ms White was not consulted about the Rich pardon and was reportedly "livid" when news of it emerged.

Mr Rich and his co-defendant Pincus Green fled to Switzerland before the case went to court more than 17 years ago, and both men have remained there ever since, while continuing to expand their hugely profitable commodities trading businesses.

The US authorities have been involved in regular talks for the past 17 years to try to resolve the Rich case, but proposed deals have fallen through because Mr Rich refused to serve a jail sentence.

Early last year Ms White refused to negotiate with Mr Rich, saying that it would "give defendants an incentive to flee [from the US]".

Mr Rich has now abandoned his US citizenship. In 1993 his 27-year marriage to the former Denise Eisenberg broke up.

The key issues in the new investigation are why and how Mr Clinton added Mr Rich's name to the list of 141 presidential pardons.

After Mrs Rich returned to the US with her three daughters in the mid-90s, she made a glittering career as a Manhattan socialite and a courtier at the Clinton White House, and became a major donor to the Democratic party.

She gave it more than $500,000, and pledged at least $450,000 to Mr Clinton's presidential library fund. Some reports, denied by both sides, say her library pledge is far larger and could be as high as $10m.

Last year she also gave a set of two coffee tables and upholstered chairs to the Clintons, worth $7,735, which the former presidential couple took with them when they left the White House.

Such support raises the question of whether Mrs Rich tried to buy her former husband's pardon, either with her own assets or with money transferred to her from Switzerland. Mrs Rich personally spoke to Mr Clinton twice.

So far she has refused to testify on the grounds that she might incriminate herself.

Other issues under scrutiny are the means employed by Mr Rich and his US lawyer Jack Quinn to orchestrate the behind-the-scenes lobbying which led to the pardon and, in particular, how the justice department and Ms White's office were kept in ignorance of it.

Mr Quinn says he focused his main effort on Mr Rich's behalf by using his own access to the White House as a former counsel there and by encouraging prominent Israelis to pressure Mr Clinton.

The former head of Israel's Mossad spy agency, Avner Azulay, said that former prime ministers Ehud Barak and Shimon Peres both spoke personally to Mr Clinton about Mr Rich's proposed pardon.

Mr Azulay said he believed Mr Clinton granted the pardon because of Mr Rich's role in helping Jews get out of Ethiopia and Yemen.

Mr Quinn said this week that he informed the deputy attorney-general Eric Holder on November 21 last year that he would send a pardon petition for Mr Rich to Mr Clinton, and that he sent a copy to Mr Holder on January 10.

Mr Holder claimed this week that he had first learned about the petition on January 19, a day before the pardon was issued, and that he assumed the Rich case had already been referred to his department and to the New York prosecutor's office.

But it emerged on Wednesday that the first notification came shortly after midnight on January 20.

The presidential pardon power is enshrined in the constitution. In all, Mr Clinton issued 395 pardons in eight years, compared with 393 issued by Ronald Reagan in his two White House terms.

The main players

Marc Rich

Now 67, born in Belgium, lived in the US, and holds Spanish and Israeli passports. Lives in Zurich. A powerful and controversial billionaire said to own most of Peru.

Denise Rich

Daughter of Holocaust survivor and millionaire. Lives on Fifth Avenue, New York. Former songwriter for Sister Sledge, Bette Midler, Celine Dion and Aretha Franklin.

Jack Quinn

Brooklyn-born lawyer and a Democratic party power-broker. Al Gore's ex-chief of staff and former White House counsel who runs his own lobbying firm, Quinn Gillespie.

Pincus Green

Charged with Rich, fled to Switzerland with him and was pardoned with him.

Eric Holder

Assistant attorney-general under Janet Reno. Knew of plan to seek pardon but is accused of not telling others in time to carry out checks.

webTitle: Israel buries bus stop terror victims

fields.headline: Israel buries bus stop terror victims
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Under the leaden clouds hanging over the working class town of Ashkelon, mothers reached out to touch the wooden coffins for the last time before their daughters, victims of Wednesday's hit-and-run bus attack, were finally laid to rest.
fields.body:
Under the leaden clouds hanging over the working class town of Ashkelon, mothers reached out to touch the wooden coffins for the last time before their daughters, victims of Wednesday's hit-and-run bus attack, were finally laid to rest.

In the town's suburban cemetery, dotted with palm trees and surrounded by fields of pungent grapefruit trees, scores of people mourned the loss of their fellow soldiers and friends.

Khalil Abu Olbeh's attack on a crowded bus stop south of Tel Aviv was the deadliest in Israel in nearly four years.

Seven Israeli soldiers, four of them women, and a civilian, were killed. Two, Sergeants Rachel Levy, and Kochava Polanski, both 19, were buried at Ashkelon yesterday. Simcha Shetrit, 30, was buried in Rishon Letzion yesterday and Sergeants David Elouz, 21 and

Ofir Magidish, 20 were buried a military cemetery on Wednesday. Sergeant Julie Weiner, 21, who left France to live with an "adopted family" on a kibbutz so that she could explore life in Israel, will be buried in Jerusalem today.

In Ashkelon teenage soldiers and elderly Russian immigrants huddled together.

"Why, why?" they chanted. "Why did they do this?"

Palestinian officials said that "Israeli aggressions" were to blame for the attack.

It followed an Israeli helicopter missile strike on Tuesday which killed Massoud Ayad, 54, a member of Yasser Arafat's elite security guard claimed by Israel to be an agent of the Hizbullah guerrilla organisation in Lebanon.

The conflict showed no signs of respite yesterday. The Israeli army said a man was shot as soldiers foiled an attempt by armed Palestinians to enter houses in the Jewish settlement of Kfar Darom, in the Gaza Strip.

Palestinians identified him as Nasser Hassanat, 23, a resident of the Deir El Balah refugee camp. He was not in uniform but allegedly carried documents identifying him as a member of the Palestinian preventative security service.

Thousands of Arab protesters marched at his funeral in Gaza yesterday.

Israel tightened its blockade of Palestinian areas after the bus stop killings, which brough the violence to a new peak in the week since the rightwing Likud party leader Ariel Sharon was elected.

As Israelis buried their dead yesterday, Mr Sharon and his predecessor, Ehud Barak, pressed ahead with their efforts to for a joint government.

Mr Barak, considered by many as the man who has landed Israelis in this mini-war, said he had conditionally accepted Mr Bark's offer to join a unity government.

"We don't need Barak around any more. He has caused more harm that good," said Kfir Melkhaim, 20, a friend of one of the dead women soldiers.

"Sharon is what we need. He must use force on the Arabs. Maybe he could just get rid of them altogether. Maybe that would solve the problem."

fields.headline: Civilian was 'invited' to raise vessel
fields.trailText: The civilian who pulled the lever which made the US nuclear submarine Greeneville surface off Hawaii and sink a Japanese training ship last week has spoken on television about the incident.
fields.byline: Duncan Campbell in Los Angeles and  Jonathan Watts in Tokyo
fields.body:
The civilian who pulled the lever which made the US nuclear submarine Greeneville surface off Hawaii and sink a Japanese training ship last week has spoken on television about the incident.

At least nine Japanese died in the collision.

John Hall, who had been invited on board by naval public relations, told NBC's Today programme that the submarine's commanding officer had asked if he would like to operate the lever for "the blowdown", an emergency drill that takes the submarine to the surface at high speed.

Mr Hall said he had been "nervous" about it, but a naval officer had been at his elbow.

Mr Hall and another civilian, Todd Thoman came forward after questions were raised about the part civilians played in the sinking of the fishery training vessel Ehime Maru on Friday.

Sixteen civilians were on board the 108-metre (360ft) submarine at the time of the accident. All were in the control room.

Mr Hall said: "I was to the left in the control room, and I was asked by the captain if I would like the opportunity to pull the levers that start the procedure.

"I said, 'Sure, I'd love to do that.'"

At the moment of impact, he said the entire submarine shuddered and he heard the captain, Commander Scott Waddle, say: "Jesus, what the hell was that?"

Cmdr Waddle has been relieved of his duties pending the inquiry. Officers and crew may face criminal charges.

Mr Thoman denied that the presence of civilians contributed to the accident.

He said: "It was nothing but professional, not one thing got done on that submarine that the commanding officer was not aware of and in total control of.

"We went nowhere on this vessel without an escort. Nothing out of the ordinary took place."

At first Japan took a restrained approach to the accident, but yesterday it lodged a formal protest with the United States as its people became increasingly outraged that corporate sightseers were at the controls when the attack submarine tore through the Japanese ship's hull.

"I cannot help but say that this is an extremely serious matter if civilian participation in the surfacing manoeuvre somehow led to the accident," the foreign minister, Yohei Kono, told his US counterpart, Colin Powell, in Tokyo's most strongly worded criticism of the US yet.

Twenty-six people were rescued from the training ship after the accident, but the bodies of nine Japanese, including four 17-year-old fisheries students, have yet to be found.

The US navy admitted yesterday that the accident happened outside a submarine training zone.

Questions are also being asked about the US navy's refusal to release the names of all 16 civilians on the tour of the submarine.
