Scotland takes its name from an Irish tribe. But prejudice still reigns

Special report: devolution in Scotland
fields.trailText: A lthough the resignation of Frank Roy has scarcely shaken the government as much as Peter Mandelson's enforced departure, it is also connected with Ulster. Mr Roy was parliamentary private secretary to Helen Liddell, the new Scottish secretary. And behind his departure is a truly fascinating story.
fields.body:
A lthough the resignation of Frank Roy has scarcely shaken the government as much as Peter Mandelson's enforced departure, it is also connected with Ulster. Mr Roy was parliamentary private secretary to Helen Liddell, the new Scottish secretary. And behind his departure is a truly fascinating story.

Last weekend, the Irish prime minister Bertie Ahern was due to visit Scotland, to unveil an Irish famine memorial in Lanarkshire, after attending Sunday's Celtic v Rangers match. But Roy appealed to Mr Ahern to stay away, saying his presence at an Old Firm match would inflame sectarian passion, notably in Roy's own Motherwell and Wishaw constituency. Ahern cancelled his visit, but Roy's intervention was criticised vehemently in Scotland and he resigned. This might at least give him the leisure for historical reflection.

Underlying every other Irish republican claim is a belief that Ireland is discrete: Sinn Fein is variously translated as "ourselves alone" or "we ourselves". The name intends that Ireland is an entirely separate country, or should be, or would have been but for "800 years of English rule", presumably dating from the arrival of Strongbow and his Norman knights in Wexford in the 1160s.

This historical interpretation ignores a relationship - and continual reciprocal movements of population - between the two islands going back not hundreds but thousand of years.

As republicans rightly say, the Ulster Protestants were originally "colonists". There were indeed no Scottish Protestants in Ireland 500 years ago, just as were were no Normans in Ireland 1,000 years ago, no Vikings 2,000 years ago - and no Celts 3,000 years ago. The Celts or Gaels arrived in Ireland as colonists by way of Britain several centuries before Christ, subduing and disposing of the existing population.

T hat only began the to and fro. Scotland takes its very name from an Irish tribe, the Scotii, who crossed from Ulster around the fifth century and settled the west of the country. For the next thousand years or more, the Highlands and Islands of Scotland were correctly regarded as a Irish colony. "Scots Gaelic" used to be known as Erse and is in fact Irish.

The next movement was in the opposite direction when Ulster was planted by Protestant settlers in the 17th century. Not all were from Scotland, but it was they who gave the province its distinctive character to this day. Hence the faintly comical demand by loyalists that the Belfast Agreement should recognise Ulster Scots as a local lingo along with Gaelic.

And then came the last migration, numerically the largest of all, of Irish who left their country after the great famine of the 1840s. They settled throughout Great Britain (and America and Australia, of course) but nowhere in such concentration as in west-central Scotland.

At that very time, a notorious piece of invented tradition was under way. Those Gaelic Highlanders had never been more than a small minority of the population of Scotland, and Jacobite risings and clearances had seen them defeated and dispossessed. But their culture - or a version of it, tartan, bagpipes and all - came to be regarded as authentically Scottish.

One turning point had been in 1822 when George IV visited Scotland and hoped to humour the natives by disporting himself in a kilt (worn over pink tights). Or as Macaulay put it, he "thought that he could not give a more striking proof of his respect for the usages which had prevailed in Scotland before the Union, than by disguising himself in what, before the Union, was considered by nine Scotchmen out of ten as the dress of a thief".

The Scottish lowlands were now acquiring an authentic new culture, brought by those Irish Catholic incomers. Why else does Glasgow have a football team called Celtic, or Edinburgh one called Hibernians? Roman Catholicism was practically unknown in lowland Scotland 200 years ago, but became almost more powerful than the Kirk.

Not least, Labour in Scotland was for long a strongly Catholic party; I take it from Frank Roy's education at Our Lady's High School in Motherwell that he belongs to this tradition.

If his nervosity about Ahern's visit seems excessive, remember that migration imported Ireland's sectarian bitterness into Scotland. The miserable violence attending Old Firm games isn't Roy's imagination: after Celtic won 6-0 last August, there were 13 stabbings, two attempted murders and one murder.

But the final paradox is this. Behind the passions, history has left north-eastern Ireland with a prevailing Scottish-Protestant culture, and western-central Scotland with a prevailing Irish-Catholic culture. Who in these islands can really say "ourselves alone"?

fields.headline: Assassinating Palestinians simply doesn't work
fields.standfirst:
Even Ariel Sharon understands that fighting still equals failure


Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Even Ariel Sharon understands that fighting still equals failure.
fields.body:
A symmetrical war is the name given to it by military theorists. What it comes down to in real life is this: one man killed by precision munitions fired from a state of the art helicopter in one place, and eight young men and women crushed to death by an ordinary diesel bus in another place about 50 miles away. One was carefully planned, the other may have been hardly planned at all. One was the act of a strong state and a strong army, the other an act typical of a weak society. But, different though they were, they could not have been better timed, as Ariel Sharon prepares for power, to illustrate not just the limitations of force in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, but the way in which its use constantly defeats any rational purpose.

For what will happen as a consequence of these two acts? Will the thought that they might be selectively assassinated by the Israelis make Palestinian leaders shrink from organising or encouraging attacks? All that can be said is that it never has in the past, and that the effect of assassinations - and over the years there have been so many, in Beirut, Tunis, Malta, and many other places, as well as in the West Bank and Gaza - has nearly always had the reverse effect, leading to more, rather than less, violence. Has the disappearance from the scene of the 20 or so men the Israelis are said to have targeted and killed in the troubles that began last September changed anything for the better? The truth, rather, is that in a situation like the one in which the Palestinians find themselves there is no shortage of men, driven by both anger and ambition, anxious to step into the shoes of people who are killed.

Some figures, notably Arafat himself, are irreplaceable, and one prominent Israeli this week took the argument to its reductive end by raising the possibility that the Israelis might destroy the Palestinian Authority itself, not necessarily by assassination but by making it impossible for it to function at all. That idea will not have many followers in any Israeli government, which desperately needs somebody to talk to on the other side and understands in practice, whatever spokesmen say in public, that there are some restraints being imposed by the Authority on Palestinian military action. Still, the decapitation of the enemy is an old Israeli fantasy and remains a temptation. What the assassinations show is that Israeli policy is driven not by what it may be rationally useful to do but rather merely by what can be done. All kinds of options, from full-scale bombardments of areas from which they are fired on to the reoccupation of Palestinian towns, are ruled out, at least for the moment. But assassinations are technically possible, not too risky for the forces involved, and not too costly politically, in spite of international protests. So they are done - because "something" has to be done.

What will follow the bus attack? First, it is probable that the Egged bus company will sack many, or all, of the few Gaza and West Bank men it still employs, and that other Israeli firms will do the same, so that, regardless of how long the borders are sealed or virtually sealed, there will be, even if the restrictions are eased, even less work for Palestinians in Israel. There is madness here, too: 30,000 Gaza workers commuted to Israel before last September. It was work useful to Israel, but vital to Gaza, which has little industry or agriculture of its own. Now the United Nations estimates that unemployment in the West Bank and Gaza is nearly 40% - higher in Gaza - and this is probably an underestimate. That there is any work at all in Gaza and the West Bank is largely due to the money the international community is putting in, including emergency payment of civil service salaries. How can it help Israel, one might ask, that in Gaza, where half the population is under 14, there should be almost no jobs and no possibilities for advancement, however modest, except in the single field of fighting Israelis ?

If Israel's main problem in negotations with the Palestinians was, and remains, that it is too strong, then that is also its main problem in the state of quasi-war that now exists. Strength does not necessarily produce effective policies, and it may rule out others that might be effective. One of Israel's leading intellectuals, the military writer Martin van Creveld, has been incisive on the subject of the disadvantages of strength. "A war waged by the strong against the weak," he wrote, "is problematic for that very reason ... Fighting the weak demeans those who engage in it and therefore alienates its own purpose. He who loses out to the weak loses; he who triumphs over the weak also loses. In such an enterprise there can be neither profit nor honour."

I t was in part a perception of this problem which led Israel, after the first intifada, down the road of negotiations, if not far enough. And it is in part a perception of this problem that guides the Palestinians when they provoke the Israelis into actions that they believe will shame them before the world community and in their own eyes.

When military establishments are asked by governments, particularly by governments headed by ex-generals, for suggestions as to what to do, they tend to come up with answers, because that is their job. But the frustrating truth is that both know the answers are no good. Reoccupation would, the experts say, be relatively easy, although casualties might be quite high. Three or four days of tough fighting might be tolerable if it were not for the international condemnation that would follow, the confirmed enmity of the Muslim world, and even more the years of hell holding the Palestinians down that would then lie before Israel. Separation with coercive population transfers and the liquidation of outlying settlements? Harder to do, because it would involve deportations, somewhat easier to maintain, but you would still have to have military positions deep in Palestinian territory, and you would still be an island in a sea of rancour. And what if, at the end of a long period, strategic realities do shift, and Israel ceases to be the strongest power in the region? Possible to deal with such a change when the background is one of a fair peace, concluded years before: not so easy if you are still at harsh odds with the Palestinians.

That is why Yossi Beilin, the departing minister of justice and one of the Israelis who has done most for peace, is right to argue that to formally set aside the goal of a final settlement is wrong and dangerous. There are no acceptable radical military options for Israel, and even Sharon seems to half see that. There is, meanwhile, no evidence that the present policy of limited confrontation, occasional assassination, and punitive economic measures will induce the Palestinians to agree to the interim settlement and the abandonment of any real effort to reach a final settlement which Sharon proposes. The reality is that while a final settlement was a desirable goal before the Camp David failure, it now represents the only way out of an increasingly desperate situation for both Israelis and Palestinians.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
 Spare a thought today for my noble friend Tim Bell, the PR shaman ennobled by Major despite an 80s cocaine habit and a conviction for onanistic indecency (out of his bathroom window). That old resilience is evident when my colleague Marina Hyde calls after the crash of Legacy's dome bid - Tim handled the PR - and finds him calm. But is it true, she wonders, that you're also involved with English Partnerships, the violently anti-Legacy dome quango? "It's not true." Phew. "Well, it is true that we have a contract with English Partnerships through our public affairs company, Bell Pottinger Public Affairs." A totally separate company? "Well, my company Chime Communications actually owns Bell Pottinger Public Affairs ... but I don't work in their office and am not part of their operating team or management structure." Tim then emphasises this separation of duties - his own included trying to repair damage from the recent leaking to the Telegraph of an English Partnerships letter savaging Legacy - and thank God. Even if his PR failed, Tim can comfort himself for so nimbly steering clear of any conflict of interest.

 Our Alastair Campbell madness special strikes a chord. "Four years ago I was appointed town crier at Brighton and Hove by the lord of the manor, Chris Eubank," writes Margaret Pracy. "Our council tried to ban me. I've been told that I too am 'a bit of a nutter'. Very difficult to fight back against." Mandy and others will agree, Margaret, and you are hereby conscripted into the Hola! (Hartlepool One Liberation Army) third battalion under the command of Major the Lord Rees-Mogg.

 Sad news, however, on the Skippy Hammond front (Skippy is a kangaroo court reference, by the way, for any stragglers baffled by the nickname). The sole volunteer to wear the kangaroo suit and give the Hinduja whitewash man his jigsaw (to keep him busy until the report is out) has pulled out. The fee is raised to £125, for an hour's work outside the Home Office. Don't make us hire a prostitute at half the price. Volunteer now - but remember, you must be 5ft 7in or under.

 Of all the slurs against Mr Tony Blair, one that always upsets me is the idea that he derides the principle of collective government, racing through cabinet meetings and using colleagues as a rubber stamp for policies decided by Ali and Derry backstage. How ridic... but no, why dignify such infantile spite with a serious rebuttal? Meanwhile, on signing up for the New Labour website's "eNews" weekly bulletin of government news, we're pleased to find it going well. "The eCampaign's team has been delighted at the number of requests for eNews," it says, "never more so than when a senior cabinet minister requested it." Ah well, as long as they keep up with government developments, does it really matter how?

 Mirror motoring writer Quentin Willson has a hot tipabout "the nearest thing ... to a theft proof stereo". Kenwood's Mask unit "automatically hides itself," he explains, and is "completely useless if you steal it". Mm. Our first one survived a week. Word about its post-theft uselessness must have spread, though, because the second lasted three days. The third went after 16 hours. Rush now while stocks last.

 Also in the Mirror, proud non-driver Paul Routledge has a go at motorists. Once again, as with ownership of all those rental properties, Mrs Routers gets off less lightly. Whether it's his thirst that pedestrianises him or gout in the clutch foot, what a relief he has a willing chauffeuse on hand.

 Michael Stone, a cock-up. UTV's Inside the Mind of A Killer was, of course, about the loyalist hitman, not the man awaiting retrial for the Lawrence murders. Let's all try to be more careful in the future, shall we, and leave it at that.

webTitle: Business: Wind of change for nuclear generator

fields.headline: Power play
fields.standfirst: Wind of change for nuclear generator
fields.trailText: Wind of change for nuclear generator
fields.body:
British Energy, reviled over the years by environmentalists because of its nuclear power stations, yesterday announced plans to move into wind power.

The country's biggest nuclear generator has set up a joint venture with Renewable Energy Systems to bid for an offshore wind farm site, and plans to look for other renewable energy sources.

Appropriate offshore sites are to be leased out over the next four years by the Crown Estate, which administers the seabed.

A British Energy spokesman said that the new venture, called Offshore Wind Power, had pre-registered for a site "so we are not ruled out at the first hurdle".

The nuclear group is aiming to produce up to 2% of its electricity from wind power by 2010, the year when electricity supply companies have to obtain 10% of their energy from renewable sources.

Britain's first offshore wind farm, at Blyth in Northumberland came into operation last month. The project, owned by a consortium including Powergen, has two 2MW turbines.

British Energy is intending to build a project, with up to 30 turbines delivering a total of 90MW.

A site of that size would require investment of about £20m. The company chose RES as its partner, because it was the largest UK-based wind energy developer, and because its parent company, Robert McAlpine, has experience of offshore construction.

RES is planning to build the world's largest wind farm in Texas, with a capacity of 280MW. The company already has more than 1,100MW of capacity on its books in the US, Europe, Asia and the Caribbean.

webTitle: Artificial knee supports Smith & Nephew profits

fields.headline: Artificial knee supports Smith & Nephew profits
fields.trailText: A ground-breaking artificial knee has put a spring in the step of health care company Smith & Nephew, which yesterday produced a 44% surge in annual pre-tax profits to £261m.
fields.body:
A ground-breaking artificial knee has put a spring in the step of health care company Smith & Nephew, which yesterday produced a 44% surge in annual pre-tax profits to £261m.

The increase was partly due to one-off gains on the sale of consumer businesses, including Elastoplast dressings.

However, Smith & Nephew's ongoing performance was buoyed by its Genesis "total knee replacement system", which allows surgeons to fit together a different type of knee for each patient. Genesis has become the firm's first orthopeadics product to produce sales of $100m (£70m).

webTitle: BG joins the big profits crowd

fields.headline: BG joins the big profits crowd
fields.trailText: BG Group, the integrated gas business, yesterday fuelled the campaign for a windfall tax on energy companies by revealing that it more than doubled its profits last year.
fields.body:
BG Group, the integrated gas business, yesterday fuelled the campaign for a windfall tax on energy companies by revealing that it more than doubled its profits last year.

The group said its net profits rose 153% to £425m last year but claimed that organic growth had contributed as much as higher gas and oil prices.

It claimed that it did not deserve to be placed in the same bracket as BP Amoco and Shell, which triggered calls for a windfall levy by announcing huge profit rises earlier this month.

BG's finance director, Andrew Bonfield, said the group had a very different product mix to BP and Shell. Fluctuations in the oil price had less impact on BG because oil accounted for only 25% of its production.

Although the group is the fifth largest gas supplier in Britain, it has only 9% of the home market, and about 90% of its UK sales are under long-term contracts with automatic annual price changes based on factors such as the price of oil.

Mr Bonfield said that British gas prices had gone up by 12% although oil prices had risen by 65%.

At the operating level, BG's profits before exceptional items rose 108% to £688m. Stripping out the effect of the oil and gas price changes, the rise was 59%.

The bulk of the £358m increase in operating profit stemmed from its exploration and production activities, with £87m flowing from increased production and £163m from higher oil and gas prices.

The group's liquefied natural gas, transmission and distribution, and power generation operations all reported big profit rises.

Substantial extraordinary costs arising from the write-down of storage interests, a Northern Ireland electricity contract, and the demerger of Transco, the British pipeline business, were almost entirely offset by a £280m profit on the disposal of Dynegy, a US associate.

BG's exploration and appraisal drilling programme last year resulted in oil or gas finds from all wells, identifying "significant new reserves" in Kazakhstan, Bolivia, Britain, Egypt and the eastern Mediterranean.

These included the major Kashagan field in the Caspian sea, and reserves in Bolivia which, the group said, could provide the source of important new gas exports.

By the year end, proved or probable reserves amounted to more than 3bn barrels of oil equivalent - giving the group sufficient reserves for the next 30 years at the current rate of production.

During last year BG delivered the first gas from the Rosetta field, in offshore Egypt, and completed the second phase of Seabank power station near Bristol.

It has also won clearance from the Trinidad government to open up a new gas province by developing BG-operated fields off the north coast.

Striking it rich

Egypt 5

UK North Sea 3

Bolivia 2

Offshore Palestine 2

Kazakhstan 1

Israel 1

webTitle: Blavod hopes cult tipple will become City favourite

fields.headline: Blavod hopes cult tipple will become City favourite
fields.trailText: A craze for an unusual tipple reached the City yesterday with the £14m flotation of Blavod Black Vodka, a company which uses an Indian herb to produce opaque vodka.
fields.body:
A craze for an unusual tipple reached the City yesterday with the £14m flotation of Blavod Black Vodka, a company which uses an Indian herb to produce opaque vodka.

The Fulham-based firm's drink has attracted a cult following, particularly among clubbers. It is particularly popular when added to the energy drink Red Bull, to produce a mixture known as Black Bull.

Blavod sold more than a third of a million bottles of black vodka last year. Richard Ambler, its chief executive and former Diageo executive, said: "We've changed the colour of vodka without changing the taste. It adds a bit of fun to peoples' lives."

The concept was invented five years ago by marketing director Mark Dorman, an advertising executive who previously headed campaigns for Levi jeans. Mr Dorman was sipping vodka in a bar in California when a customer ordered a coffee. Inspiration struck when the barman asked: "Black or white?"

Early support came from the supermarket chain Tesco, which agreed to stock Blavod in selected stores. Then Baron Eric de Rothschild, the French financier, tried it and agreed to invest nearly £2m in the firm.

Mr Ambler said the appeal had become widespread. "It's great if you're sitting in a club but we also get middle-aged, middle-income housewives buying it - it's the sweet sherry syndrome."

webTitle: Notebook: Future of the post office

fields.headline: The stamp of not-so firm government
fields.standfirst:
Post offfice crisis is not addressed

More about the Post Office
fields.trailText: When sub-postmasters and sub-postmistresses are quitting in droves, it is sensible of the government to do something to encourage others to take their place. But the meagre package of measures announced yesterday by industry minister Alan Johnson will do little to stem the tide.
fields.body:
When sub-postmasters and sub-postmistresses are quitting in droves, it is sensible of the government to do something to encourage others to take their place. But the meagre package of measures announced yesterday by industry minister Alan Johnson will do little to stem the tide.

The main measures are a £2m fund to help community groups maintain or reopen about 200 post offices, and the abolition of the fee equivalent to 25% of first year earnings that new sub-postmasters had to pay the Post Office. These come at a time when post office closures during the past nine months have already outstripped last year's total of 382.

The government does not seem to realise that the problem is not becoming a subpostmaster, but staying one.

The decision to pay benefits directly into bank accounts from 2003 is expected to wipe out about 40% of post offices' earnings at a time when they are already struggling to remain solvent.

The Post Office's universal bank, if it ever starts, may restore some of the lost income. But by then it may be too late.

Most post offices are small businesses. Their owners are having to decide now whether to continue to invest in the business or get out.

The politicians who have created the mess have done little to help. The prime minister has promised to protect the post office network, trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers leaned on the banks to back the nebulous universal version, and now Mr Johnson has come up with a couple of million pounds and a few pious aspirations.

It is all too tempting to think that what the government has in mind is not the health of the post office network but votes in the forthcoming election.

Post office closures, especially in rural areas, are politically sensitive. Yesterday's "initiative" will enable Labour candidates to say that the government has done something. Voters should be aware that that something is in fact precious little.

Permutations

Having run a pools and bingo business for seventy years, the Zetter family were accused of being chumps a little over a year ago after selling their stake in the company bearing their name to a group of financial gamblers.

Paul Zetter, the 74-year-old chairman, who inherited the business from his father and who had sat on the board for more than 40 years, had previously conceded that the company was fighting a losing battle against larger competitiors and the national lottery.

The 38% holding fetched £3.6m, at 135p a share. A new investment-cum-management team included Jonathan Sparke, the founding managing director of spread-betting firm City Index, and Durlacher, the flash-in-the-pan internet investment bank. The idea was to develop an international online gaming business, and they looked pretty smart as the share price rocketted towards 400p in a matter of days. The Zetter family seemed to have missed out on an £8m jackpot.

A year on, the picture is rather different. In fact, yesterday the shares were back at the level the family sold at, following a "trading update" which knocked 50p or 27% off the quote.

Last summer the new management team bought a company called IFX as part of a plan to build "a sophisticated global trading, betting and gaming platform using the internet," which promises to provide everything from quotes on financial instruments to the outcome of a particular sporting event "in a fully regulated and secure environment".

While this gleaming cyber-punting future was under construction, IFX has been getting on with its relatively old-fashioned core business of market making in the currency markets.

Currency markets being the dangerous and volatile things they are, it now emerges that IFX has been caught with unhedged exposure to the soaraway euro, and Zetter's second half figures are going to be "substantially below market forecasts." Clearly, old man Zetter had not run out of sense. If you now own these shares, sell them.

Pitch battle

Rupert Murdoch once notably described sport as the "battering ram" to break into new markets for broadcasters. ONdigital's decision to turn its sports output into a premium channel may test that rule.

Football's Premiership, on which BSkyB has built its success, may convince fans to put their hands in their pockets, but will a cocktail of the Nationwide League, Worthington Cup, Champions' League and a sprinkling of second-tier tennis tournaments do the same? Right idea, but ONdigital will need to invest further in content to make any real impact.

webTitle: Bel Littlejohn never liked Peter Mandelson

fields.headline: I never liked that Mandy
fields.standfirst: Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: Good riddance, says I. I never trusted Peter Mandelson, never fell for his pernicious brand of spin, and when I heard that he had finally been given his comeuppance I literally whooped and punched the air with sheer, unadulterated joy.
fields.body:
Good riddance, says I. I never trusted Peter Mandelson, never fell for his pernicious brand of spin, and when I heard that he had finally been given his comeuppance I literally whooped and punched the air with sheer, unadulterated joy.

Unlike many of my more gullible colleagues, bless 'em, I was always wary of him, and never believed a word that he said. Why was I so clear sighted, when so many were blind? My friends would ascribe it to my integrity, my enemies, no doubt, to what they delight in describing as my razor-sharp intelligence. But the fact remains that, unlike all the others, I was always immune to his so-called "charms".

On holiday with him in 1994, and again in 1996, I always kept my distance. To assure my journalistic "independence", I would refuse to accept an incoming call from him if he was already in the same room as me. Similarly, if he had asked to write my political think-pieces for me, I would always have told him to take a running jump: it may come as a surprise to Mr Mandelson, but one soon loses one's reputation as a political commentator of seasoned integrity when you start letting those in power dictate their own thoughts under your own name.

Your needs must have a long spoon if you're going to sup with the devil, and I always made a point of letting him serve himself with his own Mediterranean mixed-leaf salad, unless it was strictly my turn. On the beach with him, I learnt never to trust what he said. I found myself weekending with him in Cornwall for research purposes in June 1998, when he offered me an expensive Cornetto, claiming that it would be "just what the doctor ordered".

Call it instinct, call it integrity (and - yes - some of us still do possess a fair measure of that vital asset, you know!) but I simply wasn't prepared to accept a free ice-cream from this man. To my horror, I was later to discover that, far from being medically recommended, a Cornetto is in fact full of calories, with a heavy ice-cream content, plus potentially debilitating wafers. Once again, I had cause to congratulate myself that I had seen through the man's evil underhand ploys.

I was, I like to think, the first to condemn this wicked man's slippery wiles. Nor was I ever taken in by his claims to genius. As long ago as 1996, I wrote a profile of Mandelson in the Observer ("New Labour's presiding genius" January 5 1996) in which I had the courage to point out one or two glaring character faults. "Beneath the charming and forceful exterior," I wrote - thus boldly indicating that he was a man who was not above using force to get his way - "lies a sensitive and highly intelligent man." By skilfully employing that charged word - "lies" - I became the first journalist to question his relaxed attitude to the truth.

I'm glad to say I never had lunch with the guy other than when strictly necessary, and then only between the hours of 12.30 and 3pm. Looking back, I always resented the way he would hand me the menu and ask me what I wanted to eat, and would I like something to drink, blah, blah: in other words, all the familiar ploys of deception we have come to recognise in monomaniacal control freaks. And at the end of the meal, he would sometimes motion his hand to his jacket pocket - a signal which I realise was now a covert means of "buying me lunch". Sorry, Peter - but I'm not so easily bought.

More alert than my colleagues (sorry, guys!) I could see through these insincere questions to the dark heart that lay within. I am proud to say I never liked him in the first place. I deplored the way that, when the two of us were alone together, he would listen to tittle-tattle for hours on end when he must have known full well that not only was it disloyal to the victims but that both of us had more important things to do. And as I inferred as recently as December of last year ("Brilliant Mandelson saves Northern Ireland"), I always regarded his competence as secretary of state as highly questionable.

We've all met his type in our workplace. They take a holier-than-thou position - but only when their victims cannot answer back. It is one of the less appealing characteristics of the Mandelson type that they kick people when they're down. The moment they see someone has fallen from grace and can be of no further use to them, they discard him. Then they dance on his grave, whooping and throwing their hands in the air - often claiming in the process that they never liked him in the first place. Believe me, it's not a pleasant sight.

Personally, I like to live in a country that regards lying as a resigning offence. In that way, politicians like Mandelson bring out the best in journalists like me, for he reminds us that without our integrity, we are nothing.

webTitle: Cuts in OECD aid condemn African poor

fields.headline: Cuts in OECD aid condemn African poor
fields.trailText: Rich western countries have helped condemn poor people in sub-Saharan Africa to poverty by deep cuts in official aid during the 1990s, the World Bank said yesterday.
fields.body:
Rich western countries have helped condemn poor people in sub-Saharan Africa to poverty by deep cuts in official aid during the 1990s, the World Bank said yesterday.

Despite mounting evidence of the effectiveness of development assistance, the Bank's latest figures showed that official aid from the wealthy states that make up the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) fell to $19 (£13) a head in 1998 from $32 a head in 1990.

"During the 1990s, aid to Africa became more focused on poor countries with reasonable policies and, as a result, it became more effective in reducing poverty. But this did not get through to OECD electorates," Paul Collier, research directorof the Bank's development economics department, said.

"OECD governments were cutting aid budgets to Africa during precisely the period when it started to work really well. Millions of Africans are in poverty today partly because of these cuts, which occurred at a time of unprecedented OECD prosperity."

The Bank released its figures on the eve of a joint visit to Africa by its president, James Wolfensohn, and the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, Horst Köhler.

The report found that growth in sub-Saharan Africa fell sharply in the aftermath of the global financial crisis of 1997-8, with per capita incomes falling by 1% in 1998-9.

While the Bank detected a rise in the standard of literacy and in the number of girls enrolling in school, the African development indicators revealed that 300m people on the continent were living on less than $0.65 a day, while in 24 countries per capita GNP was less than $350 (£240) a year.

It said the decline in aid was compounded by a drop in foreign direct investment (FDI), with both sources of external finance concentrated on a small number of countries.

FDI tended to reach those countries with "lucrative mining and oil industries", while aid flowed to those "with sound social and economic policies". Well over half of FDI went to Angola, Lesotho and Nigeria; Tanzania was the biggest beneficiary of aid, which dropped to $10.8bn (£7.4bn) by 1999 from a record $17.9bn in 1992.

The Bank said that sub-Saharan Africa had shown the smallest improvement of any region in the world in infant mortality since 1970: 151 out of 1,000 children died before the age of five.

Kenya, Zambia, Mozambique and Ivory Coast suffered from rising infant-mortality rates in the 1990s.

webTitle: Private lives: I've lost my hair after chemotherapy. My sister-in-law sent me scarves which I hate.

fields.headline: Private lives
fields.standfirst: I've lost my hair after chemotherapy. My sister-in-law sent me scarves which I hate. Now she's asking if I like them. What do I say?
fields.trailText: I've lost my hair after chemotherapy. My sister-in-law sent me scarves which I hate. Now she's asking if I like them. What do I say?
fields.body:
In November I was diagnosed with a malignant ovarian tumour and, following a hysterectomy, I am on chemotherapy. A side-effect is hair loss. I found this difficult, not being a hat or scarf sort of person, and avoided deciding what to do until the need arose. I discussed it with some close, supportive friends and family. My sister-in-law (my husband's brother's wife), with whom we have little intimate contact, sent me two headscarves with a note that this was an unbirthday present. I was devastated and reminded that something I was dreading was round the corner. The scarves were no doubt meant kindly, but I was left a weeping heap. She then emailed me to ask if I liked them. Do I tell her how I felt or lie to avoid offence? My hair has since fallen out rapidly. I have had my head shaved and been on a shopping expedition. But I have to reply to my sister-in-law.

Appreciate her actions

I can only begin to imagine the trauma you are going through, however it seems to me your sister-in-law is a very caring person and only meant to give you love and support in your time of need.

My father suffered with a brain tumour so I have a little understanding about coming to terms with cancer and its possible consequences. I was the weeping baby of our family while he went through the pain of his illness. My mother and sister expressed their emotions in diverse ways. We showed our concern, love and support very differently, but all were equally valid.

You say that you do not know your sister-in-law intimately, so she would not know the most appropriate way of expressing her care about you. Appreciate her actions and email her to thank her for her support, whether or not her gift was exactly right. Given this perspective you may find that you don't have to tell any lies.

Sue Harris, London

Forget her feelings

I have lost my hair three times; twice with alopecia, and once during chemotherapy for ovarian carcinoma. This time, it looks like being permanent, whereas your hair will, happily, regrow when you finish your treatment. But I do not seek to diminish the huge blow to well-being and self confidence that even temporary hair loss can cause, especially when it occurs as a result of treatment for a grave disease.

My advice is to forget your sister-in-law's feelings. You don't have to support her through her fear of cancer, for that is what has caused her to act like this. It is you that need empathetic support now. Reply politely, telling her that you are far too low and miserable to feel like trying on her scarves at the moment (if that is how you feel).

Name and address withheld

It's the same old you

I was diagnosed with ovarian cancer in early December. I had a part hysterectomy, and I am now undergoing chemotherapy. Most of my hair has gone. Like you, I dreaded the loss of my hair and expected tears. But when the time came, there were none. What helped me was that I felt I was still the same person. I am the same old me, hair or no hair. And I am sure that to your sister-in-law, you are still you, although temporarily without hair - and this she addressed in a practical way. Talk to her openly about your feelings, without hurting hers, and maybe you will become closer that way. Good luck.

Name and address withheld

Enjoy the opportunity

Why not tell her the truth? You can thank her for the present, explain that you have decided not to wear hats: as you say yourself, you are not a hat person. Your sister-in-law is simply trying to get close to you. Sometimes an illness sends ripples through a family and those concerned can find past relationships up for "reassessment". Don't read anything sinister into it. Enjoy this opportunity for a new email-pal.

Name and address withheld

You don't have to reply

You say you have to reply to your sister-in-law, but why bother? Your health and well-being is at the top of the agenda of everyone who loves you and should be at the top of your own. Do nothing you don't feel like doing. You sound like one tough cookie who can shave her head and then indulge in retail therapy. I think that's enviably courageous. Your facial features, now they've no hair to flop around and obscure them, will speak for themselves and will reveal a beauty and significance previously unglimpsed. Don't get weighed down by trivialities.

Celia Mason, Near Presteigne

Value your sister-in-law

A sickness as serious as this causes great upheaval, upset and, probably, sheer terror. It takes a great effort of will to see demonstrations of love for what they are. The kind giver cannot be you: she can only be a concerned bystander who is seeing very clearly what you, right now, cannot see - namely, your successful rehabilitation. Don't trip over paving stones that are not there: it won't do your health or your psyche any good. Phone your lovely sister-in-law right now and say how you value her and her kindness. Outrage both real and imagined is damaging and leads nowhere. Look only to the brightness that is coming.

Jeremy Davies, Anglesey

Next week

When I remarried three years ago my 12 year-old son (then my only child) chose to live with me and his stepmother. His mother was very upset but accepted his choice.

Three years on, my wife and I have just had a baby and my son is, at 15, going through a very rebellious phase, so much so that my wife thinks it would be better for him to go back to live with his mother as we need some peace.

But my former wife says she is not prepared to be "switched off and on". She has a boyfriend and intends to work in Germany for a year. She wants our son to spend his holidays with her there, but that's it. My wife accuses her of selfishly organising her life with no concern for her son but I don't think it is that simple.

In the meantime, to give everyone a breathing space, my son is staying with my parents who live near his school. They adore him but feel he should be with one of his parents. I want to do what is best for everyone, but it isn't easy. How can I best tackle this?

 Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies, giving an account of your personal experience, should reach us by Thursday. Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words. Write to Private Lives, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, fax 020-7239 9935, email private.lives@theguardian.com (please do not send attachments).

webTitle: Analysis: Working rights in developing countries

fields.headline: Cheap labour, ruined lives
fields.standfirst:
Attempts to enforce better working conditions in manufacturers in developing countries can backfire on the people they were meant to help

Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: Attempts to enforce better working conditions in manufacturers in developing countries can backfire on the people they were meant to help.
fields.body:
The Nicaraguan capital, Managua, recently witnessed a protest about globalisation - a protest with a difference. While thousands of activists were gathering in Porto Alegre in Brazil to call for a halt to free trade as promoted by the World Trade Organisation and similar bodies, Nicaraguan workers picketed the American embassy ... in favour of freer trade. They wanted an end to a campaign against sweatshops that has involved boycotting their products. Their livelihoods, they said, were under threat.

American human rights groups see Nicaraguan workers being employed in appalling conditions, making jeans for department stores such as Wal-Mart and JC Penney. An ill effect of globalised trade, they say. But the Nicaraguan workers say that while their conditions are not great, they would rather have the sales and the jobs they bring.

At issue is the attempt to enforce worldwide labour standards - the chart shows the International Labour Organisation's principles. Protest action along such lines helped derail attempts to launch a new round of trade talks in Seattle in 1999. Developing countries were dismayed when President Clinton arrived calling for such core labour standards to be incorporated into new agreements.

India and Mexico argued that putting such principles in WTO agreements is disguised protectionism - another excuse for rich countries to keep their markets closed to goods from the third world. Developing countries threatened to walk out, hastening the collapse of the talks.

Some economists argue that forcing poor countries to upgrade labour standards to first world levels is inappropriate. Jagdish Bhagwati says labour standards, unlike human rights, cannot be universalised. Instead they should reflect economic and cultural circumstances. Other economists say minimum standards are necessary to prevent workers being exploited. The question is what the minima should be and how they should be enforced.

Incorporating global labour standards into WTO agreements is likely to get short shrift from the new Bush administration, which is not exactly friendly to unions. But while official American enthusiasm for labour standards has waned, consumer and student protest, particularly at the use of sweated labour by sportswear manufacturers, has been growing.

But boycotts may do more harm than good. In 1993 American television broadcast pictures of Bangladeshi children making clothes for Wal-Mart. After a public outcry the store cancelled its contracts in Bangladesh and a senator proposed a bill to block imports of goods produced by child labour.

Faced with losing one of its biggest markets, the Bangladesh garment manufacturers' association announced it would eliminate the use of child labour within four months. Thousands of children were sacked, many of whom then found work in more dangerous industries. Few returned to school because their families simply could not afford it.

In the end the campaign against child labour in Bangladesh did have some positive results. Unicef, the United Nations children's agency, negotiated a voluntary code of standards with the factories and provided money to send some of the children back to school.

Yet the incident illustrates another weakness of using boycotts of exports to raise labour standards in the third world: workers in the export sector usually enjoy better conditions than the vast majority of other third world workers who earn their livelihoods in the informal sector where there are no employment rights or health and safety provisions.

In Nicaragua, the garment workers are getting paid well above the minimum wage. Many Bangladeshi women aspire to jobs in the Dhaka's clothing factories as an escape from rural poverty. Kevin Watkins of Oxfam says that a majority in the developing world are not working in the formal sector and they are not producing goods for export. "There is no case you can point at where sanctions have improved labour standards. It's about a labour aristocracy in the north protecting its jobs and conditions."

The National Labour Committee, a New York human rights group, which has brought a court case on behalf of Nicaraguan workers sacked by the Chentex jeans plant, agrees that boycotts are almost always counter-productive. It tells American companies not to drop sweatshop suppliers but to work for better conditions. Its approach has been to use the media to try to embarrass companies into putting pressure on their subsidiaries; it seems to have worked.

Non-government organisations in the UK prefer to take a behind-the-scenes approach rather than naming and shaming the companies sourcing goods from dubious third world factories. Working in partnership with companies and unions with money from the Department for International Development, such NGOs have helped develop an "ethical trading initiative". This is a voluntary code which sets standards for retailers buying goods from the third world. Abuses in factories approved under the initiative are usually addressed by the company concerned before they become public.

Voluntary codes may not satisfy the anti-globalisation lobby but they represent an approach workers in Managua who want to work might prefer.

 Charlotte Denny is the Guardian's economics reporter.

charlotte.denny@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Labour's spring double
fields.standfirst:
Inflation has fallen; unemployment too

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: The question Gordon Brown must be asking himself as he surveys this week's amazing economic indicators is: "Where on earth do we go from here?" If the election were to be fought on his handling of the economy, he could hardly have dreamed of better figures.
fields.body:
The question Gordon Brown must be asking himself as he surveys this week's amazing economic indicators is: "Where on earth do we go from here?" If the election were to be fought on his handling of the economy, he could hardly have dreamed of better figures. Unemployment - admittedly as measured by the controversial claimant count - is down to a 25-year low of 3.5% and the underlying rate of inflation at 1.8% is the lowest in Europe. If you add the rate of unemployment to the rate of inflation you get what economists call the "misery index". In the mid 1970s, when Labour was last in power and inflation was raging at over 20%, this index was over 30 points. It is now 5.3 points, at which level it to ought to be renamed the happiness index. Even the Daily Telegraph was moved yesterday to admit in a page one headline that "Things can't get any better for Blair".

In fact, things are not quite as good as they look. There is a record trade deficit that could spoil the party. But that does not detract from the extraordinary success of Mr Brown's economic policy. Unlike the Conservatives, whose policies were responsible for two unnecessarily sharp recessions in a decade, he steered the economy clear of the first downturn during his period in office. And he has a fighting chance of avoiding a recession - defined as two successive quarters of negative growth - this time too.

He has, of course, inherited an exceptionally favourable environment. Inflation has fallen all around the world as a result of globalisation (lower trade barriers enable people to buy from the cheapest source) and the effects of the digital revolution. The prices of computers, microchips and software have been falling in real terms for decades and now that they are moving into consumer goods and cars, the price falls follow them. At the same time the arrival of the internet, enabling shoppers to click around the globe for the cheapest prices, has provided a constant downward pressure on prices, even where companies think themselves immune from the effects of the net. Mr Brown has also been helped by some reforms of the Thatcher period, particularly in the labour markets where Labour has been conspicuously slow in unravelling them.

Where does he go now? There is only one way - to keep testing the limits of the new economy to see how far further unemployment can fall. On the International Labour Office's definition of unemployment (those looking for work and not just those claiming benefit) it is 1.56m rather than 1m. If you include others not in either definition (such as people with family responsibilities who would like to work, or some of those claiming long-term sickness benefit who could be working), the real total of unemployed people could be over 3m. This is not to deny that there are serious skill shortages in specialised areas. But in terms of continued economic growth, the existence of a submerged reservoir of unemployed could be a source of strength. During the 1950s and early 1960s it was the norm to have unemployment at under 500,000 or even below 300,000. Maybe recent high inflation was merely a delayed response to the explosion of oil prices during the 1970s. Why can't we get back to the unemployment rates of the post-war era? We won't know until we try, and, unless we try, we will never know. Gordon Brown should continue his gradualist policy of nudging unemployment down until it can realistically go down no further. The fall to below a million which is expected next month should be seen not as the end of the road but as a fresh start.

fields.headline: Yahoo's Europe MD quits in frustration
fields.standfirst:
Yahoo
More net news
fields.trailText: Fabiola Arredondo, the second most powerful businesswoman in Europe according to Fortune magazine, has stepped down as managing director of the European arm of the US-based internet portal, Yahoo!
fields.body:
Fabiola Arredondo, the second most powerful businesswoman in Europe according to Fortune magazine, has stepped down as managing director of the European arm of the US-based internet portal, Yahoo!

A spokeswoman for the company said that Ms Arredondo had decided to leave Yahoo! where she has worked since 1997, "to pursue private business interests".

Ms Arredondo is thought to have been frustrated by the level of commitment to international expansion.

In October last year, she told reporters that Yahoo's expansion into the rapidly growing European market had been restricted by profit targets set by US executives and Wall Street.

Referring to the European operation, she said: "We have a challenge as an organisation because we are consolidated into the USA. My flexibility can be constrained and ... we may be limited in our ability to invest in the business as strongly as we would like."

Ms Arredondo said in a statement yesterday: "I am proud to have been part of a team that has built one of the leading internet companies in Europe." Jeff Mallett, president and chief operating officer, praised Ms Arredondo's leadership.

In Fortune magazine's October edition last year, Ms Arredondo took second place to Pearson's Marjorie Scardino in a ranking of Europe's most powerful businesswomen.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.body:
In a report headed Soft touch for Uncle Sam's envoy, page 11, yesterday, we may have given the impression that William Farish's appointment as US ambassador in London had been confirmed. It has not. Apologies to Mr Farish for making him Mr Furnish a couple of times later in the report. At one point we referred to "seven US state departments". There is, of course, only one.
In a report headed Unions snub job plan for Wales, page 28, Finance, yesterday, we gave the wrong figures in our summary of EXi telecoms' financial performance. We mistakenly quoted those for 1997. fields.headline: It's a cull
fields.trailText: Call me paranoid if you like, but does the scheme to "allow" us to work beyond 65 not have ulterior motives (Able but wasted, Leader, February 15)?
fields.body:
Call me paranoid if you like, but does the scheme to "allow" us to work beyond 65 not have ulterior motives (Able but wasted, Leader, February 15)? If you consider retirement statistics for doctors - retire at 60, live till 72; retire at 65, pop your clogs by 69 - the scheme seems to be more a matter of a cunning plan to cull the number of people collecting pensions without resorting to cyanide.
Tim Webb
Denbigh, Clwyd
Tim.Webb@cd-tr.wales.nhs.uk

fields.headline: Be quick
fields.trailText: If Jonathan Freedland wants to start renationalising he had better be quick (Comment, February 14). Negotiations start next month at the WTO on the general agreement on trade in services.
fields.body:
If Jonathan Freedland wants to start renationalising he had better be quick (Comment, February 14). Negotiations start next month at the WTO on the general agreement on trade in services. This free trade agreement locks in place the privatisation and deregulation of public services, making them effectively irreversible. It has been heavily lobbied for by many of the same companies that have filled their pockets while failing to deliver adequate essential services. Freedland will find the grip of multinational companies on these services difficult to release while the UK government is committed to an agreement that the EU boasts is "an instrument for the benefit of business".
Barry Coates
World Development Movement
barry.coates@wdm.org.uk

fields.headline: Electing a new system
fields.trailText: Polly Toynbee does a disservice to the cause of electoral reform (Labour is simply going to guarantee a Tory comeback, February 14) by implying that its major benefits are a realignment of the centre-left and the consignment of the Conservatives to permanent opposition.
fields.body:
Polly Toynbee does a disservice to the cause of electoral reform (Labour is simply going to guarantee a Tory comeback, February 14) by implying that its major benefits are a realignment of the centre-left and the consignment of the Conservatives to permanent opposition. The real argument for a change in the current voting system is that it is demonstrably unfair and undemocratic. Those of us campaigning for the Labour party to maintain its commitment to reform do so out of principle rather than political expediency or a belief that we can predict long-term political trends in a crystal ball.
Phil Woodford
Labour prospective candidate, Kingston and Surbiton

 I was surprised to read (Voters back referendum on electoral reform, February 14) that voters overwhelmingly want a referendum on PR. ICM provided me with the polling data which showed that there was indeed an overwhelming result. A whopping 80% of respondents said the issue would not make the slightest difference to the way they voted and 78% said Tony Blair would not go down in their estimation if he dropped the pledge to hold a referendum.
Tom Watson
First Past the Post

 Why does Polly Toynbee believe the Lib Dems would always put Labour in at Westminster? They don't in local government. One thing is sure, whether it is a Labour or Tory-dominated government, they will always be in government with less than one-fifth of the popular vote.
John Lodge
Lancaster

webTitle: Letters: Oliver James responds over Mandelson comments

fields.headline: Allow me to have my say
fields.trailText: I would love to know what prompted you to pay Henry Porter to administer his kicking to me (What's Up Doc, February 15) for daring to comment about Peter Mandelson.
fields.body:
I would love to know what prompted you to pay Henry Porter to administer his kicking to me (What's Up Doc, February 15) for daring to comment about Peter Mandelson. Every day your columnists make dozens of speculations about the motives and intentions of public figures (Henry Porter's dubious piece about Auberon Waugh being a prime example). You recently published a fascinating, if potentially homophobic, analysis of the possible association between gay "barebacking" and Mandelson's risk-taking. Whenever I am criticised for using my knowledge of psychology to speculate about public figures, I cannot understand why the same does not go for analyses by journalists. Why is it unethical for me to do so and not for Henry Porter?

In the case of Mandelson, I spent an hour and a half interviewing him about his psychology for television with his full cooperation, more than enough time for a professional to form a judgment about a person's psychopathology. As it happens, I have also met and talked with him in some detail subsequently on several occasions, but Henry Porter did not bother to contact me so he could not have known this (I could also have told him that I am not a doctor). In the end, what I was saying anyway bordered on the obvious. Who would not feel suicidal and depressed on bringing such a sadly abrupt end to their career and why is it unacceptable for me to say so, but alright for Henry Porter?
Oliver James
London
oj@ziggie.demon.co.uk

fields.headline: Bog off
fields.trailText: Surely the prime minister would wish comprehensive schools to be "bog standard" (Letters, February 14)? In the construction industry from the late 19th century to 1950, the normal standard for engineering steel was "British or German" - the foremost industrial nations - hence BoG.
fields.body:
Surely the prime minister would wish comprehensive schools to be "bog standard" (Letters, February 14)? In the construction industry from the late 19th century to 1950, the normal standard for engineering steel was "British or German" - the foremost industrial nations - hence BoG. It is, therefore, correct to refer to "bog standard" as opposed to "boxed standard".
Tom Boulding, David Bagnall
Sheffield

webTitle: Business: Iceland comes out of the cold

fields.headline: Iceland comes out of the cold
fields.trailText: Mum may not be going to Iceland anymore but someone is and they have been passing through the checkout with trolley loads of its battered stock in the past few sessions. Market professionals are pointing the finger of suspicion at Rewe, Germany's largest food retailer.
fields.body:
 Mum may not be going to Iceland anymore but someone is and they have been passing through the checkout with trolley loads of its battered stock in the past few sessions.

Market professionals are pointing the finger of suspicion at Rewe, Germany's largest food retailer.

On Wednesday, about 3% of Iceland's issued share capital changed hands, with dealers noting a series of large block trades executed by a top City broking house, said in some circles to be ABN Amro, one of Iceland's brokers.

According to the gossips, the mystery broker had matched the seller, one of Iceland's large institutional investors, possibly Putnam or Legal & General, with the buyer, Rewe.

Apart from operating 11,600 grocery stores throughout Europe, Rewe is probably best remembered in the Square Mile for selling its 28% stake in Budgens, the convenience stores group, to Ireland's largest wholesale food distributor, Musgrave, in August last year.

If the speculation is to be believed Rewe has acquired 2% of the frozen food retailer. Apparently it views the stake as an investment and not, as the wilder sections of the market were claiming yesterday, as a platform for a takeover.

Shareholders, who have watched the value of their investment drop from 339p at the time of chairman Malcolm Walker's share sale in December to 149p and following Iceland's second profits warning at the end of January, may find this difficult to believe.

Nonetheless, many traders think Iceland's second alert, delivered by new chief executive Bill Grimsey, was overtly pessimistic. They believe Iceland could surprise when it delivers preliminary figures in March. Iceland shares ended 19.5p higher at 162.5p, with sources close to the company attributing the gains to institutional buying.

The day of respite for Iceland came as the FTSE 100 index received some comfort from a mini-revival in the battered telecoms sector.

 The biggest stock on the market, Vodafone, gained 5.75p to 216.25p after suffering a bout of negative sentiment brought on by the flotation of France Télécom's Orange.

The better performance from Vodafone helped to ensure a positive day for the FTSE 100 index, which ended 21.7 points higher at 6,197.9.

Orange, after a far from prestigious market debut, managed to put on 14p to 573p although was still under water as far the major institutions were concerned. Telewest, another telecoms stock, was the biggest FTSE 100 gainer of the day, ending at 139.5p, up 12.25p.

 Logistics group Exel was also among the day's buoyant stocks, having another good session, rising 24p to 982p. Dealers said the stock was still benefiting from Wednesday's upgrade from HSBC Securities, although they noted market tittle-tattle about an offer from the other side of the Atlantic.

 Another firm helped by takeover speculation was hotels group Hilton which added 2p to 235p, as Bass's name was again linked to the group. As far as anyone can tell such talk seems to be based squarely on the fact that Bass is cash rich following the sale of its pub division to Belgian brewer Interbrew.

 Barclays rose to a high of £23.45 before ending at £23.30, up 14p. Ahead of its 2000 profits to be released this morning Lloyds TSB gained 2p to 713p as the City waited for news on its bid for Abbey National, steady at £12.30.

 BBA slipped 10.5p to 637p, despite supposedly well-sourced talk that the aviation and materials technology group, which loses its widely admired chief executive Roberto Quarta in March, is working on a break-up plan.

fields.headline: On reducing obesity
fields.trailText: I am overweight, albeit not excessively, but conscious that I need to lose weight to fit the profile of Mr Perfect Citizen (Action urged to cut the fat of the land, February 15).
fields.body:
I am overweight, albeit not excessively, but conscious that I need to lose weight to fit the profile of Mr Perfect Citizen (Action urged to cut the fat of the land, February 15). I have tried many avenues to reduce my size and exercise regularly, but weigh around the same at each spot check. The doctor tells me there is medication available to remove appetite and force the body to consume its fat more effectively, but it's not available unless the patient is deemed to be dangerously overweight and a potential health problem is imminent.

I know intimately the misery associated with overweight. Silly things like tying shoelaces, getting through narrow turnstiles and an endless list of taunts and snide remarks. Even so, I haven't had the need to visit a doctor for ill health for three years. Most overweight people would gladly take a course of medication if they could lose weight. So stop scorning us and order GPs to prescribe medication now, not when we are dying from heart attacks or hanging from the end of an electrical flex.
S Bridger
Southampton
SBridger@ndsuk.com

 We must not allow this epidemic, one of the most serious public health problems facing the developed, world to be medicalised. Obesity is not unnatural in our society. It is the natural adaptation by our bodies to the warped environment in which we live. If we wish to create a healthier society, then we must change our environment and that involves making policy decisions on behalf of the people and not just on behalf of corporations.

The horror in this is the accelerating rates of childhood obesity. This week's British Medical Journal reports a 70% increase in obesity in four-year-old children between 1989 and 1999. We are seeing type 2 obesity in our young children as a result. We now run the real risk of following the US, where some 30% of 10-year-olds have developed this form of diabetes.

Child's play is the misunderstood and much maligned jewel of childhood. We need a greater understanding of the central role play provides in our children's physical and emotional development. Spontaneous play in streets and play areas near where children live should be a priority. This spontaneous play is the key to preventing obesity in children and, because children become adults, the key in adult obesity as well.

Numerous surveys show that what prevents children playing is not their sloth or computer addiction but the very real threat from speeding vehicles. Our streets are child-unfriendly linear car parks with race tracks down the middle. Measures such as a blanket urban speed ban of 20mph are now vital if we are to help save our future.
Dr Colin Guthrie
Glasgow
grey_triker@hotmail.com

 A 20mph speed limit in built-up areas, to make streets safe for walking and cycling, would have the additional health benefit of at least halving the road casualties that (the charity Roadpeace calculates) take up 26% of NHS budgets.
Judith Hanna
London
jehanna@gn.apc.org

 From the basic statistics, the UK is a quarter of a million tonnes overweight - a pyramid covering a hectare and 50m high. Rendered down it would be well over 1m barrels, worth £200m on the garage forecourt. This reserve could power our bikes. That is a lot of journeys to and from work, school or the shops. Will we ever get an integrated transport policy that takes in the health implications?
Andy Brown
Cambridge
andy.brown@carltd.com

fields.headline: At this price?
fields.standfirst: Brown & Jackson
fields.trailText: Brown & Jackson
fields.body:
Discounter Brown & Jackson yesterday reported a big dip in profits but insisted it is pressing on with expansion plans. The company, which had warned of the profits slump before Christmas, operates more than 700 stores under four brands: Poundstretcher, What Everyone Wants, Your More Store and The Famous Brunswick Warehouse. All performed dismally in the six months to the end of December.

At What Everyone Wants, which has 127 outlets, operating profits collapsed by 74% as margins were squeezed. Profits dived 45% at the 124-strong Your More Store, and Poundstretcher's slumped by 22%. The Brunswick chain was "below expectations".

Overall group profits were down 33% at £20.8m and the shares, which 15 months ago were changing hands at 220p, closed up 8p at 64p.

Chief executive Johann Visser said: "Our profits have dropped reasonably heavily, but we must take into consideration that we are going through one of our worst trading periods in a long time.

"We had a horrible summer and then the petrol crisis and then C&A hit the discount market with prices that even we could not do."

B&J had a plan to improve performance, based on interviews with customers and other shoppers. "They want decent service. They don't want to queue and they want branded merchandise at great prices. We are going to open the aisles to show them the products."

The group's town centre stores are performing worse than those on retail parks: "It is not going well on the high street. But we are there and we are staying there". He did not intend to scale back B&J's expansion plan because discount retailing "has only just begun in the UK".

Like-for-like sales were down 2.2% in the first five weeks but Mr Visser said he believed they would be back in positive territory by the end of the financial year. "There is a fight on", he said. Investors should not leap into the ring just yet.

Overall group profits were down 33% at £20.8m and the shares, which 15 months ago were changing hands at 220p, closed up 8p at 64p. Chief executive Johann Visser said: "Our profits have dropped reasonably heavily, but we must take into consideration that we are going through one of our worst trading periods in a long time. "We had a horrible summer and then the petrol crisis and then C&A hit the discount market with prices that even we could not do." B&J had a plan to improve performance, based on interviews with customers and other shoppers. "They want decent service. They don't want to queue and they want branded merchandise at great prices. We are going to open the aisles to show them the products." The group's town centre stores are performing worse than those on retail parks: "It is not going well on the high street. But we are there and we are staying there". He did not intend to scale back B&J's expansion plan because discount retailing "has only just begun in the UK". Like-for-like sales were down 2.2% in the first five weeks but Mr Visser said he believed they would be back in positive territory by the end of the financial year. "There is a fight on", he said. Investors should not leap into the ring just yet.

webTitle: Stagecoach favourite for London to west country franchise

fields.headline: Stagecoach on inside track
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Brian Souter's rail subsidiary, South West Trains, last night emerged as favourite for a 20-year, £3.5bn franchise to run the route between London and the west country, which serves heavily populated areas.
fields.body:
Brian Souter's rail subsidiary, South West Trains, last night emerged as favourite for a 20-year, £3.5bn franchise to run the route between London and the west country, which serves heavily populated areas.

Mr Souter, chairman of Stagecoach, one of Britain's largest bus and train companies, is expected to be awarded a new franchise by the strategic rail authority in the next few weeks.

The SRA, publicly embarrassed by its indecision over a new franchise for the east coast main line, is under pressure from John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, to announce some good news before the election is called.

SWT has been running the franchise for the past four years and early on almost brought the service to a standstill when it sacked 76 drivers.

Its operates 1,700 trains each day from Waterloo in central London, and has considerably more experience than its rivals for the franchise, Great North Eastern Railway and Great Western Trains, both long-distance operators.

GWT bears some responsibility for the Southall rail crash three years ago after being found guilty of failing to operate adequate safety equipment.

SWT has impressed the SRA by its straightforward approach to the bidding process. It has promised that by August next year it will start replenishing its fleet with 1,200 new coaches, built by Siemens, the company responsible for the Heathrow Express.

The repercussions from the SRA's decision to halt the bidding process for the east coast main line, where GNER and Stagecoach/Virgin Trains are competing, could be considerable.

The government is angry at the way the issue has been handled by Mike Grant, the SRA's franchise director and chief lieutenant to Sir Alastair Morton, the body's chairman. His position was said by industry sources last night to be under threat.

Neither the government nor the SRA can agree on who should be awarded the east coast franchise. They have sought to avoid possible legal action from the bidders by blaming Railtrack for overestimating the cost of modernising the route.

Nick Pollard, Railtrack's director of network development, said it was only carrying out a feasibility study in close consultation with the SRA.

"We are stunned that we are being blamed. We have held regular meetings with the SRA, who know all the facts. The cost of the scheme has not doubled. We are offering the SRA and the train operators a range of options from £1.9bn to £2.4bn and they can be tailored to whatever the customer wants."

To date the SRA has managed to negotiate only two franchises, Chiltern and South Central, the London commuter franchise operated by Connex.

fields.headline: Inchcape targeted
fields.trailText: Inchcape, the motor dealer, has become the latest target for Guinness Peat, the New Zealand-controlled investment firm that specialises in stirring up trouble.
fields.body:
Inchcape, the motor dealer, has become the latest target for Guinness Peat, the New Zealand-controlled investment firm that specialises in stirring up trouble.

Guinness Peat, which has a 16% stake in Inchcape, has written to chairman Sir John Egan demanding a complete break-up of the company, claiming a sale of assets could raise 500p a share.

Inchcape has already been through a £600m disposal programme, offloading businesses involved in bottling, distribution and financial services in order to concentrate on cars.

Guinness Peat reckons there is little logic in having an international network of motor dealers, which it dubs a "legacy of a bygone colonial era".

Inchcape's shares edged up 2.5p to 327.5p, although Guinness Peat's record has been patchy recently and defeat is likely at today's annual general meeting of hotels firm De Vere.

webTitle: Views divided on Lloyd-Webber's new musical

fields.headline: Divided views on composer
fields.trailText: There are times when it is possible to feel sorry for Andrew Lloyd-Webber. All his life the composer of Cats and Phantom of the Opera has been ridiculed by the critics. So last night when his tormentors pronounced The Beautiful Game the musical of the year, he was entitled to feel a little triumphant.
fields.body:
There are times when it is possible to feel sorry for Andrew Lloyd-Webber. All his life the composer of Cats and Phantom of the Opera has been ridiculed by the critics.

So last night when his tormentors in the Critics Circle relented and pronounced The Beautiful Game the musical of the year, he was entitled to feel a little triumphant.

There was, however, a sting in the tail. For while the press were won over by the story of love across the Ulster barricades - penned with Ben Elton - the public who have flocked to his musicals down the years turned on him.

Only 3% in a poll of 6,500 West End theatregoers thought the musical worthy of the award, while 56% went for the Donmar Warehouse's production of Stephen Sondheim's Merrily We Roll Along. The Beautiful Game came last in the category behind The Witches Of Eastwick and Fosse.

The critics' choice of Sir Michael Gambon as best actor in The Caretaker was also given short shrift by the public, who voted heavily for Conleth Hill, one of the two stars of Stones In Their Pockets. His co-star Sean Campion is also riding high in the internet poll, conducted by Whatsonstage.com, which culminates with the Olivier Awards at the end of the month.

For best play, the critics chose Joe Penhall's Blue/Orange, while the punters preferred Frank McGuinness's Dolly West's Kitchen, staged at the Old Vic.

fields.headline: Amstrad's digits squeezed
fields.standfirst:
Key board statement

More net news
fields.trailText: Sir Alan Sugar yesterday said an 82% drop in Amstrad's six-month profits was caused, in part, by a drying up of sales of set-top boxes for digital television.
fields.body:
Sir Alan Sugar yesterday said an 82% drop in Amstrad's six-month profits was caused, in part, by a drying up of sales of set-top boxes for digital television. But profits were also hit by the start-up costs of Amstrad's email-enabled telephone, pictured, by delays in the development of the company's low-cost mobile phone handset business, and competition in the television and audio goods market.

Yesterday shares in Amstrad - 29.8% of which are owned by Sir Alan as chairman - fell 9.47% to close at 110p. Howard Brooks, an analyst at house broker Beeson Gregory, said that pre-tax profits of £1.5m for the six months to January - compared with £8.2m in 1999 - were in line with his expectations, which had been lowered following the profits warning in November last year.

Mr Brooks forecast that full-year profits would be £4.9m, with profits of £2.5m for the year to July 2000.

The low cost mobile phone handset business, which has been in development for about 12 months, is now six months behind schedule.
