webTitle: Opposition loner is thorn in flesh of South African government

fields.headline: Opposition loner is thorn in flesh of South African government
fields.trailText: Not so long ago Patricia de Lille was chanting "one settler, one bullet" with the rest of the Pan Africanist Congress. Now the white "settlers" who once lived in fear of South Africa's most controversial MP are among her biggest fans as she is hailed as an unlikely champion of the country's new found liberties.
fields.body:
Not so long ago Patricia de Lille was chanting "one settler, one bullet" with the rest of the Pan Africanist Congress. Now the white "settlers" who once lived in fear of South Africa's most controversial MP are among her biggest fans as she is hailed as an unlikely champion of the country's new found liberties.

She is leading the call for an investigation into alleged corruption in South Africa's purchase of weapons costing £4bn from British and other European manufacturers.

She says she has good evidence of high level graft, and wants the inquiry to be led by Judge Willem Heath, the country's most powerful investigator. The government has rejected the demand, and set about vilifying Judge Heath and Ms de Lille.

"They say I'm mad. You can't imagine the insults I've had to endure since I started exposing this arms deal," she said

"It's painful for me because they want to create the perception I'm out to embarrass the country and I'm unpatriotic. And when that doesn't work they say, 'Oh, Patricia de Lille, she's just mad'."

Ms de Lille, who will be 50 tomorrow, is the PAC's chief whip in parliament. But as the party has only three MPs, she is more a lone guerrilla politician, driven by what she describes as the African National Congress government's betrayal of its promises to the poor.

The role comes at a price. Since stirring up the arms controversy, she has become convinced, not without reason, that she is being monitored and bugged.

A spokesman in President Thabo Mbeki's office gave the game away last month when he said the government had "intercepted" a letter she had faxed to Judge Heath.

Having a conversation in Ms de Lille's parliamentary office means competing with a speaker blaring the soundtrack to Power Rangers: an attempt to prevent others listening.

"I received six death threats in three days. The voice said: 'You must stop or we will kill you.' Why say we if it's just one individual? I think there is an organisation behind this," she said. "I've got a gun but I've never fired a bullet in my life. I've never pulled the trigger. I'm shit scared of a gun."

Ms de Lille joined the black consciousness PAC in 1976, when it was still banned, and agitated against apartheid as vice-president of the national council of trade unions.

At that time she was all for violent revolution and expelling the whites.

"After Mandela was released, the radical group in our party still wanted to go with one settler, one bullet. The other group said we must negotiate, because they realised we could not shoot our way to power. I have a very big mouth and every time our delegation came back I was criticising them for making too many concessions.

"They said, 'Since you are so critical, go and do it yourself.' It was one hell of an experience. It slowly grew on you that you had to negotiate."

Elected as an MP six years ago in South Africa's first all-races elections, she soon fell out with the government. In 1997 she read out in parliament the names of ANC MPs she alleged had spied for the apartheid regime. The ANC tried to suspend her from parliament, but she won a high court judgement that the government party had overstepped its powers.

Ms de Lille finds herself better treated by the white rightwingers who occupy the Freedom Front offices a few doors from her own.

"Only one ANC MP actually greeted me," she said after the opening of parliament last week. "The moment they see me ... they all look at the ceiling or suddenly have to talk on the cell phone."

fields.headline: Police armourer arrested over guns
fields.standfirst: Special report: gun violence in Britain
fields.trailText: The official armourer for the Norfolk and Suffolk police forces has been arrested and a substantial cache of weapons seized in a raid at his home, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
The official armourer for the Norfolk and Suffolk police forces has been arrested and a substantial cache of weapons seized in a raid at his home, it emerged yesterday.

Police confirmed yesterday that Richard Ashley, 55, of Pakenham, Suffolk, was arrested on suspicion of various firearms offences.

It is understood that officers found an array of weapons at his cottage, including rocket launchers, machine guns and assault rifles.

Detectives are trying to establish whether he had proper licences for the weapons, which are believed to have come from eastern Europe, and where they were intended to be sold.

Mr Ashley is a registered arms dealer who supplies and maintains weapons for both police forces.

He was questioned following an investigation which involved Suffolk police, Interpol and customs, and was released on police bail.

A source said: "A substantial amount of arms have been recovered. Mr Ashley is a registered arms dealer, so it is not entirely surprising we found weapons at his house. The investigation is ongoing."

An official statement said: "Suffolk constabulary arrested a 55-year-old man at his home in Pakenham, north east of Bury St Edmunds, on Wednesday, February 14. The man was questioned about possible firearms offences. He has been released on police bail pending further inquiries to return to Bury St Edmunds police station on Monday April 16."

webTitle: TV review: The truth is we prefer Scully

fields.headline: The truth is we prefer Scully
fields.trailText: The X-Files | Bedroom Confidential | Danger! Unexploded Bomb
fields.body:
Hurray! After eight years of looking out there for the Truth, Moany Fox Mulder has finally found it. Or rather, it found him. At the end of the last series of The X-Files (Sky One) after years of "My sister was taken away in a flash of light" and "There are shadowy multi-national organisations doing all sorts" and "Armageddon is coming - and not in a good way", he was abducted by aliens. But is Mr Self-Obsessed happy? He certainly is not.

Now that he is aboard a shimmering spaceship, all he can do is whine and shout for Scully. Admittedly, he is stark naked in what looks like a chilly room and he is being experimented on with big drills and scary pizza cutter implements but really, you should be careful what you wish for, shouldn't you? Well, mister, she can't help you now. They've got you and your little dog, so to speak.

And who are They anyway? Aside from only dealing with the self-centred - remember They were involved with Mimi Rogers - they aren't what you would call very sophisticated. Still doing experiments on humans with big metal probes, clearly They haven't seen Star Trek, where it's all done with lights and whooshing sounds. And are more experiments really necessary anyway? Surely if They had a hand in the evolution of humanity and They can build ships which travel at light speed and They can shapeshift into whomever they want, by now They should have established how we work. It can't be that difficult. Evidently, we have been invaded by the stupidest aliens in the galaxy. Pah.

Still, Scully is trying to help, bless her. Now that she is finally being given some room to breathe and develop as a character - as opposed to simply saying, "I'm sure there is a rational explanation for this", as a woman gives birth to snakes or a stretchy liver-eating man attacks her through the air conditioning - Scully is blooming. With Mulder out of the way, she is the radiant crusader to new partner John Doggett's sceptic. While not remotely as narcissistic or as annoyingly smug as Mulder, she has taken on his mantle and his quest. In doing so, she has gained confidence and gravity. In the stonking debut of the eighth series, The X-Files has - at last - become Gillian Anderson's show. Not before time.

It may even have become Dana Scully's show too. For a start, she is pregnant. Supposedly infertile after her abduction experiences some years back, Scully seems as confused as the rest of us with this development, and is yet to reveal whether she got pregnant by Mulder or through some immaculate conception. The latter being the case, Scully as some sort of Madonna is a great idea. As a scientist with a deep religious faith, such a plot is as ripe as a ripe thing, especially when you consider how her maternal instincts have been explored over the last few years. And who wouldn't want Gillian Anderson to be the birth of a new saviour? In short, hail Mary. Well, that's what I want to believe (though there may be a rational explanation for it all).

Bedroom Confidential (Channel 5) and Danger! Unexploded Bomb (Channel 4) both made me wince. The former because the story of table/pole/ lap/whatever dancer Ann Marie and her errant husband Lee showed just how excruciatingly dumb people can be, and the latter because it was all about 22-year-olds defusing bombs. Luckily, they were doing so during the second world war, so they weren't quite as hopeless as today's 22-year-olds, whom I can't imagine wiring a plug successfully, let alone unquestioningly laying down their life for King and country. I don't know if this is a bad thing or not.

Whatever, 60 years on, these brave blokes were alive to tell their tales, even if some colleagues were not. Wrinkles and wet eyes telling of lives unimaginable, they talked of digging bombs out of muddy pits, transporting them across London and detonating them on Hackney Marshes. As you do. Some smiled while others bowed their heads as they talked of bombs smashing through cots. (Hope you never have reason to say the words, "I picked up what I could of this baby and put it in the pillowcase.") Proof, perhaps, that They don't make them like they used to.

Disarming bombs is a lot like love. In theory, it's simple. It's the practice that's the bugger.

Films

City Slickers (Ron Underwood, 1991) 8pm, FilmFour
Likeable comedy with a trio of easy living, middle-aged, middle-class men moseying westwards to rediscover themselves on a cattle-drive holiday: plenty of horse-laughs, and thoughtful on the pressures of urban life. Billy Crystal, Daniel Stern and Bruno Kirby are the slickers who learn what a man's gotta do, but star of the show is tough-as-boots trail boss Jack Palance, who won an Oscar.

The Negotiator (F Gary Gray, 1998) 10.10pm, Sky Premier
Samuel L Jackson's ace hostage negotiator is framed for murder and embezzlement; he reacts by taking his main accuser (JT Walsh) and a bunch of admin staff hostage, demanding that a negotiator from another district (Kevin Spacey) investigates the crisis. The pair are soon working together to root out top-level corruption. The face-off between two of US cinema's most charismatic leads provides Gray's clever drama with a powerful charge; it's a pity, though, that the pair share so little time on screen.

After Hours (Martin Scorsese, 1985) 9pm, TCM
An eery comedy, with Griffin Dunne's computer whizz Paul Hackett stumbling into that insane twilight zone which it seems awaits all unwary yuppies (Bonfire Of The Vanities, Something Wild and all). Trapped in a menacing Manhattan after a weird date with Rosanna Arquette's Marcy (he was asking for trouble), the question is, can he make it through the night?

Possession (Andrzej Zulawski, 1981) 12.30am, FilmFour
Isabelle Adjani and Sam Neill are serious actors, but if you come to this expecting a scarily cerebral horror story in the style of Zulawski's countryman Polanski, you'll be disappointed. However, if you fancy a deranged Friday-night shlocker involving a desperately dysfunctional couple, Adjani in the arms (well, tentacles really) of a loathsome alien lover, plus buckets of blood and God-knows-what, well, look no further ...

The Apostle (Robert Duvall, 1997) 2.30am, Sky Premier Thirteen years in the making, Duvall's labour of love is the story of Pentecostal preacher Sonny Dewey, on the road to salvation after hitting his wife's lover with a baseball bat. Hitting the road too, he winds up in a poor Louisiana backwater where he sets up his own church. It's an ideal role for the fine character actor Duvall: a man whose belief is shot through with regret, occasional rage and high-energy showmanship.

Sport

Live Nordic Combined Skiing 9am, 1pm, 3.30pm, British Eurosport
Those world championships just keep on coming. This week it's Nordic combined skiing, a gruelling mix of jumping and cross-country, live from Lahti in Finland. There is a range of both team and individual medals to be won, with the hosts favourites for the former - if they can hold off a strong challenge from Japan - and World Cup leader Adam Malaysz of Poland the top tip for today's individual jump, ahead of Finland's Janne Ahonen.

webTitle: Radio review: The art of conversation

fields.headline: Radio review
fields.standfirst: The art of conversation
fields.trailText: Midweek | The Mancunian Way | Today
fields.body:
What Ruby Wax tries to engender on those let's-have-dinner-in-a-studio efforts, Libby Purves pulls off most Wednesday mornings. I don't know what they lace the buns with at Midweek (Radio 4), but listening regularly feels like staggering into a stranger's dinner party where much wine and maybe some Pro-Plus have been enjoyed. The guests reveal all about themselves and don't stop because you've walked in.

Twiggy was on this week, and loudly. Her father was deaf, "so I grew up having to shout", she bellowed. Barrie Rutter, artistic director at Northern Broadsides, yelled too, and in cantankerous fashion. This doesn't mean he's not sensitive - Rutter left his boxing club to join a church choir as a youngster. "They knocked seven bells out of me", he said, lip-smackingly, as if it was the best thing that ever happened to him.

Most strange, though, was Alison Oddey, a woman who lives up to her surname. Her latest performance piece, What Shall I Do With My Amstrad?, explores "what it means to be an academic" (what it means is that you still use an Amstrad). "Basically," she began, though there is nothing basic about what follows, "I smashed it up and placed parts of it over my body. I ripped up some floppy disks and placed them on my breasts; the smaller disks were nipple protectors." The question "from what?" hung in the air. Twiggy was beside herself, forming a small branch.

No such surreality on The Mancunian Way (Radio 2), Mark Radcliffe's new series on the history of Manchester music, another seriously fine music documentary on the station despite the slightly stiff format.

Seemingly everyone who paid 50p to see the Sex Pistols at the Lesser Free Trade Hall in 1976 went on to form seminal bands. With typical Mancunian attitude, they all thought they could do better than these London upstarts, Mark E Smith said. I think that's what he said; he sounded as if he'd forgotten to put his teeth in. Mick Hucknall revealed that punk appealed to him because "I had spots and felt insecure about myself." In 1976 he cycled to Barrow-in-Furness and cut his long ginger locks off on the beach, a personal farewell to hippydom.

I sometimes like to think of Today (Radio 4) presenters in hippy garb. Sue McGregor sounded positively aglow with patchouli on Monday, introducing the story about Bumble, a Bristol cat, ruining its owner's life by bringing its prey into the house every night. Today went all investigative on Bumble, using state-of-the-art tracking equipment to follow him through the night. A reporter sacrificed a night's sleep, running round back gardens, jumping over wheelie bins. At 2am, finally, some action, the only action in fact. Cat catches mouse. Hold the front page.

fields.headline: Country Diary
fields.standfirst: A cow and bull story
fields.trailText: Northumberland
fields.body:
Northumberland

Snow lay in Chillingham park this week when I accompanied the warden of the herd of wild white cattle to lay out hay. Only in severe weather do they receive any nourishment. We keep our distance as the beasts straggle down from the bracken-covered upper slopes of this lovely park in the Glendale valley. In 1947, the herd had dwindled to a low of just five bulls and eight cows and there has been much in the news recently pondering why it now has 49 healthy animals.

In theory this unique herd should be so badly inbred that it is heading for oblivion. Recessive or faulty genes should have caused deadly mutations and diseases. Not being one to do things over the telephone, I have come up to visit the herd again and to hear at first-hand what the warden has to say. "The king bull reigns for a maximum of three years," Austin told me. "It could be even less, but he fathers all calves born during his reign. As heifers which he sires don't conceive until they are over three years old, he doesn't mate with his daughters. He is also the fittest and he has to fight for his title. So he has to topple the reigning king, by which time he is likely to be six years old. So no bull can take over directly from his father as king."

So the Chillingham herd has unwittingly selected healthy genes to give it strength. Distinctive white cattle , these animals still look almost exactly as they have always done for hundreds of years. Austin goes to the park every morning to look for the herd, so I asked him if this didn't get monotonous? He put me right immediately. "I stand in this lovely park every morning and look over the valley of Glendale and I know that I'm a lucky man."

fields.headline: Pass notes
fields.standfirst: No 1821 Samson
fields.trailText: No 1821 Samson
fields.body:
Age: Born in Judah in the 12th century BC, so work it out for yourselves.

Appearance: Hairy.

Life: Even hairier.

Mental condition: Bonkers.

You can't say that! Imagine what the readers' editor would say. OK. Mentally unbalanced.

Says who? Dr Eric Altschuler, a neuroscientist at the University of California, who reveals in this week's New Scientist that Samson is the earliest recorded example of anti-social personality disorder (ASPD).

This is the biblical superhero Samson, champion of the Israelites, scourge of the Philistines and vessel of God's will? That's the boy. Reckless, aggressive and clearly dysfunctional, according to Dr Altschuler. Hence the tearing apart of lions, the killing of 1,000 Philistines with the jawbone of an ass, the setting fire to the tails of 300 foxes to devastate the Philistines' wheatfields, the womanising, bullying, frequenting of prostitutes and inability to keep secrets from the scheming Delilah (lustily pictured above, courtesy of Rubens).

Why, why, why Delilah? We can't answer that, but money was a factor.

OK, so Samson had problems. Life was tough in Israel in the 12th century BC. Ask Desmond Dekker. You are obsessed with pop trivia.

Hey Judah. And that's just a gratuitous joke you have failed to fit into the organic unity that Pass notes strives to be.

At least Samson brought the house down in the end. The killing of 3,000 Philistines in the destruction of the temple of Dagon was certainly an appropriate finale to the paranoid pyromaniac's troubled life.

What does Oliver James think? I'm sure we'll find out soon enough.

Not to be confused with: David, Daniel, Gideon, Jephthah, Eminem.

Traditionalists say: "Samson hath quit himself / Like Samson, and heroically hath finished / A life heroic."

Revisionists say: "Don't forget the lithium, Sammy."

webTitle: Feature: Crunch time. Are the new kids on the slopes the real menace?

fields.headline: Crunch time
fields.standfirst: Princess Caroline's painful collision shows once again that skiing can be dangerous. But is it the new kids on the slopes - the snowboarders - who are the real menace?  Ed Douglas reports
fields.trailText: Princess Caroline's painful collision shows once again that skiing can be dangerous. But is it the new kids on the slopes - the snowboarders - who are the real menace?  Ed Douglas reports.
fields.body:
Even the über-elite of European aristocracy can have their holidays spoiled. Princess Caroline of Monaco was flown to hospital this week for emergency keyhole surgery on her knee after being flattened on the ski slopes of the exclusive Austrian resort of Zuers by a man one local resident described as a "piste-lout".

Her husband, Prince Ernst August of Hanover, flew the 32 miles to a private clinic with his wife. Prince Ernst, who last summer was photographed urinating against the Turkish pavilion at Expo 2000 in Hanover and later called a journalist interviewing him about it a "fat arse", returned with the couple's daughter Alexandra to the five-star Loruenser Hotel where the family were staying.

There is something overwhelming about the recipe of wealth, skiing and cold, crisp mountain air - with a dash of risk thrown in. James Bond never infiltrated himself into a corporate box at Old Trafford, but would find any excuse to whiz down a mountainside on planks with a range of villains shooting from the hip as they slalomed after him. Hence the rush of punters in the 70s to sign up on package ski holidays to Bulgaria for a taste of that exoticism.

But Princess Caroline was in some ways very lucky. The list of celebrities who have met an untimely end while skiing includes Michael Kennedy, killed on New Year's Eve 1997 when he collided with a tree in Aspen, and the singer turned Republican politician Sonny Bono, who did something very similar six days later. Even our own royalty is not immune, with Prince Charles narrowly escaping death in an avalanche at Klosters that swept away his bodyguard, Major Hugh Lindsay. And while the celebrities get the biggest headlines, the death toll on the general public is equally remorseless.

Earlier this month, Nathan Hall, a 22-year-old former lift operator at Vail in Colorado, was sentenced to 90 days in jail for a fatal collision in 1997 with British-born Alan Cobb, 33, who had been skiing with his fiancee Christi Neville. Hall, a former ski-racing champion, was found guilty of negligent homicide in the first criminal prosecution of a reckless skier in the US. With litigation now a regular feature in skiing, Cobb's family reached a $300,000 settlement with the Vail resort. Denver lawyer Jim Chalat, a leading litigator of the skiing industry in Colorado, says the state averages 10m skier visits a year from which 20,000 accidents occur, of which "only about 1% have a claim". In 1995, Chalat acted on behalf of a five-year-old girl, Nicole Handley, who had her femur broken by an out-of-control skier, and won an award of $2.4m for a ballerina whose career was ended in a collision with another skier. Chalat's firm also acted in the action against Hall.

With so much apparent risk, non-skiers could be forgiven for wondering why Princess Caroline or anybody else bothers. The US National Ski Areas Association, concerned by the heavy media coverage given to Hall's conviction, reassured potential clients that the sport was safer than its recent image suggested, pointing out that last year 30 people died skiing and snowboarding in the US, out of 10m participants. Even Christi Neville was moved to say after her fiance's death: "Five minutes before the accident, he turned to me and said: 'This has been the best day.' I just never dreamed this could happen skiing."

But if accidents are rare, the culture of safety around skiing is constantly evolving, even if attitudes on either side of the Atlantic are radically different. In America, skiers will be told to slow down by the ski patrol or face having their passes confiscated. Alcohol, so much a part of the European scene, is not tolerated and in some resorts skiers are breathalysed. Skiing behaviour is regulated by legislation, bringing the courts into how a sport is conducted. Many European skiers feel such restraints take some of the fun out of the sport, but where do you draw the line? Skiing is not getting more dangerous, but technological advances such as Fat Boys and Free Ride skis allow easier turns and faster speeds - so inexperienced skiers are moving on to difficult off-piste terrain that used to be the preserve of the experts. The Ski Club of Great Britain produces a booklet on skiing safely with the new technology but is reluctant to see skiers' freedoms curtailed.

"Skiers should understand what's involved," says spokeswoman Vanessa Haines. "The element of danger is there but that's part of the sport. Skiers should build up experience slowly and understand what causes avalanches. A lot of it is common sense. But hundreds of thousands of Britons go skiing each year and never get hurt and never see an avalanche."

Haines points to a growing trend at European resorts for American-style controls, like slow skiing areas, incentives for skiers - especially children - to wear helmets and sanctions against reckless skiers. But Gavin Foster, who runs the ski tour company Ski Weekend, warns against following the American model too closely. "There's already a problem with people who ski with guides that they think they are removing any risk. But guides aren't infallible and we shouldn't expect them to be."

Foster, who meets skiers ranging from the outstanding to the unfit weekend warrior, believes individuals should be responsible for making sure they are in control on the slopes. "It's a common problem with British skiers that they stay on the intermediate plateau for too long. It's not so much speed that is dangerous, as not being in control. Skiers often need more instruction than they think."

Nor is he impressed by the ski snobs who see snowboarders as "piste-louts" who shouldn't be allowed on the mountain. "It's very dangerous to discriminate. Although it's true that the learning curve for boarders is a lot steeper, and that boarders are perhaps not getting as much instruction, these issues are being addressed."

Boarders have been portrayed in the press as the bad boys of the skiing industry, arrivistes who have muscled their way into the action. With a patois incomprehensible to most traditional skiers and a much younger demographic, even their clothes are looser. Snowboarders were outraged by a suggestion in the press that a cigarette flicked away by a boarder started the fire that swept through the funicular at the Austrian resort of Kaprun killing 159 people. According to Carl Doherty, deputy editor of Snowboard UK, snowboarders' mixed reputation is undeserved. "It's a bad media perception," he says. "We regularly carry articles on safety and are constantly pointing out that this is a dangerous sport. The snowboarder was portrayed as being ugly and baggy, but he's still there and he's not going away." Haines sympathises with the boarders. "With Free Ride skis, the style and terrain of boarding and skiing have a lot more in common."

Snowboarding started as a grassroots sport in the 80s, growing partly out of the skateboarding craze, and partly out of frustration with a staid skiing scene. Steve Bailey, at 26 a veteran boarder with British titles dating back to 1993 and the current British Big Air champion, says the antagonism between boarders and skiers is "a total myth".

Bailey says snowboarding has rescued skiing from its conservative image. "Skiing had gone through a real dead patch; it was too set in its ways. But now it's all gone towards boarding - the style, the clothes." Bailey himself has a contract with boarding fashion gurus Helly Hansen. "Loads of boarders have switched back to skiing," he says. "Two years ago there was no such thing as a twin-tip ski. Now skiers can do the tricks that boarders have been doing for years. We need to get skiing back buzzing."

Born in Manchester, and one of the first 50 boarders in the country, Bailey's can-do attitude is a long way from the posh atmosphere of Zuers, but he rejects the accusation that boarders are piste-louts who are spoiling the mountains. "Of course," he says, "there are wankers in any sport. But I'm into anyone who's into the mountains. I've got loads of friends who are skiers."

And while skiers may fear the threat of a piste-lout hurtling out of the mist towards them, they are as much at risk from simply being in the mountains. In the past few years, the skiing industry has been rocked not by bad behaviour on the slopes but by a catalogue of disasters from avalanches striking mountain villages to fires in railway and road tunnels. The industrialisation of the mountains, it seems, holds the biggest risks of all.

Skiers often need more instruction than they think." Nor is he impressed by the ski snobs who see snowboarders as "piste-louts" who shouldn't be allowed on the mountain. "It's very dangerous to discriminate. Although it's true that the learning curve for boarders is a lot steeper, and that boarders are perhaps not getting as much instruction, these issues are being addressed." Boarders have been portrayed in the press as the bad boys of the skiing industry, arrivistes who have muscled their way into the action. With a patois incomprehensible to most traditional skiers and a much younger demographic, even their clothes are looser. Snowboarders were outraged by a suggestion in the press that a cigarette flicked away by a boarder started the fire that swept through the funicular at the Austrian resort of Kaprun killing 159 people. According to Carl Doherty, deputy editor of Snowboard UK, snowboarders' mixed reputation is undeserved. "It's a bad media perception," he says. "We regularly carry articles on safety and are constantly pointing out that this is a dangerous sport. The snowboarder was portrayed as being ugly and baggy, but he's still there and he's not going away." Haines sympathises with the boarders. "With Free Ride skis, the style and terrain of boarding and skiing have a lot more in common." Snowboarding started as a grassroots sport in the 80s, growing partly out of the skateboarding craze, and partly out of frustration with a staid skiing scene. Steve Bailey, at 26 a veteran boarder with British titles dating back to 1993 and the current British Big Air champion, says the antagonism between boarders and skiers is "a total myth". Bailey says snowboarding has rescued skiing from its conservative image. "Skiing had gone through a real dead patch; it was too set in its ways. But now it's all gone towards boarding - the style, the clothes." Bailey himself has a contract with boarding fashion gurus Helly Hansen. "Loads of boarders have switched back to skiing," he says. "Two years ago there was no such thing as a twin-tip ski. Now skiers can do the tricks that boarders have been doing for years. We need to get skiing back buzzing." Born in Manchester, and one of the first 50 boarders in the country, Bailey's can-do attitude is a long way from the posh atmosphere of Zuers, but he rejects the accusation that boarders are piste-louts who are spoiling the mountains. "Of course," he says, "there are wankers in any sport. But I'm into anyone who's into the mountains. I've got loads of friends who are skiers." And while skiers may fear the threat of a piste-lout hurtling out of the mist towards them, they are as much at risk from simply being in the mountains. In the past few years, the skiing industry has been rocked not by bad behaviour on the slopes but by a catalogue of disasters from avalanches striking mountain villages to fires in railway and road tunnels. The industrialisation of the mountains, it seems, holds the biggest risks of all.

fields.headline: Ken Kiff
fields.standfirst: Painter on a poetic journey into colour
fields.trailText: Painter on a poetic journey into colour.
fields.body:
The painter Ken Kiff, who has died aged 65, never quite starred on the media's British art stage, but his work has many admirers. To them he was a true painter, ever fresh yet firmly rooted in the best traditions. His work has been shown often, from 1970 onwards in thematic and group shows, and, beginning in 1979, also in solo exhibitions, in London, New York and elsewhere.

In 1992-93, he was the National Gallery's associate artist. As a teacher, there was no mistaking the way he cared for art, and his deep under standing of it. Occasionally, he gave public lectures - thoughtful, unhurried personal comments on his own art and the art of those he especially valued.

Many of us thought of him as an art guru, a very wise man opening up important issues. The abstract painter John McLean introduced us in 1969. At the time, I was writing mostly about abstract art, puzzled by English resistance to it, and eager to draw attention to a remarkable upsurge of outstanding work, especially among English artists. Ken's was wholly and insistently figurative. It was also full of colour, sonorous, sometimes delicate, sometimes tough, but never crude. It was always, in that sense, musical, and indeed he had wide knowledge of classical music of all periods.

His subject-matter struck one as openly poetical - a woman, water, a tree and rocks, a little heap of clothing; a lizard, sand, a small rock, a large geometrical sun-moon of the painter's inventing - with more than a hint of myths and legends. He spoke of poetry out of a deep personal attachment to, among others, Yeats, Frost, Wallace Stevens and Emily Dickinson. His pictures took some of their resonance from these attachments, and can be utterly enchanting. They can also be deeply disturbing.

When Ken spoke about art, it was about about the aspects people call formalist, those that condition our reading of images. Colour mattered to him especially. The exhibition which ended his time at the National Gallery, a museum dominated by relatively low-toned work, sang with colour. Many of the exhibits were personal reworkings of the gallery's pictures of the 13th and 14th centuries, before elaborate tonal modelling and sfumato [the gradual transition between colours] made colour secondary and ornamental, not an essential structural as well as expressive element.

Also important were the character and disposition of forms, the spaces between them, their firm or broken outlines, the dynamics of rising or sinking forms. These were aspects he was eager to talk about, in his own art or others', from Chinese landscapists to the old masters and moderns, notably Picasso, Matisse, Klee, Miró and Pollock. He had a special passion for Chagall, finding in him a venturing, partly playful spirit akin to his own, but Klee was the essential precursor, not only for the delicacy and economy of his working methods but also for Klee's guiding principle, the genetic process by which images arise out of the marks made and the materials being used.

Not that Ken's work ever looks like Klee's, or Chagall's, or anyone else's. Often his images are benign and cheerful, but at times they were grim, even ghastly. Generally his work was dream-like, neither a description of reality nor accounts of dreams and daydreams, but drawing on both as raw materials. He had no doubt that art should be beautiful, but that did not mean pretty or polite. Art lovers have sometimes been offended by the cruel or coarse actions he included, up-front and without apology. More often his compositions, large and small, from commanding triptychs down to enticing little prints and monoprints, involve a little man (himself?), radiantly beautiful women, elements of landscape (trees, hills, caves, rivers, a boat) or of towns (streets, houses, a pillar-box), but also fairy-tale ogres, truncated bodies and floating heads. Everything has the presence of intense imaginings, and lives on the surface of his pictures as being of now, this minute. The life of colour and form concerned him above all else once a painting was started, and many a work changed both as to cast and script. His pictures end up looking spontaneous, off-hand even. He was always reluctant to say a work was finished, needing to reconsider this or that aspect of it. He was also reluctant to talk about its specific meaning, and not keen to have us speculate about it.

His origins were simple: he was born in Essex, and his father had worked in a woodyard being killed in the first months of the war. One of his two step-fathers appears in an emblematic portrait - a sad, silent image. He did not speak of his mother; a brother died in 1998 after a grave illness. Ken studied at Hornsey School of Art, pottery first, then stained glass under an inspiring teacher, and thence moved on into painting. He married a fellow artist, Jane, later to become a psycho-therapist, when they were still quite young; their children, Anna and Sam, were tremendously important to him.

Many of Ken's pictures suggest journeys or adventures, with himself as protagonist. In 1970, he embarked on a series of small pictures on paper as a parallel activity to his painting on canvas and on boards. He called this project The Sequence. Its nearly 200 numbered pictures relate to himself more openly, in many instances picturing him in various actual and imagined situations, sometimes in an almost illustrational manner, often allegorically. Its essential subject is the harmonies and discords, marvels as well as dismays, occasioned by the interaction of outer reality and the realities of thought and memory. Quentin Blake has included a Kiff in his Tell Me A Picture show at the National Gallery (open until June 17); a selection of Kiff's prints will be at Charleston, near Lewes, from May 13 to June 24.

 Ken Kiff, painter and printmaker, born May 29 1935; died February 15 2001

webTitle: Business: NEC deal revives Psion fortunes

fields.headline: NEC deal revives Psion fortunes
fields.standfirst:
Psion
More net news
fields.trailText: Psion yesterday broke through the gloom surrounding its share price, at least temporarily, with a deal to supply its Bluetooth technology to NEC Computers.
fields.body:
Psion yesterday broke through the gloom surrounding its share price, at least temporarily, with a deal to supply its Bluetooth technology to NEC Computers.

The agreement lifted the handheld computer group's shares by 4.72% to 194.75p. Psion will supply a range of Bluetooth products such as PCs, laptops, mobile phones and handheld computers, which would be able to communicate with each other without using cables.

The deal with two divisions of the computer group, NEC Online in the commercial market and Packard Bell for consumers, is unlikely to create significant revenues until next year, but a Psion spokesman said the announcement marked NEC as a Bluetooth player.

NEC has about 5% of world laptops sales. The deal follows a similar agreement between Psion and Compaq.

"Volume sales of Bluetooth will really kick in next year," the spokesman said. "It's the network effect. It's like mobile phones - once people around you had one then they started to really take off. We are on our way."

Psion has some way to go,, before repairing damage to the share price caused by a steady stream of negative news. A profits warning at the end of last year, the collapse of a joint venture with Motorola to develop an "internet in your pocket" product and the broad sweep of sentiment against the mobile phone sector have combined to bring the share price down from £15 this time last year.

Much of the value attributed to Psion has been from its lead role in Symbian, the venture with leading mobile phone manufacturers to develop the standard operating platform for the next generation of high-speed wireless devices.

Bluetooth is being driven by a group including IBM, Microsoft, Motorola and Nokia which are working together to establish an industry standard.

The separate venture with Motorola which collapsed last month amounted to Psion's second profits warning in the space of three months. The company claimed it was a victim of internal restructuring at Motorola which had led to the cancellation of a number of projects.

The palm-sized gadget being worked on was a cross between a Psion personal organiser, a mobile phone and a unit for accessing the internet at high speed. It was to have been one of Psion's main products launched this year.

webTitle: Guthrie warns of risk in US defence planning

fields.headline: Guthrie warns of risk in US defence planning
fields.standfirst:
 'The Americans think peacekeeping is for wimps'
 'Missile shield could be very divisive for transatlantic alliance'
 'We can't go around as the world's policeman'

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: General Sir Charles Guthrie, chief of the defence staff, warned yesterday that the US was planning a radical rethink of the shape and role of its armed forces - including its plan for a national anti-missile shield - with serious implications for Britain and Europe.
fields.body:
General Sir Charles Guthrie, chief of the defence staff, warned yesterday that the US was planning a radical rethink of the shape and role of its armed forces - including its plan for a national anti-missile shield - with serious implications for Britain and Europe.

The Americans talked as though "peacekeeping is for wimps", he told the Guardian in a wide-ranging interview where he warned of a doomsday scenario with Washington's national missile defence system plans driving a wedge between Europe and the US.

He was speaking on his last day in office, and he also made plain his strong opposition to women fighting alongside men in frontline combat.

The Bush administration was moving towards light, flexible forces which can "get there quicker but not stay around for ever", Sir Charles said. He added: "The Americans talk about the warrior ethic and ... that peacekeeping is for wimps."

He warned that the US had different preoccupations from the Europeans - for them, he said, Taiwan, Korea and Osama bin Laden, the Islamic militant extremist living in Afghanistan, were more important than the Balkans.

Russia, he added, had similar preoccupations. At a recent meeting, Sir Charles's Russian opposite number, Anatoly Kvashin, had spoken of nothing other than the spread of Islam in the Caucasus and Afghanistan.

However, Sir Charles also spoke of the potentially serious threats posed by the US national missile shield project. "It could be very divisive for the transatlantic alliance if the Russians thought Europe was on their side," he said referring to strong opposition to the plan in France and Germany.

The Russians and the Americans had to talk through the shield proposal "very carefully" if a new nuclear race was to be avoided, he said.

Sir Charles admitted the government would probably be asked by the US to allow the upgrading of the Fylingdales radar station in North York shire for the US project. That would raise serious questions, and would reawaken what he called the whole nuclear debate.

It would be "terrible", he added, if the Russians became more nationalistic and were able to "drive a wedge" between Europe and the US.

He castigated international organisations for not helping to restore stability in Kosovo quickly enough. "One pace behind [Nato troops] should have been civil policemen, doctors, judges, even tax collectors," Sir Charles said. "Where the hell was Mrs Sadako Ogata [then UN high commissioner for refugees] when we went in?' he asked. "We can't go around as the world's policeman", he said.

Sir Charles robustly defended EU plans for joint peacekeeping operations so long as they led to real improvements in the military capability of Britain's European allies and did not duplicate Nato - an eventuality he described as "silly and perhaps impossible" despite suspicions of French intentions.

If the Europeans were not prepared to pool their forces they would be "in dead trouble", he said.

Turning to issues at home, Sir Charles described some barracks as "slum dwellings". And he conceded that the proportion of ethnic minorities in Britain's armed forces - around 1% - was not good enough, though recent recruitment figures are running at 2.4%.

He delivered blistering parting shots at what he and other senior military officers see as damaging political correctness. "It is not my job to be a social engineer and accept equal opportunities in all ways ... We have got the greatest armed forces in the world and I'm not going to muck about with it," he said.

He referred to Brad Tinnion, the SAS soldier killed when British troops rescued their colleagues from the West Side Boys militia in Sierra Leone last year. "What would it have been like if he had been a woman?" he asked.

Women on ships or as aircrew was very different from women in army platoons, he said. Asked about Ellen MacArthur, the round-the-world yachtswoman, he insisted that working in a team was different.

Sir Charles will be succeeded as chief of defence staff today by Admiral Sir Michael Boyce.

webTitle: Straw calls halt to £80m IT system

fields.headline: Straw calls halt to £80m IT system
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: The government faced embarrassment yesterday over its efforts to modernise Whitehall computers when it emerged that the final phase of an £80m system intended to clear the backlog of asylum seekers had been scrapped.
fields.body:
The government faced embarrassment yesterday over its efforts to modernise Whitehall computers when it emerged that the final phase of an £80m system intended to clear the backlog of asylum seekers had been scrapped.

Jack Straw, the home secretary, admitted that the system, which was designed to save more than £100m and should have been completed in 1998, would not now become fully operational.

It is the latest in a series of technical problems to hit the government and the Home Office in particular. Two years ago the fiasco over passport processing led to huge queues at offices across Britain.

The system, designed by the German company Siemens Business Services, was to have been used by the immigration and nationality directorate to replace much of the paperwork in asylum cases.

But the project was troubled from the start. An early breakdown led to a backlog of 102,000 cases last year. An interim solution brought the backlog down to 66,000 and ministers have decided not to risk further breakdowns.

Mr Straw announced the decision to scrap the system in a written parliamentary answer. He said it was "over-complex and out of touch with current working practices".

Speaking on BBC Breakfast TV, the Home Office minister Barbara Roche blamed the previous government. "The Tories, when they were in power, ordered this flawed system which the national audit office said was overambitious, so we have inherited a real problem from them."

But Simon Hughes, who speaks for the Liberal Democrats on home affairs, said that Labour should have turned the project around. He claimed that more than 70% of Home Office IT projects were either delayed, over budget or both.

The developments will focus attention on the government's struggle to reshape IT in Whitehall. Successive governments have been accused of wasting taxpayers' money on flawed projects.

In the 1970s some IT projects were undertaken in-house, others by consultants whom civil servants found difficult to manage. By the late 80s the consultants were being done away with and IT development was contracted out.

In January last year the public accounts committee published a report on the government's IT record. There had been more than 25 cases in the 1990s where implementing IT systems had led to "delay, confusion and inconvenience to the citizen".

The committee chairman David Davis yesterday said one of the major problems was the "horrible interface" between civil servants who understand all there is to know about, for example, the national insurance system but know little of how a computer works, and technicians who know just the reverse. Mr Davis said: "They don't spend enough time at the start of a project explaining where they are both coming from."

Another problem was that Whitehall was excellent at producing all-rounders but not experts in fields such as IT. A civil servant might only oversee one project - if he or she failed there would not be another chance. Success, however, would lead to promotion into another area. A civil servant would probably not lose his job if a computer project failed as his counterpart in the private sector would.

And if a minister demanded a new computer system to come online within two years, said Mr Davis, it would be a brave civil servant who ignored the deadline even if it meant producing a substandard system. Mr Davis said: "Throw in the Sir Humphrey factor and you've got a heady brew".

In May last year the Cabinet Office minister Ian McCartney launched a review of the way government IT projects are managed. It set out 30 recommendations. Among them was that a senior civil servant should be placed in charge of each project to establish accountability. Projects were to be broken down into smaller pieces so they were easier to manage.

The government's so-called e-envoy Andrew Pinder was charged with ensuring that the recommendations were implemented. In December he made an interim report on progress in which he said that 19 of the recommendations had been met.

Computer error

 Final phase of Home Office asylum and immigration case work system scrapped at alleged cost of £77m.

 Public had to queue in the rain for new passports in summer 1999 because of breakdown of new computer system. Not yet completed.

 Debacle over the contributions agency computer dealing with 65m in national insurance accounts has led to compensation payouts to personal pension holders and benefit claimants.

 Ministry of Defence: Project Trawlerman. New computer system for defence intelligence staff written off at cost of £41m.

 Prison service system to prevent inmates phoning victims. Four years late.

 Clinical coding system for NHS patients. Abandoned after more than £32m and eight years.

 Home Office asylum support project. Likely to be two years late. Already £2m over original budget.

The committee chairman David Davis yesterday said one of the major problems was the "horrible interface" between civil servants who understand all there is to know about, for example, the national insurance system but know little of how a computer works, and technicians who know just the reverse. Mr Davis said: "They don't spend enough time at the start of a project explaining where they are both coming from." Another problem was that Whitehall was excellent at producing all-rounders but not experts in fields such as IT. A civil servant might only oversee one project - if he or she failed there would not be another chance. Success, however, would lead to promotion into another area. A civil servant would probably not lose his job if a computer project failed as his counterpart in the private sector would. And if a minister demanded a new computer system to come online within two years, said Mr Davis, it would be a brave civil servant who ignored the deadline even if it meant producing a substandard system. Mr Davis said: "Throw in the Sir Humphrey factor and you've got a heady brew". In May last year the Cabinet Office minister Ian McCartney launched a review of the way government IT projects are managed. It set out 30 recommendations. Among them was that a senior civil servant should be placed in charge of each project to establish accountability. Projects were to be broken down into smaller pieces so they were easier to manage. The government's so-called e-envoy Andrew Pinder was charged with ensuring that the recommendations were implemented. In December he made an interim report on progress in which he said that 19 of the recommendations had been met. Computer error  Final phase of Home Office asylum and immigration case work system scrapped at alleged cost of £77m.  Public had to queue in the rain for new passports in summer 1999 because of breakdown of new computer system. Not yet completed.  Debacle over the contributions agency computer dealing with 65m in national insurance accounts has led to compensation payouts to personal pension holders and benefit claimants.  Ministry of Defence: Project Trawlerman. New computer system for defence intelligence staff written off at cost of £41m.  Prison service system to prevent inmates phoning victims. Four years late.  Clinical coding system for NHS patients. Abandoned after more than £32m and eight years.  Home Office asylum support project. Likely to be two years late. Already £2m over original budget.

fields.trailText: Caribbean step to death penalty | Waters rising in Mozambique | Peru fugitive in arms scandal | Paedophile's case rejected | Southern wind blows ill
fields.body:
Caribbean step to death penalty

Nine Caribbean states have agreed to replace the privy council in London, which has blocked their use of the death penalty, with a regional supreme court.

The former British colonies of Guyana, Barbados, Antigua and Barbuda, Belize, Jamaica, Grenada, Trinidad and Tobago, St Lucia, and St Kitts and Nevis have been joined by the former Dutch possession Suriname. Others have held back.
AP, Bridgetown

Waters rising in Mozambique

Floods have killed 17 people in Mozambique a year after the country's worst flood disaster.

The situation is critical in the central Tete province, where many people are stranded, the prime minister, Pascoal Mocumbi, said.
AFP, Maputo

Peru fugitive in arms scandal

Interpol in Peru has issued a warrant for the former secret police chief Vladimiro Montesinos, according to a police official.

It says he helped sell arms to the Colombian Revolutionary Armed Forces as part of a deal in which Peruvian army officers allegedly bought 10,000 rifles from Jordan.
AFP, Lima

Paedophile's case rejected

A court at Arlon, south Belgium, has rejected the paedophile Marc Dutroux's complaint that his jail conditions are illegal and degrading.
Reuters, Arlon

Southern wind blows ill

Ann Bancroft and Liv Arnesen, who gave up trying to parasail across the Antarctic Ross Ice Shelf for lack of wind, are having to wait for the wind to drop so a plane can take them to safety.
AP

webTitle: Law gives women a lift into French council chambers

fields.headline: Law gives women a lift into French council chambers
fields.trailText: Whether right or left wins next month's French local elections, one group is already assured of a triumph: under a new law, thought to be unique, women must be as well represented as men on each party's candidate list.
fields.body:
Whether right or left wins next month's French local elections, one group is already assured of a triumph: under a new law, thought to be unique, women must be as well represented as men on each party's candidate list.

The parity act, a brainchild of Sylviane Agacinski, the philosopher wife of the Socialist prime minister, Lionel Jospin, became law last summer and seems likely to transform the political life of a notoriously chauvinist state.

"It has already had one dramatic effect," said Claire Bernard, a member of the government agency set up to monitor sexual equality in politics and the workplace, the parity observatory.

"There is no more arguing about women's role in politics; the law has simply imposed legitimacy."

Promised by Mr Jospin in his 1997 election campaign, the law applies to party lists in local, regional, parliamentary and European elections. For the March 11 local council elections it has obliged parties to put up equal numbers of men and women in every district with at least 3,500 inhabitants.

On paper that means only 2,800 of the 36,000 communes, but the observatory says they are big enough to ensure that by Easter 40% of local council members should be conseillères rather than conseillers - a huge change in the political scene.

Whereas 45% of Swedish MPs are women, French women, who got the vote only in 1944, have just 8.7% of the national assembly's 577 seats - the lowest in any EU country and 52nd in the world, behind such countries as Tunisia and Senegal.

The bill was opposed by many conservatives and some leading women's rights campaigners, who argued that only sustained grassroots pressure could lead to real change.

But many of the tens of thousands of women seeking election for the first time next month argue that the law has changed their lives.

Odile Barbat-Blanc, 27 a law student in Aix-en-Provence, volunteered to help the campaign of a mayoral candidate for the centre-right UDF.

"It didn't take him long to ask me to join his list," she said. "My friends and family said 'For heaven's sake steer clear of politics', but so far I'm loving it.

"It's teaching me about life and about myself, but above all I feel I'm being useful, and I'm respected. People listen to what I have to say."

The number of women councillors may soar, but this time around at least number of female mayors is unlikely to rise dramatically above the present the 8%, even though some prominent women are standing in big regional towns, including the former employment minister Martine Aubry, her successor Elisabeth Guigou, and the environment minister, Dominique Voynet.

"That's because the law requires an equal number of men and women on each list, but only per group of six candidates," Ms Bernard said.

"There's nothing to say the first three names [on the party list] can't be men, and the second three women. But at least now there will be many more women deputy mayors, and that's where the next mayors will come from."

Anne Hidalgo, a Socialist standing for mayor in a Paris district, said that persuading the party to put her name at the top of its list was gruelling.

"The criteria [for proof of commitment] for many older male militants is the amount of time you're prepared to spend in late-night meetings, and that's not a woman's way. We are much more efficient; we have kids to get to school the next day."

In certain districts some parties, mainly from the right, have had trouble recruiting enough women, Ms Bernard said. Elsewhere, mayors have complained bitterly that they have had to ask longstanding male councillors to step down, dismembering "happy teams".

webTitle: Pandas still facing threat of extinction

fields.headline: Pandas still facing threat of extinction
fields.trailText: Despite a 20-year battle to save the giant panda, the bear-like creature is still sliding towards extinction, WWF - formerly the World Wide Fund for Nature - admitted yesterday.
fields.body:
Despite a 20-year battle to save the giant panda, the bear-like creature is still sliding towards extinction, WWF - formerly the World Wide Fund for Nature - admitted yesterday.

The panda, used as a logo by the WWF for 40 years, is down to fewer than 1,000 in the wild. They are separated into isolated groups because the bamboo forests they need for survival are being cut down.

A lack of funds has prevented panda reserves declared by the Chinese government from being properly managed and poaching and illegal logging continue to be a problem, the WWF said.

In the Sichuan province of China, where the greatest number of pandas cling to survival, habitats suitable for the animals shrank by 50% between 1974 and 1989. A survey in 1999 in one county revealed that since 1987 there had been a 30% decrease in panda habitat.

A new panda count is under way but is expected to find fewer than 1,000 in the wild. However, there is new hope for the creatures. Devastating floods in 1998 led the Chinese government to ban further logging in the mountains to prevent excess water run off.

The isolated nature of the panda populations creates a problem of inbreeding which further weakens the ability of the species to survive.

The Chinese and the WWF hope to create wide bamboo corridors between reserves to allow pandas to travel and mix.

Poaching increased after the logging ban of 1998 but a number of poachers have received life sentences.

webTitle: Nine years in jail for Jackal helper

fields.headline: Nine years in jail for Jackal helper
fields.trailText: Hans-Joachim Klein was sentenced by a Frankfurt court yesterday to nine years in prison for murder, attempted murder and hostage-taking, acts which took place in 1975 at the Opec oil ministers' meeting in Vienna.
fields.body:
Hans-Joachim Klein was sentenced by a Frankfurt court yesterday to nine years in prison for murder, attempted murder and hostage-taking, acts which took place in 1975 at the Opec oil ministers' meeting in Vienna.

Klein, 53, was part of a six-man terrorist unit led by the Venezuelan Ilich Ramirez Sanchez, known as Carlos the Jackal, which attacked the Opec session, shooting dead an Austrian policeman, an Iraqi bodyguard and a Libyan delegate, and taking 70 people hostage.

Austria supplied the terrorists with a plane and they flew via Libya to Algeria, where the hostages were set free.

Klein, who was shot in the stomach when police stormed the conference centre, went underground after the attack, eventually making his way to France ,where he was captured in 1998 and extradited to Germany.

During the trial he admitted being involved in the raid, but denied firing the fatal shots.

Summing up, Judge Heinrich Gehrke told Klein, who sat without showing any emotion: "This was not just some bank robbery but a politically motivated crime."

The trial, which began four months ago, brought to light the radical pasts of some highly respected politicians, most notably the German foreign minister, Joschka Fischer.

Mr Fischer, a friend of Klein in their youth in Frankfurt in the 1970s, was called last month as a character witness in the trial.

He told the court that he had tried to steer Klein away from violence, but had not managed to prevent him joining the Revolutionary Cells (RZ), an extreme faction through which Klein met Carlos the Jackal.

The trial has depicted Klein's life as tragic. Mr Fischer and other witnesses described him as "a bit of a loser" who inadvertently fell into the extreme militant scene in a desperate attempt to be accepted by his peers.

Klein made the same point, saying of the raid: "Ten minutes of Opec destroyed my life."

His co-defendant, Rudolf Schindler, 57, who Klein said had recruited him into the RZ, was acquitted.

Mr Fischer's presence at the trial intensified the debate about his radical past. The latest twist came this week, when he admitted that he had spent an hour at a PLO conference in Algeria in 1969, but left because, according to an aide, "he found it too boring".

He is also fighting allegations that during his days in Frankfurt he and a flatmate, Daniel Cohn-Bendit, now a prominent French Green MEP, harboured the Red Army faction terrorist Margit Schiller.

The Frankfurt state prosecutor's office announced on Wednesday that it would start proceedings against Mr Fischer which could lead to perjury charges.

Earlier in the trial Mr Fischer denied that Schiller had lived with him.

A few days later, however, he revised his statement to say that she might have been in the same building.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Sword attack trial halted | Barman died after binge | Disabled mother loses car badge | Police raid Soho brothels | Driver killed 'after family row' | Hunt saboteur loses damages | Ex-wrestler jailed for attack | Pit charity in funds inquiry | GM virus could fight skin cancer | Console price cut to £99.99
fields.body:
Sword attack trial halted

A man accused of a samurai sword attack in which a Cheltenham Liberal Democrat party worker, Andrew Pennington, 39, died and the town's MP Nigel Jones was seriously injured was yesterday declared unfit to stand trial by a jury at Bristol crown court. Robert Ashman, 50, of Cheltenham, Gloucestershire, was said to be suffering from paranoid delusions.

Barman died after binge

A barman who died after a drinking race at the Flying Dutchman, in Jump, South Yorkshire, in August was eight times over the drink-drive limit, a Sheffield inquest heard yesterday. A verdict of misadventure contributed to by neglect was recorded on Paul Ellis, 30.

Disabled mother loses car badge

A mother born with only one arm has had her application to renew her disabled parking badge refused. Gwylfn Evans, Oldham's social services director, blamed guidelines for turning down Lesley Fitzpatrick, 33.

Police raid Soho brothels

Police raided more than 50 brothels in Soho, central London, in what is believed to have been the biggest clampdown on prostitution in recent times.

Driver killed 'after family row'

A woman motorist was killed when she swerved into the path of a lorry during an argument with her estranged husband about access to their children, Chester crown court heard yesterday. Kevin Whitlow, 41, of Chester, who denies manslaughter, is alleged to have said the crash happened when he threatened to hit Kathryn Whitlow, 33, but later denied the admission. The trial continues.

Hunt saboteur loses damages

A hunt saboteur who suffered brain damage and epilepsy when a hunt supporter he attacked with a baseball bat turned the tables in self defence, was not entitled to compensation, the House of Lords ruled yesterday. Harry Cross, 47, of Wissett, Suffolk, had been awarded £52,000 by the high court after the incident involving a farmer, Bill Kirkby, 56, at the Brocklesby hunt in Lincolnshire in 1992.

Ex-wrestler jailed for attack

A former wrestler, Sandra Lace, 48, who kept admirer Michael Hill, 48, "hostage" in her home in Margate, Kent, for 10 weeks, beating him and stealing more than £20,000 of his cash, was jailed for 18 months yesterday at Canterbury crown court.

Pit charity in funds inquiry

The running of Durham Mining Convalescent Homes has been put in the hands of the receivers until an inquiry takes place into an alleged misapplication of funds, the charity commission said yesterday.

GM virus could fight skin cancer

A genetically modified cold sore virus could fight skin cancer. A trial by Glasgow University scientists showed that the virus kills malignant tumour cells, the Lancet reports.

Console price cut to £99.99

Sega has cut the price of its Dreamcast console by a third, to £99.99, weeks before production of the machine ends.

webTitle: UN races to halt forgotten Afghan tragedy

fields.headline: UN races to halt forgotten Afghan tragedy
fields.standfirst: Emergency chief in camps as drought, cold and war deepen crisis
fields.trailText: The UN emergency relief coordinator, Kenzo Oshima, visited overcrowded refugee camps around the western Afghan city of Herat yesterday, where cold and hunger are already claiming lives, and warned that a major catastrophe could develop unless something was done to relieve the worsening problem.
fields.body:
The UN emergency relief coordinator, Kenzo Oshima, visited overcrowded refugee camps around the western Afghan city of Herat yesterday, where cold and hunger are already claiming lives, and warned that a major catastrophe could develop unless something was done to relieve the worsening problem.

Mr Oshima, appointed UN under secretary general for humanitarian affairs a month ago, added: "It is clear that no amount of international assistance is going to be enough."

Mr Oshima is having talks with representatives of the Taliban regime, and has met the deposed President Burhanuddin Rabbani, who is still recognised by the UN as Afghan head of state.

Throughout Afghanistan drought and the currently intensifying civil war have forced more than 500,000 people to flee their homes in the past year, sell their few belongings and travel to makeshift camps, where they depend for survival on a slow trickle of foreign aid.

Every day adds another 360 to the 80,000 living in tents and mud huts in the six camps around Herat.

In Maslakh camp, the only site with space left, most tents hold two families.

At night the temperature falls as low as -25C (-13F). More than 170 people, 130 of them children, have died in Herat in the past month. Although the snow is melting 20 refugees die every week from hunger and exposure.

Soon after a particularly cold spell brought the first deaths, the US and Norway airlifted blankets and tents directly to Herat. But UN aid workers, who have been warning of a crisis for nearly a year, remain frustrated at the west's slow response.

"It took the deaths of more than 100 people to trigger a more coherent response from the donors," Antonio Donini, the UN's deputy coordinator for Afghanistan, said in Herat.

There is growing concern about the thousands still in remote areas of the nearby Badghis, Ghowr and Faryab provinces. Mr Donini estimated that 500,000 people, difficult to reach, remained severely affected in their home areas.

Oxfam has been working in such areas since August, trying to encourage farmers to stay put. Its programme director in Herat, Rod Slip, said: "We found people eating different types of roots and leaves normally reserved for animal fodder,"

"Livestock numbers are down to 20% of the normal levels. Farmers don't have the seeds to plant new crops.

"A lot of people in the camps have sold everything to be where they are and they are pretty much 100% reliant on external aid. At least these people who are staying behind have the chance to work together to find the resources to plant a crop."

Unlike their previous experience of drought, the refugees have no money, no crops to plant and little incentive to return home, aid workers say.

To compound the problem, heavy fighting between the Taliban, who control most of the country, and opposition forces has continued throughout the winter.

The opposition won its biggest victory since 1997 on Tuesday, when it retook Bamiyan, a key city 80 miles west of Kabul.

Many western governments appear reluctant to fund long-term projects in Afghanistan while the Taliban are in charge. In recent years the UN has received less than half the money needed for its Afghan aid programme.

Hans-Christian Poulsen, who runs the UN relief operation in Herat, said: "[Disaster] has been coming for some time. But because it has happened bit by bit it doesn't attract the same kind of attention as an earthquake. That is the tragedy."

"It took the deaths of more than 100 people to trigger a more coherent response from the donors," Antonio Donini, the UN's deputy coordinator for Afghanistan, said in Herat. There is growing concern about the thousands still in remote areas of the nearby Badghis, Ghowr and Faryab provinces. Mr Donini estimated that 500,000 people, difficult to reach, remained severely affected in their home areas. Oxfam has been working in such areas since August, trying to encourage farmers to stay put. Its programme director in Herat, Rod Slip, said: "We found people eating different types of roots and leaves normally reserved for animal fodder," "Livestock numbers are down to 20% of the normal levels. Farmers don't have the seeds to plant new crops. "A lot of people in the camps have sold everything to be where they are and they are pretty much 100% reliant on external aid. At least these people who are staying behind have the chance to work together to find the resources to plant a crop." Unlike their previous experience of drought, the refugees have no money, no crops to plant and little incentive to return home, aid workers say. To compound the problem, heavy fighting between the Taliban, who control most of the country, and opposition forces has continued throughout the winter. The opposition won its biggest victory since 1997 on Tuesday, when it retook Bamiyan, a key city 80 miles west of Kabul. Many western governments appear reluctant to fund long-term projects in Afghanistan while the Taliban are in charge. In recent years the UN has received less than half the money needed for its Afghan aid programme. Hans-Christian Poulsen, who runs the UN relief operation in Herat, said: "[Disaster] has been coming for some time. But because it has happened bit by bit it doesn't attract the same kind of attention as an earthquake. That is the tragedy."

fields.headline: Arredondo quits from Yahoo! Europe
fields.trailText: Fabiola Arredondo, the second most powerful businesswoman in Europe according to Fortune magazine, has stepped down as managing director of the European arm of the US-based internet portal, Yahoo!
fields.body:
Fabiola Arredondo, the second most powerful businesswoman in Europe according to Fortune magazine, has stepped down as managing director of the European arm of the US-based internet portal, Yahoo!

A spokeswoman for the company said that Ms Arredondo had decided to leave Yahoo! where she has worked since 1997, "to pursue private business interests". It is believed she intends to work for a private venture.

Ms Arredondo is thought to have been frustrated by the level of commitment to international expansion.

In October last year, she told reporters that Yahoo!'s expansion into the rapidly growing European market had been restricted by profit targets set by US executives and Wall Street.

Referring to the European operation, she said: "We have a challenge as an organisation because we are consolidated into the USA. My flexibility can be constrained and _ we may be limited in our ability to invest in the business as strongly as we would like."

Ms Arredondo said in a statement yesterday: "I am proud to have been part of a team that has built one of the leading internet companies in Europe."

Jeff Mallett, president and chief operating officer, praised Ms Arredondo's role in "achieving solid financial and overall business performance".

A company spokeswoman said Ms Arredondo revealed her plans to leave earlier this year. She will stay on for a few more months and the search for a successor is under way.

When Ms Arrendondo joined Yahoo! Europe in 1997 the operation was active in three European countries and generated some 45m page views a month.

In December, Yahoo! Europe, with operations in eight countries, generated 1.4bn page views and counted 31m unique users.

fields.headline: Ellison sets $895m puzzle
fields.standfirst:
Oracle founder cashes in share options but retains a quarter of software group

More net news
fields.trailText: Larry Ellison, the founder and chief executive of Oracle and one of the world's richest men, earned $895m (£618m) last month when he sold shares in the software group.
fields.body:
Larry Ellison, the founder and chief executive of Oracle and one of the world's richest men, earned $895m (£618m) last month when he sold shares in the software group.

Mr Ellison, a flamboyant businessman known for flying fighter aircraft across the Pacific Ocean, has not explained why he decided to cash in part of his stake in the company he founded in 1977.

An Oracle spokeswoman said the 29m shares sold by the 55-year-old represented less than 2% of his total holding. After selling 29m shares last month, he still owns about 1.4bn, about a quarter of the total shares on issue. At yesterday's closing price this stake was valued at about $36bn.

Oracle's share price has fallen from a 52-week high of $46.50 last year to $25.50 yesterday amid concerns over weak demand and the economic slowdown. Wall Street believes there is a strong chance the company will miss earnings estimates for the current quarter.

Mr Ellison's personal wealth, which last July was estimated at $47bn, is understood to have shrunk along with his shares. His paper value has risen from about $6bn in 1997 on the back of Oracle's improving fortunes. Mr Ellison last sold a significant number of his shares in 1996.

According to a securities and exchange commission filing released yesterday, Mr Ellison exercised options to buy 22.2m shares for about 10 cents less than he was subsequently able to sell them. This exercise of options which were due to expire in August netted $686m. He then sold an additional 7m shares for $208.7m.

Potential uses for Mr Ellison's new cash hoard are numerous. Described by his biographer, Mike Wilson, as "Larryland - a one-man amusement park", Mr Ellison has expensive tastes.

Thrice married and divorced, he is rumoured to have used "can I buy you a car?" as an occasional chat-up line. In one year he bought four $50,000 Acura sports cars. Tales of largesse are understood to have prompted 4,000 women to write to him after he appeared on the Oprah Winfrey television show.

As well as flying a $38m Gulfstream jet, Mr Ellison tried to import a decommissioned Russian MiG-29 jet fighter before being stopped by the US authorities.

He is building an opulent house in the swanky Atherton area of Silicon Valley. With many of the materials imported from Asia, the house is rumoured to be wired to meet Mr Ellison's every need.

His wealth has largely been derived from the success of Oracle. He was born in Manhattan to a young, unmarried mother and subsequently raised by his mother's aunt and her husband, an accountant, near Lake Michigan.

Like Bill Gates, the founder of Microsoft, Mr Ellison dropped out of college to start working in the hi-tech arena. He has long been a passionate critic of Microsoft, or the "Redmond beast" as he likes to call it. Last year, Oracle was found to have paid private investigators to dig into Microsoft rubbish.
