fields.headline: It's minus 60, there's no heating and no electricity... Welcome to Vladivostok
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: The mood is bleak in the former coalmining town of Artyom, whose residents are beginning to wonder if they have been condemned to die a slow, freezing death. Russia's far east is experiencing its bitterest winter for 70 years and the region's heating system is in collapse.
fields.body:
The mood is bleak in the former coalmining town of Artyom, whose residents are beginning to wonder if they have been condemned to die a slow, freezing death. Russia's far east is experiencing its bitterest winter for 70 years and the region's heating system is in collapse. Since the cold set in, the shuddering energy network has left 86,000 people battling to survive in unlit, unheated flats, as temperatures outside drop as low as minus 60 degrees.

Some people have been stranded without heat and electricity for just a few days. Others - such as thousands in Artyom, an hour from Vladivostok - have been living in Arctic conditions since the first frosts arrived last October.

The political fallout from the crisis is rippling across Russia as accusing fingers are pointed in every direction. The governor of the far eastern region Primorye, the tyrannical Yevgeny Nazdratenko, sought refuge in hospital claiming heart pains on the day he was meant to explain the disaster to a presidential commission. Last week he was forced to resign by an angry Vladimir Putin, the president; Alexander Gavrin, the energy minister, was also fired.

But these dismissals have not brought heat to the region. The collapse within Russia's decrepit infrastructure is so extreme that personnel changes have only marginal impact. At the root of the crisis is a tangle of problems, with incompetence and corruption among senior politicians knotted up so inextricably with poverty and mismanagement at a local level that the Kremlin will need to devote years to unravelling the mess.

Meanwhile Viktoria Garazhenko's family of five remain squeezed in one room, their beds lined up like a cramped hospital ward. Two metal heaters give out faint waves of warmth - when the electricity is working - but are too weak to banish the overpowering cold. The children stamp about in fur boots, their bodies wrapped inside padded dressing gowns and heavy layers of clothes. At night they lay their coats on top of the blankets and tie scarves around their heads; despite these precautions two are recovering from bronchitis.

A 2cm-thick crust of ice covers the inner window panes in the rest of the flat; only a thin blue echo of daylight glimmers through the frost. Chicken legs stored on a shelf in the kitchen stay frozen. Long, dagger-sharp icicles trail down from the corrugated roof outside.

"It's not just that we're cold," said Mrs Garazhenko, a teacher at one of Artyom's secondary schools, her words forming delicate clouds of condensation. "We haven't had any water since the pipes burst. The toilet froze and broke several months ago and then the electricity began to black out. These are inhuman conditions."

Two young girls trying to keep warm in an unheated flat in Artyom recently died in their sleep when their electric blanket short-circuited. Officially no casualties have been registered, but deaths of dozens from the cold and from fires caused by faulty heating equipment have been unofficially linked to the crisis.

In the nearby village of Razdolnoye, apartment blocks remain unheated. Lyubov Krasilnikova, a night caretaker at one of the local army bases, has taken to cooking soup on an electric stove balanced on her bedside table to keep the room at a bearable temperature. When the electricity cuts came, there were no candles to be had in the shop; the family sat in the dark.

A vicious circle of disaster has triggered her problems. Unusually extreme temperatures meant heating pipes burst; shortages of fuel meant power stations could not cope when people began turning on their electric heaters. Power cuts began and the temperatures dropped lower. But as the crisis stretches into its fourth month, Mrs Krasilnikova has begun searching for an individual to blame, settling finally for Nikolai Yudin, director of the nearby brick-making factory.

Under a Soviet era-designed scheme, Mr Yudin is paid by the local government to heat village apartment blocks using steam from the factory to provide virtually free constant heating for the entire winter. Rusting pipes run overground from the plant for a mile, to reach the radiators in the flats. The water is much cooler by the time it arrives (bits of cladding have been stolen for scrap metal) but usually the system works. In January, when temperatures were plunging to -50c, his boiler broke down and 2,000 people were left to freeze. By the time the system was mended, the pipes and radiators had already frozen and the thick metal had cracked open; the heating network was ruined.

Sitting beneath a yellowing portrait of Lenin in his director's office, muffled in his coat and fur hat, Mr Yudin lays the blame elsewhere. Every year the local administration is meant to deliver 6,000 tonnes of coal to fuel the heating process; this year only 123 tonnes arrived. Desperate telegrams were sent to the local mayor, Alexander Prokhurov, but no response arrived. The boiler stopped working when they resorted to low-grade coal.

"I spent factory money on buying more coal, because I felt sorry for the people who were beginning to freeze. We had to stop producing bricks to conserve coal for heating," Mr Yudin said angrily. The factory has been officially bankrupt for years, largely because of unpaid regional heating debts. "Despite all the promises, we've only got enough fuel now to last for four more days, and then more homes will be cut off."

In the draughty mayor's office, Mr Prokhurov wearily accuses those further up the food chain. "There isn't enough fuel and no one has done any repairs on the heating system for 40 years. What can you expect?" he said. On the roads outside his window, men can be seen dragging felled trees back to their yards, to be burnt in the home-made metal stoves that many have installed over the winter.

The buck-passing continues inside the Vladivostok White House, the head of the regional administration, where two major culprits are identified by those officials still loyal to Mr Nazdratenko: the International Monetary Fund and Russia's electricity monopoly UES. The IMF is blamed for helping close a dozen coal mines as part of a restructuring programme in 1996, leaving Primorye with just one pit. Artyom, one of the worst hit regions, is the site of seven abandoned mines. Half the coal burnt by the region is brought by train 4,000 miles from central Siberia. The officials claim that if the mines were still open, the region would never have frozen.

Protest

UES, run by the privatisation guru Anatoly Chubais, is accused of failing to ensure that the regional electricity stations had enough fuel to deal with the sudden surge in consumption. When Mr Putin sacked the energy minister, Mr Chubais was sternly reprimanded. UES has retorted that the local government failed to stockpile enough fuel. The recriminations go on and on. Mr Nazdratenko's opponents insist that corruption streaking through his administration, 6,000 miles from the eyes of the Kremlin, is the real cause of the region's suffering.

Vladimir Gilgenberg, a deputy in the regional parliament, says he has evidence to show that Mr Nazdratenko was buying fuel at inflated prices through a company owned by his son. The former governor denies the claim.

It was only late in January that Primorye's stoic population burst into protest. Razdolnoye's residents marched to the track of the Trans-Siberian express and attempted to block it off, and demonstrators filed through Vladivostok. Alarmed at the widespread coverage of the government's failure to resolve the crisis, Moscow sent the region another $16m to help and officials from the emergency situations ministry were dispatched on the 10-hour flight to Russia's eastern tip to launch a new rescue operation.

Five brigades of specialist plumbers have been sent in from northern Siberia and Moscow to replace the pipes and radiators in flats in Razdolnoye and Artyom. Their work has already reduced the number of freezing residents to 3,500, but the mission has been criticised as an extravagant face-saving exercise.

The six new radiators in Mrs Garazhenko's flat were flown at considerable expense from Moscow this week. The pipes are not yet connected, but she is hoping life will become easier when the job is done. "The workmen said the system is so rotten that if it works at all, the heat will be feeble. Next winter will be just as bad."

Analysts believe that about $5bn a year needs to be invested in Russia's decrepit energy system; the government is able to spend only $1.2bn. Primorye's crisis looks set to be the first of many winters of misery.

The cold facts

 Oymyakon in north-east Siberia, with a population of 4,000, is the coldest permanently inhabited place in the world. In 1933, the temperature fell to -68C; more recently, an unofficial reading reportedly touched -72C

 Verkhoyansk, in Siberia, experiences the greatest range of temperatures on the surface of the planet, from -68C to 37C

 The Pole of Inaccessibility, Antarctica, has an average temperature of -58C

 The lowest temperature ever registered on Earth was -89.2C, at Vostok, Antarctica in July 1983

 Over six days in February 1959, the most snow ever produced in a single snowstorm, 4.8 metres (189 ins), fell on Mt Shasta ski bowl, in California Source: Guinness Book of Records

fields.headline: Cup clash  Liverpool fans stabbed
fields.standfirst: Football site
fields.trailText: Italian football fans stabbed six Liverpool supporters and fought pitched battles with police in Rome last night before and during a Uefa Cup match.
fields.body:
Italian football fans stabbed six Liverpool supporters and fought pitched battles with police in Rome last night before and during a Uefa Cup match.

Gangs supporting AS Roma ambushed the visitors as they arrived at the Olympic Stadium, slashing their victims in the buttocks before turning on police. The six were taken to hospital where three were said to be in serious condition. Two were Norwegian and the rest believed to be British.

Police fired teargas before baton-charging the rioting Roma fans, who fought back with bottles, stones and branches snapped from trees. A taxi and a scooter were burned in the melee.

Some Italian media reports blamed drunken Liverpool fans for provoking their rivals. An AP television crew were beaten up before police in riot gear moved in under a hail of rocks and bottles. All the violence was blamed on a hardcore group of Roma fans dubbed "ultras".

More than 1,000 police escorted visiting fans from the stadium after the game, which Liverpool won 2-0, to guarded hotels in a convoy of buses.

The fourth-round tie was especially volatile because the clubs last met in the 1984 European Cup final, a memory seared into Roma hearts because they lost 4-2 on penalties. In the build-up to last night's match, ultras warned that they would would take revenge.

One of the tightest security clampdowns since Italy hosted the 1990 World Cup failed to avert clashes earlier in the day, when three Liverpool fans were injured in separate incidents. Supt Dave Lewis, one of five Merseyside officers liaising with police in Rome, said: "It does appear that these three Liverpool fans were going about their business and were picked on by Italian fans in the centre of Rome. I am as sure as I can be that these were not big gang fights."

A temporary ban on the sale of alcohol, which infuriated bar owners, was circumvented as some of the 4,000 visiting contingent were drunk hours before the 8pm kick-off.

Horseplay around the Trevi fountain, immortalised in the film La Dolce Vita, slid into hooliganism when bystanders were thrown in.

A Liverpool spokesman, Ian Cotton, said: "There is no suggestion that any of our fans have been causing trouble."

Horseplay around the Trevi fountain, immortalised in the film La Dolce Vita, slid into hooliganism when bystanders were thrown in. A Liverpool spokesman, Ian Cotton, said: "There is no suggestion that any of our fans have been causing trouble."

webTitle: New interest cut likely as Brown rules out big tax cuts

fields.headline: New interest cut likely as Brown rules out big tax cuts
fields.standfirst:
Special report: election countdown
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown will today clear the way for further cuts in interest rates from the Bank of England this year when he pledges Labour not to surrender its tough stance on taxation in order to win the coming general election.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown will today clear the way for further cuts in interest rates from the Bank of England this year when he pledges Labour not to surrender its tough stance on taxation in order to win the coming general election.

Addressing Labour's spring conference, the chancellor will promise party activists a five-point programme of social and economic reform - but not at the price of jeopardising stability as "stop-go, quick fix" tactics did before 1997.

Answering critics who say he has been too cautious and tight-fisted, he will say: "In the first term we have put stability first. In the second term we will put stability first. Every term of a Labour government will put stability first."

With polling day increasingly looking like May 3 Mr Brown will promise a "radical second term of achievement for our country" in the shape of full employment; closing the productivity gap, especially in industries and areas that lag behind; over 50% of young people going to college or university; the halving of child poverty by 2010; revitalised public services.

But the coded message behind the chancellor's uncompromising words in Glasgow today is that the budget on March 7 will only contain modest pre-election tax and benefit concessions, targeted at investment and the needy.

Most City analysts believe he has a budget surplus of £15bn compared with his own estimate of £10bn. But he is keen to reassure the Bank's monetary policy committee that, provided he keeps a tough grip on tax-and-spending, it can make further cuts in interest rates on top of last week's 0.25%.

"The budget will lock in the tough fiscal stance I set out in last year's budget and pre-budget report. There will be no return to the irresponsible election give-aways of the past" - an assault on William Hague's apparent willingness to repeat Tory errors of the 80s.

Some analysts fear that, despite this week's low inflation figures - at 1.8% well below the official 2.5% target - the ultra-cautious Bank will use the huge sums of extra public spending Mr Brown has pledged to health, transport and education as an excuse not to cut rates further.

His Glasgow speech seeks to allay those fears while also reassuring impatient activists that there is no trade-off between economic stability and Labour's long-term plans for public investment.

Mr Brown will say: "The reason we put stability first, the reason I have always said our prudence is for a purpose is that it is through locking in stability that we can reach higher in a radical second term of achievements for our country."

fields.headline: Commons soap comes to the Crossroads
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: This week I spoke at one of those dinner clubs that seem rather popular these days. You don't get paid or anything, but you have a nice meal in amiable company.
fields.body:
This week I spoke at one of those dinner clubs that seem rather popular these days. You don't get paid or anything, but you have a nice meal in amiable company. Before we sat down to the soup, someone asked me how I could bear to write about politics day in, day out, when it was such a boring subject.

But it isn't boring. Obviously many of the policies are, and so are most of the speeches. But the drama, the human interest, the sheer operatic soapiness of the whole thing!

Take industry questions yesterday. There was enough character development spread out in front of us to keep the new Crossroads going for months.

For example, Patricia Hewitt (junior manager of the motel), seems to be playing minister for renewable energy. She was asked by the Labour MP David Kidney ("Oooh, you are offal, but I like you!") whether her department would invest in what appears to be inventing a perpetual motion machine.

Ms Hewitt has a precise, sympathetic and caring voice. She sounds as if she is addressing a class of very sweet but backward children. When MPs ask her supplementary questions, she smiles at them encouragingly and nods her head brightly. She would have been perfect 30 years ago on Blue Peter.

"Our aim is for 10% of all energy to come from renewable sources within the next 10 years," she fluted. "So you'll need two empty yoghurt pots, some sticky-backed plastic, and an elastic band. Don't forget to ask mummy and daddy first!"

(Obviously I made the last bit up, but my point is that nobody would have been remotely surprised if she had said it.)

Or take Peter Hain. Until a few weeks ago, when the government was reshuffled, Mr Hain was the Foreign Office minister in charge of half the globe. The Middle East, Africa, the United Nations .. He bestrode the globe, if not like a colossus, at least like someone rather taller than his boss.

Now, he is in charge of breathing difficulties. Former miners are complaining that they can't get compensation for their ailments. Within two weeks, Mr Hain has become an expert.

Where once murmuring civil servants placed briefs about President Mbeki, and the election prospects of Mr Sharon, now they tell him of "domiciliary cases" and "identified causes of asthma". Last month he would have been appealing for calm in a difficult and potentially explosive situation. Now he is assuring MPs that "doctors prefer to see respiratory cases in person, so they can make a better judgment".

Or then there's Denis MacShane, the MP for Rotherham. He is the Benny of the new soap opera, because however well he starts, he always makes an idiot of himself by the end.

Yesterday he was complaining about the industry department's failure to bring down electricity prices. So far, so good.

Then he raved: "Put the officials into electric chairs, then if in 10 days' time they can't delivered electricity prices the same as on the continent, let me push the button!" Duh!

Finally there is Stephen Byers, a gentle soul who simply doesn't understand the wicked ways of industry. Mass redundancies, the heist of government subsidies, predatory practices - all these come as a terrible surprise.

Some politicians resemble bulls in china shops: one thinks of John Prescott or Ann Widdecombe. Others are the opposite, and are more like Mr Byers: porcelain teacups abandoned in a stockyard, kicked hither and yon, crushed under the unthinking heels of rampaging animals.

webTitle: Report of attack by Bulger killer was 'fabricated'

fields.headline: Report of attack by Bulger killer was 'fabricated'
fields.standfirst:
Newspaper story about clash in secure unit fabricated, court told

Special report: the Bulger case
Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: Two tabloid newspaper stories claiming that one of James Bulger's killers had attacked other inmates in his secure unit were in one case a fabrication and in the other blown up out of proportion, the high court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
Two tabloid newspaper stories claiming that one of James Bulger's killers had attacked other inmates in his secure unit were in one case a fabrication and in the other blown up out of proportion, the high court heard yesterday.

The articles in the Sunday People were presented as evidence supporting a legal move by the murdered child's father to block the release of Robert Thompson and Jon Venables.

One story claimed that Thompson had come to blows with another boy, while another said that he had attempted to strangle a fellow inmate with a flex.

But counsel for the home secretary said one of the stories had been invented - and a faked official report reproduced in the newspaper - while in the row that led to the "strangling" it was the other boy who was the protagonist.

Lord Woolf, the lord chief justice, recommended in October that Thompson and Venables should be eligible for release this August, when they will be 19, and said neither boy had shown "any aggression or propensity for violence during his period of detention".

Alan Newman QC, appearing for James's father Ralph, said yesterday that Lord Woolf would never have used those words if the Home Office had told him about the two attacks Thompson had allegedly perpetrated in 1997 and 1999.

Both were published on the front page of the Sunday People after the judge made his decision.

Mr Newman told the high court that official local authority reports had documented the first attack.

"There was a fight which occurred between Thompson and a fellow detainee, John Howells - each of whom was boasting about who had committed the most evil crime. Howells had apparently battered his mother to death with a hammer.

"Each person was the subject of a separate report. The official filing the report has written: 'During a volatile shift an incident occurred in which Robert Thompson and another young person, John Howells, came to blows. The situation was quickly confronted and both received medical attention and were sanctioned [punished]. Thompson suffered a graze to his knee and a bruise to his left cheek. Howells suffered a scratch to his right eye and a graze to his chest.'"

However, David Pannick QC, counsel for Jack Straw, the home secretary, said the fight "simply did not occur" and that Thompson, then 14, and Howells, then 16, had in fact been friendly.

A prison service official who investigated the claims found that the two boys had formed "a positive, supportive relationship" and that on the day the newspaper report was published Howells contacted the unit and said he had been "deeply upset" by the story.

Mr Pannick said: "This alleged incident is a complete fabrication. Someone has obtained a blank form which they have filled in and they have supplied it to the Sunday People. We don't know whether the Sunday People paid for this information or not. There is no reference to the alleged incident in the unit's records. In fact, the unit's log book for that day shows that John Howells left for court that day at 8am and didn't come back until 6.30pm. The report says that the incident occurred at 3pm."

Mr Pannick did not deny that the second alleged attack, the strangling, had taken place. But he said: "It was far more minor than Scott Walker [the alleged victim], no doubt for his own purposes, suggests - and Mr Walker was himself the protagonist in the incident. Robert Thompson was the subject of prolonged provocation.

"The persons responsible for discipline in the unit and the experts who have reported to the lord chief justice did not think that this minor incident was worth commenting on."

Mr Newman said: "In all the welter of litigation that has gone on hitherto, this is the only time Mr Bulger has been able to challenge any part of the proceedings.

"What we submit is that the lord chief justice has recommended a tariff so low that it has no regard for the enormity of the crime and threatens to undermine confidence in the criminal justice system."

The hearing continues.

webTitle: Suspected arson raises safety fears at Commons

fields.headline: Suspected arson raises safety fears at Commons
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: Ministers spoke of their fears of inadequate security in the House of Commons yesterday as police stepped up their investigation of a suspected arson attack on a government minister.
fields.body:
Ministers spoke of their fears of inadequate security in the House of Commons yesterday as police stepped up their investigation of a suspected arson attack on a government minister.

Scotland Yard has been drafted in to investigate how the blaze, which they are treating as suspicious, broke out in the office of the social security minister, Jeff Rooker, in a ministerial corridor below the Commons chamber on Tuesday night. While detectives are playing down the idea that animal liberation activists may have been involved, some ministers fear Mr Rooker - a former agriculture minister who approved a massive badger cull - may have incurred their wrath by voting against a total fox hunting ban in the hunting bill.

The fire erupted on the evening the bill completed its committee stage in the Commons, and Mr Rooker's office is flanked by ministerial committee rooms which were believed to have been used on the day by lobby groups.

Last night George Foulkes, one of two ministers who put out the 3ft flames on Mr Rooker's desk, suggested inadequate security meant someone with unauthorised access could have found their way into the ministerial corridor and lit the fire.

"I do think there's a real security problem here," the junior Scotland minister said. "There's no policeman at the end of the corridor and no CCTV cameras."

He added that there should also be a crackdown on who could use both committee rooms, which offer easy access to the ministerial offices. Mr Foulkes, who dowsed the fire with wastepaper bins of water, added: "There is a balance between access to MPs by constituents and lobby groups making legislative representations and proper security, and it is very, very difficult to get the balance right."

Police sources at Westminster insisted security was tight: police are positioned on each door, and no one can enter the building without a pass, only granted after a thorough vetting, or without being accompanied by a passholder.

Westminster officials said they would be looking at security.

fields.trailText: Good day
fields.body:
Good day

Peers. Far from being the embodiment of all that is anachronistic, the Lords have embraced the technological revolution far more swiftly than the elected Commons chamber. Peers will have their parliamentary questions answered by email from next month.

Exchange of day

Ex-Tory cabinet minister Sir Norman Fowler claimed Tony Blair was getting an easy ride with only one 30-minute question time a week instead of two 15-minute ones under the previous Conservative administration. But Commons leader Margaret Beckett said the long session was "much harder for a prime minister. It gives an opportunity for the opposition - were they to be a competent opposition - to conduct a line of sustained questioning".

Today

Commons: Not sitting. MPs return from half term recess on February 26. Lords: Debates on science and technology committee reports on science and society, and on air travel and health.

fields.headline: 29 new hospitals to be built
fields.trailText: A £3bn NHS hospital building programme announced yesterday will include 26 "fast-track" centres to speed up the treatment of non-urgent patients who often have their appointments cancelled.
fields.body:
A £3bn NHS hospital building programme announced yesterday will include 26 "fast-track" centres to speed up the treatment of non-urgent patients who often have their appointments cancelled.

Health secretary Alan Milburn said 29 building projects, worth £3.1bn, had been approved by his department. There will be an 11% increase in funding for training NHS staff, to alleviate the shortage of doctors, nurses and other professionals.

Every region in the country would be required to increase hospital beds to end the misery of patients being shipped to hospitals miles from home because of bed shortages.

"This is an unprecedented expansion in new hospital developments in the NHS," Mr Milburn told the House of Commons. "For millions of patients and thousands of staff it will provide modern state-of-the-art hospital treatment and care." The Department of Health was preparing to allow 18 schemes, but is approving all 29 recommended by its expert advisers.

The hospital projects will be built under the public finance initiative, with an option for the NHS to resume ownership at the end of the contract.

Work will begin this year on the first 12, in Birmingham, Bradford, Bristol's mental health services, Central Middlesex, East Kent, Leicester, Lewisham, Peterborough, Salford, Tunbridge Wells, Wakefield and Whipps Cross in London.

"You cannot deliver 21st century care in 19th century buildings," Mr Milburn said. "For too long investment in NHS infrastructure has been a low priority when it should have been a high priority.

"The consequences are plain for all to see: buildings that are shoddy, equipment that is unreliable, hospitals that are out of date. In too many places the environment where staff work and patients receive care is simply unacceptable."

Sixteen of the new hospitals will have the fast-track centres, which will treat only patients who need routine operations such as hip replacements. In most hospitals, planned surgery is always at risk of being cancelled to make way for emergencies. Ten other fast-track facilities will be built at existing hospitals.

"Patients will be able to book their admissions at their convenience rather than simply being given an appointment date," said Mr Milburn.

"Some will operate at weekends. Crucially they will mean greater reliability for patients by helping to end the misery of last-minute cancelled operations."

There are serious shortages of doctors and, particularly, nurses in the NHS, but Mr Milburn claimed that numbers have already risen in response to recruitment campaigns and new training places.

Between September 1999 and September 2000, there were 2,500 more doctors, 3,500 more scientists, therapists and technicians and over 6,300 more nurses in the NHS. The new money is intended to keep staff numbers increasing until 2010. The bed-cutting which has been a feature of the NHS for four decades is at an end, Mr Milburn said.

He told the Commons that 157,000 were cut between 1980 and 1997 alone. Every new hospital will have more beds than the one it replaces - 3,000 more in all.

Peter Hawker, chairman of the British Medical Association's consultants committee, said the big rise in beds was "excellent news provided the NHS is successful in recruiting the nurses and doctors required to staff them".

webTitle: Driver to get £500,000 after hitting girl

fields.headline: Driver to get £500,000 after hitting girl
fields.trailText: A motorist whose life "disintegrated" as a result of the post- traumatic stress he suffered after hitting a four-year-old deaf girl in his car was awarded   £476,500 damages yesterday.
fields.body:
A motorist whose life "disintegrated" as a result of the post- traumatic stress he suffered after hitting a four-year-old deaf girl in his car was awarded £476,500 damages yesterday.

Mark Cooper, a former scaffolder, was awarded the money by the court of appeal after Lords Justices Brooke, Keene and Ward agreed to dismiss an appeal against the award because of Mr Cooper's "parlous state" after the accident, which was not his fault. They deducted £5,950 from the original amount awarded to Mr Cooper by Judge Medawar in the Central London county court in December 1999 because he claimed loss of earnings for the nine months he spent in jail after being convicted of affray.

Elizabeth Reed, a minicab driver, was escorting "a little deaf girl of four back from her school in Hornchurch, east London, to her home," in May 1991, Lord Justice Brooke told the court.

"When the taxi came to a halt by the kerb outside the girl's home, she ran out into the road and into the path of Mr Cooper's car as he was driving at 20-25 mph along the road. Mr Cooper, who was at that time a 28-year-old self-employed scaffolder, had no chance of avoiding her," he said.

Mr Cooper, a father of two, made a claim saying he became moody and depressed after the accident in which he had first believed that he had killed Sarah Sykes, four.

The child made a full recovery, but Mr Cooper suffered from acute sickness, anger and flashbacks following the accident, the court was told.

He also dreamed about accidents involving his own children and became acutely anxious about their safety.

Mr Cooper claimed that because of his condition he was unable to run his business, which went on to collapse, and his wife left with their children because of his behaviour.

Lord Justice Brooke said there was expert evidence that Mr Cooper was still suffering severe psychological symptoms - including depression and preoccupation with the accident - two years after it had happened.

The minicab driver and her employers challenged Mr Cooper's claim, saying he had been working as a bouncer at a country club in Epping Forest after the accident and had been charged with affray and spraying CS gas with intent after chasing a carload of club customers who had caused trouble.

fields.headline: Home is the sailor
fields.standfirst: MacArthur's happy return
fields.trailText: Ellen MacArthur yesterday returned to Britain and said her triumph in the Vendee Globe round-the-world race had been made worthwhile thanks to the children she helps through her charitable work.
fields.body:
Ellen MacArthur yesterday returned to Britain and said her triumph in the Vendee Globe round-the-world race had been made worthwhile thanks to the children she helps through her charitable work.

Holding up a banner with the words "Thank you Ellen", she said a French boy had written the message to wish her well.

At a news conference at Southampton, she said: "When you are out there in the worst of times and closest to despair and things are very difficult, you have to think of them. I chose to be out there, they did not choose to have the problems they have, but they come through those problems with smiles on their faces."

The 24-year-old returned accompanied by a flotilla of 60 boats on the final leg of her journey home up the Solent. About 1,000 people watched her return.

She is now planning to spend some time with family and friends before travelling back to Les Sables d'Olonne to watch other Vendee Globe competitors cross the finish line.

webTitle: Dyke's savings plan sparks BBC row

fields.headline: Dyke's savings plan sparks BBC row
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Greg Dyke, the BBC director general, is facing the first big internal opposition to his plans to save money at the corporation after staff voted for industrial action over a new expenses policy.
fields.body:
Greg Dyke, the BBC director general, is facing the first big internal opposition to his plans to save money at the corporation after staff voted for industrial action over a new expenses policy.

In a ballot of more than 6,000 members of the broadcast union Bectu, 85% voted for a work-to-rule, while 60% supported strike action. The union claims the policy, which imposes a limit of £55 on nightly hotel bills and abolishes flat-rate meal allowances, is unreasonable.

But the BBC said yesterday the new rules were in line with industry standards, and were part of Mr Dyke's overall strategy of saving money on running the corporation and redirecting it into programme-making.

Union leaders will meet to discuss what industrial action to take. The BBC must be given seven days' notice of any action, which is likely to start in the last week of February. Industrial action would hit all areas of the BBC, apart from its commercial arm, BBC Worldwide, and its orchestras.

Bectu claimed the BBC introduced the new rules "without agreement" on February 1. As well as the cap on hotel bills, a range of allowances has been abolished. Staff on location near a BBC centre may not claim for meals, and shift workers must work more than 12 hours to claim for subsistence.

"We think the BBC has been unreasonable with its decision on allowances, which are inconsistent with industry standards. Workers can get a hot meal after 7.30pm at ITV but BBC workers have to work 12 hours before they can," a union spokesman said.

He added that BBC managers authorised and set their own levels of allowance, whereas a cap had been placed on staff expenses. "It's basically one rule for management and one rule for those that make the programmes."

A spokeswoman for the BBC said the corporation wanted to move towards reimbursing out-of-pocket expenses, rather than paying flat-rate allowances. "It's part of the rationale of putting more money into programmes. You would expect us to tighten up expenses within the overall remit of putting money into programmes, but we also want to ensure staff are not left out of pocket."

She said there were no plans for further talks with Bectu. "We hope that it won't come to action but we can't predict it."

fields.headline: Unions fear cuts at dockyard
fields.trailText: Defence unions have demanded government guarantees on the future of the Rosyth dockyard after obtaining what they claim are secret plans to run down the facility with the loss of more than 1,000 jobs.
fields.body:
Defence unions have demanded government guarantees on the future of the Rosyth dockyard after obtaining what they claim are secret plans to run down the facility with the loss of more than 1,000 jobs.

Jack Dromey, the TGWU national officer and joint defence unions spokesman, said they had received documentation from a whistleblower employed by the privatised yard's operators, Babcock Rosyth Defence, detailing plans to reduce the four docks at Rosyth to one, and the workforce from 2,200 to less than 1,000.

The claims have been dismissed by Babcock and the Ministry of Defence. The armed forces minister, John Spellar, said Babcock had given him an assurance that big cuts were not planned. "It is a ridiculous scare story," he said.

Union leaders held a mass meeting of defence staff at the Faslane nuclear submarine base on the Clyde yesterday. Afterwards, Mr Dromey said there was "unprecedented anger" at the development. He refused to produce the documents obtained by the unions, saying he wanted to protect the anonymity of their source.

He said the plans would have devastating consequences for the community of Rosyth as a whole. "We are calling on ministers and managers to come clean and we are asking them to rule out plans to run down Rosyth."

The former MoD yard was bought by Babcock in 1997. It had been guaranteed MoD work until 2007, but under the government review of warship maintenance will have to compete for the work with other dockyards. The unions say Babcock is prepared to forgo the MoD programme of work if it secures the contract to take over repair and maintenance work at the Faslane base. Union leaders have already warned that 1,000 jobs could go at Faslane if services are privatised at the yard.

"Rosyth is being used as a bargaining tool by Babcock which wants to shift its focus from the east of Scotland to the west of Scotland," said Mr Dromey.

"We are absolutely confident as to our source," he added.

Babcock's managing director, Murray Easton, said it refuted any suggestion that the Rosyth facility would be reduced to one dry dock, as this would be totally impractical.

"Any talk by trade union officials of secret plans is nonsense, and they surely recognise that Rosyth is a privately owned facility and, as such, Babcock determine the future business strategy and therefore implement their own plans."

The local Labour MSP Scott Barrie said he and his Westminster colleague Rachel Squire would seek further assurances on the yard's future.

webTitle: Plan to give award for design draws a blank

fields.headline: Plan to give award for design draws a blank
fields.standfirst: Decision delivers drubbing to claims of 'creative rebirth'
fields.trailText: British design is in such a parlous state, with young designers being forced to work on a "paltry scale" or go abroad, that a leading innovation prize will not be awarded this year.
fields.body:
British design is in such a parlous state, with young designers being forced to work on a "paltry scale" or go abroad, that a leading innovation prize will not be awarded this year.

The £10,000 Arts Foundation award for product design was to have been handed out last night by the MP Glenda Jackson at the Imagination Gallery in London, but the foundation's trustees could not find any younger British designers with good enough ideas capable of being mass produced.

Instead the money will be divided among new writers and theatre designers.

The news will be deeply embarrassing for the government, which has made design a central tenet of its "creative industries" vision.

One of the prime minister's first actions on taking power was to invite the French president, Jacques Chirac, to a meeting in Canary Wharf which showcased the work of British designers. The meeting, at the height of the Cool Britannia charm offensive, was to become notorious as the "style summit".

Ministers have also queued to praise the 1,000 millennium products assembled in the Millennium Dome as proof of the renaissance of design and innovation.

The Arts Foundation, however, suspects the problem is not that there is a shortage of nascent brilliant young British industrial designers, but that they are not being allowed to think big.

"The trustees decided to make this award in the knowledge that this country is renowned for the great talent of young designers," a foundation spokeswoman said. "However, it became apparent that there was not a sufficient range of nominated product designers to choose from who were truly embracing, or allowed to embrace, designs for mass production, one of the criteria for this particular award."

But according to design guru Stephen Bayley, the founder of the Design Museum and the man behind Ford's new global design centre which will open in London in the spring, the problem is not with the designers, but with British industry.

"Put brutally, I am afraid there is very little British manufacturing industry left to design for. That, I am afraid, has been the story for a very long time, and that is why younger designers are forever condemned to playing with bits of balsa wood here or taking their talents abroad.

"The reason there are so many great Japanese product designers over the last 40 years is that they have had so many products to design."

Mr Bayley said that the government's idea of design was 20 or even 30 years out of date.

"In a way we have gone beyond product design. We don't need it any more and it will be done in Taipei and in California anyway. Where there is a future here is in graphic design. We are among the best in the world at that because we have such a big publishing and broadcasting industry here to feed off."

Roger Sale, of the Industrial Design Centre at the University of East London, said the world of design was changing faster than politicians and even manufacturers realised and "worrying gaps" were opening up.

"There is a major gap between the hype and the reality around design in the UK. Designers have to be in at the beginning or there is almost no point anymore," he said.

But Clive Grinyer, of the Design Council, and a former partner of Jonathan Ive, the star British name behind the revolutionary iMac computer, said he was deeply disappointed that the Arts Foundation could not find a single younger designer worthy of the prize.

"There is still a great deal of inspirational product design going on in this country, whether that be in new seats for British Airways and Virgin or in-house with Black & Decker." He insisted that many foreign designers are being attracted to London because of its "vibe".

Nevertheless, he admitted that he understood the problem the Arts Foundation had highlighted.

"It is true that 65% of our designers don't end up in design, and many others move over to the craft aspect of furniture making, for instance, because of the difficulties of getting their designs mass produced."

Mr Grinyer added: "There are islands of brilliance but I do realise overall that we have a lot to do to encourage companies to be innovative and trust young designers."

Mr Grinyer, who has just been appointed as the council's design and innovation director, said he took on the job just to work on this weakness. "One way of turning this around is for designers to become entrepreneurs. I think we have a lot to learn from the dot.com experience in Silicon Valley".

The novelist Michel Faber, shortlisted for this year's Whitbread prize for Under The Skin, is the best known of the Arts Foundation winners. He and Ali Smith were chosen in the short story writing category while Susanna Heron, a scion of the painting dynasty, picked up the £10,000 for landscape design.

The film award went to Asif Kapadia, the jewellery prize to Lin Cheung. Lisa Lillywhite and Fred Meller both picked up awards for theatre design.

The designer drain

 Jonathan Ive, the doyenne of the army of expat British designers who made their home on the US west coast, is responsible for Apple's ultra-trendy range of multicoloured iMac computers.

 The German-based design team behind the new range of Porsches has almost entirely been plucked from the Royal College of Arts vehicle design department or Birmingham University. One of the great ironies of the car industry is that the fewer "British" cars are sold, the more our designers are desired by foreign manufacturers.

 Another star British designer Julian Brown has turned around the workaday Italian stationery firm Rexite with his trendy range of office equipment, including an iconic stickytape dispenser called Hannibal.

 Jasper Morrision is probably the most successful British designer of the last decade. The brains behind groovy new trams in Hanover, he has worked for a number of Italian furniture makers as well as Alessi, the kitchen company that makes accessories you don't need but must have.

 Australian-born Marc Newson is another British designer with a finger in many pies. He works mainly in Italy with Biomega bicycles and chi-chi furniture makers Cappellini. He once came up with a highly praised concept car for Ford. He has also made lights for Flos and devised ranges for the Finnish glass firm Iittala.

 James Irvine, another leading light of the emigrant design aristocracy, having worked with trendy Sottsass Associati in Milan for many years, is returning to London with his own consultancy.

webTitle: Three stabbed as fans clash in Rome

fields.headline: Three stabbed as fans clash in Rome
fields.standfirst: Football site
fields.trailText: Thousands of police were mobilised in Rome last night as trouble flared between fans of Liverpool and AS Roma before their Uefa Cup match.
fields.body:
Thousands of police were mobilised in Rome last night as trouble flared between fans of Liverpool and AS Roma before their Uefa Cup match.

Two Liverpool followers from Norway were stabbed in the buttocks outside the stadium one hour before kick-off. The men, both aged 28, were taken to hospital where they are expected to remain for a week, said the Italian newsagency Ansa.

Other Liverpool supporters threw bystanders into city's historic Trevi fountain.

Police officers guarded hotels, shadowed supporters and escorted them on to buses in one of the tightest security clampdowns since Italy hosted the 1990 World Cup.

Gerard Collins, 27, was stabbed in the left arm and thigh early yesterday morning after his group was allegedly ambushed by rival fans. Hospital authorities said his condition was not serious.

Glen McAlbin and Terry Blake were briefly hospitalised for head injuries sustained in a separate incident.

Superintendent Dave Lewis, one of five Merseyside officers liaising with police in Rome, said: "It does appear that these three Liverpool fans were going about their business and were picked on by Italian fans in the centre of Rome. I am as sure as I can be that these were not big gang fights."

A temporary ban on sale of alcohol, which infuriated bar owners, appeared to have been circumvented as some of the 4,000 visitors were visibly drunk hours before the 8pm kick-off.

A newspaper photographer, Angelo Franceschini, was kicked and punched when he resisted being dragged into the Trevi fountain. Two Bangladeshi street-vendors and a Japanese tourist were thrown into the fountain.

Liverpool fans were also accused of smashing a bar window and threatening police officers.

Police herded the visitors to Villa Borghese where a fleet of buses took them at 6pm to Stado Olimpico for the match.

It was the clubs' first meeting since the 1984 Champions Cup final, a memory seared into Roma hearts because they lost 4-2 on penalties. Italian government ministers attended the game.

By shuttling Liverpool supporters into the stadium early and detaining them for at least an hour after the match police hoped to avoid further incidents.

Two Liverpool supporters, aged 31 and 50, were arrested for drunkenness on Wednesday night.

Security will remain heavy around hotels and monuments until the bulk of the visitors fly out this afternoon.

fields.headline: Colds in babies 'ward off asthma'
fields.trailText: Babies with runny noses are less likely than other children to get asthma as they grow older, a new study indicates.
fields.body:
Babies with runny noses are less likely than other children to get asthma as they grow older, a new study indicates.

The findings add weight to the growing body of evidence that colds and minor infections brought about by a child's normal exposure to dirt can prime the immune system to fight off allergies such as those which can bring on an asthma attack.

Writing in the British Medical Journal, Sabina Illi and colleagues from the University children's hospital in Munich report how they followed up a group of 1,314 children at regular intervals from birth until they were seven years old.

The parents of the children were interviewed when their children were one, three, six, 12 and 18 months, and then at yearly intervals

webTitle: Pregnant minister praised for taking maternity leave

fields.headline: Pregnant minister praised for taking maternity leave
fields.trailText: Yvette Cooper, one of Labour's rising stars, is to become the first government minister in Britain to take maternity leave.
fields.body:
Yvette Cooper, one of Labour's rising stars, is to become the first government minister in Britain to take maternity leave.

In a move hailed last night by maternity rights campaigners, Ms Cooper, the public health minister, announced that she will take 18 weeks leave on full pay when she gives birth to her second child, which is due in August.

Ms Cooper, 31, who is married to Ed Balls, Gordon Brown's closest adviser, plans to stop working in July. She will return to work by the end of the year. After discussions with the health secretary Alan Milburn, she will take her maternity leave in line with Department of Health guidelines. Civil servants in the department are entitled to 18 weeks leave on full pay. Ms Cooper will therefore continue to draw her salary of £76,657 while she is on leave.

This is more generous than women's statutory rights. By law women are entitled to 40 weeks' maternity leave, 18 of which is paid - six weeks at 90% at full pay and 12 weeks at £60.20p a week. Mr Balls, 33, who is the treasury's chief economic adviser, will take paternity leave, as he did when their first child was born.

Ms Cooper, MP for Pontefract and Castleford, said yesterday that she was planning to have her baby at the NHS hospital in her constituency where she had her first child, Meriel, who is 20 months old. "We are planning to have the baby in Pontefract," Ms Cooper said. "The NHS staff there were wonderful to us last time round."

Maternity rights campaigners last night congratulated Ms Cooper for setting a good example to employees and employers alike.

Joanna Wade, a spokeswoman for the Maternity Alliance, said: "It is good to know that she feels confident enough to be up front that she will be taking time off. We strongly hope that this will set an example to high level employees that there are times when family has to come before work and mothers should not be punished for that."

Ms Cooper's announcement came as ministers finalise details of a government review of parental rights. They are expected to approve an increase in statutory maternity pay and in the amount of time mothers are allowed to take off work.

Campaigners are hoping that Tony Blair, who took two week's paternity leave after the birth of Leo last year, will endorse radical changes. Ms Wade said: "We are very hopeful, but there is a danger that the changes may not be as wholehearted as we would have liked to see."

Ms Cooper is regarded as one of the brightest stars in the government who is favoured by both the Blair and Brown camps. A former journalist, she was appointed to the frontline post of public health minister in 1999, two years after her election to parliament.

webTitle: Market just keeps growing for the sentimental gem

fields.headline: Market just keeps growing for the sentimental gem
fields.trailText: The Anglo-Oppenheimer bid for De Beers comes at a time of rapid growth in the market for diamond jewellery.
fields.body:
The Anglo-Oppenheimer bid for De Beers comes at a time of rapid growth in the market for diamond jewellery.

As a demonstration of romance - and riches - there is nothing like a diamond. Once that was epitomised by the 33.19 carat Krupp diamond given to Elizabeth Taylor by Richard Burton.

Today it may be the £1.2m diamond and sapphire necklace worn by Kate Winslet in Titanic, or the £10,000 waist chain with diamond fob presented to Posh Spice by her husband.

Sparklers, it seems, are still a girl's best buddy and women want more and better baubles.

In 1999 sales were driven by the "millennium effect" as buyers snapped up diamonds to mark the new century.

De Beers ran special adverts to mark the end of the millennium like: "Show her you love her for the next 1,000 years" and the worldwide value of diamonds in retail jewellery surged 11% to $13bn. An estimated $500m of that increase was linked directly to a boom in jewellery sales ahead of the new year celebrations.

In 2000 jewellers expected a downturn, but sales continued to increase.

Tiffany, the iconic American luxury label with its trademark blue boxes and 119 stores worldwide, generates more than three quarters of its $1.7bn in annual sales from jewellery and 13% of that comes from its flagship store in New York, where sales top $6,000 per square foot. Tiffany has increased its sales by 10% a year since 1995.

De Beers' new joint venture with Bernard Arnault's LVMH luxury combine aims to grab a share of that big ticket business. The two groups are pouring $400m into a four-year project to open 50 De Beers stores worldwide, which analysts predict should generate sales of $250m and profits of $25m. The first five outlets, in New York, London, Tokyo, Paris and possibly Milan, should be open next summer.

But it is not just the luxury end of the market that is sparkling. Jurek Piasecki, chairman of the Goldsmiths group, recently reported a 12% surge in sales in the month before Christmas which was mainly a result of diamond sales, including rings which average £800 each.

webTitle: Storm breaks over £12bn bid for De Beers

fields.headline: Storm breaks over £12bn bid for De Beers
fields.standfirst: Disgruntled shareholders accuse Anglo American and Oppenheimer family of conflicts of interest and 'lack of information'
fields.trailText: Disgruntled shareholders accuse Anglo American and Oppenheimer family of conflicts of interest and 'lack of information'.
fields.body:
Diamonds have caused some of the bloodiest civil wars on the planet but yesterday the battlefield was the boardroom.

The wealthy Oppenheimer family supported by mining giant Anglo American unveiled a $17.6bn (£12.1bn) deal to buy the biggest name in diamonds, De Beers.

The offer was better than the one put on January 31 when speculation led to a cautionary statement to the Johannesburg stock exchange but minority shareholders were still up in arms.

The carefully staged presentations of the improved offer led by Mr Oppenheimer in Johannesburg and linked to London via satellite was expected to be a jovial affair yesterday.

But the calm of Anglo's offices in Carlton House Terrace was soon broken as a bad tempered spat developed when disgruntled independent shareholders expressed their concern.

They accused the Oppenheimers and Anglo of conflicts of interest and said there had been a lack of information.

Mr Oppenheimer insisted the deal agreed by independent directors at De Beers was good value for shareholders and South Africa alike and he said there was no question of secrecy.

"Once De Beers goes private, it has no intention of disappearing behind locked doors and becoming an organisation unavailable for scrutiny," insisted the family scion. But Jeremy Hosking, a director of Marathon Asset Management which has a stake in De Beers questioned whether the board of directors, which had been considering the bid, really thought of themselves as independent. Many were past employees of De Beers, he pointed out.

Gary Ralfe, managing director of De Beers dismissed this. "I think that is grossly unfair. We had people of great integrity and honour [on the board]. Four of them who were non-executives were absolutely independent," he argued.

Critics fear the highly secretive diamond trade will become even more opaque as the the Oppenheimers take De Beers off the stock market and away from the prying eyes of financial analysts.

Many point out that Nicky Oppenheimer, head of the family and already chairman of De Beers and deputy chairman of Anglo, is a man who hates publicity.

In person, Nicky comes across as a a shy and diffident individual who proclaims he is happiest flying his personal helicopter or poring over antique books or playing cricket.

But supporters say he is an iron fist inside a very soft velvet glove and he knows a good deal when he sees one. He is also a political animal - winning the backing of South Africa's president Thabo Mbeki - and determined to keep the blood line intact.

No entry to US

Securing political backing was seen as a triumph for Nicky. Under the proposed offer, De Beers would de-list from the Johannesburg stock exchange - a major blow to the South African bourse's share turnover - after more than 100 years. But the astute chairman made it clear South Africa would benefit, saying the transaction would generate $2.8bn in cash flow into the country.

De Beers which coined the phrase "A Diamond is Forever" has never shaken off the image of secretiveness despite an 18-month programme of trying to make itself more accessible to shareholders.

Diamonds are loved by celebrities such as Elizabeth Taylor and Naomi Campbell but Mr Oppenheimer and De Beers directors are disliked by antitrust officials who accuse them of running a cartel and ban them from travelling to the US, by far the biggest retail market for precious stones.

For Nicky, say some, taking De Beers private would also shelter the group from analysts who have noticed recently a crop of rivals make in-roads into the Oppenheimers' fiefdom. Although the group still controls 65% of the $8bn uncut diamond market, it has lost ground.

Mr Oppenheimer has become increasingly agitated about the activities of Lev Leviev, an Israeli-Russian who has effectively prised control of Russia and Angola from the family.

There are also growing fears in the company about the growing power of Rio Tinto, an Anglo-Australian group which is by some measures the biggest commodity miner in the world and is becoming increasingly interested in diamonds.

It is not impossible that the offer made by the Oppenheimers for De Beers could produce a counter offer from Rio Tinto although a complex web of cross shareholdings between De Beers and Anglo would make this difficult.

The formal world of diamonds is also worried about the illegal mining and trading which has become endemic in parts of Africa. Illicit exports of diamonds have exacerbated conflicts in Angola, Sierra Leone and the Democratic Republic of Congo.

Ironically the tougher climate for De Beers comes as the company makes record profits due to the economic boom and the "millennium effect" in the world's biggest diamond retail market, the US.

De Beers had earnings of $1.3bn last year compared to $831m for the 12 months before. But it warned that the consumer slowdown in north America was already evident in slackening diamond jewellery sales.

The deal is complicated - not least due to the number of cross-holdings that make up the dense relationship between Anglo and its sibling De Beers. The takeover is proposed by a consortium called DBI which is made up of the Oppenheimer's family firm Central Holdings Ltd (CHL) with a 45% stake, Anglo (45%), and Debswana (10%) which is a joint venture between De Beers and the Botswana government. CHL would hold a management contract for De Beers with Mr Oppenheimer at its head.

Cautionary note

The Oppenheimer family is funding its $1.2bn stake in De Beers by reducing its stake in Anglo from 8% to 5%. Under the terms of the deal De Beers shareholders would receive $43.17 per share which represents a 31% premium to the price of De Beers on January 31, the day before a cautionary note was issued to the stock exchange, and 69% premium to the 12-month average of De Beers shares.

Anglo already has a 32.3% stake in De Beers while the diamond group controls in return 35.4% of Anglo, an increasingly expansionist mining conglomerate which recently bought British aggregates group Tarmac. Anglo moved its primary listing from Johannesburg to London in 1999 and De Beers admitted it considered a similar move.

Yesterday's deal must still be confirmed by a majority of shareholders so the war over diamonds has not ended.

fields.headline: Diamonds and gold
fields.standfirst: The Oppenheimer story
fields.trailText: De Beers which has been effectively controlled by the Oppenheimers for nearly 70 years, was not established by them. It was formed by British merchant-adventurer Cecil Rhodes but the Oppenheimers stepped in when it ran into trouble during the Great Depression of 1929-33.
fields.body:
De Beers which has been effectively controlled by the Oppenheimers for nearly 70 years, was not established by them. It was formed by British merchant-adventurer Cecil Rhodes but the Oppenheimers stepped in when it ran into trouble during the Great Depression of 1929-33.

Harry's father Ernest Oppenheimer arrived in South Africa as a diamond agent from London where he had taken British citizenship.

He was born in Friedburg, Germany, in 1880 and worked for diamond merchant Dunkelsbuhler & Co in Hamburg before moving with the firm to London.

He reached Kimberley in 1902 still with Dunkelsbuhler and become mayor of the city in 1912. Four years earlier his son Harry was born.

Ernest Oppenheimer soon found a growing interest in gold and in 1917 he established Anglo American to exploit gold on the Witwatersrand.

Three years later Oppenheimer was buying up the competition. He created Consolidated Diamond Mines of South West Africa to acquire German concessions in what is now Namibia.

The following year he was knighted and in 1925 he formed the New London Diamond Syndicate which pulled together a range of diamond interests.By 1932 the Depression had forced the closure of De Beers diamond mines and the Oppenheimers and Anglo stepped in.

In 1938 Ernest sent his 30-year-old son Harry to the US to investigate the power of consumer advertising. But the second world war intervened and shut most De Beers mines once again. The company's London offices in Charterhouse Street were destroyed by the Luftwaffe.

fields.headline: City diary
fields.trailText: There does seem to be a curse attached to the annual Retail Week conference..
fields.body:
 There does seem to be a curse attached to the annual Retail Week conference. Last year - you may recall - there was sensation when Jim Hodkinson, the chief executive of New Look clothing chain, was given a £600,000 payoff on being sacked after (allegedly) sexually harassing a female employee at the conference's awards night disco. The bad luck has rubbed off on this year's "outstanding panel of speakers" (according to the blurb). Day two promises a talk on "Ecological and environmental issues of modern retailing", by Susan Falk, billed as the president of Body Shop International. Sadly, Ms Falk resigned from her position (responsible for products and marketing) back in January after only nine months. The curse extends to Alan McWalter,marketing director at M&S, who is speaking on "Using your brand to deliver success". Mr McWalter's masterstroke at rebranding M&S using the "size 16" ad (remember? a naked woman shouting "I am normal" on a hilltop) delivered so much success that shoppers went elsewhere.

 Speaking of curses, Richard Branson seems to be under one. First it was the National Lottery, then the east coast rail franchise, and now it's a £6,000 bet with Nicola Horlick. In March 1998, Branson bet Horlick (famous for her one-woman siege of Deutsche Bank HQ in Frankfurt after being sacked) that her Société Générale Asset Management UK growth fund would not be able to outperform the Footsie all-share index by 2% for three years running. With just a month remaining until the wager's end, SGAM's fund is up 29% while the FTSE All Share has gained 14.5%, according to number-crunchers at Money Marketing magazine. Virgin Direct's tracker fund lags at 11.1%.

 Clients hoping to get any sense out of Deutsche Bank's London office today won't have much luck: the annual bonuses were announced yesterday and such was the size of the company's largesse that the celebrations will have meant sore heads from the booze and sore fingers from counting their money.

 Some hopeful news for those (such as Bank of England hard man Mervyn King) who did not get presents on Valentine's Day: perhaps your lover ordered them from Lastminute.com. In which case they might still be on the way. Chris Greene ordered a tasteful Valentine's gift (a pink helium balloon with I Love You on it, very classy) from the dot.com on February 8, and was puzzled when his girlfriend didn't get it on Wednesday. On telephoning Lastminute to inquire, he was told: "Oh yes, we did have some delivery problems." A refund was eventually offered, but only after Chris had to point out the significance of the date.

 A strange notice has appeared in the corridors of the Treasury. Calling for "Budget buddies" (staff who accompany embargoed copies of the Budget to various places, including the media), the notice offers the following incentives: "You can meet a famous correspondent and ride in a chauffeur-driven car." Whee. Life there must be deadly dull if that's seen as an attraction.

 Astonishing news that GE Capital (the finance arm of US megacorp GE) gets its callcentre staff in India to adopt anglicised aliases when talking to western customers. Yesterday the company claimed it was "extremely common in Asia" for people to shorten their names (which is not quite the same thing, surely?) and that UK or US staff were also asked to simplify their names. I did intend to call GE Capital's Asia-Pacific region press officer, Marcy Brucellaria, to discuss if this smacked of racism, but I couldn't pronounce her name.

Calling for "Budget buddies" (staff who accompany embargoed copies of the Budget to various places, including the media), the notice offers the following incentives: "You can meet a famous correspondent and ride in a chauffeur-driven car." Whee. fields.headline: Owen thrives on Roma therapy
fields.standfirst:
Liverpool take two goals to Anfield as Eriksson finds food for thought
Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: On a night that will live long in the minds of Liverpool fans, Gerard Houllier's men placed one foot in the last eight of the Uefa Cup last night thanks to a brace from Michael Owen.
fields.byline: Ian Ross at the Olympic stadium
fields.body:
Michael Owen, starting his first game for a month, scored two priceless goals for Liverpool on a magnificent evening in Rome here last night.

Watched by the England coach Sven-Goran Eriksson - keeping tabs on possible players for the friendly against Spain at Villa Park on February 28 - Owen handed his team a golden chance of reaching the last eight of the Uefa Cup when they play the second leg at Anfield on Thursday next week.

In the same stadium 17 years ago Liverpool defeated the same opposition to win the last of their four European Cups.

"I am very, very proud of them," said the Liverpool manager Gérard Houllier, his face almost betraying the astonishment which must have enveloped him as his most fanciful, dreams were given substance and life.

"To come to the home of the Serie A leaders and win so well, so convincingly, is absolutely wonderful. You can never take anything for granted in football but we are all very content," he added.

Roma, of course, will not readily concede defeat but, if they are now to turn logic on its head, they will have to play much better on the banks of the Mersey than they did beside the Tiber last night.

Roma were off-colour and weakened by injuries and omissions but nothing should detract from Liverpool's sweet victory nor dilute their sense of satisfaction. They played with intelligence and style, defended with gusto and bravery and, after safely negotiating an uncomfortable early spell, never once looked like losing. "We were poor - very poor," said the Roma coach, Fabio Capello. Actually they were made to look poor. There is a difference.

Italian football boasts many qualities and yet, curiously, only rarely does it surprise. Roma's approach to a game of such importance was predictable inasmuch as Capello's team never once betrayed a sense of undue urgency and might, to any non-partisan onlooker, have been playing a team of waiters plucked from any Via Veneto restaurant.

Indeed, in those moments of a chess-like opening half when Liverpool gifted them sufficient space and time in which to weave their magic, Roma did not so much stroll as swagger, prodding away gently at their opponents' defence in the familiar Latin belief that even the most secure of locked doors will eventually open. It was not to be.

Capello recently insisted that winning the Italian League title was his sole priority this season - Roma are six points ahead of Juventus at the top of the table - and with Sunday's game against Lecce in mind, he chose to leave Gabriel Batistuta on the substitutes' bench and omitted completely Francesco Totti.

Initially Liverpool were stretched - and pulled and manipulated - as Roma's intricate movement and precise passing carried them from no man's land to positions of potential too often for English comfort. But Liverpool's resistance was most admirable.

After they had held firm for 20 or so minutes a sense of adventure began to draw Houllier's side forward; it was a warning Roma chose to ignore.

The opening half's one genuine chance was to fall to Marco Delvecchio on 42 minutes but, having risen well to reach Amadeo Mangone's cross, he could do no more than head high of Sander Westerveld's goal. Had Houllier replaced the tiring Owen during the interval and instructed his side to be cautious he would have been forgiven. He did not because he enjoys a gamble.

The Frenchman's reward was handsome, indeed. Just 40 seconds into the second half, Owen intercepted Alessandro Rinaldi's awful cross-field pass and, having side-stepped Mangone, he drove the ball home, low and hard.

Staring a first home defeat this season full in the face, Roma duly poured forward with, it must be said, a certain recklessness. It was to cost them dearly.

With 18 minutes remaining Owen struck for a second time, arriving unannounced to head in a Christian Ziege cross after the sweetest ofexchanges with Gary McAllister. And that was that - a remarkable performance, a remarkable result.

Roma ( 3-4-1-2) Antonioli; Samuel, Rinaldi, Mangone: Cafu, Tommasi (Batistuta, 66min), Emerson, Candela; Nakata (Assuncao, 52); Delvecchio (Guigou, 82), Montella

Liverpool ( 4-4-2 ) Westerveld; Babbel, Hyypia, Henchoz, Carragher; Barmby, McAllister, Hamman, Ziege (Smicer, 75); Fowler, Owen (Litmanen, 80).

Referee: M Mark ( Germany).
