fields.headline: Ken Russell's guide to movie-making
fields.standfirst: How do you get two reluctant male stars to wrestle in the nude? Or force a child actor who can’t swim to jump into a deep lake? The veteran director of Tommy and Women in Love explains
fields.trailText: How do you get two reluctant male stars to wrestle in the nude? Or force a child actor who can’t swim to jump into a deep lake? The veteran director of Tommy and Women in Love explains
fields.body:
THE PITCH

Everyone who has ever tried to get a film made is a con artist. All right, I'll amend that: everyone who has tried to set up a movie is a liar and a cheat, or at best, a big fat fibber.

Harry Saltzman, producer of the Bond films, The Battle of Britain, and the Harry Palmer trilogy, wanted me to make the third and last Harry Palmer. "I understand you make art films," he said at our first meeting. "I like art, my house is full of it. And I'd like to make an art film with you. Anything special you have in mind?"

"How about Tchaikovsky?" I ventured.

"Tchaikovsky's fine," he said. "In the meantime, if you wanna break into features, you've gotta start off with a sure thing. The Ipcress File and Funeral in Berlin were big box-office bonanzas and Billion Dollar Brain's gonna be the biggest yet. Get that one under your belt, get yourself a name and then we'll talk Tchaikovsky."

So I let him talk me into it.

Some time later, when I reminded him of his promise, he was deeply offended that I'd had the effrontery to bring it up. Billion Dollar Brain was not the box-office hit Harry had hoped for, so he was less than happy when I reminded him of his promise to let me make a film on Tchaikovsky.

I did get to make that film on Tchaikovsky, but Harry didn't produce it, United Artists did. They had financed and distributed Billion Dollar Brain, and talked me into directing Women in Love. Although the Harry Palmer movie had only made a respectable financial return, the D H Lawrence movie went through the roof, so understandably they were going to look with a friendly eye on any other movie I might propose. But at the mention of the word Tchaikovsky, their faces fell. "What's it about?" they asked mournfully.

"It's about a homosexual who falls in love with a nymphomaniac," I said. Without another word they gave me the money. It was the most successful pitch of my life.

CASTING

Casting - I tremble at the very mention of the word. It's like Russian roulette, walking the plank in shark-infested waters, running over a bed of red-hot coals, jumping into a snake pit . . .

Experience has taught me to be well on my guard and to take an actor's talents according to his CV with a large pinch of salt. Nevertheless, such is the cunning of the average thespian that they are able to slip through one's defences and pull a fast one. After all they are "actors" and learn their survival techniques from a very early age, as I found to my cost on Mahler.

Casting the young Gustav was a bit of a problem, owing to the fact that he had to ride, swim and play the piano. Most of the boys I auditioned could manage two out of three, but finding a contender who could handle the lot proved difficult. Finally I settled for Gary someone or other, who assured me he was fine so far as his athletic abilities were concerned, but was a bit rusty on the piano. However, he read his lines well and looked remarkably like Robert Powell, who was playing Mahler.

So, on the understanding that he practised the piano every day, I hired him. After all, he only had to play scales and I assumed he could manage that with ease. He was a bright boy, keen as Colman's, and desperate to do the part.

I stopped worrying and got caught up in the hurly burly of pre-production, but still managed to phone him from time to time. Gary was never there; he was always down at the baths according to his mother, who added reassuringly that the piano tuition was coming on fine. I guess I should have smelt a rat but I had far greater problems to sort out and missed the obvious.

What should have been obvious became horrifyingly so on choppy Derwentwater five weeks later. We had reached the point in the schedule where the young Mahler, wishing to show off to his school chums, attempts to demonstrate that he is as at home in the water as they are by plunging into the chilly waters of the lake in a foolhardy attempt to swim across it. In the event, he only manages a few yards before getting into difficulties and being ignominiously rescued.

So, imagine the scene. There we are, with me and the camera crew in a boat moored a little offshore and young Gary poised on the water's edge in his underwear ready to plunge in, swim into close-up, become exhausted, and start to drown. Everyone knew exactly what was expected of them and we were all keyed up for the take when Gary's forlorn little voice was caught up by the wind and whipped across the choppy waters towards me.

"Mr Russell," he shouted through cupped hands. "I've got a confession to make . . . I lied to you, I can't swim! I can only manage a few strokes." So that's why he was always down at the baths when he should have been practising the piano, I thought, before shouting back at him: "Never mind, Gary, just do your best, swim out a few strokes - and then pretend to get into difficulties."

"But Mr Russell, I don't want to, I'm scared." "Nonsense! You can do it if you try," I shouted back with a touch of steel in my voice. "Ready now - roll camera, action!"

It's amazing how that word "Action" galvanises the mind. Even a pathetic wimp like Gary was galvanised sufficiently to wade into the water and take the plunge, for all the world like a cross-channel record-breaker. He got all of three yards, started blubbing, and waded shivering and snivelling back to shore. This was disastrous. Defeat was staring us in the face. True, we'd got him in the water and starting to swim - but that was all in long shot. We still needed a few shots in close-up of him swimming and getting into difficulties. And the drowning scene was crucial to the film - we simply had to have it.

"Great, Gary, we've got it," I shouted. "Now just jump in a boat and we'll row you out here to discuss the next scene before the light goes." He wasn't happy, but before he could object, an assistant director had bundled him into a boat.

"Here Gary, let me give you a hand," I said as he was brought alongside. Trustingly he did so, whereupon I sort of lost my balance and poor Gary was hurled into the deep - as both boats pulled away from him like mad and the camera, primed for the crucial moment, purred into action. And what do you know? Gary managed to swim half a dozen strong strokes before giving up the ghost. It was the most convincing drowning scene I have ever seen.

PRINCIPAL PHOTOGRAPHY

The male stars of Women in Love were a problem. The nude wrestling scene was coming up. Initially they'd been very gung-ho about it, but as the shooting day drew near, their enthusiasm rapidly diminished. One of the contenders complained of a sore ankle and took to limping, while the other began to develop a cold and went about sniffing and coughing. At first I didn't take them seriously, but when they both produced doctors' certificates excusing them from stripping off regardless, I ignored their protestations, brushed aside their medical certificates and advised them to have an early night, so as to be on set the following morning, ready for the fray.

What I didn't tell them was that I had also scheduled an alternative scene featuring the girls in case the boys dug their heels in and refused to strip off. The fateful day arrived with everyone poised ready to rush on to the alternative set in case our two unwilling protagonists should really chicken out. But dead on the stroke of 8.30am, they both strode into the baronial hall, where the fight was due to take place, whipped off their dressing-gowns without demur and stood there as naked as the day they were born - proud as peacocks. So for the rest of that day and most of the next, we shot the controversial wrestling scene that made screen history - without any sign whatever of a sore ankle or a single nasal sniff. Who or what had worked this seemingly major miracle?

Well, when it was all over, I finally found out. The person responsible was the stand-in for the more macho of the two actors. According to his testimony, he had cajoled them into joining him for a drink at the local pub in order to drown their depression and further strengthen their resolve to stand firm in their decision. Not usually the best of friends, the alcohol mellowed them into becoming quite chummy and by the time their bladders reached bursting point, they staggered off to the outside loo, giving each other mutual support. And it was much to their mutual relief that as far as their manhood was concerned, there wasn't much to choose between them. It had all been a question of "size" and male vanity. Having said that, it has to be admitted that one of the contestants cheated by giving nature a helping hand just before every take.

THE PREMIERE

Personally I've had more than my fair share of first-night disasters, but as they evoke painful memories, they are best forgotten. I'll let just one example suffice to prove my point. It happened at the premiere of Billion Dollar Brain - my first big-time movie.

I was sitting in the front row of the dress circle next to the film's producer, Harry Saltzman, when suddenly, on the changeover from one projector to the other at the start of reel three, the picture popped on to the screen without sound.

"This can't last," I thought to myself, "the projectionist is bound to notice and do something about it." But as the agonising seconds turned into excruciating minutes and the slow hand-clapping began, I somehow overcame the slow paralysis creeping over me, sprang to my feet and went in search of an usherette.

"Where's the projection box?" I shouted to a dark silhouette above the growing hubbub of protest.

"The wot?" she replied.

"The place where they show the films."

"Search me," she snapped, "you'd better ask the commissionaire."

Tearing down the stairs two at a time, I found him in the foyer chatting up the refreshments girl. I repeated the question. Stunned, he stammered a reply . . . which I doubt you will believe.

"Straight out the swing door, guv'nor, down the first alleyway on your right, up the fire escape and across the roof to what looks like a brick shithouse - and give four raps for admittance." And as I ran like fury to the swing doors, his final words echoed in my ears. "Make sure it's four knocks or they won't let you in - vandalism."

Two minutes and four knocks later, I was finally admitted to the inner sanctum by an astonished, ageing projectionist - too surprised to talk.

"Sound!" I screamed at him. "There's no fucking sound!" He took the news with surprising calm.

"I thought it was a bit quiet for a Bond film," he said, confusing his Saltzman heroes, before slowly putting down the girlie magazine that had been occupying his mind and flicking a switch, which mercifully restored the sound. Two men in smart suits now hit the scene. I recognised them as company execs.

"What happened?" they said in unison.

"There was a blip on the automatic changeover," said the projectionist and left it at that.

"So what are we going to do?" I said. "We've lost nearly six minutes of important plot development; the audience won't have a clue what's happening."

"How long will it take to rewind and start the reel again?" barked one of the execs.

"Give or take a minute, I'd say five minutes," mused the projectionist.

"More like 10," I mumbled.

"That's suicide," said the other exec, "we'll have a riot on our hands."

He was right. So, somewhat shattered, we left the film to churn on, crossed the roof, went down the fire escape, up the alley and back into the cinema, passing disgruntled patrons on their way out. What a night . . . and it wasn't over. Worse was to come - over which I will draw a veil, lest I am tempted, as I relive the debacle in my mind's eye, to cut my own throat.

Extracted from Directing Film by Ken Russell (Batsford, www.batsford.com).

He took the news with surprising calm. "I thought it was a bit quiet for a Bond film," he said, confusing his Saltzman heroes, before slowly putting down the girlie magazine that had been occupying his mind and flicking a switch, which mercifully restored the sound. Two men in smart suits now hit the scene. I recognised them as company execs. "What happened?" they said in unison. "There was a blip on the automatic changeover," said the projectionist and left it at that. "So what are we going to do?" I said. "We've lost nearly six minutes of important plot development; the audience won't have a clue what's happening." "How long will it take to rewind and start the reel again?" barked one of the execs. "Give or take a minute, I'd say five minutes," mused the projectionist. "More like 10," I mumbled. "That's suicide," said the other exec, "we'll have a riot on our hands." He was right. So, somewhat shattered, we left the film to churn on, crossed the roof, went down the fire escape, up the alley and back into the cinema, passing disgruntled patrons on their way out. What a night . . . and it wasn't over. Worse was to come - over which I will draw a veil, lest I am tempted, as I relive the debacle in my mind's eye, to cut my own throat. Extracted from Directing Film by Ken Russell (Batsford, www.batsford.com).

webTitle: The debt is £16m? So what, this is Wednesday

fields.headline: The debt is £16m? So what, this is Wednesday
fields.trailText: The crisis at Sheffield Wednesday is down to the short-sightedness of those at the top and their failure to show enough ambition.
fields.body:
It saddens me to see Sheffield Wednesday, where I had two spells as manager, struggling to stay in the First Division. Some unsuccessful signings have not helped but above all the crisis is down to the short-sightedness of the board and their failure to show enough ambition.

When it was apparent last season that Danny Wilson was in serious trouble they should have re-invested to make sure the club did not go down. Instead Wednesday slipped out of the Premiership and, rather than everything being geared to getting straight back up, they are being run with almost non-league thinking.

There has been cost-cutting, chipping away at the squad and a failure to bring in players. I feel sorry for Paul Jewell, who was sacked this week after being given one of football's most thankless tasks. Basically he was swimming upstream and I doubt if Sir Alex Ferguson could have done any better.

Paul not only had to do the job with his hands tied but also had to get rid of the high earners, with Peter Atherton, Niclas Alexandersson and Ian Nolan among those sold since the summer. Some of the young lads who have been thrust into the first team may turn out to be very good players but they can hardly be expected to thrive under these circumstances.

When youngsters are thrown in at Manchester United they have quality team-mates to help them along. Wednesday's midfield four have been so inexperienced at times it is inevitable results have suffered.

When the club were relegated the board's priority should have been to re-invest and win promotion as quickly as possible. The cost-cutting is false economy.

I know the debts are supposedly £16m but in football these days the only way to get that back is to be in the Premiership, where the rewards are massive. That is why the board at Hillsborough should have speculated to accumulate both this season and last. They can attract 30,000 for every home game if things on the pitch are right.

Instead Wednesday have fallen further behind and, if they slip straight into the Second Division, it could take years to get the club back where it has been for the last decade. Peter Shreeves, the caretaker manager, has a hell of a job on his hands.

Peter is a big pal of mine and we speak a lot. He worked with me at Wednesday and Nottingham Forest and I really hope he can carry on as he started on Tuesday, with a win at home to Tranmere, and lead Wednesday to safety.

Coming out of the bottom three in midweek will have given everyone a lift, though they have played more games than the clubs below them. The loan signings of Carlton Palmer and Trond Soltvedt will help as well but the new arrivals must not stop there. The board need to give Peter whatever help they can in the transfer market and show they will not just lie down and accept the inevitable.

I must say that when I was at Wednesday for the second time in 1997-98 I was never given the impression the club were in financial trouble. In fact it was always spelled out to me that they were ambitious and wanted to be right among it.

My intention, as the then chairman Dave Richards knew, was to add the two or three quality players I thought were needed to make the club capable of mounting a European challenge.

When I left less than three years ago I felt there was a very useful first-team outfit with people such as Benito Carbone, Paolo di Canio, Emerson Thome, Petter Rudi, Alexandersson, Des Walker and Andy Hinchcliffe, who was an England international then. Now it seems the only way they will make an impression on Europe in the next 10 years is if they write a decent song.

For all the board's failure, you would have to point fingers at certain players and wonder whether Danny Wilson made the right signings as well. Some of those brought in over the past couple of years have failed to produce, particularly Gilles de Bilde, Wim Jonk and Gerald Sibon.

In that respect the club can feel a bit robbed and it will be hard for them to offload people for anything like the fees they paid. In the Premiership players' values automatically go up and even moderate players are worth more.

I know how much the fans will be hurting. Wednesday are a massive club with a huge support base who should be big enough for the top 10 of the Premiership. The next 14 games are perhaps the most important they have ever had.

webTitle: FA Cup preview: Wycombe v Wimbledon

fields.headline: Straight man who found fame in the Crazy Gang
fields.standfirst: Lawrie Sanchez won the Cup for a club he hopes to topple, writes  Martin Thorpe
fields.trailText: Lawrie Sanchez won the Cup for a club he hopes to topple, writes Martin Thorpe.
fields.body:
The mist was lifting at Wycombe Wanderers' rural training ground as the players finished their morning session and headed over for a photocall, gathering round the manager and his assistant who already had the FA Cup in their hands.

"You can only touch it if you've won it," said the manager with a straight face. The responding groans were inevitable but for Lawrie Sanchez and his No2 Terry Gibson pride at their achievement underpinned the joke.

The pair have been taking endless trips down memory lane this week, recounting that boiling Wembley day 13 years ago when they helped Wimbledon take the art of FA Cup giantkilling to the final, beating the then mighty Liverpool 1-0.

Many flamboyant characters have been involved in building the legend of the Crazy Gang - Vinnie Jones, John Fashanu, Dennis Wise. But it is Sanchez's name in the history books. For it was the midfielder who scored the winner that May afternoon in 1988. Now, all these years later, he and Gibson find themselves drawn at home in the fifth round against the club where a large part of their collective heart still resides.

No doubt the Wycombe management team will be upset to see at first hand the old banger which the once spiky hot rod has now become. But while they clearly want to claim another First Division scalp following the earlier-round defeats of Grimsby and Wolves, a soft spot remains. "Obviously we want to go through," says Sanchez, "but if we go out I'd rather it be to Wimbledon."

Not only did Sanchez spend nine years playing in dark blue; he knows the current manager Terry Burton well and five of the current Dons squad played for Sanchez when he coached the reserves after returning from a successful stint managing Sligo Rovers.

But, despite the Wimbledon link, do not expect any tracksuit-burning stunts or decapitated socks in the Wycombe Wanderers dressing-room. While Vinnie, Fash and Wisey were the heart of the Crazy Gang, Sanchez was in the More Serious Gang along with Gibson and Dave Beasant.

"I looked at all those antics and thought, 'They're not for me,"' says the former grammar school boy with a university degree in management. "But, though we were not the greatest mates off the field, once we put the shirt on we became part of a team.

"That's what unnerved Liverpool. In the tunnel before that final you could see they were nervous. They wouldn't make eye contact. They were saying to themselves, 'Hang on a minute, they're not in awe of us.' And they were right. It was the biggest day of our careers."

Sanchez has only one complaint of that day: "When I scored the goal Wisey jumped on me and in all the pictures afterwards he is covering my face."

The memories are recalled with a twinkle, for Sanchez loves his football. He calls being a manager a lifestyle, not a job. And, though he pores over his statistics and videos with scholarly enthusiasm, he is no dry intellectual. The 41-year-old is refreshingly clear in his decisions and human in his dealings. He will never put a team sheet up before calling in the players who have been dropped and explaining why.

Sanchez, who came through the tragic death of his wife with breast cancer three years ago, took over a demoralised set-up at Adams Park a year later and saved them from relegation to the Third Division.

It is his first management job in the Football League but this season, after wheeling and dealing with limited financial resources, he harbours hopes of reaching the Second Division play-offs. Injuries are a problem, with last season's top scorer Sean Devine out long-term and the current top hot-shot Andy Rammell struggling to be fit for tomorrow's sell-out tie.

But it appears that neither injuries, nor his beloved Wimbledon, will stop the inevitable rise of Sanchez. "I always wanted to be a manager," he says. "I had already taken my coaching badge before that famous final. Now I am following in the footsteps of two well-known managers here, in Martin O'Neill and John Gregory. In five years' time I hope I'll have become the third to be managing at the top level."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Straw calls halt to £80m IT system

fields.headline: Straw calls halt to £80m IT system
fields.standfirst: Collapse of bid to modernise Whitehall technology
fields.trailText: February 16 2001: The government faced embarrassment yesterday over its efforts to modernise Whitehall computers when it emerged that the final phase of an £80m system intended to clear the backlog of asylum seekers had been scrapped.
fields.body:
The government faced embarrassment yesterday over its efforts to modernise Whitehall computers when it emerged that the final phase of an £80m system intended to clear the backlog of asylum seekers had been scrapped.

Jack Straw, the home secretary, admitted that the system, which was designed to save more than £100m and should have been completed in 1998, would not now become fully operational.

It is the latest in a series of technical problems to hit the government and the Home Office in particular. Two years ago the fiasco over passport processing led to huge queues at offices across Britain.

The system, designed by the German company Siemens Business Services, was to have been used by the immigration and nationality directorate to replace much of the paperwork in asylum cases.

But the project was troubled from the start. An early breakdown led to a backlog of 102,000 cases last year. An interim solution brought the backlog down to 66,000 and ministers have decided not to risk further breakdowns.

Mr Straw announced the decision to scrap the system in a written parliamentary answer. He said it was "over-complex and out of touch with current working practices".

Speaking on BBC Breakfast TV, the Home Office minister Barbara Roche blamed the previous government. "The Tories, when they were in power, ordered this flawed system which the national audit office said was overambitious, so we have inherited a real problem from them."

But Simon Hughes, who speaks for the Liberal Democrats on home affairs, said that Labour should have turned the project around. He claimed that more than 70% of Home Office IT projects were either delayed, over budget or both.

The developments will focus attention on the government's struggle to reshape IT in Whitehall . Successive governments have been accused of wasting taxpayers' money on flawed projects.

In the 1970s some IT projects were undertaken in-house, others by consultants whom civil servants found dif ficult to manage. By the late 80s the consultants were being done away with and IT development was contracted out.

In January last year the public accounts committee published a report on the government's IT record. There had been more than 25 cases in the 1990s where implementing IT systems had led to "delay, confusion and inconvenience to the citizen".

The committee chairman David Davis yesterday said one of the major problems was the "horrible interface" between civil servants who understand all there is to know about, for example, the national insurance system but know little of how a computer works, and technicians who know just the reverse. Mr Davis said: "They don't spend enough time at the start of a project explaining where they are both coming from."

Another problem was that Whitehall was excellent at producing all-rounders but not experts in fields such as IT. A civil servant might only oversee one project - if he or she failed there would not be another chance. Success, however, would lead to promotion into another area. A civil servant would probably not lose his job if a computer project failed as his counterpart in the private sector would.

And if a minister demanded a new computer system to come online within two years, said Mr Davis, it would be a brave civil servant who ignored the deadline even if it meant producing a substandard system. Mr Davis said: "Throw in the Sir Humphrey factor and you've got a heady brew".

In May last year the Cabinet Office minister Ian McCartney launched a review of the way government IT projects are managed. It set out 30 recommendations. Among them was that a senior civil servant should be placed in charge of each project to establish accountability . Projects were to be broken down into smaller pieces so they were easier to manage.

The government's so-called e-envoy Andrew Pinder was charged with ensuring that the recommendations were implemented. In December he made an interim report on progress in which he said that 19 of the recommendations had been met.

webTitle: Poet wins grant for round-the-world voyage

fields.headline: Poet buoyed up by £75,000 for sea trip
fields.standfirst: Poet wins grant for round-the-world voyage
fields.trailText: Poet wins grant for round-the-world voyage.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Gwyneth Lewis, a poet and seasick sailor, said sternly yesterday: "It's the chance of a lifetime, but it's work, it's serious, it's not just a jaunt."

Nevertheless, any desk-bound poet, staring for inspiration at an urban brick wall, may feel a stab of jealousy at the news that Ms Lewis has won a £75,000 grant to spend almost five years on a yacht, sailing around the world and writing poems. The money comes from the national endowment for science, technology and the arts.

Ms Lewis's sailing has so far been confined to the Bristol Channel. Her father worked for Cardiff port health authority, her cousin is a sea captain, her husband was in the merchant navy and her cousin, Joe Tanner, is an astronaut. "We've got ants in our pants in my family, big time," she said.

She is fascinated by the seafaring history of Cardiff. The harbour, which was once the largest port in the world, is now a marina backdrop for expensive new flats and cafes.

"Cardiff coalers went around the world, and we will try to trace that route," Ms Lewis said. "It seems to make sense to cross the Atlantic first and go to America, Argentina, Brazil and places like Patagonia, where the Welsh links were extraordinarily strong, and then continue to the far east. There are communities in Cardiff of people from all those places where Welsh ships traded, such as the Somali and Yemeni communities."

Until last year Ms Lewis worked with the documentary unit of the BBC, and sees the creative side of the journey bridging the gap between documentary and poetry. The enterprise will be chronicled on the internet, and she is about to make contact with round-the-world sailor Ellen MacArthur to see how she set up her website and webcam.

Ms Lewis and her husband, Leighton Denver Davies, who will be crewing while she writes, already have the boat, the 30-year-old, 35ft Jameeleh.

She said: "Her last owner told me 'she's not only sturdy, she's comfortable and by God she's pretty', which seems a good start."

There is just one problem. Ms Lewis is a rotten sailor. "I did my competent crew course and my teacher still remembers me as the most seasick pupil he has ever had. I found it helped when we got our own boat. Focusing on not crashing into the quay does distract you from being sick. But I'm still collecting remedies."

fields.headline: Sorcery from Bach's youngest son
fields.standfirst:
Amadis de Gaule
Theatre Royal
Wakefield
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Amadis de Gaule
Theatre Royal
Wakefield
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Johann Christian Bach, the youngest son of Johann Sebastian, was the only member of the great Bach clan to write any operas - not that we in his adopted homeland are particularly aware of them. This production of JC's last and most ambitious opera is the first to be heard on British shores.

Amadis de Gaule was written for the Paris Opera in 1779, and for the collector of 18th-century curios there is plenty to admire. The diabolic sorceress Arcabonne arrives direct from the line of histrionic Handelian necromancers; the passionate wailing of a prisoners' chorus presages Fidelio; and the interjection of a statue from beyond the grave may have given the young Mozart (who was in Paris for the premiere) a useful idea for Don Giovanni.

If all this creates the impression that Amadis is something of a mish-mash, then that is what its first Parisian audiences made of it. Bach had stepped into a celebrated operatic squabble between the avant-gardist Gluck and the old-school Italian, Piccinni. The beau monde had hoped that Bach might build a bridge between styles, and were notably deflated when he offered them a ferry.

The present revival, presented by Bretton Hall College of the University of Leeds alongside a professional contingent of instrumental players and soloists, is as much a triumph of scholarship as stagecraft. Conductor Clive Brown has gone directly to Bach's autograph score and the extensive ballet sequences - unheard anywhere since the 18th century - have been pieced together by Patric Standford from the original ballet master's rehearsal copy.

The dance music is effervescent, life-affirming stuff well worth exhuming: indeed these sequences, choreographed by Jo Butterworth, provide uplifting moments of respite much as they would have done at the Parisian premiere. Though Steve Muir in the role strikes out boldly towards the stratosphere his stage presence never develops much beyond clutching his chest and turning purple with effort.

fields.headline: Don't rush to buy MPPI
fields.trailText: News that Norwich Union is refusing to sell mortgage payment protection insurance (MPPI) to Rover staff in Birmingham is a prime example of insurer 'cherry picking', but it's also worth considering if this type of insurance is even worth having.
fields.body:
News that Norwich Union is refusing to sell mortgage payment protection insurance (MPPI) to Rover staff in Birmingham is a prime example of insurer 'cherry picking', but it's also worth considering if this type of insurance is even worth having.

MPPI is not the right insurance for everyone with a mortgage. The Financial Services Ombudsman has said it is expecting a 20% rise in complaints on the issue this year linked, including many who have lost their jobs but had claims rejected.

For example, MPPI, frequently does not cover people who lose their jobs as a result of stress-related illness. Furthermore, MPPI usually pays out for just a year - yet some policyholders are under the impression it will cover their mortgage until they find another job, even if this takes longer.

Before anyone considers buying the cover, they need to be clear that they understand exactly what it is and whether it is being offered at a fair price and what the alternatives are.

First time buyers, in particular, should beware of pressure selling tactics from advisers and lenders.

MPPI will usually cover the monthly mortgage payments for up twelve months, starting one or two months after an accident, illness or unemployment happens. Some policies will only protect against redundancy and so are cheaper. This can be useful in households that rely on a single income, although in areas of high unemployment, 12 months may not be long enough to find another job, or might not be enough to cover time off work though an accident or sickness.

Despite its limitations, sales of MPPI are rising. At the end of last year, around a third of all new mortgages were protected by the insurance. The government is also keen for sales to grow to stop reliance on the state. And certainly MPPI is an improvement on the state's provisions.

Those on income support or jobseekers allowance have to wait 26 weeks before receiving assistance with eligible mortgage interest, if their mortgage pre-dates October, 1995.

For the first eight weeks, they receive no assistance at all and the next 18 weeks they get up to 50% of the eligible interest.

Borrowers taking out a mortgage after October, 1995, would have to wait 39 weeks obtaining full assistance with mortgage interest and in the meantime receive no help at all.

Stephen Devine, general manager of corporate communications at Pinnacle Insurance, one of the main MPPI providers for high street lenders says: "This is a product designed to be a sticking plaster. It is essential those buying it realise it is short term and is meant to keep you afloat until you find another job."

He explains that the average person who is made redundant takes around 150 days to find another job and adds that one in five people will become unemployed at some stage of their working lives.

But, it is also worth remembering there are alternatives. Siobhan Hotten, marketing manager for mortgage advisers, John Charcol says: "We do recommend MPPI for some people, but it is not suitable for everyone. In some cases, redundancy cover on its own is cheaper and more relevant if other benefits are supplied through work."

She believes critical illness cover provides far greater peace of mind if someone becomes seriously ill such as with a heart attack or cancer as MPPI does not cover for a long enough recovery time. Income protection is another option. It pays an income - typically around 60% of salary - until the claimant returns to work or retires. Like critical illness cover, this will cost more than MPPI, although is viewed by many as more valuable.

The average price of MPPI is around £5.60 per £100 of benefit to be paid. But, there are variations. Marks & Spencer Financial Services is well priced at £4 per £100 of benefit, while the cheapest in the Market Harborough Building Society sells the cover at £1.75 per £100 - little more than its cost value - but this is only available to those taking out a Market Harborough mortgage.

Market Harborough has defended its stance and says there is an argument for compulsion, according to spokeswoman Alison Dodd. She says the cover helps prevent arrears and its customers having to rely on state benefits.

But, it is also worth remembering that having the insurance in place is not a guarantee against repossession. A survey by Mortgage Finance Gazette found 47% of lenders would continue with repossession even if the homeowner had the cover.

Details on MPPI can be found on the Association of British Insurers' website.

Checklist before you buy MPPI

What is the cost?
Compare your quote against the average price of £5.60 - and this is the top end of average - per £100 of benefit. If the cover is very cheap, check to see if there is a longer waiting period before you claim. 30 days is average. If you have savings, it may be worth buying a cheaper policy and waiting 60 days.

Are you considering becoming self-employed?
Check if the cover would still be valid (unlikely).

Do you have any health problems?
This again could invalidate payment.

Look at other options
Critical illness or income protection insurance can be an alternative.

Donêt forget that MPPI is only a short-term product.
It is unlikely to pay out for more than 12 months.

What other benefits do you have through work?
If your health is covered, it could be cheaper to buy redundancy only cover.

Consider seeing an independent financial adviser before buying MPPI.

fields.headline: Edinburgh's dangerous wallpaper
fields.standfirst:
Painted Spaces
Talbot Rice Gallery
Edinburgh
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Painted Spaces
Talbot Rice Gallery
Edinburgh
Rating: ***
fields.body:
In this exhibition of giant murals, the gallery's ground floor is occupied by seven artists working directly onto the walls. Six have gone for high drama to produce vast canvases like stage sets - a massive panel of geometric abstraction in citrus colours, a row of bony white legs on a black background towering above us, a cage-like grid of orange and turquoise. Forming a seamless progression around the gallery, the murals creep round fire alarms and an entrance to a lift, like manic reams of wallpaper.

David Thomas has covered a whole wall in black gloss, highlighting the surface's history - strips of old masking tape, bumpy bits, gouged out areas. At other venues with smoother walls, his work acted as a mirror to the gallery and the other murals; here, it is the exhibition's heart of darkness, gloomy, imperfect and menacing. At the exhibition opening, the room is still full of paint fumes. "Is it still wet?" a visitor asks, bewildered, of Thomas's shiny, glistening panel.

Disrupting the theatricality of the large-scale works is Sabina Ott's flickering video projection, a layering of colours and shapes, like a gentle, psychedelic pulse. Pools of translucent pinks and greens - soft and indulgent in contrast to the finished, solid murals - they deepen and transform, all kaleidoscopic and swirly. About movement and chance rather than pattern and fixity, Ott's work makes you think again about the construction of the bigger panels of paint too. Without her intervention, they might remain too monumental to do much more than be in awe of.

In a mezzanine gallery high above the main space, the artists have painted their murals in miniature, in tiny, fleeting works on the walls. You can't get to these without seeing the larger versions downstairs, and this neatly subverts our conventional ways of looking. If we saw the smaller works first, we'd survey them intently, invest them with extra significance; think the bigger ones overblown. This way round, they are like eccentric afterthoughts, an echo of the murals downstairs. You don't know what to make of them, can't fathom the relationship between the two versions (is it like a study and then the realised work?), and don't know where to look.

 Until March 24. Details: 0131-650 2211.

fields.headline: Philharmonia/Thielemann
fields.standfirst:
Royal Festival Hall
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Royal Festival Hall
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Schumann's Violin Concerto has had a rocky ride into the repertoire. The concerto was one of Schumann's last orchestral pieces, and was written in 1853 during the onset of the mental illness that would kill him in 1856. The solo part was written for the 22-year-old Joseph Joachim, who was initially dissatisfied with it. At the suggestion of Schumann's widow Clara, Joachim revised the final movement, but never performed the work in public.

Such was Clara's embarrassment over Schumann's mercurial concerto that she did not print the piece in her complete edition of Schumann's music. Only in 1937, after Schumann's daughter had granted her consent, did the concerto finally reach the concert stage.

At the Festival Hall, violinist Gidon Kremer was a compellingly persuasive advocate for Schumann's concerto, accompanied by the Philharmonia Orchestra and Christian Thielemann. If the piece is problematic, it is not because of Schumann's supposedly diminishing musical powers. Rather, the sometimes bizarre structure of the work's three movements reflects the contradictions at the heart of Schumann's aesthetic.

The first movement reverses the priorities of the typical romantic concerto. Although there is a conventional contrast between a martial first theme and a lyrical second idea, Schumann's development section is anything but traditional. Instead of a tempestuous, dramatic passage, he composes music of uneasy, meditative reflection. Kremer's performance seemed to suspend the movement's momentum, and this section was the dark heart of the whole concerto.

The dominance of lyricism in the concerto is most completely expressed in the second movement. Kremer played the endless melody with mesmerising concentration. Even in the finale, Schumann eschews a virtuosic showpiece. Orchestra and soloists are united in an ebullient, triple-time dance, and Kremer and Thielemann created a dynamic partnership.

Either side of the complex concerto were bleeding chunks from two of the most supremely confident operas of German romanticism: the overture from Wagner's Die Meistersinger, and Richard Strauss's Suite from Der Rosenkavalier. In the Wagner, Thielemann allowed the Philharmonia to flourish only in the central love-music, but he was much more generous in a sumptuous performance of Strauss's Rosenkavalier suite. Thielemann and the Philharmonia were as vivid in Strauss' nostalgic waltzes as they were in the voluptuous music from the famous act three trio.

webTitle: Business: Sun Life quits the doorstep

fields.headline: Sun Life quits the doorstep
fields.standfirst:
End of the road for 1,700 in life insurance salesforce

Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Sun Life of Canada, the recently demutualised life assurer, yesterday said it would cut 1,700 jobs after it reported that a tough competitive market in the UK had led to a sharp drop in revenues.
fields.body:
Sun Life of Canada, the recently demutualised life assurer, yesterday said it would cut 1,700 jobs after it reported that a tough competitive market in the UK had led to a sharp drop in revenues.

The Toronto-based company said it would close down its direct sales operation, leading to a reduction in its workforce from 2,000 employees to 300.

The decision follows a similar announcement by the Prudential, which plans to jettison its 2,000 direct sales staff.

After a year-long struggle to keep the 780-strong door-to- door sales force on the road, Sun Life of Canada said the prospect of an upturn had receded rather than improved.

Last year the company warned that its British arm could be sold if it failed to achieve a 15% return on equity within two to three years. In 1999 it racked up losses of £126m caused mainly by a £186m provision to cover pension mis-selling costs. The company was fined £600,000 by the regulator, one of the largest fines paid by a life insurer for pensions misselling.

But rather than sell its operation, Sun Life will complete a series of cuts by the end of 2003, with an interim target of 900 employees by the end of this year, it said.

"There has been a downward pressure on margins and competition has been getting increasingly fierce and without the benefit of a big brand or deep pockets we cannot continue," said a spokesman.

"The direct selling model is easily the most expensive way of selling products. We tried to make it work and we did cut costs, but when there are so many new entrants going for market share there was no way we could compete."

Company sales staff generated most of their income in the form of commission from the sale of endowment policies, usually linked to mortgages, and personal pensions. In the last year endowment sales have dropped following heavy criticism by consumer groups angry at their poor performance and the level of charges and commission taken by insurance companies and their sales staff.

The profits generated from personal pension sales have fallen following the government's proposals for stakeholder pensions, due to go on sale in April. Life insurers annual fees are capped at 1% under the new scheme, which is about a quarter of the fees traditionally charged by life companies. Many direct providers have already moved to cap their annual fees in stakeholder-style pensions. The move by rivals to slash their fees in the run up to April has intensified pressure on Sun Life of Canada to cut its own costs further.

Ned Cazalet, an independent life insurance analyst, said he told Sun Life last year it was unviable to maintain a direct sales force. "Direct sales forces have been in long-term decline. Just 10 years ago there were 190,000 of them and now there are about 30,000. The profits from mortgage endowments and personal pensions has collapsed and Sun Life of Canada didn't really have the variety of products needed to survive."

The company said a new communications centre and administration system in Basingstoke would provide an improved service to existing clients who hold 800,000 policies. Other UK businesses - Group Insurance, Sun Bank and SLC Asset Management - will continue as normal.

Canadian parent Sun Life Financial Services reported a 37% increase in fourth-quarter net income to £95m.

fields.headline: Alliance & Leicester trades down
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Alliance & Leicester has sold its head office on Park Lane in London and is moving the bulk of its headquarters to Leicester as part of its effort to cut £100m from costs in three year's time.
fields.body:
Alliance & Leicester has sold its head office on Park Lane in London and is moving the bulk of its headquarters to Leicester as part of its effort to cut £100m from costs in three year's time.

The company intends to keep a scaled corporate presence in the capital but will employ less than 35 people in the new offices, which are yet to be found.

The move was revealed yesterday when it reported a £47m slump in pre-tax profits to £447m hit, as expected, by investment in new technology.

Peter McNamara, the bank's managing director, said some functions would be retained in London.

The bank, which is four months into a plan to reinvigorate its business by selling more products to its customers and expanding into business banking, is to spend £14m this year on installing 1,500 new cash machines across the country. It now has just 946 machines, which amounts to a 2.7% share of the cash machines in the country, compared with its 4.2% share of the current account market which it is trying to increase by the end of the year.

Many of the new cash machines will be in post offices, with which A&L has a special relationship as a result of its acquisition of Girobank.

It also intends to install cash machines in corner shops in partnership with installer TRM at which users will be expected to pay for cash withdrawals.

A&L, which only two years ago was trying to merge with Bank of Ireland, insisted it was committed to pursuing an independent strategy.

"We believe that speed is more important than size. While Alliance & Leicester is big enough to be powerful it is also small enough to be fast," said John Windeler, chairman of the bank.

He said A&L would look at partnerships for parts of the business but refused to reveal whether talks were taking place with broking firm Charles Schwab about installing share sale points inside A&L's 300 branches.

The bank has £200m of excess capital, which it might give back to shareholders in the form of a share buyback.

Its shares, which have outperformed the FTSE 100 index in recent months, fell 9p to 714p yesterday, but remained well above the 533p at which they were given to members when it floated on the stock market four years ago. It will pay a 33p dividend.

It also intends to install cash machines in corner shops in partnership with installer TRM at which users will be expected to pay for cash withdrawals. A&L, which only two years ago was trying to merge with Bank of Ireland, insisted it was committed to pursuing an independent strategy. "We believe that speed is more important than size. While Alliance & Leicester is big enough to be powerful it is also small enough to be fast," said John Windeler, chairman of the bank. He said A&L would look at partnerships for parts of the business but refused to reveal whether talks were taking place with broking firm Charles Schwab about installing share sale points inside A&L's 300 branches. The bank has £200m of excess capital, which it might give back to shareholders in the form of a share buyback. Its shares, which have outperformed the FTSE 100 index in recent months, fell 9p to 714p yesterday, but remained well above the 533p at which they were given to members when it floated on the stock market four years ago. It will pay a 33p dividend.

webTitle: Norwich Union helps bring social responsibility into the mainstream

fields.headline: Norwich Union helps bring social responsibility into the mainstream
fields.trailText: News that Norwich Union has expanded its range of Socially Responsible Investment funds is growing evidence that this sector is fast moving into the mainstream.
fields.body:
News that Norwich Union has expanded its range of Socially Responsible Investment funds is growing evidence that this sector is fast moving into the mainstream.

The Norwich Union launch is an SRI open ended investment company (OEIC), which will comprise six sub-funds; Corporate Bond, UK Growth, Absolute Growth, Global Growth, Managed and European Growth.

Among the sectors targeted are education, water management and renewable energy.

Clare Brook, who manages the SRI, said: "We believe the companies and industries that will perform best in the 21st century are precisely those that consider how their actions will affect the world in 25 or 50 years' time."

But many investors are confused by the differences between so-called 'ethical' investment and 'socially responsible' investment and need to understand what each term means before buying into a fund, says CIS, one of the market leaders.

For CIS, ethical investment requires a company to fit into certain criteria. If it fails to meet these, it is simply rejected, and if it is accepted but its standards later change, then support is withdrawn.

SRI, on the other hand, means investing in a much wider range of companies and trying to bring about change through dialogue. Robert Taylor, who heads the CIS's SRI team said: "In our SRI funds we might still invest in tobacco, but would want to make sure the products are marketed sensibly."

He said private investors should find out how active a fund manager is in following an SRI philosophy: "We will always vote on AGM resolutions, for example. To find out exactly what a company is planning is quite an undertaking, but is something we devote a lot of resources to."

In general, ethical investment is more rigid, while SRI offers far more scope for compromise.

Ethical funds were hit last year by the technology slump. This led to poor performance, and Taylor admits CISÕs Environ fund did not perform well last year. "It was middling really, but we expect technology to improve," he said.

Longer term, prospects appear good as according to Lipper, the financial information provider, the average UK ethical fund has grown by 92% over the past five years. The average UK All Companies unit trust grew by 87%.

The largest fund in the ethical market is Friends Provident Stewardship. Its stock picking follows the companyÕs Quaker roots and avoids buying shares linked to alcohol, tobacco and gambling.

Among the best performing ethical funds last year were Jupiter's Environmental fund, up 14.9%, Aberdeen's Ethical fund, up 9.1% and Norwich UK Ethical, up 3.2%, managed good performances. Friends Provident Stewardship, dropped back 4.5% over the year.

fields.headline: Ernest Ranglin
fields.standfirst:
Queen Elizabeth Hall
London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Queen Elizabeth Hall
London
Rating: **
fields.body:
Ernest Ranglin may be a legendary musician, renowned as the godfather of the Jamaican music scene, but he refuses to look or act the part. The man once offered a "lifetime job" as teacher and musical director by Bob Marley, ambles on stage wearing glasses, grey jacket and slacks, with the air of an amiable retired academic. When he first picks up his guitar he doesn't play reggae but eases into a burst of cool, rapid-fire jazz improvisation, a reminder that one of his early heroes was Charlie Christian.

Ranglin has had an extraordinary, varied career and this show, which was by no means as satisfying as many of his earlier appearances, at least proved that he is still taking chances and switching styles. Ranglin worked with every ska and reggae hero going in Jamaica - from Prince Buster through to Jimmy Cliff, the Melodeons and of course the Wailers - but he was always a great jazz guitarist, winning praise for his lengthy stints at Ronnie Scott's, even back in the 1960s.

In recent years he has found new inspiration by working in Africa; one of his finest albums, In Search of the Lost Riddim, was recorded in Senegal with help from the likes of Baaba Maal and his band. But now Ranglin has moved back towards mainstream jazz styles, though still with an African and Jamaican edge. His latest album, Modern Answers to Old Problems, was licensed to a jazz label, presumably because his record company thought it was not suitable for more commercial promotion.

Performing the new songs live at the QEH, in the company of many of the musicians who joined him on the album, Ranglin showed off his virtuoso skills but, even at his best, he was merely impressive rather than remarkable. For all the displays of high-speed guitar technique, the results often sounded laid-back and at times even soporific.

He was joined by an excellent band with three percussionists, including Fela Kuti's celebrated drummer Tony Allen, but for most of the set their playing was worryingly sedate, as if they didn't want to startle Ranglin by showing what they could really do. So they eased from funk to African and ska styles, providing a respectful backing while he traded solos with his saxophonist and keyboard player.

Singer Sylvia Tella tried hard to inspire a little excitement, but her over-frantic stage act looked out of place, and she caused some confusion by colliding two songs (she appeared to break into Profiles in the middle of Sound Invasion).

There were, admittedly, a few patches where Ranglin and his team showed what they could do - as when he matched a funk keyboard riff with a quite ridiculously fast guitar run, or when Tony Allen at last decided to show off his drum skills on his own song, Many Roots - but these merely added to the frustration. Working with the Baaba Maal band, Ranglin was inspired, but here he was merely going through his paces.

fields.headline: The mutant Mau-Maus sound
fields.standfirst:
Mau-Maus
Monarch
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Mau-Maus
Monarch
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Maybe warming up the bar-hugging crowd with a spot of Eminem was an inspired move for the Mau-Maus. As the biggest pop star on the planet fades out and a slice of 1970s rock guitar blasts out, we're shocked into listening.

Rap is just about the only genre not dissected, rearranged and thrown into the mutant Mau-Maus sound. The as-yet unsigned London quartet are musical magpies, spotting a bright and sparkly influence from 100 yards and causing havoc with it. Though as RTB gets the orchestral treatment, singer Peter de Havilland - hands gripping the mike stand as though he's afraid it'll make a run for it if he lets go - looks more like an intense gap year survivor than an experimental pop provocateur.

There's a vision there somewhere, but as the sound swerves and dips from indie to dance to choral in the space of a second, it's difficult to keep up. Every note takes us somewhere else, never allowing the crowd to rest easy and enjoy the ride.

And that's just the first song. "Do you want it? Do you want it?" de Havilland asks a clearly bemused crowd. "I know you want it," he chuckles before beginning the frugally named Wan It. Just when you thought it couldn't get weirder, in comes a sample of the Star Wars theme matched with a close relative to the Minder soundtrack, the jaunty keyboards quickly dispensed with to make room for some bleeps. Imagine you're at home with a nice video only to be intermittently interrupted by the jukebox in the pub next door and you're close to the key elements of the Mau-Maus sound.

Thankfully, most of the prevalent influences are the right ones. From the backbeat of the Italian Job theme to the drums of Lust For Life, Pat Walters hits those skins with a passion. The Mau-Maus are obviously over the moon with their heady concoction, as guitarist CJ and de Havilland whisper to each other before giggling like kids trying out some dodgy punch at a party.

Their enthusiasm is catching too. One brave girl heads towards the front of the stage and dances her heart out to Disco Suxx, the upcoming first single on Mau-Maus' own label that touches on Bloodhound Gang territory with its singalong retro sound and questionable lyrics. The Mau-Maus are either geniuses or madmen and tonight they've certainly kept us guessing.
